1401 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Lee v. Biderman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


143 Misc. 2d 658; 541 N.Y.S.2d 724; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 293



May 11, 1989 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the foregoing reasons the petition herein is granted and the matter is remanded to respondent HPD for further determinations consistent with this decision.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 special proceeding, petitioner individual sought to compel respondents, the City of New York Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) and its commissioners, to issue a senior citizen rent increase exemption order (Order) freezing the rent for her apartment at the maximum collectible rent (MCR) rate for the month prior to her 62nd birthday. The HPD had previously denied her request.


OVERVIEW: The individual, who had lived in her apartment more than 20 years, turned 62 on January 15, 1987. She received a MCR notice increasing her rent, effective January 1, 1987. On January 27, 1987, the individual applied for an Order from HPD. That application was denied because the individual was not 62 on the day the MCR took effect. The court held that the application should have been granted and remanded it back to the HPD. The court reviewed the HPD's administrative decision to determine if it was arbitrary, capricious or an abuse of discretion pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7803. The court found that the purpose of the rent regulation, New York City, N.Y. Admin. Code § 26-405(m) was to alleviate hardships on senior citizens over 62 with low incomes. Because the statute was remedial in nature, the court construed it literally in order to carry out its purpose. The court, analogizing to an action that arose under an eviction prevention statute, found that the rent regulation statute required the HPD to issue an Order once the individual reached the age of 62. Because the individual was 62 when she applied for the Order, the HPD's denial of her application was arbitrary and capricious.


OUTCOME: The court granted the individual's petition to compel HPD to issue a rent control order and remanded the action back to HPD for further determinations consistent with the court's decision.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Senior Citizen Rent Exemption Order

Petitioner, who turned 62 on January 15, 1987, 15 days after the maximum collectible rent increase took effect, was improperly denied a senior citizen rent increase exemption order (SCRIE Order) freezing the rent for her apartment at the rate of her maximum collectible rent for December 31, 1986 on the ground that she was not 62 at the time the rent increase took effect since the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development must issue a SCRIE Order once an applicant meets all the statutory criteria (Administrative Code of City of New York § 26-405 [m] [2]). The purpose of the statute is to alleviate hardships on senior citizens over 62 with low incomes created by escalating rents in New York City. Such a remedial statute should be construed in order to carry out the reform and to spread the beneficial results as widely as possible.

 

1402 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Gabin Assoc. v. Grayson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


143 Misc. 2d 1051; 543 N.Y.S.2d 611; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 392



May 9, 1989 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion to vacate the action of respondent as arbitrary and capricious is denied (see, Matter of Johnson v Joy, 48 NY2d 689), and the cross motion to dismiss the petition is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Through a motion to vacate, petitioner, an owner of property subject to real estate taxes, sought a judgment declaring an increase in the assess valuation of the property to be void and unenforceable as violative of petitioner's constitutional rights. Further, petitioner sought a judgment restoring the assessed valuation to its former level. Respondent Commissioner of Finance of the City of New York filed a cross-motion to dismiss the petition.


OVERVIEW: Despite having failed to reveal his interest in the property by neglecting to file an owner's registration card upon purchasing the property, as required § 1512 of the New York City, N.Y. Charter, petitioner contended that respondent's valuation assessment was arbitrary and capricious. The court, however, noted that notice of the valuation had been sent to the parties from whom petitioner purchased the property, who were the only publicly known owners as they had, during their term of ownership, filed an owner's registration card. Given that respondent's provision to insure notice was ignored by petitioner, the filing of a real property transfer tax return by petitioner was not sufficient notice that petitioner was the owner of the property. Therefore, he was not entitled to contest any increase in the assessment. The filing of a transfer tax return had never been held to be chargeable notice of ownership to the municipal subdivision responsible for promulgating notices to property owners. Accordingly, dismissal of the petition was warranted, as no arbitrary conduct was perceived and the notification requirements were properly interpreted and followed by respondent.


OUTCOME: The court denied petitioner's motion to vacate, and granted respondent's motion to dismiss the petition.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Assessment -- Filing Owner's Registration Card in New York City

Petitioner was not deprived of due process by the failure of the City of New York to notify it of a change in assessed valuation before the increased assessment became final since it was petitioner's failure to file an owner's registration card with the City Collector following its purchase of the subject property in 1987 that caused the city to send the requisite 10-day notice to the former owners then listed with the City Collector at the time of the assessment (NY City Charter § 1512). Consequently, it cannot be said that respondent arbitrarily disregarded petitioner's right to notification of the assessment increase. Petitioner's filing of a transfer tax return with the City Register is no substitute for filing an owner's registration card and cannot constitute constructive notice to the city of a change in ownership for purposes of the notification of an assessment increase.

 

1403 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Leonard v. Regan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Albany County


143 Misc. 2d 574; 540 N.Y.S.2d 958; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 275



April 28, 1989 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Respondent Nassau County to submit order denying petition as to all respondents.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner applicant filed a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 seeking a judgment reversing and annulling the findings by respondent Nassau County (county), which denied the applicant's request for disability retirement and benefits. The applicant sought a declaration that § 71 of the New York Civil Service Law in conjunction with § 605 of the New York Retirement and Social Security Law was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The applicant was employed as a school crossing guard by the county police department when she sustained an injury during the course of employment. As a result of the injury, the applicant was granted workers' compensation benefits and was placed on sick leave of absence without pay. The applicant subsequently requested disability retirement benefits pursuant to New York Retirement and Social Security Law § 605, and the hearing officer denied her request. Pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, the applicant petitioned for a judgment to reverse and annul the denial, as well as a declaration that § 71 of the New York Civil Service Law in conjunction with § 605 of the New York Retirement and Social Security Law was unconstitutional. In denying the applicant's petition and granting the county's cross motion for dismissal, the court noted that § 71 of the New York Civil Service Law did not require a pretermination notice and hearing. Holding that both § 71 of the New York Civil Service Law and § 605 of the New York Retirement and Social Security Law were constitutional, the court found no violation of the applicant's rights.


OUTCOME: The court denied the applicant's petition to reverse a decision denying her retirement benefits and for declaratory judgment regarding the constitutionality of a section of the New York Civil Service Law. The court granted the county's cross motion to dismiss the petition.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Retirement and Pension Benefits -- Accidental Disability Retirement

Petitioner's application for disability retirement filed on September 24, 1986 as a result of a job-related accident which occurred on September 10, 1984 (the date she was last paid on the payroll before being placed on sick leave of absence without pay) while she was employed as a school crossing guard by the Nassau County Police Department was properly rejected as untimely since it was not "filed within three months from the last date the member was being paid on the payroll or within twelve months of the last date he was being paid on the payroll provided he was on a leave of absence for medical reasons without pay during such twelve month period provided the member was disabled at the time he ceased being paid" (Retirement and Social Security Law § 605 [b] [2]). The fact that petitioner was on sick leave without pay and paid for nine holidays per year while not working, pursuant to her union contract, does not change the fact that petitioner was not paid on the payroll. Furthermore, the statute governing reinstatement of employees after they were separated from service due to a disability caused by a work-related injury (Civil Service Law § 71) does not require a pretermination notice and hearing. Holding a posttermination hearing afforded petitioner all the due process to which she was entitled.

 

1404 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Barnwell


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


143 Misc. 2d 922; 541 N.Y.S.2d 664; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 294



April 25, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss and a motion for an evidentiary hearing in criminal proceedings charging defendant with possession of a controlled substance.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arraigned and charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance. Defendant moved to dismiss the charge on the ground that his arrest and prosecution constituted selective prosecution in violation of the New York Constitution and the United States Constitution. In the alternative, in order to further substantiate his claim, defendant requested an evidentiary hearing to determine if his arrest was motivated by improper considerations, and to determine the ordinary disposition of similarly situated offenders. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss and motion for an evidentiary hearing, holding that defendant failed to show that his arrest and prosecution were invidious or based upon impermissible considerations, and that defendant failed to show that he was more likely than not to succeed on the merits.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motions, holding that defendant failed to establish necessary elements to show selective prosecution in criminal proceedings against him.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Arrest -- Selective Prosecution

Defendant, a high school principal charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance in the seventh degree (Penal Law § 220.03) who has allegedly been offered a less favorable plea as compared to other first offenders prosecuted under the same statute because of the policy of the Manhattan District Attorney's office to consider "the defendant's position in the community as a relevant factor in plea discussions", has failed to establish that his arrest and prosecution were based upon unconstitutional considerations such as race, religion or any other arbitrary classification. Since defendant, as a school principal, occupies a position of public trust, a legitimate interest is served through his prosecution in promoting a more general compliance with the law. Since defendant has not presented sufficient evidence to demonstrate that he has been unfairly singled out for prosecution, he is not entitled to an evidentiary hearing on the issue of selective prosecution.

 

1405 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Curcio v. Boyle


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Nassau County


142 Misc. 2d 1030; 542 N.Y.S.2d 1005; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 243



April 18, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner residents sought judgment annulling a determination of respondent county attorney, who determined that the residents' proposed amendment to the county charter was illegal. The proposal, to be submitted to the voters in the next election, substituted a system of weighted voting by a board of supervisors in place of the existing single-member-district legislature. The action also involved other related individuals as respondents.


OVERVIEW: The residents submitted petitions for a referendum on their proposal to the county charter to substitute a system of weighted voting by a board of supervisors in place of the existing single-member-district legislature. The county attorney determined that the proposal was illegal under Suffolk County, N.Y., Charter § C7-3B. The court vacated the determination and declared the proposed amendment legal and proper. The suggestion that a weighted voting system had to, of necessity, effect a dilution of minority voting in violation of the Voting Rights Act was wholly undocumented. The mere suggestion of a violation, standing alone, was insufficient to arrest the initiative and referendum process at birth. The claim that the proposal would have allowed for insufficient time to prepare a plan went to the merits of the proposal, not its legality. The proposed amendment fell outside the temporal limitation of N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 10 and did not violate the Equal Protection Clause. The court also held that the geographical requirement contained in Suffolk County, N.Y., Charter § C7-3 was unconstitutional in that it did not employ the least drastic means necessary to achieve its ends.


OUTCOME: The court vacated the determination of the county attorney and declared that the proposed voting amendment was legal and proper for purposes of a charter amendment. The court also declared that the petitions as filed satisfied the requirements of the Suffolk County Charter. The court severed and continued the claims of two related respondents for the purpose of conducting a hearing on the challenge to the petitions.


HEADNOTES

Counties -- Initiative and Referendum -- Weighted Voting System

Respondent Suffolk County Attorney improperly determined that petitioners' proposed amendment to the County Charter, providing for the replacement of the existing single-member-district Legislature with a system of weighted voting by a board of supervisors, is illegal and thus cannot be submitted to the voters since the United States Supreme Court has not invalidated all systems of weighted voting (see, Board of Estimate v Morris, 489 U.S.   , 109 S Ct 1433) nor is respondent's undocumented suggestion that a weighted voting system would effect a dilution of minority voting in violation of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 sufficient to arrest the initiative and referendum process at birth. In addition, since the proposed Charter amendment can take effect no earlier than January 1990 and since the districts comprising the Suffolk County Legislature were altered last in 1981, the proposed amendment falls outside the temporal limitation proscribing any effort to restructure a local legislative body more than once each decade commencing with 1970 (Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 [1] [ii] [a] [13] [f]). Lastly, the Charter's geographical distribution requirement for the initiative and referendum process requiring the signatures of at least 50 voters from each of the county's 10 towns (§ C7-3) is unconstitutional.

 

1406 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Villacis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Kings County


143 Misc. 2d 568; 541 N.Y.S.2d 178; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 244



April 18, 1989 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended June 26, 1989.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, upon the close of the People's case, made an oral motion requested dismissal of the fourth count in the indictment charging her, under N.Y. Penal Law § 260.10(1), with endangering the welfare of a child. Defendant asserted that the People had failed to make out a prima facie case with respect to the fourth count and challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Penal Law § 260.10(1).


OVERVIEW: Defendant and the complainant, both females, were high school students. Defendant was alleged to have made some contact with the complainant that resulted in injury to the complainant's face. Defendant was charged under N.Y. Penal Law § 260.10 (1) for endangering the welfare of a child. Specifically, defendant was accused of knowingly acting in a manner likely to be injurious to the physical, mental, or moral welfare of a female child less than 17 years old. After the People presented their case, defendant moved to dismiss the charge under N.Y. Penal Law § 260.10(1) and challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Penal Law § 260.10(1). The court held that N.Y. Penal Law § 260.10(1) was unconstitutional because it failed to put defendant, a person of ordinary intelligence and subject to prosecution under it, on notice of the nature of what acts were prohibited. Defendant's conduct was not the kind of conduct that the statute sought to prevent. The court further stated that, notwithstanding the statute's invalidity, the People had failed to prove that defendant was guilty of violating the statute.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the count of the indictment charging defendant with endangering the welfare of a child. The statute under which defendant was charged was unconstitutional as vague and overbroad, and, in any event, the People failed to prove that defendant had violated the statute.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Endangering Welfare of Child -- Constitutionality of Statute

That count of the indictment charging defendant with endangering the welfare of a child is dismissed. Penal Law § 260.10 (1) provides that a person is guilty of endangering the welfare of a child when he or she knowingly acts in a manner likely to be injurious to the physical, mental or moral welfare of a female child less than 17 years old. Defendant, a 19 year-old female, and the complainant, a 16-year-old female, were both students at high school when some contact between them resulted in an injury to the complainant's face. Defendant's conduct was not the kind of conduct that the statute seeks to prevent. The statute was intended to enhance the Family Court Act provisions controlling the acts of adults which are likely to result in neglect or delinquency of children where Family Court proceedings would be inappropriate for that purpose, and to aid in the prosecution of those who would take advantage of young persons, particularly young female runaways; traditionally, prosecutions under the statute have dealt almost exclusively with sexual offenses or morals cases. The statute fails to give a reasonable person subject to it notice of the nature of what conduct is prohibited and what conduct is required of him or her, and is, accordingly, unconstitutional. In any event, the statute would not be applicable in this case since the People failed to prove that defendant had any degree of control over the complainant which would enable her to take advantage of the complainant.

 

1407 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Alderson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


144 Misc. 2d 133; 540 N.Y.S.2d 948; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 229



April 14, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Criminal defendants filed motions to dismiss the charges brought against them in the furtherance of justice.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were each charged with one count of criminal trespass for illegally entering and remaining in a private office belonging to a commissioner of a city health department. Defendants were members of a group focusing attention on the AIDS crisis. Defendants raised a justification defense, claiming their action constituted a necessary emergency meeting held for the purpose of saving lives. Defendants filed motions to dismiss the charges in furtherance of justice. The court held that defendants could not use the necessity defense to justify unlawful action intended to limit the advancement of ideas contrary to their own.


OUTCOME: Defendants' motions to dismiss were denied because the necessity defense could not be used to excuse their criminal activity, which was intended to express their disagreement with positions reached by the lawmaking branches of government.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Justification -- Necessity Defense to Trespass Charge

Defendants, members of a gay activist organization who entered unannounced and uninvited into the office of the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Health, disrupted an ongoing meeting, screamed epithets and slogans and otherwise prevented the Commissioner from engaging in his scheduled business to protest a recent report of the Department reducing the number of persons estimated to be infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, the precursor to AIDS, have failed, as a matter of law, to offer sufficient evidence to support a justification defense (Penal Law § 35.05 [2]) to the trespass charges against them since defendants offered no proof that the issuance of the report created an imminent emergency to anyone's life other than their personal beliefs that it might; they offered no proof that the report would have any immediate impact on funding for AIDS health care nor did they offer substantive proof that the report would even have such impact in the future. In addition, even if defendants believed the report contained erroneous conclusions which needed immediate correction, the actions they took were not reasonably designed to accomplish the goal of changing the report. Defendants cannot use the necessity defense to justify unlawful action intended to limit the advancement of ideas contrary to their own. Accordingly, since defendants were each personally warned that they were trespassing and each refused to leave after being lawfully ordered to do so, they are found guilty of criminal trespass in the third degree (Penal Law § 140.10).

 

1408 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Children of Bedford, Inc. v. Petromelis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


143 Misc. 2d 999; 541 N.Y.S.2d 894; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 284



April 12, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner foundation filed suit against respondents, victims assistance organization, seeking a judgment annulling the determination of the victims assistance organization that a certain book was subject to N.Y. Exec. Law § 632-a, the so-called "Son of Sam Law."


OVERVIEW: The author of the book at issued was prosecuted for the death of an individual. The foundation was involved with the publishing of the book. N.Y. Exec. Law § 632-a affected the rights of the perpetrator of a crime to receive any profit from communications concerning the crime unless and until all proceeds had been held in escrow for five years and made available to satisfy any civil judgment obtained against the wrongdoer. The victims assistance organization determined that the book at issue was subject to § 632-a. The foundation argued that the victims assistance organization did not comply with due process requirements, and the statute was unconstitutional. On appeal, the court found that the victims assistance organization's proposed determination contained a detailed statement of the issues involved in the controversy, thus providing adequate notice of the nature of the proceeding and not offending due process. The court also found that to the extent that the statute inhibited the U.S. Const. amend. I, the statute's burden on speech was narrowly tailored to a compelling state interest.


OUTCOME: The court denied the foundation's petition that sought a declaration against the victims assistance organization that a victims rights law was not applicable to a certain book and the statute was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Literary Property -- Distribution of Moneys Received as Result of Commission of Crime

The contract for an autobiographical book written by Jean Harris, currently incarcerated for the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, purportedly concerning "the plight of children with mothers behind bars" but also containing details of her relationship with the victim and her well-publicized trial, is subject to the "Son of Sam Law" (Executive Law § 632-a; 9 NYCRR 526.1 [f]), which precludes the perpetrator of a crime from receiving any profit from communications concerning the crime unless and until all proceeds have been held in escrow for five years and made available to satisfy any civil judgment obtained against the wrongdoer, notwithstanding the fact any profits from the book will go toward the creation of a trust to benefit disadvantaged children of incarcerated mothers, since the funding of a trust with moneys derived from the sale of a book about a crime is contrary to statutory intent and adverse to the interests of those who suffered a pecuniary loss as a direct result of the crime. The statute is not violative of First Amendment rights since the State's interests in providing a source of funds to compensate victims of a crime who might otherwise have no source of redress and in barring a given perpetrator from reaping a potential windfall from the publicity generated by a particularly controversial or infamous crime significantly outweigh the minimal impact on the dissemination of information. In addition, the mere possibility that the statute might be applied to some protected expressive activity does not render the statute constitutionally infirm as vague and overbroad.

 

1409 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kotler


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Kings County


143 Misc. 2d 287; 540 N.Y.S.2d 937; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 219



March 31, 1989 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the foregoing reasons, the defendants' motion to dismiss is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant property owners filed motions to dismiss the charges against them for violations of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code §§ 27-2118 and 27-2005 for the alleged failure to make repairs in their buildings pursuant to orders by the housing court.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with failing to make repairs in their buildings. Defendants argued that only the corporation counsel had jurisdiction to prosecute the charges. The court stated even though the criminal charges were misdemeanors and could be prosecuted in the criminal court, they could also be prosecuted in the supreme court because it had original jurisdiction. The court held that the district attorney had concurrent jurisdiction to prosecute violations of the Code. The court determined that pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.40, the court, in its discretion, could refuse to return the case back to the housing court even though that was the order that the property owners failed to comply with. The court reasoned that the grand jury was able to direct the district attorney to file in a local criminal court and if only the corporation counsel could prosecute, then the grand jury would be severely hampered pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 190.70(1).


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Jurisdiction of Offenses

The District Attorney has concurrent jurisdiction with the New York City Corporation Counsel to prosecute criminal violations of the New York City Housing Maintenance Code.

 

1410 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Anonymous Female


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Buffalo


143 Misc. 2d 197; 539 N.Y.S.2d 868; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 190



March 27, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court issued its findings of fact and conclusions of law in a case charging defendant with public lewdness in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 245.00 based on a consensual act of oral sodomy in a public place.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with public lewdness in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 245.00. The evidence showed that defendant entered a vehicle which was driven to quiet street in a residential area, after leaving a parking lot which was not secluded. Police officers observed defendant performing oral sodomy on the driver of the car and made the arrest. The court held that the state did not establish a case of public lewdness under the statute because there was no evidence of intent for the act to be viewed by the public. The evidence showed an attempt to be clandestine instead. The court held that the nature of the place itself, public or private, was not determinative since the state had an expectation of privacy under certain circumstances even in public places.


OUTCOME: The court determined that the state did not prove all the elements of the offense of public lewdness beyond a reasonable doubt because the evidence showed that defendant as attempting to avoid public view.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Public Lewdness

Defendant cannot be charged with public lewdness (Penal Law § 245.00) for performing oral sodomy on a male in his car parked at the curb of a quiet residential street at 11:00 p.m., undercover police officers having followed the car after defendant entered the vehicle in an area of the City of Buffalo noted for its "prostitution, or sexual activities", since the statute requires that the lewd conduct have been intended to be seen or observed by the public. The public lewdness statute, designed to proscribe lewd "exhibitionism" with all its public ramifications involving lewd acts intended to be seen by "targeted" viewers, was misapplied by the police to conduct intended to be nonpublic.

 

1411 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Dreska v. County of Nassau


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Nassau County


143 Misc. 2d 321; 540 N.Y.S.2d 637; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 222



March 13, 1989 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, as the petitioners' cause of action arose before the McCann decision (supra), and was not "still in the normal [litigation] process" at that time, the cross motion to dismiss the petition is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, petitioner titleholders sought an order that annulled respondent county's denial of their application to redeem certain real property sold at a tax sale. The county filed a motion to dismiss the petition.


OVERVIEW: The county acquired tax lien certificates on the titleholders' property for unpaid school and general taxes. The titleholders sought to redeem the property and the county denied their requests. They alleged that notice of publication only preceding the tax sale denied them of due process. They argued that in conjunction with an opinion by the appellate court, actual notice of tax lien sales was required. The court held that the titleholders' cause of action arose before the appellate decision and because there was no retroactive application afforded in the opinion then the titleholders were unable to rely on its decision.


OUTCOME: The court granted the county's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Tax Liens, Tax Sales and Tax Titles -- Notice to Delinquent Titleholder -- Retroactivity of Holding Nullifying Prior Notice Procedure

A petition seeking an order annulling the denial by county officials of petitioners' application to redeem certain real property sold at a tax sale is dismissed where petitioners seek to void the transfers of title made pursuant to the tax sale on the basis of Matter of McCann v Scaduto (71 NY2d 164), which declared that the former real estate collection enforcement provisions of the county code in question were unconstitutional in that actual notice of tax lien sales was required, since the court provided explicitly that McCann was to have prospective application only, and while the instant proceeding was commenced after McCann was decided, it was based on an event prior to that decision; an event which occurred, or a cause of action which arose, before the decision is not one which could be relied upon to commence suit unless retroactive application was afforded. Moreover, petitioners' argument that as long as the presumption of notice regularity remains rebuttable under the six-year Statute of Limitations provided for in the county code, an action commenced after McCann based on a tax sale prior to McCann is still in the normal litigation process and, thus an exception to McCann's prospective direction, is without merit since once the six-year period has run, the court's mandate of a prospective application to prevent societal havoc would have been unnecessary, as the Statute of Limitations itself would be a sufficient defense.

 

1412 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Long v. Pompey Hill Volunteer Fire Dept., Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Onondaga County


143 Misc. 2d 408; 539 N.Y.S.2d 1014; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 210



March 9, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff heirs sought recovery of a parcel of real property granted to defendant fire company on the condition that the premises were used to house a fire department.


OVERVIEW: The heirs filed suit to enforce a right of reentry which provided that certain real property, granted to the fire company, would revert to the heirs in the event that the premises were no longer used to house a fire department. The fire company alleged that the premises were used as a fire department, and sought to have the restriction removed. The fire company further alleged that the reverter had been extinguished by N.Y. Real. Prop. Law § 345(4), which required the heirs to file a declaration of intent to preserve the restriction within a specified period. After trial the court awarded title to the heirs. The court found little evidence of fire company activity on the premises: the utilities were disconnected, and the fire company's equipment and personnel were housed at a different location. The court rejected the modification argument because the grantor had clearly and unambiguously restricted the use of the land for a particular purpose. Finally, the court found N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 345(4) unconstitutional because it barred the reverter before the event that would trigger the reverter had occurred or the parties at interest had been identified.


OUTCOME: The court awarded title of the real property to the heirs.


HEADNOTES

Deeds -- Right of Reentry -- Extinguishing of Possibility of Reverter -- Constitutionality of Statute

In an action to enforce a right of reentry against a volunteer fire department, inasmuch as defendant no longer used the conveyed premises to "house a fire department", the land and building erected thereon should revert to the heirs of the grantors in accordance with the terms of the deed, and Real Property Law § 345 (4), which required plaintiffs herein to file a declaration of intention to preserve a reverter not less than 27 nor more than 30 years after the condition subsequent or special limitation was created is unconstitutional as applied to plaintiffs (see, Board of Educ. v Miles, 15 NY2d 364); since the deed was recorded in 1949, the declaration would have had to have been filed not later than 1979, which was prior to the discontinued use of the parcel in question, the triggering event for the reverter to take effect, and, thus, plaintiff's failure to file the declaration of intention pursuant to an unconstitutional statute does not defeat the reversionary interest. Moreover, RPAPL 1955, which allows for the modification or extinguishment of certain restrictions on the use of land held for charitable purposes, is inapplicable, since the grantors herein specifically restricted the use of the land and defendant's use no longer conforms to the restriction; the purpose of the restriction was to insure that the land itself, rather than simply the value of the land, be devoted to housing a fire department.

 

1413 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York v. Castro


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


143 Misc. 2d 766; 542 N.Y.S.2d 101; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 320



February 22, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city brought an action against defendants, owner and lessee, to close a property used as an unlawful gambling establishment. After the court issued a temporary closing order of the premises, the city filed a motion for an order, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6301 and New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 7-707, preliminarily enjoining the owner and lessee from the use and occupancy of the first-floor rear area of a building.


OVERVIEW: The city submitted sworn affidavits from police officers attesting to the illegal gambling activity on the premises. The owner contended that issuance of a preliminary injunction violated its due process rights. The lessee argued that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 7-703(g) was unconstitutionally vague and that § 7-706(g) improperly presumed an agency relationship between the owner or lessee and the operators of a public nuisance. The court granted the city's motion for a preliminary injunction to the extent of continuing the temporary restraining order contained in the order to show cause. The court found that the city made a sufficient demonstration of its right to and the necessity for a preliminary injunction to protect the public. The court rejected the owner's contention, as a judicial hearing on the merits provided adequate due process and that the closing order could be vacated upon a proper showing that the public nuisance had been abated. The court concluded that repeated illegal conduct on a particular property constituted a "violation" and, therefore, could be considered a public nuisance.


OUTCOME: The court granted the city's motion for a preliminary injunction enjoining the owner and lessee from the use and occupancy of the first-floor rear area of a building.


HEADNOTES

Nuisance -- New York City Nuisance Abatement Law -- Preliminary Injunction

Plaintiff City of New York is entitled to a preliminary injunction pursuant to the Nuisance Abatement Law (Administrative Code of City of New York § 7-707) enjoining defendants from the use and occupancy of the first-floor area of a building where arrests were made on six occasions for illegal gambling activities since the minimal intrusion of defendants' rights are outweighed by the legitimate exercise of the police power to protect the public. There is no denial of due process in view of the requirement that a judicial hearing on the merits be held within three days and the fact that the closing order may be vacated upon a proper showing that the public nuisance has been abated. The Nuisance Abatement Law is not void for vagueness for failure to clearly define the term "violation" since it is clear that where there is repeated illegal conduct on a particular property and that conduct violates what is sought to be protected under the law, there is a "violation" that may be considered a public nuisance. The statute is not violative of the lessee's Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination since the statute clearly provides for rescission of the closing order upon proper showing, other than by testimony, that the public nuisance has been abated.

 

1414 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Keta


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Queens County


142 Misc. 2d 986; 538 N.Y.S.2d 417; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 129



February 21, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, charged with multiple counts of criminal possession of stolen property in the third degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 165.50, filed a motion to suppress evidence seized during a so-called "administrative search" of his business premises. Defendant also filed a motion to suppress any statements made to the police following his arrest.


OVERVIEW: After an administrative search pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 451-a and Charter of the City of New York § 436, defendant was charged with multiple counts of criminal possession of stolen property in the third degree. Defendant filed a motion to suppress the evidence seized during the administrative search and filed a motion to suppress his statements made to the police following his arrest. The court granted the motion. The court held that: (1) the provisions of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 451-a and Charter of the City of New York § 436 were violative of the Fourth Amendment rights against unreasonable searches and seizures, and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 12; and (2) the subsequent search with a warrant, and statements made to the police after his arrest, were the by-product of an illegal search and were suppressed as fruit of the poisonous tree.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to suppress evidence seized during an administrative search of defendant's business premises and granted defendant's motion to suppress any statements made to the police following his arrest.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Unlawful Search and Seizure -- Administrative Search -- Constitutionality of Statutes Authorizing Searches

New York City Charter § 436 and Vehicle and Traffic Law § 415-a (5) (a), which authorize warrantless "administrative searches" of automobile dismantling businesses, are violative of the constitutional protections against unreasonable searches and seizures extended to the citizens of New York through NY Constitution, article I, § 12; although both statutes have been held not to violate the US Constitution 4th Amendment, States are free to interpret their own Constitutions in ways that afford their citizens broader protections than those offered under the Federal Constitution. The statutes in question may be fundamentally defective in that they authorize searches undertaken solely for the purpose of uncovering evidence of criminality, rather than enforcing a regulatory scheme. Accordingly, statements made by defendant, the operator of a licensed automobile dismantling business, and the search conducted by the police pursuant to a subsequently obtained search warrant were by-products of the illegal search and seizure conducted pursuant to the statutes in question, and must be suppressed as fruits of the poisonous tree.

 

1415 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Forti v. New York State Ethics Com.


RJI No. 01-88-017007


Supreme Court of New York, Albany County


142 Misc. 2d 702; 538 N.Y.S.2d 177; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 124



February 8, 1989 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended March 28, 1989.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff attorney filed a motion for summary judgment in his action against defendant New York State Ethics Commission seeking declaratory judgment to declare the commission's advisory opinion void, which stated that the new prospective restrictions of N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 73(8) applied to all former state employees or officers who appeared before agencies on January 1, 1989 and thereafter, which included the attorney.


OVERVIEW: The attorney commenced an action seeking declaration that the commission's advisory opinion was null and void and that N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 73 was unconstitutional as applied to state officers and employees because it violated the Equal Protection Clause and the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and N.Y. Const. art. I, §§ 11 and 6. Thereafter, he filed a motion for summary judgment, and the court granted the motion. The court found that the commission had failed to demonstrate a rational basis for the distinction between state employees and legislative employees in view of the statutory purpose of the Ethics in Government Act. The court concluded that the commission had failed to adequately demonstrate a constitutional basis to distinguish between state officers and state employees and those who had previously worked for the legislature. The court stated that the attorney's expectations to be entitled to practice law were legitimate property rights protected by the Fourteenth Amendment.


OUTCOME: The court granted the attorney's motion for summary judgment in his declaratory judgment action against the commission seeking to have its advisory opinion declared null and void and rendering the portion of the Ethics in Government Act distinguishing between state officer and state employees unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Employment Prohibitions on Former State Employees

Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which prohibits former State officers and employees from representing any interest before their former agency for two years after they leave the agency and prohibits such officers and employees from ever representing any interest in relation to any case or transaction with which they were directly and personally involved while employed by the State, is unconstitutional and violative of the Fourteenth Amendment and NY Constitution, article I, § 6, since the statute classifies State employees differently from State legislators and legislative employees, imposing on the latter two groups considerably less restriction upon their engaging in either the practice of law, lobbying or representing other clients with respect to State government than plaintiff, a former attorney with the Department of Environmental Conservation, and those in his class; the record is devoid of any functional, economic or geographic basis for discriminating between plaintiff and legislative employees. Plaintiff has a substantial property interest in his entitlement to practice law, and defendant State Ethics Commission has failed to demonstrate a rational basis for the distinction between State employees and legislative employees in view of the statutory purpose of the Ethics in Government Act (L 1987, ch 813), which amended section 73 in order to restore public trust and confidence in government; if the purported purpose of the Ethics in Government Act is to regulate the "revolving door" syndrome, certainly members of the Legislature and their employees engage in that activity to no greater or lesser degree than former State officers or employees, many of whom were not political appointees but civil servants.

 

1416 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Peluso v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


142 Misc. 2d 642; 540 N.Y.S.2d 631; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 100



February 8, 1989 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the foregoing reasons, petitioner's CPLR article 78 and declaratory judgment action is granted only to the extent of directing respondent, NYC-D/P, to hold a fact-finding evidentiary hearing under CPLR 7804 (h) to examine, apply and determine the applicability of the factors set forth in Correction Law § 753 in relation to petitioner's presumption of rehabilitation created by the certificate of relief from disabilities; otherwise denied, without prejudice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner employee sought an order to direct respondents, a city commissioner of department of buildings and the city personnel director, to issue a site safety manager certificate, a declaration that respondent city commissioner's certification requirements were invalid and unconstitutional, and a hearing on petitioner's qualifications for a site safety manager certificate.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner employee was found guilty of improper activities in his position as a city construction inspector and was discharged from his job. Petitioner later sought a site safety manager license required for a new position and applied for and received a certificate of relief from the courts of all disabilities and bars to employment, excluding the right to be eligible for public office. When petitioner was notified that he had been found "Not Qualified" for a certificate for site safety manager without a hearing or any reference to petitioner's certificate of relief from disabilities, he brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding claiming that respondents, the city commissioner of department of buildings and the city personnel director, improperly denied his application for certification necessary to retain his position of site safety coordinator. The court determined that respondent was denied due process and that he was entitled to a fact-finding evidentiary hearing under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7804(h). Respondents were ordered to examine and apply the factors set forth in N.Y Correct. Law § 753 in relation to petitioner's presumption of rehabilitation.


OUTCOME: The court granted petitioner employee's request for a declaratory judgment to the extent of directing respondent city commissioner of department of buildings to hold a fact-finding evidentiary hearing to allow petitioner to rebut a presumption of rehabilitation created by the certificate of relief from disabilities.


HEADNOTES

Civil Rights -- Discrimination Based upon Previous Criminal Prosecution -- Licensure Procedures

Petitioner, a former construction inspector of respondent New York City Department of Buildings convicted in 1984 of bribe receiving, was denied procedural due process when respondent improperly rejected petitioner's application for a license as a site safety manager because of "fitness, character, soliciting and receiving a bribe and unsatisfactory prior public employment" without any reference to the certificate of relief from disabilities issued to petitioner by the sentencing Judge in 1987 since the certificate creates a presumption of rehabilitation which respondent must rebut even if there is a "direct relationship" between the criminal offense and the "specific license or employment sought" (Correction Law § 752 [1]). Accordingly, petitioner is entitled to a fact-finding evidentiary hearing to examine the eight statutory factors the licensing agency must examine (Correction Law § 753 [1]) with regard to the presumption of rehabilitation created by the certificate of relief from disabilities.

 

1417 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Crivillaro


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County


142 Misc. 2d 527; 538 N.Y.S.2d 152; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 54



January 27, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Criminal defendant moved to dismiss an indictment for possession of a loaded firearm, arguing that weapon involved did not meet the statutory definition of a firearm within N.Y. Penal Law § 265.00(3).


OVERVIEW: Criminal defendant was charged with possession of a loaded firearm in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 265.02(4). Defendant moved to dismiss the indictment, arguing that the shotgun in his possession was not a firearm as defined in N.Y. Penal Law § 265.00(3) because the weapon did not meet both barrel length and overall length standards. Court denied the motion, holding that the statutory definition of § 265.00(3) created two different standards that applied to two different and mutually exclusive types of weapon. Based on the plain meaning of the statute and legislative history, court read the statute in the disjunctive and found that barrel length requirement applied only to shotguns and overall length standard applied only to weapons made from shotguns. Further, court found that defendant failed to overcome the presumption of statute's constitutionality by showing, beyond a reasonable doubt, that the law was unconstitutionally vague.


OUTCOME: The court denied criminal defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment, holding that the crime of possession of a loaded firearm required proof that the weapon, if a shotgun, met the statutory barrel length requirements, rather than both the barrel length and overall length standards.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Possession of Weapon -- Shotgun

Penal Law § 265.00 (3), which included within the definition of "firearm" "a shotgun having one or more barrels less than eighteen inches in length and any weapon made from a shotgun (whether by alteration, modification, or otherwise) if such weapon as modified has an overall length of less than twenty-six inches" (the statute having been amended by L 1988, ch 264), must be read in the disjunctive as setting out two separate standards for two mutually exclusive kinds of weapons rather than creating a requirement that a shotgun have a barrel length of less than 18 inches and an over-all length of less than 26 inches to be considered a "firearm". Accordingly, defendant may properly be charged with criminal possession of loaded firearm (Penal Law § 265.02 [4]) for possessing a shotgun having a barrel length of 16 1/4 inches with an over-all length of 29 inches.

 

1418 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hall


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


142 Misc. 2d 532; 538 N.Y.S.2d 155; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 55



January 27, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charges against him for violating New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 10-115, which prohibited soliciting passersby on a street or sidewalk in front of stores, based on the ground that § 10-115 violated the First Amendment protection of speech.


OVERVIEW: The police allegedly observed defendant stop passersby, engage them in conversation, and solicit pedestrians by attempting to bring them into a store for the purpose of a sale. Defendant was charged with violating § 10-115. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charges, alleging that the conduct proscribed by § 10-115 was commercial speech protected by the First Amendment. The court granted the motion, holding that § 10-115 was not constitutionally valid. Although § 10-115 concerned lawful activity, sought to address a substantial government interest, and directly advanced that interest, the court concluded that §10-115 was more extensive than necessary to serve the interest of promoting public convenience as well as preserving the peace. The court explained that §10-115 banned all commercial advertising not just false misleading, or deceptive commercial speech that advertised or promoted unlawful activity. The ordinance was not limited to conduct that interfered with the use of city streets, or even conduct that promoted littering of the streets. Instead, it was a total prohibition of the use of the city streets and sidewalks for a particular type of solicitation.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the charges against defendant for soliciting pedestrians to bring them into a store for the purpose of a sale.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Solicitation of Pedestrians by "Pullers-In"

An ordinance of the City of New York prohibiting the solicitation on city streets or sidewalks of pedestrians by "pullers-in" attempting to bring them into a store for the purpose of a sale (Administrative Code of City of New York § 10-115) is unconstitutional as an infringement of defendant's First Amendment rights since the ordinance, in attempting to regulate commercial speech without any time, place or manner restrictions, is more extensive than necessary to serve the city's interest in maintaining the peaceful use of city streets. The ordinance could have lawfully prohibited the solicitation of pedestrians in order to promote the city's interest in the peaceful use of its streets by specifying hours when the activity complained of might interfere with the use of the city streets, for example, during the morning or evening rush hours, and the ordinance could also have limited the prohibition to areas of the city where traffic might be greater than in other areas.

 

1419 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


A. F. v. Spence Chapin Agency


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Kings County


142 Misc. 2d 412; 537 N.Y.S.2d 752; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 11



January 20, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner birth father petitioned for custody of his child who had been put up for adoption after he and the birth mother consented to such placement.


OVERVIEW: The birth father and birth mother, both teenagers, consented to placing their newborn baby up for adoption. Respondent adoption agency met with the birth father at the birth mother's home and obtained his consent. The birth father had concealed the pregnancy from his family. The adoption agency failed to inform the birth father of any of his rights; it merely obtained his consent. After the birth father's parents learned of the birth, the birth father petitioned for custody of the child. The court denied the petition. The court first held that the birth father's consent was invalid; however, his consent was not required pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 111(1)(e) because he did not live with the child or the birth mother, did not hold himself out to be the child's father, and did not pay for any of the medical expenses incurred in connection with the pregnancy and birth. The court then turned to the custody petition and applied a best interest of the child test to determine that the adoptive parents were better suited to raise the child.


OUTCOME: The court denied the birth father's petition for custody of his child who had been put up for adoption after he and the birth mother consented to such placement.


HEADNOTES

Adoption -- Consent -- Validity of Consent Given by Unmarried Minor Father

1. The consent to adopt an infant given by his unmarried, minor father was not valid where the adoption agency which procured the consent failed to exercise the extraordinary care demanded in dealing with a minor who lacks the assistance of a parent or guardian. The meeting with the agency should have included a discussion of the planning alternatives available to the father and should have encompassed a full explanation of his legal rights, including the right to consult an attorney and the right to take a copy of the consent document home to reread and reflect upon. Although the father did understand that by signing the document he would be giving the child up for adoption, the father's consent cannot be held to be knowing and voluntary in the absence of some showing that he had been made aware of the options open to him, and the social worker's attempt to draw the father out by asking him to discuss the profile of the adoptive parents does not substitute for an effort to find out how the father felt about the proposed adoption itself. Moreover, petitioner was genuinely confused and assumed that he had 30 days in which to revoke his consent; the fact that the meeting was conducted in such a fashion that there was a substantial likelihood that a person of the father's age and circumstances would become confused or pressured invalidates the consent.

Adoption -- Consent -- Consent of Unmarried Minor Father

2. The consent to adopt an infant is not required from an unmarried, minor father who met none of the three criteria set forth in Domestic Relations Law § 111 (1) (e), and the mere fact that the adoption agency sought his consent is no concession that it was required. The father did not live with the child or his mother for six months preceding the adoptive placement; he did not openly hold himself out to be the father, and he made no contribution whatsoever towards the birth expenses, making only minimal loans or gifts of money to the mother during the pregnancy. Although the father asserted that he proposed marriage to the child's mother and suggested that they live together in his parents' home, the insincerity of that proposal was apparent in view of the father's adamant refusal even to tell his parents of the pregnancy.

Parent and Child -- Custody -- Standing of Unmarried Minor Father

3. Although the consent to adopt a child is not required by an unmarried, minor father who met none of the criteria set forth in Domestic Relations Law § 111 (1) (e), the father retains standing to petition for custody of the child and the court must apply the best interest of the child standard in the adjudication, without any presumption in favor of the father; the fact that the father's consent is not required should put him on an equal footing with a parent who has executed a valid consent to adoption (see, Social Services Law § 383 [6]). There is no question that the infant's best interests will be served by his adoption by the preadoptive couple. The father has nothing to offer a child; he is a high school dropout without even a part-time job; he has shown no capacity to nurture another human being, is emotionally immature, and would actually have the child raised by his mother, notwithstanding the fact that his family is dysfunctional in ways which bear directly upon its parenting capacity. The preadoptive couple, by contrast, have good educations, good jobs, and a lovely home, and exhibited extraordinary compassion.

Adoption --  Consent  -- Consent of Unmarried Minor Father

4. In a child custody proceeding in which an unmarried, minor father seeks to revoke the consent he gave to free his child for adoption, petitioner's testimony concerning his resistance to going to a meeting with representatives of the adoption agency lacks credibility and leads to the conclusion that no duress or coercion was used to secure petitioner's presence at the meeting where the adoption documents were signed. The alleged threat that petitioner's parents would be told that he had fathered a child, if it was said at all, was not so fear-inspiring as to override the exercise of petitioner's free will.

Adoption -- Consent -- Execution of Consent Documents

5. In a child custody proceeding in which an unmarried, minor father seeks to revoke his consent to free his child for adoption, inasmuch as the consent of a qualified father is required under Domestic Relations Law § 111 (1) (e) regardless of whether the father is an adult or a minor, it appears that the statute does contemplate that a minor father of an out-of-wedlock child can consent to his child's adoption.

Adoption -- Consent -- Consent of Unmarried Minor  Father -- Constitutionality  of Statutory Requirements

6. Domestic Relations Law § 111 (1) (e), which sets forth three criteria which must be met before the consent of the father of an out-of-wedlock child need be obtained in order to place a child out for adoption, is not unconstitutional as applied to an unmarried, minor father who did none of the things which were well within his power to assert his interest in the child. The father failed to consult with his parents, failed to obtain a part-time job to help out financially, and failed to forthrightly and consistently declare to the child's mother his desire to raise the child; on the contrary, the father took the approach that the pregnancy was her problem and that he would not interfere in whatever she decided to do about it, giving no indication that he was prepared to inconvenience himself in the slightest for the sake of establishing a relationship with the child.

 

1420 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York Horse & Carriage Ass'n v. New York, Dep't of Consumer Affairs


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


144 Misc. 2d 883; 545 N.Y.S.2d 439; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 494



January 17, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff licensees moved for summary judgment, and defendant city cross-moved for summary judgment dismissing a complaint filed by the licensees for declaratory judgment that provisions of the licensing code were unconstitutional, that the city's policies violated due process, and that decisions revoking or suspending licenses were arbitrary and capricious.


OVERVIEW: The licensees, who operated horse-drawn carriages, requested judgment declaring that the licensing code was unconstitutionally vague because the provision for the display of the license was not clear. The court denied the licensee's motion for summary judgment, and granted the city's cross motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint. The licensing statute was not void for vagueness even though city inspectors differed in construing the provision for display of the license. An intelligent licensee, and any inspector possessing common sense, could determine that the provision that the license be posted in a conspicuous place meant that the license was to be displayed openly and notoriously. The lapse of time between the offense and a hearing could make it more difficult for the licensee to present evidence, but did not rise to the level of a constitutional deprivation because there was an adequate opportunity for the ultimate judicial determination of liability. Inspections of the horse-drawn carriages without prior notice was reasonable under the Fourth Amendment because unannounced searches conducted were necessary to further the city's regulatory scheme.


OUTCOME: The licensee's motion for summary judgment was denied, and the city's cross motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint for declaratory judgment was granted.


HEADNOTES

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- Constitutionality of Statute

1. A declaratory judgment action is the proper vehicle to review the validity of a legislative act; it is a proper vehicle for invalidating an unconstitutional application of a statutory provision. The exercise of a power which offends against the Constitution may be attacked at any time, and defendant agency cannot give legality to an unconstitutional or void statute by exercising power under it.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Different Interpretations of Statute

2. A statute which is so vague that people of common intelligence must necessarily speculate as to its meaning in the absence of some comprehensible standard or guide cannot pass constitutional muster; however, the fact that people may differ in construing a statute or in applying it does not mean it is void for vagueness. A statute is void only if it specifies no guide or standard at all, but not if there is a comprehensible normative standard capable of interpretation.

Animals -- Regulation of Horse-Drawn Cabs -- Display of License

3. In a proceeding challenging the constitutionality of a municipality's regulation of horse-drawn cabs, the terms in Administrative Code of the City of New York § 20-375, "securely affixed" and "conspicuous and indispensable", which describe the manner in which a license is to be displayed, are not arbitrary and vague, but have plain meanings, i.e., that the license must be openly displayed and not hidden. It is not necessary that the statute specify the precise location for display of the license as long as it meets the requirements of visibility and permanence, giving the carriage owner some flexibility to determine the best location and means for attachment, depending on the nature of the carriage on which it is displayed; such flexibility cannot be equated with impermissible vagueness.

Animals -- Regulation of Horse-Drawn Cabs -- Procedural Due Process -- Time Lapse between Offense and Hearing

4. In a proceeding challenging the constitutionality of a municipality's regulation of horse-drawn cabs, although a large lapse of time between allegedly committing an offense under the regulations and the hearing on a citation may make it more difficult to recollect the circumstances or to round up witnesses by the carriage owner, that fact does not amount to an unconstitutional deprivation of due process. Given the existence of a three-year Statute of Limitations for the exaction of penalties or forfeitures imposed by statute (CPLR 214 [2]), the serving of a notice of violation within months of the alleged offense is not repugnant to any sense of fundamental fairness; a governmental agency is not required to bring charges instantaneously upon the discovery of a violation. Moreover, licensees are required to maintain their records for a three-year period, so it should not be so difficult for them to establish compliance with departmental requirements.

Animals -- Regulation of Horse-Drawn Cabs -- Unannounced Inspections

5. In a proceeding challenging the constitutionality of a municipality's scheme for regulating horse-drawn cabs, the municipality's practice of conducting inspections without prior warning does not violate a cab owner's right to be secure from unreasonable searches and seizures since there is a substantial government interest that informs the regulatory scheme pursuant to which the inspection is made: horse-drawn cabs may create traffic hazards and be environmentally burdensome; moreover, treatment of the animals must be on a humane basis, and the general public is not to be victimized. Unannounced and spot searches are necessary to further the regulatory scheme (see, Administrative Code of City of New York § 20-371); such inspections can serve as an effective deterrent, and advanced notice of inspection would frustrate that scheme. The statute under which inspections are conducted meets the constitutional requirements as to notice and scope; Administrative Code § 20-378 specifies regular inspections at least once every four months, and Administrative Code § 20-377 provides that the objective of the inspection is to determine if the horse-drawn cab is fit for operation.

 

1421 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Buckley


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Second District, Nassau County


142 Misc. 2d 262; 536 N.Y.S.2d 948; 1989 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 41



January 5, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The town charged defendant by information with violations of Hempstead, N.Y. Code § 78-41 prohibiting the use of beach chairs without the approval of the concessionaire. Defendant sought to dismiss the information on the grounds that prohibiting the use of his own beach chairs was unconstitutional and violated the Due Process Clause of N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6.


OVERVIEW: The town established a special park district and operated and controlled a beach club. One of the rules and regulations issued with regard to the use of beach club property by a resident of the park district prohibited the use of beach chairs that were not rented from the concessionaire. On four separate occasions, defendant brought his own beach chairs to the club for his family of nine children. The town charged defendant with violation of Hempstead, N.Y. Code § 78-41. The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss, holding that the part of § 78-41 regulating the use of beach chairs at the beach club by the concessionaire was an unreasonable use of police power as it violated the Due Process Clause of N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6. The People offered no evidence to explain the necessity for a restriction on privately owned beach chairs only at the beach club. There was no evidence that there ever had been any beach chair-related injuries at the beach club, or at any other public beach operated by the town. There was no evidence that the law had any impact on municipal insurance rates.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion for an order dismissing the information was granted as the statute's mandated method of implementing the safety goal was prohibitively expensive to local residents, too dubiously related to the goal it was intended to serve, and the prohibition created was so excessive that it interdicted otherwise legitimate activity.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Prohibition on Use of Privately Owned Beach Chairs at Municipal Beach

A portion of a local ordinance prohibiting the use of privately owned beach chairs at a municipal beach is unconstitutional and an unreasonable use of the police power since the statute's mandated method of implementing the safety goal asserted by the municipality is prohibitively expensive to local residents, who must rent beach chairs from a concessionaire who enjoys an exclusive contract with the municipality, and is too dubiously related to that goal; moreover, the prohibition created by the statute is so excessive that it interdicts otherwise legitimate activity, and there is an absence of any legislative finding or any other demonstration by the People that there exists a reasonable relation to the prohibition established by the law and the public good. Defendant, who was charged with violating the ordinance, has met his burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the law is an arbitrary abuse of the police power.

 

1422 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Davis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County


142 Misc. 2d 881; 537 N.Y.S.2d 430; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 789



December 15, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County issued an opinion to explain the judge's reasons for three related rulings regarding peremptory challenges in a criminal trial in which the defendant was charged with the attempted murder of nine white and Hispanic police officers.


OVERVIEW: After issuing three rulings related to peremptory challenges exercised by the defendant in a criminal trial for attempted murder of nine white and Hispanic police officers, the court issued an opinion to explain the rulings. The court found that the procedures which applied to the peremptory challenges of the prosecution also applied to the defense. The court held that in light of caselaw that required the prosecutor to provide racially neutral reasons for peremptory challenges, once the appropriate showing of discrimination has been made, the same was required of the defense. The court found the reasons given by the defense in utilizing its peremptory challenges were not racially neutral. Accordingly, the court found that the only appropriate remedy was the discharge of the entire venire and commencement of a new jury selection during which the defense would be required to provide nonpretextual racially neutral reasons for the peremptory challenges of white prospective jurors.


OUTCOME: The court held that defendant was obligated to the same standard as the prosecutor in the use of peremptory challenges.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of Jury -- Use by Defense of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges

1. The holding in Batson v Kentucky (476 U.S. 79), wherein the Supreme Court limited a prosecutor's use of peremptory jury challenges, concluding that the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment prohibited a State prosecutor from exercising peremptory challenges solely on the basis of race, is also applicable to limit a defendant's exercise of race-based peremptory challenges, which are not of constitutional dimension but are a privilege granted by statute (see, CPL 270.25).

Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of Jury -- Use by Defense of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges -- State Action

2. The holding in Batson v Kentucky (476 U.S. 79), wherein the Supreme Court limited a prosecutor's use of peremptory jury challenges, concluding that the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment prohibited a State prosecutor from exercising peremptory challenges solely on the basis of race, is also applicable to limit a defendant's exercise of race-based peremptory challenges, since the implementation of racially discriminatory defense peremptory challenges constitutes State action,  [***2] not because defense attorneys are paid by the State pursuant to County Law article 18-B, but because the Trial Judge and other State officials must participate, facilitate and acquiesce in the racial discrimination.

Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of Jury -- Use by Defense of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges -- State Equal Protection Clause

3. The holding in Batson v Kentucky (476 U.S. 79), wherein the Supreme Court limited a prosecutor's use of peremptory jury challenges, concluding that the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment prohibited a State prosecutor from exercising peremptory challenges solely on the basis of race, is also applicable to limit a defendant's exercise of race-based peremptory challenges, since the Equal Protection Clause of article I, § 11 of the NY Constitution is at least coextensive with the Federal Equal Protection Clause and, therefore, also prohibits State action implementing racially discriminatory defense peremptory challenges. Moreover, inasmuch as the State Constitution prohibits discrimination by private persons and is violated by private acts of discrimination infringing upon the civil rights of another, defense counsel's action [***3] of peremptorily challenging jurors on the basis of race deprives the excluded jurors of their civil right of jury service, which is a privilege of citizenship (see, Civil Rights Law § 13; see also, NY Const, art I, § 1).

Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of Jury -- Use by Defense of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges -- Statutory Protection

4. The holding in Batson v Kentucky (476 U.S. 79), wherein the Supreme Court limited a prosecutor's use of peremptory jury challenges, concluding that the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment prohibited a State prosecutor from exercising peremptory challenges solely on the basis of race, is also applicable to limit a defendant's use of race-based peremptory challenges pursuant to CPL 270.25, which provides for peremptory challenges, since the plain language of the statute does not differentiate between the prosecution, which must provide racially neutral reasons for the challenges once the appropriate showing of discrimination has been made, and the defense; the legislative intent is clearly that the prosecution and the defense be accorded equal treatment in the use of peremptory challenges, which is consistent with the right [***4] of both parties to a fair trial and an impartial jury. Moreover, the State, which undeniably has a right to a fair trial, is also entitled to a petit jury drawn from a fair cross section of the community; the loss of the varieties of human experience resulting from race-based peremptory challenges, coupled with the odious nature of racial discrimination, which is contrary to the public policy of the State, can only lead to the conclusion that peremptory challenges cannot be permitted to be the judicially countenanced vehicle of racial discrimination.

Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of Jury -- Use by Defense of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges -- Procedure

5. The procedure enunciated in Batson v Kentucky (476 U.S. 79), wherein the Supreme Court prohibited a State prosecutor from using race-based peremptory jury challenges and required the People to come forward with a racially neutral explanation for their use of the challenges after a prima facie showing of purposeful discrimination has been made, is equally applicable to the defense where it is alleged to be using race-based challenges; accordingly, once the prosecution makes a prima facie showing that the defense is making [***5] peremptory challenges solely on the basis of race, the defense is required to come forward and articulate a racially neutral explanation for its challenges.

Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of Jury -- Use by Defense of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges -- Prima Facie Showing

6.
