A granddaughter, born more than 20 years after the ingestion of the drug diethylstilbestrol (DES) by her grandmother, does not have a cause of action against the drug manufacturer for birth defects alleged to have resulted from her mother's injuries which are linked to the drug ingestion since the Legislature, in enacting the revival statute permitting the late filing of DES claims for an identifiable group of victims (L 1986, ch 682, § 4), could not have intended the statute to cast liability backward to third generation unconceived plaintiffs. Although the Court of Appeals has not specifically approved either the concerted action, alternative liability, enterprise or market share theories of liability in affirming a judgment against a drug manufacturer in a DES case (see, Bichler v Lilly & Co., 55 NY2d 571, affg 79 AD2d 317) the decision of the Appellate Division in that case allowing a "limited expansion of the doctrine of [***2] concerted action to cover the type of circumstances faced in a DES case" where it is difficult to establish which particular drug manufacturer produced the DES actually ingested, must be followed so as to defeat defendants' motion for summary judgment. Exceptional circumstances, due to the undetectability of DES injuries until the second generation, support the constitutionality of the revival statute, which also revives any derivative claim of plaintiff's husband for loss of consortium.

 

1441 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Himelein v. Frank


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Cattaraugus County


141 Misc. 2d 416; 532 N.Y.S.2d 977; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 620



September 15, 1988 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended November 29, 1988.



DISPOSITION: For all of the reasons stated herein the motion of the defendant to dismiss the complaint is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court was defendant's motion to dismiss a forfeiture action brought by plaintiff district attorney after defendant was permitted to enter a plea to the crime of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the seventh degree, a misdemeanor. Defendant contended that the acceptance of the plea of guilty to a misdemeanor in satisfaction of the felony charge terminated the right of the district attorney to proceed for a forfeiture.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with felony drug crimes and he entered a guilty plea to criminal possession of a controlled substance in the seventh degree. The district attorney subsequently filed a forfeiture action against defendant. The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the complaint. Under the doctrine of issue preclusion the guilty plea precluded relitigation in the forfeiture action of all issues determined by the conviction. Defendant did not waive his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination as to any felony counts charged against him in the forfeiture action by reason of his plea to the unspecified misdemeanor. Those rights continued. Since the procedure under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 13-A required defendant to answer drug-related felony charges by admitting or denying them at the risk of a judgment by default against him, it denied defendant the protection against self-incrimination provided under the Fifth Amendment and was unconstitutional. The district attorney was precluded from bringing a criminal proceeding against defendant on charges that were dismissed as a result of the plea and he was not entitled to bring a civil proceeding of forfeiture for the same crimes.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the complaint filed by the district attorney seeking a forfeiture.


HEADNOTES

Forfeitures and Penalties -- Forfeiture of Proceeds of Crime

New York's forfeiture statute ( CPLR art 13-A), which permits a prosecutor to initiate and conclude a forfeiture action for enumerated drug-related felonies without the necessity of ever proceeding against the defendant by way of an information or an indictment charging crimes in a criminal action, is unconstitutional as violative of the Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination by requiring a defendant to answer drug-related felony charges by admitting or denying them at the risk of a default judgment without any exclusionary provision as to the use of evidence in the forfeiture action in any subsequent criminal action (see also, CPLR 4501). Defendant herein did not waive his right against self-incrimination as to any drug-related felony counts now charged against him in the forfeiture action by reason of his guilty plea in Justice Court to the misdemeanor of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the seventh degree (Penal Law § 220.03). The District Attorney, by permitting [***2] defendant to plead to a misdemeanor in satisfaction of the drug-related felony count, cannot, as a matter of due process, completely ignore the plea bargain and bring a forfeiture action more than two years after entry of the plea based upon the dismissed felony count or another drug-related crime that was never charged but is now alleged to have arisen from the same transaction. In addition, the forfeiture action would be dismissed in the interest of justice in any event ( CPLR 1311 [4]).

 

1442 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Subaru Distributors Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Village of North Hills, Nassau County


141 Misc. 2d 723; 534 N.Y.S.2d 305; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 690



September 13, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant's motion to dismiss the two captioned summonses is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant commercial vehicle owner sought dismissal of two summonses issued against it by the State of New York (state) for violation of vehicle length and width restrictions, pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law §§ 385(1), 385(4)(a).


OVERVIEW: The state issued two summonses against the commercial vehicle owner for driving a vehicle in excess of length and weight restrictions on a state expressway. The state expressway was a qualifying highway under § 1627(a). The commercial vehicle owner filed a motion, after a trial, dismissing the summonses. The motion was granted. The court held that the attempt by the state to regulate vehicle length and width encroached on an area of federal preemption. The court further held that because the state expressway was a qualifying highway, that the length and width of the vehicle were not outside the state-imposed limits.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the two summonses issued against the commercial vehicle owner for the operation of a vehicle in violation of state length and width limits on the state expressway.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Special Dimension Vehicles -- Hours of Operation Restrictions

New York State's Hours of Operation Restrictions prohibiting over-dimension trucks and trailers from using the Long Island Expressway (a Federally funded "qualifying" highway [Vehicle and Traffic Law §§ 134-a, 1627]) between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. ( 15 NYCRR 8028.00) is invalid as an unconstitutional intrusion into an area preempted by the Surface Transportation Assistance Act (49 USC § 2301). A footnote to a regulation of the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) providing that portions of the Expressway are "available to through traffic with operating limitations during the morning and evening peak traffic periods" (23 CFR part 658, appendix A) does not authorize the State to promulgate such a restrictive regulation without the approval of the FHWA (23 CFR 658.11) (the footnote having been removed from the regulation in response to a decision invalidating a similar New York City traffic regulation [see, New York State Motor Truck Assn. v City of New York, 654 F Supp 1521, affd 833 F2d 430]). Accordingly,  [***2] since defendant's motor vehicle transporter was otherwise within legal limits, having combination length of less than 72 feet in over-all length (seen, 23 CFR 658.13 [d] [1]), the traffic violations against it based upon using the Expressway at 4:55 p.m. are dismissed. Any attempt by the State to enforce an over-all length limitation for such transporters which is less than that permitted by the Federal Government or to impose Hours of Operation Restrictions would be invalid under the Supremacy Clause.

 

1443 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Dana Distributors, Inc. v. Department of Environmental Conservation


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


140 Misc. 2d 1071; 532 N.Y.S.2d 351; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 577



September 2, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff distributor sought declaratory and injunctive relief with respect to certain provisions of the New York State Returnable Container Act, N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-1001 et seq., and the regulations pursuant to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs., tit. 6, § 367 in its action against defendant New York State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation.


OVERVIEW: The distributor brought an action against the New York State Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation (commissioner), seeking declaratory and injunctive relief with respect to certain provisions of the New York State Returnable Container Act (Act), and the regulations promulgated by the commissioner under § 367. The court resolved the action in the commissioner's favor. With respect to the regulations promulgated by the commissioner, the court found that they were neither unauthorized nor in conflict with the terms of the Act. N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-1013 authorized the commissioner to promulgate rules and regulations governing the circumstances in which distributors could be required to accept the return of empty containers, including the imposition of "handling fees." The court held that the requirement that the distributor accept empty containers for which it did not initiate the deposit was not unconstitutional as "arbitrary and capricious." Furthermore, the court held that even assuming that the distributor had been adversely effected by the Act, it did not mean it was constitutionally infirm.


OUTCOME: The court held that the commissioner's regulation requiring the distributor to pay handling fees to dealers and redemption centers with which it did not have agreements was a proper exercise of its rule-making authority and that the requirements that the distributor accept empty containers sold by them even though they did not receive the initial deposit were not arbitrary and capricious and did not violate its right to due process of law.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Environmental Conservation -- Bottle Bill -- Handling Fees

A regulation of the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation requiring distributors of beverages to pay handling fees on returnable containers to dealers and redemption centers with which they do not have express agreements (6 NYCRR 367.6) is a proper exercise of the Commissioner's rule-making authority, and the requirement that distributors accept empty containers of every kind sold by them even though they did not receive the initial deposit is not arbitrary and capricious and violates no right of such distributors to due process of law. Inasmuch as the Returnable Container Act ( ECL, art 27, tit 10) requires distributors to accept returns from redemption centers with which they have agreements as well as from those with which they have no agreements, there is no valid reason to require handling fees in one instance and not in the other; moreover, assuming that distributors are adversely affected by the regulation, the mere fact that regulatory legislation imposes a heavy, or even an unequal, financial burden is not a sufficient basis for judicial relief.

 

1444 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Alliance for Progress, Inc. v. New York State Div. of Housing & Community Renewal


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County


141 Misc. 2d 365; 532 N.Y.S.2d 821; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 601



August 25, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For all of the foregoing reasons, the petition is denied in all respects and is hereby dismissed; the motion by respondents is granted accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner not-for-profit corporation instituted a claim for funds earmarked for the not-for-profit corporation , and specifically appropriated over a period of three years by the state legislature. Respondents Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) and the Division of the Budget moved for a judgment pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211 (a) (2), (5) and (7) and 7804 (f) dismissing the petition.


OVERVIEW: The court held that the issue presented was whether the not-for-profit corporation could enforce payment of undistributed moneys appropriated under the member item system by the state legislature. The court held that the not-for-profit corporation failed to meet its burden of establishing its entitlement to relief upon the alleged enforceability of Green Book allocations for the fiscal years 1985-1986 and there was no evidence presented to the court which is even suggestive of an appropriation for 1986-1987. Furthermore, the court agreed with the contention of the DHCR and the Division of the Budget that the sole remaining claim was purely contractual, and could be brought only in the Court of Claims. Finally, that portion of the petition which sought a letter confirmation from the DHCR and the Division of the Budget of the fact that two loans were forgiven by law was denied, as there was no showing that writing such letters was a mandatory act that the DHCR and the Division of the Budget were enjoined to do under the law. Therefore, the court denied the not-for-profit corporation's petition and granted the DHCR and the Division of the Budget's motion to dismiss.


OUTCOME: The court denied the not-for-profit corporation's petition and granted the DHCR and the Division of the Budget's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

State -- Budget -- "Green Book" Allocations -- Lump-Sum Appropriation

Petitioner not-for-profit corporation cannot enforce payment of undistributed moneys appropriated under the member item system by the State Legislature, where petitioner bases its entitlement to such moneys on an allocation of a lump-sum appropriation contained in the "Green Book", the Report of the Fiscal Committee on the Executive Budget, which is prepared and submitted to the Governor by the Chairmen of the Senate Finance Committee and of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, since the allocations in the "Green Book", taken together with the budget lump-sum appropriations and the subsequent passage of the budget into law, do not establish the absolute entitlement of petitioner to the funds as a matter of law; when the lump-sum appropriations are signed into law, the power of the Director of the Budget does not become simply ministerial, since such an interpretation would vest legislative committees with the power reserved to the executive branch of segregating [***2] lump-sum appropriations. Moreover, if the Governor's line item veto power could be circumvented by the mere use of the "Green Book" device, then the executive branch would be effectively deprived of its role in overseeing and implementing programs funded by the Legislature, and would render the approval function of the Director of the Budget a rubber stamp. Accordingly, where questions of propriety are raised concerning a specific member item, which have led to a criminal investigation, the beneficiary of that allocation has failed to show that the State respondents are under a mandatory duty to fund the appropriation, and the petition is dismissed.

 

1445 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Grupe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


141 Misc. 2d 6; 532 N.Y.S.2d 815; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 583



August 17, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant instituted a motion to dismiss a count of aggravated harassment in the second degree as violative of his rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendments. Defendant was charged under N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(3) after he struck a man and shouted ethnic slurs at him. Section 240.30(3) regulated violent conduct and physical intimidation when committed intentionally and because of racial, ethnic, or religious prejudice.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that § 240.30(3) violated his freedom of speech and equal protection rights. The court disagreed and denied the motion to dismiss. The intent of the law was to prohibit violence based upon bigotry. The statute did not attempt to prohibit bigotry itself, merely violent conduct. Such regulation was a valid exercise of police power because there was a reasonable relationship between the public welfare and the prohibition of such conduct. Thus, no valid First Amendment issue was raised. Even if defendant's behavior were to be deemed expressive, however, it would not have been entitled to First Amendment protection because the subject speech was properly considered "fighting words." If § 240.30(3) did incidentally inhibit speech in some cases, the statute was narrowly drawn to the degree required to restrict speech only in cases that involved acts of violence of physical intimidation. Finally, there was no equal protection violation because the legislature had a rational basis for the classification in the statute, namely, the prevention of bias-related violence.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motions to dismiss in all respects and referred the case for determination of a trial date.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Aggravated Harassment -- Validity of Statute

Defendant was charged with aggravated harassment in the second degree (Penal Law § 240.30 [3]) in that he allegedly struck the complainant while shouting ethnic slurs, and his motion to dismiss the charge on the ground that the statute violates his rights to freedom of speech and equal protection of the laws under the US Constitution (1st, 14th Amends) is denied. No First Amendment issue is raised since the intent of the statute is to prohibit violence and physical intimidation based upon bigotry. Even if defendant's behavior were considered expressive, violent demonstrations are not protected under the First Amendment, and constitutional guarantees of freedom of speech do not prevent States from punishing "fighting words", those by which their very utterance inflict injury or tend to incite an immediate breach of the peace. There is a compelling governmental interest in penalizing bias-related violence which is unrelated to the suppression of free expression, and the statute is narrowly drawn to apply only to those situations involving acts of violence or physical intimidation. The legislative determination to classify [***2] bias-motivated harassment as a class A misdemeanor punishable by up to one year in jail, while classifying similar conduct involving harassment not based upon the race or ethnicity of the victim as a noncriminal offense punishable by no more than 15 days in jail, was a rational one, given the increasing problems of bias-related violence. Furthermore, there is a rational basis for the Legislature to have concluded that the measure was necessary to redress past discrimination.

 

1446 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hirsch


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Kings County


140 Misc. 2d 881; 531 N.Y.S.2d 865; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 503



August 5, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant's motion to dismiss is accordingly denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with having violated a Buildings Department order to discontinue a use as being contrary to the certificate of occupancy. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss, challenging New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 27-217, as unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with having violated § 27-217. Defendant contended that he was unable to recognize or understand that his conduct was in violation of law because there were no fixed standards in the Administrative Code that differentiated an office from a store. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss. The court determined that it was clear that § 27-217 afforded adequate notice that one must first obtain a new certificate of occupancy before changing a use to one not permitted by the existing certificate. The court concluded that neither the Administrative Code nor the pleadings should have been considered vague because they did not define or explain the words "office" and "store" because these words were commonly used and understood. The court noted that, when served with a notice of violation, defendant had ample warning that the city believed that he was acting illegally, and that his failure to obey the order would have constituted a prosecutable offense. The court explained that defendant's apparent inaction could only be regarded as a voluntary and calculated risk.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the charge against him of having violated a Buildings Department order to discontinue a use as being contrary to the certificate of occupancy.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Constitutionality of Ordinance

In a criminal prosecution involving the violation of a zoning ordinance, defendant's contention that the ordinance, which permits the subject premises to be used as a "store" but not an "office", is unconstitutionally void for vagueness as applied only to him, is without merit since a statute is either impermissibly vague or not vague in relation to the world-at-large and it is of no moment that one discrete individual asserts that he is unable to comprehend that which is readily apparent to other reasonable people of ordinary intelligence. Accordingly, neither the statute nor the pleadings should be construed as vague because they do not define or explain the words "store" and "office" since those words are commonly used and understood. However, defendant has asserted a valid defense which he may attempt to prove at trial, viz., that he was not using the subject premises as an "office".

 

1447 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Morgenstern


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Rochester


140 Misc. 2d 861; 531 N.Y.S.2d 751; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 496



August 4, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the criminal information for aggravated harassment in the second degree, a misdemeanor, N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(1), based on the bad language that he included on a note written on the back of the parking ticket and guilty plea that he returned by mail to the Parking Violation Bureau.


OVERVIEW: Defendant received a parking ticket. He returned it by mail along with the guilty plea and a check for the fine. He also wrote a note of protest on the back of the ticket using bad language. Defendant was then charged with aggravated harassment in the second degree, a misdemeanor, violating N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(1). Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the criminal information as unconstitutional and lacking in sufficient factual allegations to support the charge. The trial court granted the motion dismissing the petition. The court determined that the note was a protest, that the note was not legally obscene or fighting words, that, as applied to defendant for merely annoying an official, the statute was unconstitutional, and that the accusatorial instrument was defective as a matter of law because of its lack of sufficient factual allegations.


OUTCOME: The trial court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the charge because the statute as applied to defendant's written note was unconstitutional and the accusatory instrument was defective as a matter of law.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Aggravated Harassment

An information charging defendant with aggravated harassment in the second degree (Penal Law § 240.30 [1]) for writing "There are no suck f   g signs posted anywhere" on a parking ticket which he returned by mail to the Parking Violations Bureau along with his guilty plea and check for the amount of the fine is dismissed. Such words of protest are constitutionally protected, and the mere fact that the receiver of this written communication found the words "annoying" is not enough to bring it within section 240.30. The statute is unconstitutional as applied to defendant and the accusatory instrument is defective as a matter of law.

 

1448 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Stefano


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


140 Misc. 2d 801; 531 N.Y.S.2d 212; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 481



July 26, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Based upon the foregoing reasons, it is hereby ordered that the motion for discharge and release of the patient is hereby denied, and the court will proceed to make a decision regarding retention for an additional 30-day period after completion of a hearing, held pursuant to Mental Hygiene Law § 9.31.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Movant patient sought an order requiring her discharge from respondent hospital. The application was based on the contention that the application and certification for involuntary commitment pursuant to N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 9.27 were defective and violative of due process for failing to establish that the patient posed a real and present threat of substantial harm to herself or others.


OVERVIEW: A patient was involuntarily admitted to a psychiatric hospital based upon a two-physician certification pursuant to § 9.27. The patient requested a hearing pursuant to § 9.31 but, prior to the hearing, the patient sought to be discharged. The court denied her motion for discharge, after finding that (1) the involuntary commitment procedure under § 9.27 was constitutional, (2) the procedure required a finding that the patient was dangerous to herself or others, and (3) such a finding could be inferred from the descriptions of her behavior and condition given by the two physicians. The court found that the patient's manic-depressive condition, coupled with her current refusal to take medication and a past suicide attempt, created an implicit finding that the patient was dangerous to herself.


OUTCOME: The court denied the patient's motion for discharge and delayed making a decision regarding retention for an additional 30 day period until after the scheduled hearing was completed.


HEADNOTES

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons -- Involuntary Commitment of Mentally Ill Person -- Standard of Dangerousness

The appropriate, constitutionally mandated standard for the involuntary admission of a mentally ill person for a 60-day period without a court order of retention pursuant to a two-physician certification (Mental Hygiene Law § 9.27) requires a determination that the person to be committed poses a real and present threat of substantial harm to himself or others since a showing of mental illness alone is insufficient to involuntarily confine a person to a mental institution. A finding that a patient poses a real and present threat of harm to himself or others may now be considered implicit in the findings contained in the preprinted Office of Mental Health admission forms that alternative forms of care and treatment have been considered and that the patient's judgment  [***2] is impaired to such a degree as to be unable to understand the need for such care and treatment, but the facts establishing the element of dangerousness should be set forth in the physician's certification. Accordingly, the patient's long-standing mental illness of bipolar disorder, the discontinuation of her medication and recent aberrant behavior all set forth in the application and certifications are sufficient to form the conclusion that the patient should be retained.

 

1449 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Landquest, Inc. v. Planning Bd. of Hoosick


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Rensselaer County


140 Misc. 2d 513; 531 N.Y.S.2d 207; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 461



July 21, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, a real estate development company and others, filed an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7803(2) seeking an order prohibiting respondents, the Planning Board of the Town of Hoosick and others, from exercising jurisdiction over a land subdivision. Petitioners claimed that respondents had no authority pursuant to Town Law § 276 to approve or disapprove the subdivision, and respondents claimed that the Board did have jurisdiction.


OVERVIEW: Petitioners bought land in the town and obtained all necessary approvals before commencing construction of a two-family building on one of its lots at the subdivision in question, including rough grading of the site and installing gravel for a roadway. The town then adopted planning regulations that gave the Board authority to approve all land subdivisions. The Board directed all work at the subdivision to stop and directed petitioners to submit an application for review. Petitioners filed suit, seeking an order prohibiting the Board from exercising jurisdiction over the subdivision. The court ruled that the Board did have jurisdiction to review the subdivision, and that Town Law § 276(1) was not unconstitutional as applied to petitioners. The court noted that § 276(1) gave the Board review authority over plats where 20 percent or more of the lots within the plat were unimproved. Improvement did not include surveying or laying out of lots, the court ruled, but instead required a building or completed roads, sewers, water, electric and other capital improvements. Petitioners' lots were therefore unimproved and subject to the Board's jurisdiction.


OUTCOME: The court held that the Board had jurisdiction to review the subdivision. It ruled that the law granting to the Board jurisdiction over the subdivision was not unconstitutional as applied to petitioners, and it dismissed petitioner's action.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Planning -- Approval of Filed Subdivision Plats

Respondent Planning Board, which was granted authority by the town to approve land subdivisions after petitioners had been granted approval for a 15-lot subdivision, has jurisdiction to review the existing filed subdivision since a Planning Board has authority "to approve the development of plats already filed" if 20% or more of the lots within the plat are "unimproved" (Town Law § 276 [1]) and petitioners' improvements, consisting of the rough grading of the site, installation of gravel for a roadway on part of the site and the commencement of construction of a two-family residential building on one lot, do not exceed the 20% requirement regarding Planning Board review. The legislative intent, in defining improvement, was to require a building constructed on each lot or installation of fully completed roads, sewers, water, electric and other capital improvements. The statute is not unconstitutional as applied to petitioners.

 

1450 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re S. Children


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Orange County


140 Misc. 2d 980; 532 N.Y.S.2d 192; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 522



July 15, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent, party to a family court proceeding as a mother of five infants, commenced contempt proceedings against judicial invitee, a reporter from the local daily press, who had published materials regarding closed proceedings in violation of a minimal restraining order. The reporter cross-moved for a reargument against the restraining order and dismissal of the contempt proceedings based on lack of jurisdiction.


OVERVIEW: The family court proceedings concerned a matter commenced by petitioner, county department of social services, against the mother and were brought under the Fam. Ct. Act. Art. 10. The reporter had been invited to be present by the judge prior to the determination of whether to open the proceedings that were confidential and closed under the Fam. Ct. Act §§ 1043,166. The reporter published an article regarding the proceeding while under a 22-hour injunction against publication. The court denied the motion of the mother for a professional misconduct investigation of the reporter, who was also present as legal counsel for the paper, because it lacked the authority. The court held that the order was valid and that the reporter and the paper he worked for willfully violated the restraining order. The court held that when the reporter and the paper ignored a court order that they believed constituted a prior restraint of their First Amendment rights they risked criminal contempt charges. Due to the uncertainties in the law regarding prior restraints of speech, the court determined that the violation was not deserving of punishment.


OUTCOME: The court held that the reporter had violated the restraining order against publication of confidential proceedings but that the infraction was not deserving of punishment or sanctions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parent and Child -- Abused or Neglected Child -- Access of News Media to Child Protective Proceedings

A newspaper whose representative was invited to present legal arguments on the issue of whether the news media should be conditionally allowed to cover child protective proceedings against respondent, the mother of five young infants, is guilty of willfully violating a temporary court order restraining it from publishing information about the proceedings for 22 hours since the Family Court can set conditions and restrictions when permitting access to its "closed" and "confidential" proceedings (Family Ct Act §§ 1043, 166; 22 NYCRR 205.4, 205.5) that the press cannot ignore as an unconstitutional prior restraint. However, given the uncertainty in the law regarding the collision between the rights of the press to be free of prior restraints and the obligation of the courts to see that their orders are enforced, the newspaper's violation was not culpable or deserving of punishment. Family Court child protective proceedings should be conditionally open to the news media, subject to conditions protecting the identities of the children involved, in order to better inform the public  [***2] as well as the Legislature of the crisis in our society involving child abuse and neglect and the inherent inadequacies of the systems established to protect children including foster care.

 

1451 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gallagher


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Suffolk County


140 Misc. 2d 281; 531 N.Y.S.2d 970; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 425



July 6, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants sought dismissal of the charges against them for falsifying police reports, contending that the appointment of a special district attorney to prosecute the case was illegal and unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were alleged to have prepared and filed falsified police forms, which resulted in one of defendant's sons receiving a sentence of probation, as opposed to incarceration, on a pending narcotics conviction. Presentation of the case to the grand jury was by the second special district attorney (second DA) appointed pursuant to N.Y. County Law § 701. The charges initially surfaced as during an investigation by the Temporary State Commission of Investigation (commission). After first special district attorney (first DA) was appointed, the commission asked for the revocation of his appointment because it claimed that he had a conflict of interest with the commission. The appointment was revoked. Thereafter the second DA was appointed. Defendants contended that the appointment was illegal and unconstitutional. The court dismissed the charges against defendants, holding that the appointment of the second DA was a nullity because the revocation of the first DA's appointment was in excess of the commission's statutory authority, which tainted the prosecution.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the charges of falsifying police reports against defendants.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] District and Prosecuting Attorneys -- Special Prosecutor -- Revocation of Appointment

In a criminal prosecution of two police officers in which a Special Prosecutor was appointed (see, County Law § 701), the revocation of the appointment of that prosecutor was improper where there was no showing that any conflict of interest would have arisen had that prosecutor gone forward with the case, that the public would lack confidence in the prosecutor, or that there was any risk that the prosecutor would abuse that confidence; acts taken by the Temporary State Commission of Investigation to have the prosecutor removed were an abuse of power and without legal authority. Accordingly, the indictment resulting from the presentation to the Grand Jury made by the replacement of the Special Prosecutor whose appointment was revoked must be dismissed since the second prosecutor's appointment was null and void, it having been made as a direct result of the improper disqualification of the first Special Prosecutor, and, thus, the second prosecutor was unauthorized to make a presentation to the Grand Jury.

 

1452 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


595 Investors Ltd. Partnership v. Biderman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


140 Misc. 2d 441; 531 N.Y.S.2d 714; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 418



July 6, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is denied and defendants' cross motion for summary judgment is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff limited partnership filed a motion for summary judgment and defendant commissioner filed a cross motion for summary judgment. The limited partnership contended that the Real Property Transfer Tax amendment, N.Y. City Admin. Code § 11-2102(b)(1), did not on its face apply to transfers of limited partnership interests, and application of the amendment to transfers of partnership interests violated the state and federal constitutions.


OVERVIEW: A limited partnership did not own any real property itself, but was the sole limited partner in another limited partnership whose sole asset was a building located in New York City. The legislature enacted enabling legislation, under which the city amended its Real Property Transfer Tax law. Under the amendment, the city applied the tax to transfers of the limited partnership's interests. The limited partnership paid the tax and brought an action for a refund. The tax did not specifically apply to transfers of interests in an entity that did not itself own real property. The court invoked the substance-over-form rule to hold that the amendment did apply to transfers of the limited partnership interests. The legislature had intended to close a loophole in enacting the enabling legislation. The court held that sales of limited partnership interests were, in effect, sales of interests in the real property. The court held that the tax did not constitute an ad valorem tax prohibited by N.Y. Const. art. XVI, § 3, nor did it violate the Due Process and Commerce Clauses of the federal Constitution. Retroactive application was permitted because it was for a reasonable period of time.


OUTCOME: The court denied the limited partnership's motion for summary judgment and granted the commissioner's cross motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- New York City Real Property Transfer Tax -- Use of Two-Tiered Partnership Device to Avoid Tax

The New York City Real Property Transfer Tax, which, retroactive to July 13, 1986, imposes a transfer tax "on each instrument or transaction * * * whereby any economic interest in real property is transferred" (Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-2102 [b] [1]), applies to plaintiff's syndication to limited partners in October 1986 of more than a 50% interest in itself when plaintiff did not own any realty in New York City, but was the sole limited partner in a partnership that did, since the two-tiered partnership device, whereby a shell partnership is created to separate title ownership from the entity in which the economic interests with respect thereto were transferred, may not be used as a tax avoidance device when the purpose of the statute is to tax transactions which effectively, but indirectly, convey real property. The sales of plaintiff's partnership interests were, in essence, the sales of interests in real property situated in  [***2] New York City with the purchasers of the limited partnership interests obtaining their profits exclusively from revenues, capital appreciation and tax benefits attributable to the property and this is precisely the sort of transaction the statute was intended to reach. Taxation of the transfers does not violate the constitutional prohibition against the imposition of an ad valorem tax on intangible personal property (NY Const, art XVI, § 3) nor does it violate either the Commerce or Due Process Clause of the Federal Constitution. In addition, the five-month retrospective application of the statute is lawful since closing a perceived loophole in the law is a reasonable basis on which to legislate retroactively when the public was on notice at all times during the retroactive period of the city's intention to impose a tax on transfers of economic interests in real property.

 

1453 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Nemadi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


140 Misc. 2d 712; 531 N.Y.S.2d 693; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 448



June 21, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For all the foregoing reasons, the defendant's motion to dismiss is denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants were charged with failing to provide, install, and maintain window guards on apartments they owned in accordance with N.Y. City Health Code § 131.15 and N.Y. Admin. Code § 17-123. Defendants sought to dismiss the charges since the allegedly violated statutes were not published in the City Record and because of the alleged unconstitutionality of the statutes.


OVERVIEW: The statutes in question made the failure to provide window guards a misdemeanor. Under the old law, a landlord could defendant himself by showing that he inquired with the tenant whether the tenant wanted the guards, but the tenant answered negatively or gave no response. The defense was no longer allowed if a landlord had actual notice of the need for guards. The trial court denied the motion to dismiss. Strict liability criminal statutes in the area of public health and safety were lawful where there was clear legislative intent. The legislative intent was to protect children. State law did not preempt the statutes. The elimination of the landlord's defense did not create an irrebuttable presumption that the statutes were violated. The classification of all health code violations as misdemeanors was not an unlawful delegation of legislative power. Defendants did not have standing to challenge the classification of other health code provisions. Defendant's selective enforcement argument failed since they did not show that the statutes were deliberately applied unevenly based on an arbitrary classification. The new rules were not an unauthorized form of taxation.


OUTCOME: Defendants' motion to dismiss was denied. Window guard regulations were constitutional. Strict liability criminal statutes were lawful in the area of public health and safety. The elimination of one form of defense did not create an irrebuttable presumption of guilt. It was not unlawful to classify all health code violations as misdemeanors. The window guard statutes were not selectively enforced.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Window-Guard Law

New York City's "Window-Guard Law", which requires the installation of window guards in apartments inhabited by children under the age of 11 (NY City Health Code § 131.15; Administrative Code of City of New York § 17-123), is a strict liability criminal offense requiring no mens rea since effective enforcement of a program designed to protect the lives of young children from accidental death and injury resulting from window falls would be illusory if intent were made an element of the offense. The fact that a prosecution under State law for a "willful" violation of a local health regulation (Public Health Law § 12-b [2]) requires a showing that the underlying offense was committed "knowingly" (see, People v Coe, 71 NY2d 852) does not prevent the City of New York from enforcing provisions of its own Health Code on a strict liability basis pursuant to its power to enact local laws on matters of public health (NY City Charter § 558 [e]; Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 [1] [ii] [a] [12]). The State has not preempted the field nor is the "Window-Guard  [***2] Law" inconsistent with the State's general law and, even if it were inconsistent, the "Window-Guard Law" would be upheld as dealing with a unique local problem. The law does not create an irrebuttable presumption of guilt merely by virtue of the absence of window guards nor does the designation of every violation of a Health Code regulation as a misdemeanor constitute an unlawful delegation of legislative authority to the Board of Health. Lastly, defendants' bare assertions that managers of city-owned housing are not prosecuted are insufficient to establish even a colorable claim of selective prosecution.

 

1454 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Henry v. New York State Com. of Investigation


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Suffolk County


141 Misc. 2d 849; 535 N.Y.S.2d 859; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 699



June 20, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, the district attorney and the head of the narcotics bureau, brought an action against the respondent state investigatory commission (SIC) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief and they also requested the court to review the SIC's report prior to its release. The SIC filed a cross motion to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: The district attorney and the head of the narcotics bureau brought a proceeding seeking multifaceted relief. They alleged that the state commission of investigation (SIC) in the course of their two-year probe of the county police department and district attorney's office, had committed specific acts and engaged in a course of conduct which, inter alia, have exceeded the SIC's jurisdiction, impinged upon the jurisdiction of the district attorney, and violated the constitutional and statutory rights of the assistant and others. For the most part, they sought declaratory and injunctive relief, but they also asked the court to review the report which was prepared by SIC prior to its release. The court denied the district attorney and bureau head's various requests for relief. The investigation complained of was squarely within SIC's legislative mandate. Since the SIC was not a judicial or quasi-judicial body, and its role was purely investigatory, there was no basis for judicial review of the SIC's report. Lastly, the constitutionality of the act creating the SIC had been specifically upheld and the procedures governing the SIC. had also passed constitutional muster.


OUTCOME: The district attorney and the head of the narcotics bureau's requests for declaratory judgments, injunctive relief, and certiorari were all denied. The motion for discovery as well as the motion for permission to intervene were also denied. The SIC's cross motion to dismiss was granted.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Pleading -- Sufficiency of Pleading -- Allegations Accepted as True

1. In a proceeding brought by a District Attorney and an Assistant District Attorney against the State Commission of Investigation seeking a judgment declaring certain alleged conduct of the Commission unconstitutional or illegal, enjoining such conduct in the future, and prohibiting the Commission from taking any further action against petitioners, for the purposes of deciding the Commission's motion to dismiss the proceeding, all the allegations of the petition are taken as admitted.

Parties -- Standing -- Standing of District Attorney to Prohibit State Commission of Investigation from Acting against Him or His Staff

2. In a proceeding brought by a District Attorney and an Assistant District Attorney against the State Commission of Investigation seeking a judgment declaring certain alleged conduct of the Commission unconstitutional or illegal, enjoining such conduct in the future, and prohibiting the Commission from taking any further action against petitioners, petitioners do have standing where the Commission has virtually "accused" the Assistant District Attorney of certain crimes and has made those  [***2] "accusations" in written press releases, notwithstanding the fact that the Commission is an investigatory, rather than an accusatory body, since such a distinction is lost on the general public; petitioners obviously have an interest in protecting their names.

Parties -- Intervention -- Denial Where Intervention Would Complicate Proceedings

3. In a proceeding brought by a District Attorney and an Assistant District Attorney against the State Commission of Investigation seeking a judgment declaring certain alleged conduct of the Commission unconstitutional or illegal, enjoining such conduct in the future, and prohibiting the Commission from taking any further action against petitioners, an application for permission to intervene on behalf of an individual who has been named in a criminal indictment is denied where the indictment is being prosecuted by a Special District Attorney and an application has been made in that case to dismiss the indictment for the very same reasons urged in support of intervention here, i.e., that the Commission wrongfully interfered in the judiciary's role in the appointment of the Special District Attorney, that that appointment was a nullity, and  [***3] that, hence, the indictment must be dismissed; intervention will not only complicate the instant proceeding, but possibly prejudice the rights of the parties in the case being tried by the Special District Attorney. Moreover, the arguments raised in support of intervention will be adequately addressed in the criminal proceeding.

Disclosure -- Discovery and Inspection -- Pretrial Discovery

4. In a proceeding brought by a District Attorney and an Assistant District Attorney against the State Commission of Investigation seeking a judgment declaring certain alleged conduct of the Commission unconstitutional or illegal, enjoining such conduct in the future, and prohibiting the Commission from taking any further action against petitioners, the motion by the Assistant District Attorney for extensive pretrial discovery and inspection of documents is denied where it is apparent that movant or the District Attorney's office already has possession of virtually everything the Commission has done in connection with its investigation into petitioners' affairs; insofar as the demand is for all information exculpatory to petitioners or adversely affecting the credibility of any of the witnesses [***4] publicly presented or privately heard by the Commission, such information, while most likely discoverable in a criminal proceeding as Rosario or Brady material, is not discoverable at this stage of the instant civil proceeding (see, CPLR 3102 [c]), i.e., before respondents have served their answer. It is apparent that movant seeks material to help frame the allegations of his petition.

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Prohibition -- State Commission of Investigation

5. In a proceeding brought by a District Attorney and an Assistant District Attorney against the State Commission of Investigation seeking a judgment declaring certain alleged conduct of the Commission unconstitutional or illegal, enjoining such conduct in the future, and prohibiting the Commission from taking any further action against petitioners, so much of the petition as seeks relief in the nature of prohibition must be denied in view of the court's conclusion that the role of the Commission is purely investigative and that it cannot adjudicate or prosecute, since prohibition may be maintained solely to prevent or control a body or officer acting in a judicial or quasi-judicial capacity from [***5] proceeding in excess of its jurisdiction, and then only when the clear legal right to relief appears, and, in the court's discretion, the remedy is warranted. The Commission cannot indict and is not a Grand Jury; although those being investigated may be subjected to public opprobrium and scorn and the possibility of criminal prosecutions, those collateral consequences would not be the result of any affirmative determinations of the Commission and would not affect the legitimacy of the Commission's investigative function. Moreover, the instant investigation into alleged unlawful conduct by members of a local police department and the District Attorney's office is squarely within the legislative mandate of the Commission (see, McKinney's Uncons Laws of NY § 7502 [1] [a]-[c]).

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Certiorari -- Review of Report of State Commission of Investigation

6. In a proceeding brought by a District Attorney and an Assistant District Attorney against the State Commission of Investigation seeking a judgment declaring certain alleged conduct of the Commission unconstitutional or illegal, enjoining such conduct in the future, and prohibiting the Commission [***6] from taking any further action against petitioners, so much of the petition seeking relief in the nature of certiorari must be denied; since the Commission is not a judicial or quasi-judicial body, and its role is purely investigatory, there is no basis for judicial review of the Commission's report. Petitioners' request for certiorari can be granted only if the court accepts their argument that the Commission usurped the jurisdiction of a Grand Jury, but that is impossible since there is nothing in the legislation creating the Commission which even hints of an intent to vest it with authority to indict, and the report being prepared by the Commission does not come within the purview of CPL 190.85.

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- Constitutionality of Act Creating State Commission of Investigation

7. In a proceeding seeking a judgment declaring that the legislation creating the State Commission of Investigation (McKinney's Uncons Laws of NY §§ 7501-7507) is unconstitutional and that the Commission violated the due process rights of petitioners, a District Attorney and an Assistant District Attorney, petitioners' requests are denied; not only is there a strong [***7] presumption of constitutionality which accompanies every duly enacted law, but the constitutionality of the legislation in question has been specifically upheld by the Court of Appeals. The procedures governing the Commission have also passed constitutional muster, and petitioners' claim that the Commission unconstitutionally usurped the role of the Grand Jury has also been rejected, inasmuch as the Commission's function is investigatory not accusative. Moreover, petitioners' assertion that the Commission relied upon the testimony of admitted perjurors is immaterial, since when and if the time comes to prosecute, the Grand Jury considering the case(s) will be told they may indict only on the basis of competent legal evidence.

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- State Commission of Investigation Exceeding Its Authority

8. In a proceeding brought by a District Attorney and an Assistant District Attorney seeking judgments declaring that the State Commission of Investigation exceeded its statutory authority by, e.g., unlawfully intervening in the appointment of a Special District Attorney, petitioners' requests must be denied pending a hearing since many of the [***8] allegations made against the Commission have been contraverted; whether the Commission's conduct complied with the law and, if not, what affects its failure to do so would have, should only be decided after a full hearing on the issue.

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- State Commission of Investigation -- Televising of Commission Proceedings

9. In a proceeding brought by a District Attorney and an Assistant District Attorney seeking a judgment declaring that the State Commission of Investigation exceeded its authority by violating Civil Rights Law § 52 in that it allowed its proceedings to be televised, although the Commission conceded that the proceedings in question were in fact televised, declaratory judgment is inappropriate since any violation of section 52 is a misdemeanor and the court may not act as prosecutor and jury.

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- State Commission of Investigation -- Unlawful Intervention in Appointment of Special Prosecutor

10. In a proceeding brought by a District Attorney and an Assistant District Attorney seeking a judgment that the State Commission of Investigation exceeded its authority by unlawfully [***9] intervening in the appointment of a Special District Attorney, declaratory relief is inappropriate; while the conduct of the Commission in regard to the appointment in question was perhaps regrettable, being marked by a lack of cooperation with the first person so appointed, that conduct did not reach the level where it lends itself to a judgment declaring that the Commission violated its authority. The appointment was made by a Judge, who also appointed the replacement prosecutor.

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- State Commission of Investigation -- Charges of Professional Misconduct

11. In a proceeding brought by a District Attorney and an Assistant District Attorney seeking a judgment that the State Commission of Investigation exceeded its authority when some of its members engaged in acts proscribed by the Code of Professional Responsibility, a declaratory judgment is inappropriate since any charges of professional misconduct must first be referred to the appropriate Appellate Division and/or Grievance Committee. It is noted that members of the Commission who are lawyers are not "granted immunity" from their code of conduct when they act as commissioners.

 

1455 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ohrenstein


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


139 Misc. 2d 909; 531 N.Y.S.2d 942; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 452



June 15, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant state politicians brought omnibus motions challenging prosecution of indictments that alleged a conspiracy existed, under N.Y. Penal Law § 105.05, among them to commit the felonies of offering a false instrument for filing in the first degree, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 175.35, and grand larceny in the first and second degrees, N.Y. Penal Law §§ 155.35, 155.40, by using legislative employees to work on election campaigns.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff state brought an indictment against certain state politicians alleging they engaged in a conspiracy under N.Y. Penal Law § 105.05 to commit the felonies of offering a false instrument for filing in the first degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 175.35, and grand larceny in the first and second degrees, N.Y. Penal Law §§ 155.35, 155.40, by using legislative employees to work on election campaigns. The politicians brought omnibus motions challenging the prosecution of the indictment. The court ruled that the separation of powers doctrine did not require judicial deference to a patently unconstitutional and obviously unauthorized use of legislative appropriations. Further, the court held that courts did not assume that the legislature authorized its members to act in patent violation of its constitutional powers. The court sustained the indictment, concluding that it was a patent violation of the state constitution to pay legislative salaries for work which was of no value to any purpose but the election of a political candidate and to persons who never performed any service of value to the legislature or to any legislator in an official capacity.


OUTCOME: The motions challenging the indictment were denied, and the indictment was sustained.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Legislature -- Immunity from Prosecution for Legislative Acts -- Hiring Legislative Employees Solely to Work on Election Campaigns

1. Defendants, the Minority Leader of the New York State Senate, his chief of staff and three State Senators, may lawfully be prosecuted for offering a false instrument for filing (Penal Law § 175.35) and grand larceny (Penal Law § 155.40) for hiring onto the Senate payroll legislative employees to work full time on election campaigns on behalf of Democratic candidates for the State Senate in 1986 and then certifying on the biweekly payroll certification forms that such employees were performing "the proper duties of the position" of Senate legislative staff. Prosecution of defendants does not violate the separation of powers among the coordinate branches of the State government since the Speech or Debate Clause of the State Constitution (NY Const, art III, § 11), which provides that members of the Legislature "shall not be questioned" for "any speech or debate in either house", only confers immunity from prosecution on legislators and their staffs for legislative acts essential to the legislative process and defendants actions in employing persons exclusively  [***2] to perform political campaign functions which have no relation to the deliberative and communicative legislative process are not deserving of speech or debate protection. However, defendants may not be prosecuted for acts relating to the employment of three staff members who did not exclusively perform campaign work while on the legislative payroll since, once evidence appears that the activity under investigation is arguably within a proper legislative sphere, the prosecutor must establish that the prosecution will not encompass privileged legislative acts and the prosecutor herein has not met such burden as to those legislative employees.

 Legislature -- Immunity from Prosecution for Legislative Acts -- Hiring Legislative Employees Solely to Work on Election Campaigns

2. The separation of powers doctrine (see, NY Const, art III, § 11), which ordinarily protects legislative matters involving "political questions", such as the functions and duties of legislative staff, from judicial or executive interference, does not require judicial deference to a patently unconstitutional and unauthorized use of legislative appropriations and, thus, does not preclude the prosecution of  [***3] defendants, the Minority Leader of the New York State Senate, his chief of staff and three State Senators on charges of offering a false instrument for filing (Penal Law § 175.35) and grand larceny (Penal Law § 155.40) for hiring onto the Senate payroll legislative employees to work full time on the election campaigns on behalf of Democratic candidates for the State Senate in 1986 and then certifying on the biweekly payroll certification forms that such employees were performing "the proper duties of the position" of Senate staff. Defendants' expenditure of the funds appropriated for salaries of Senate staff to pay salaries of persons engaged full time in political campaigning was not a legislative function deserving constitutional protection from judicial interference, but was an unconstitutional private application of public revenue (NY Const, art VII, § 8). The constitutional prohibition against the use of State funds for private purposes, as construed by the courts, provides an appropriate source of standards by which limitations on the legislative function may be judicially determined. However, defendants may only be prosecuted with respect to the activities of staff hired solely  [***4] to work on the 1986 election since prosecution of defendants with respect to the activities of legislative employees who were employed prior to or subsequent to the 1986 election raises nonjusticiable questions regarding the internal administration of the Legislature's staff, which is an area peculiarly within the prerogative of the Legislature protected by the Constitution from executive or judicial interference.

 

1456 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


State v. County of Suffolk


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Suffolk County


140 Misc. 2d 482; 531 N.Y.S.2d 180; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 446



June 13, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] It, therefore, is ordered that the motion of plaintiff for summary judgment pursuant to CPLR 3212 is granted and the cross motion of defendant for summary judgment pursuant to CPLR 3212 is denied, and it is further ordered that the County of Suffolk is permanently enjoined from enforcing Suffolk County Local Law No. 37 due to its invalidity.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff State of New York sought a declaratory judgment pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3001 seeking a declaration of the invalidity and unenforceability of a local law of defendant Suffolk County, declaring that the use, sale or possession of "steel jaw leghold traps" to be unlawful within the County.


OVERVIEW: County of Suffolk, N.Y. Local Law No. 37 was an ordinance that declared the use, sale, or manufacture of leghold animal traps to be unlawful within the county. The authority to enact local laws was derived from the state constitution. The power granted to the county legislature was limited to that which was granted by the State. The power permitted the county to enact laws for the protection, safety, and well-being of persons and property within the county. However, the court found two reasons why the local law had to fall. First, under N.Y. Envt'l. Conserv. Law § 11-0111, county legislative bodies were not permitted to exercise powers concerning the protection or preservation of game or wildlife. Second, the State had preempted the field and had included certain leghold traps to be legal. The county could not override the general law, regardless of its motive.


OUTCOME: The court determined that the county law was invalid and enjoined its enforcement.


HEADNOTES

Game -- Steel Jaw Leghold Traps -- State Preemption

A county law which declares the use, sale or possession of steel jaw leghold traps to be unlawful within the county is invalid since the county law clearly regulates the preservation and protection of wildlife, which is expressly prohibited by ECL 11-0111 and is, therefore, violative of NY Constitution, article IX, § 2 (c) (ii); regardless of the laudable motive stated by the county in enacting the law in question, i.e., to protect persons within the county from the traps and their inherent dangers, one of the purposes of the law is to promote the more humane catching of animals and pursuant to hoary principles of statutory construction, the fact that the State has included certain traps of the sort in question and has excluded others (see, ECL 11-1101 [5], [6] [a]) makes it clear that  [***2] the Legislature intended to occupy the field and prevent local legislative bodies from passing conflicting enactments. Moreover, inasmuch as no facts are in dispute and a simple reading of the applicable laws and constitutional provisions is all that is required to determine the validity of the county law, summary judgment is an appropriate device to resolve the action in the interest of court economy.

 

1457 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York v. Park South Associates


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


139 Misc. 2d 997; 529 N.Y.S.2d 261; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 284



May 26, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendants' motion for summary judgment or dismissal of the complaint is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant landlords brought a motion for summary judgment or dismissal in an action against it by plaintiff City of New York for alleged violations of the City of New York's Unlawful Eviction Law (UEL), New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code §§ 26-521 to 26-529, asserting res judicata and preemption of the UEL by the state Omnibus Housing Act, 1983 N.Y. Laws 403.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff City of New York brought an action against defendant landlords for various acts of interference with and harassment of tenants and withholding of service on the part of defendants in order to induce tenants to vacate, in violation of the City of New York's Unlawful Eviction Law (UEL), New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code §§ 26-521 to 26-529. In similar complaints, tenants and defendants had settled, with defendants agreeing to make repairs and improvements in service and to pay tenants' legal fees. The complaints were dismissed with prejudice, and the parties agreed to use their best efforts to have the instant case dismissed with prejudice. The parties were ordered to comply with the terms of the stipulation of settlement. Defendants filed a motion for dismissal or summary judgment alleging that the matter was res judicata because of the order and that the UEL had been preempted by the Omnibus Housing Act (OHA), 1983 N.Y. Laws 403. The court denied the motion, concluding that plaintiff had no privity in the prior proceeding, so res judicata did not apply and that the evidence did not show that the OHA was intended to preempt the field of unlawful evictions.


OUTCOME: Defendant landlords' motion for summary judgment or dismissal was denied because defendants did not meet their burden of proving preemption and the invalidity of New York City's Unlawful Eviction Law.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Wrongful Eviction

The settlement of a proceeding brought by the tenants in defendants' buildings before the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) does not bar the City of New York, on grounds of res judicata, from bringing an action against defendants under the city's Unlawful Eviction Law (UEL) (Administrative Code of City of New York § 26-521 et seq.) based upon the same alleged acts of harassment of tenants and withholding of services in order to induce tenants to vacate their dwelling units since the city was not in privity with any party or otherwise in control of any party in the proceeding before the DHCR and, thus, cannot be bound by the settlement and the order of DHCR dismissing the proceeding with prejudice. The action by the city under the UEL is not preempted by the Omnibus Housing Act (L 1983, ch 403, § 1) which makes a finding that the public interest would be better served if the systems of regulation of rents and evictions were placed under a single State agency, since the State has not clearly evinced a desire to preempt the entire field  [***2] of unlawful evictions. Accordingly, the UEL continues as a tool in the hands of the Corporation Counsel to meet the city's special housing problems even after the assumption by the State of the administration of rent regulation.

 

1458 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Dowd


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Queens County


140 Misc. 2d 436; 530 N.Y.S.2d 733; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 417



May 12, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.20 to have the sentencing provisions of N.Y. Penal Law § 70.00 declared unconstitutional as applied to him as a violation of U.S. Const. amend. VIII. After he was convicted by a jury of robbery and attempted robbery, the court imposed the minimum sentence of an indeterminate term of two to six years and granted his motion for a stay of execution of the sentence pending his appeal.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's convictions were affirmed on appeal. The People took no position with respect to his motion to have the sentence set aside except to request certain conditions on a sentence of probation if the court granted the motion. The court granted the motion. Although the legislature had the power to determine sentences, the judicial branch had the power to determine whether the legislature had contravened a constitutional prohibition and the court held that it was not precluded from finding mandatory imprisonment cruel and unusual in defendant's case. It found that the punitive aspect of incarceration was not compelling because the loss to the complainants was minimal and no one was harmed. After his conviction, defendant graduated from high school and when he filed his motion, he was completing his sophomore year of college in religious studies and business administration. The court determined that the likelihood that he posed no further threat to the public was strong and that, in his case, the purposes of punishment were not best served by incarceration. Therefore, to apply a statutorily mandated term of imprisonment would have constituted cruel and unusual punishment.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to have his mandatory sentence of incarceration for robbery and attempted robbery declared unconstitutional as applied to him and directed him to present himself for sentencing.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Sentence

The imposition of a statutorily mandated term of imprisonment on defendant upon his conviction for first degree robbery for the robbery of a jacket and a small amount of currency would constitute cruel and unusual punishment since the sentencing statute's purposes of deterrence, isolation, retribution and rehabilitation will not best be served by incarceration in view of the evidence that defendant is well on the road to rehabilitation and will complete his education in religious studies and business administration. The punitive aspect of incarceration is not as compelling as in a case where injury was inflicted or the loss was great nor is the likelihood that defendant poses a further threat to the public very strong. Mandatory incarceration will not deter further criminal behavior because defendant has resolved to conduct himself within societal norms. Isolation will not serve to protect the public because defendant has taken control of his life and has struggled to conform and has successfully improved his stature in the community. The threat of incarceration for defendant during the pendency of the case has adequately served the ends of retribution.

 

1459 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


480 Suffolk Realty Corp. v. Board of Assessors


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Suffolk County


139 Misc. 2d 464; 531 N.Y.S.2d 168; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 317



May 3, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent taxing authority filed a motion for summary judgment that sought to preclude petitioner realty corporation from selecting a stratified random sample, pursuant to N.Y. Real. Prop. Tax. Law § 720(3), to support its claim of over assessment. The taxing authority also claimed, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3212(e), that N.Y. Real. Prop. Tax. Law § 720(3)(b)(1) was not applicable to the current proceedings.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Real. Prop. Tax. Law § 720 provided for the use of stratified random samples from the differing classes of real property for the purpose of comparison with a contested assessment, and further set forth that it applied to all proceedings that had been commenced prior to its effective date, but not yet finally determined by that date. Under N.Y. Real. Prop. Tax Law § 720(3)(b)(1) the court or referee was to select an expert who was to devise the methods and select parcels that were to have been appraised as part of the sample. The court denied the taxing authority's motion for summary judgment to preclude the realty corporation's use of the stratified random sample. The taxing authority's claim that the realty corporation purposefully delayed it challenge until passage of the new statute to gain the advantage of the more favorable sampling method was unsupported, and in any event the statute made itself applicable to the current proceedings. The taxing authority's claim that the statute was not applicable because it was unconstitutional was also denied because the taxing authority lacked standing to bring the challenge.


OUTCOME: The court denied the taxing authority's motion for summary judgment that sought to preclude the realty corporation's use of a stratified random sample of parcels in support of its claim that it had been over assessed, and denied its motion for summary judgment on the taxing authority's assertion that use of a stratified random sample was inapplicable.


HEADNOTES

Parties -- Standing -- Real Property Assessment Review

In consolidated proceedings in which petitioner seeks to show that its property has been overassessed for the years in question, respondents, the Board of Assessors and Board of Assessment Review, do not have standing to challenge the constitutionality of Laws of 1986 (ch 679), which amended Real Property Tax Law § 720 (3) to eliminate, as a means of proving overassessment, the sales survey method, and provided instead for stratified random samples as part of the select parcel method. Respondents would not, by complying with the statute, be forced to violate a constitutional proscription; no real property owned by respondents is involved; and finally, a nonministerial duty is not at issue.

 

1460 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


520 East 81st Street Assoc. v. Lenox Hill Hosp.


Index No.: 257007/85 002


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


142 Misc. 2d 723; 538 N.Y.S.2d 129; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 827



April 29, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant Maryann Hederman's cross motion for summary judgment ( CPLR 3212) is denied in its entirety and her counterclaims are dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff building owner filed a motion for a partial summary judgment declaring (1) that defendants, tenants and hospital, did not occupy their apartments as their primary residence and (2) which tenants were entitled to lease renewals. The hospital filed a cross-motion for a summary judgment dismissing the complaint and declaring that the hospital was entitled to a lease renewal. One tenant filed a separate cross-motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The building owner failed to give the hospital requisite notice of its intention to renew the hospital's lease and, instead, filed a declaratory action against defendants. The building owner alleged that only the tenants that continuously occupied their apartments were entitled to lease renewals. Upon review, the court denied the building owner's motion for a partial summary judgment. The court granted the hospital's cross-motion for a summary judgment dismissing the complaint. The court also granted the hospital's motion for summary judgment on its first, second, and third counterclaims. The court denied the tenant's cross-motion for summary judgment on her counterclaim. The court held that the owner was not entitled to a declaration of non-primary residence. The court further held that the building owner was required to offer the hospital a renewal lease. The court recognized that the building owner failed to follow the procedural requirements for determining a tenant's status as a non-primary resident, which included giving the tenant notice of landlord's intention not to offer a renewal lease.


OUTCOME: The court denied the building owner's motion for a partial summary judgment in its entirety. The court granted the hospital's cross-motion for summary judgment on its first, second, and third counterclaims and dismissed the complaint. The court further required the building owner to deliver renewal leases to the hospital within 30 days after service of a copy of the order. The court denied the tenant's cross-motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Lease -- Renewal Lease -- Notice of Intention Not to Renew

1.
