A landlord who failed to give a tenant notice of his intention not to offer a renewal lease between 120 and 150 days prior to the end of the lease term (Rent Stabilization Code [9 NYCRR] § 2523.5 [a]) is not entitled to a declaration of nonprimary residence and is required to offer a renewal lease, since in order to refuse to renew a lease on the grounds of nonprimary residence, a landlord must follow the statutorily mandated procedural requirements for obtaining a determination of the tenant's status.

Landlord and Tenant -- Lease -- Renewal Lease -- Hospital as Named Tenant

2. Pursuant to chapter 940 of the Laws of 1984, which amended the Administrative Code of the City New York and the Emergency Tenant Protection Act to make specific provision for not-for-profit hospitals subletting residential apartments, it is such a hospital which is entitled to renewal leases for those apartments since it is the named tenant on the expired renewal leases; the renewal [***2] leases should run prospectively from the date executed leases are delivered to the tenant. The landlord's argument that the subtenant nurses, and not the hospital which employs them, are the intended beneficiaries of chapter 940 and are entitled to the renewal leases is belied by the legislative history and statutory language of the law, since it is clear that the not-for-profit hospital is the tenant sought to be protected by the corrective legislation; in addition, subtenants have no right to renew under the Rent Stabilization Law (Administrative Code of City of New York § 26-511 [c] [12] [g]). Moreover, the landlord's assertion that chapter 940 is an unconstitutional discriminatory treatment and a taking without due process may not be considered because the Attorney-General has not been notified that the constitutionality of the statute was in issue (see, CPLR 1012 [b]; Executive Law § 71), and, in any event, that assertion is meritless.

 

1461 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Milbry


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


140 Misc. 2d 476; 530 N.Y.S.2d 928; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 447



April 28, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant who was an artist, filed a motion to dismiss his charge of displaying his paintings for the purpose of sale, in violation of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 20-453. He alleged that the requirement that he first obtain a vendor's license from the Department of Consumer Affairs was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, who was an artist, argued that the municipal statute, in requiring artists to obtain a license while exempting the vendors of written material from the licensing requirement, discriminated unreasonably against artwork. Since the artist's claim related to an alleged failure of equal protection of the laws, the court took an equal protection approach. There was no allegation that the statute operated on anything but a first-come, first-serve basis, that it was content-neutral and closed off no other means of dissemination. The vending of artwork, therefore, received all the First Amendment protection to which it is entitled. Although political artwork must be licensed and nonpolitical written matter need not be, the court still did not find that the presumption of constitutionality had been overcome. Therefore, the court denied defendant's motion to dismiss.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion was denied, but in light of the hardship he would suffer on conviction of the offense, the confiscation of his artwork and the tools of his trade, the court considered his motion to be one for dismissal in the interest of justice, which the court granted.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Hawkers and Peddlers -- Licensing of Street Vendors -- Sidewalk Sales of Artwork

The failure of New York City's street vendor licensing statute to include pictorial artwork in the exemption from the licensing requirement accorded vendors of written material (Administrative Code of City of New York § 20-453) does not constitute a denial of equal protection even though pictorial artwork, as a form of self-expression, is covered by the constitutional guarantee of freedom of speech, since not all legitimate forms of self-expression deserve the same administrative treatment. Since the licensing statute promotes a compelling purpose, the regulation of pedestrian traffic, operates on a first-come, first-serve basis, is content-neutral and closes off no other means of dissemination, the vending of artwork is receiving all the First Amendment protection to which it is entitled. Accordingly, defendant has failed to overcome his burden of showing that the coverage of the licensing exemption should be enlarged to include the sidewalk sales of his artwork but, in light of the hardship defendant will suffer on conviction of vending his paintings without having first obtained a vendor's license  [***2] from the Department of Consumer Affairs (confiscation of his artwork and the tools of his trade), the complaint is dismissed in the interest of justice ( CPL 170.40).

 

1462 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Health Ins. Ass'n v. Corcoran


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Albany County


140 Misc. 2d 255; 531 N.Y.S.2d 456; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 415



April 16, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] This court determines that the subject regulation is null and void.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners challenged the legality of respondent's amendments to 11 N.Y. C.R.R. part 52 as it related to the prohibitions against requiring or considering body fluid tests for evidence of the Human Immune Deficiency Virus (HIV) in the application for, or the risk management determinations of insurability for individual and small group health insurance.


OVERVIEW: Respondent, the superintendent of New York's department of insurance, adopted amendments to 11 N.Y. C.R.R. part 52. This amendment related to prohibitions against requiring or considering body fluid tests for evidence of Human Immuno Deficiency Virus (HIV) in the application for, or the risk management determinations of, insurability for individual and small group insurance. In issuing the regulation, respondent largely relied upon the certification of the state's health commissioner. Petitioners challenged such regulatory amendments and argued their invalidity on several grounds. The court ruled that the regulation was null and void by holding that a certain section of the state's insurance law provided no basis for the regulation, since it was arbitrary and capricious by respondent to deem HIV-positive high risk individuals to be part of the standard classifications used for ascertaining insurability. The court also concluded that the regulation itself was arbitrary and capricious and lacking a rational or factual basis as the reasons cited in the relied-upon certification were based upon social conjecture rather than objective fact or were speculative in nature.


OUTCOME: The court ruled that the regulation was null and void as a section of the state's insurance law provided no basis for the regulation. Furthermore, the regulation was deemed to be arbitrary and capricious and lacking a rational or factual basis since the reasons cited in the relied upon certification for its issuance, were based upon social conjecture or were speculative in nature.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- Health and Accident Insurance -- Tests for Human Immuno Deficiency Virus

The regulation of the Department of Insurance prohibiting insurers from requiring or considering body fluid tests for evidence of the Human Immuno Deficiency Virus (HIV) in the application for or the risk management determinations of insurability for individual and small group health insurance (see, 11 NYCRR part 52) is null and void as lacking a rational or factual basis since testing for HIV sero-positivity (HIV causes AIDS and AIDS Related Complex) produces a statistically valid basis for actuarial risk classification purposes as an accurate, significant and substantial predictor of morbidity, mortality and future medical expenses. Petitioners have established a firm foundation of minimum accepted facts and statistics in order to establish reasoned conclusions on the fiscal implications of the HIV epidemic on individual and small group health insurance policies and respondent has provided no valid basis for concluding that petitioners' position on the fiscal impact of inclusion of an uninsurable risk classification into  [***2] the standard insurable risk classifications is speculative. The prohibition against any unfair discrimination between individuals of the same class (Insurance Law § 4224) does not justify the regulation since the class of individuals consisting of sero-positive individuals is distinctly and substantially different in terms of morbidity, mortality and health expense risk from that of those who do not test positive and it is arbitrary and capricious to deem HIV-positive, high-risk individuals to be part of the standard classifications. The effect of the regulation is discriminatory since it affords the person infected with HIV a preferred economic status over persons infected with other health-threatening diseases or life-styles and requires the low-risk, uninfected policyholder to subsidize the policyholder infected with HIV.

 

1463 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Portnoy


DOCKET Nos. 7X051196-200, 7X051203-4


Criminal Court of New York, Bronx County


1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 206



April 15, 1988; Opinion withdrawn June 14, 1988; Substituted Opinion November 4, 1988


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion on separate dockets to dismiss the accusatory instruments, which charged defendants with allegedly failing to comply with the notices of violation and orders to abate nuisance issued by the department of health pursuant to New York City, N.Y., Charter §§ 558(e), 562 and New York City, N.Y., Health Code § 131.15(a) on grounds that the statutes defining the offenses charged were unconstitutional or otherwise invalid.


OVERVIEW: Defendants, who managed or control apartment buildings, received notices and orders to abate nuisance concerning window guard violations. They defaulted by failing to either appear at scheduled hearings to contest the orders or to correct the alleged violations and were charged by information with failing to comply with the notices and orders requiring them to provide, install, and maintain acceptable window guards under New York City, N.Y., Charter §§ 558(e), 562 and New York City, N.Y., Health Code § 131.15(a). Defendants then filed motions to dismiss on the ground that the informations were unconstitutional or otherwise invalid. The court held that: (1) the types of window guards deemed acceptable, and the installation requirements issued by the department were merely specifications and not regulations; (2) hence, the specifications required under § 131.15(a) were not rules having the force of law; (3) due process was not violated because the department had provided specifications as required under § 131.15, which were easily obtainable by defendants; and (4) the propriety of the orders could not be collaterally reviewed in criminal prosecutions for their disobedience.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed defendants' motions to dismiss in their entirety, in defendants' prosecution for failing to comply with the notices of violation and orders to abate issued by the department of health.

 

1464 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Amsterdam Garage v. Department of Consumer Affairs


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


139 Misc. 2d 799; 529 N.Y.S.2d 243; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 280



April 14, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Therefore, since the decision by the Hearing Officer of the Department of Consumer Affairs was not arbitrary, capricious, unreasonable, an abuse of discretion, or affected by errors of law, and was supported by the evidence, the petition is denied and the proceeding is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, three licensed parking garages, commenced an action under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 against respondents, Department of Consumer Affairs of New York City and its commissioner, alleging that respondents' determination that the garages had violated New York City, N.Y., Department of Consumer Affairs Gen. Reg. 15(2) by refusing to allow the respondents' agents to inspect their premises was unreasonable, arbitrary, and an abuse of discretion.


OVERVIEW: In the case of each garage, when the respondents' agents came to the premises, they were shown the public parts of the garage. They were then asked to wait for a supervisor before viewing the non-public parts of the garages. After waiting for various periods of time, the agents left without viewing the non-public areas. At a hearing for the violations of Reg. 15(2), the hearing officer determined that the requests to wait vitiated the purpose of the inspection, permitted possible corrections, and interfered with the agents' performance of duties. On their complaint, the garages contended Reg. 15(2) was unconstitutional because it permitted a warrantless search. The court reviewed the statutes and regulations regarding the parking industry in New York City and held that Reg. 15(2) implemented the requirements imposed on respondents by New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code §§ 20-104(b)(5), 20-114(a), 20-327(a), (b). The garages were part of a pervasively regulated industry, the inspections furthered the respondents' regulatory scheme, the respondents' ability to conduct the inspections was essential to its administrative scheme, and the inspections permitted were limited in scope.


OUTCOME: The court held that the city code providing for warrantless inspections by respondents' agents of the garages' premises was constitutional. The determination of respondents' hearing officer was not arbitrary, capricious, unreasonable, an abuse of discretion, and was supported by the evidence.


HEADNOTES

Actions -- Improper Form of Action -- Conversion to Proper Form

1. An article 78 proceeding is not the proper way to test the constitutionality of a regulation which permits warrantless searches of parking garages; rather, such proceeding is the proper vehicle to determine if a regulation or ordinance has been applied in an unconstitutional manner. However, where all proper parties are before the court, the court may treat the matter as an action for declaratory judgment and decide if the legislative enactment is constitutional.

Administrative Law -- Validity of Regulation -- Warrantless Inspections of Parking Garages

2. A regulation of the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, which authorizes the warrantless inspection of parking garages, is constitutional, since the parking garage industry is pervasively regulated, the inspections are limited to once per each two-year period, their scope  [***2] is restricted to all records or documents required to be maintained by the licensee, nonpublic areas of a garage are inspected to determine compliance with city codes, and the inspections are conducted during regular business hours. The long history of the city's regulation of the industry clearly demonstrates the existence of an "administrative scheme" to achieve regulation of parking lots and garages, and such regulations were promulgated to aid in the enforcement of specific legislative enactments regarding the maximum capacity of parking lots and garages.

Administrative Law -- Judicial Review -- Substantial Evidence

3. In a proceeding to review a determination of the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, a review of the facts adduced during the administrative hearing at which both parties had full opportunity to present their respective positions supports the findings made by the Administrative Hearing Officer; consequently, since the decision by the Hearing Officer was not arbitrary, capricious, unreasonable, an abuse of discretion, or effected by errors of law, and was supported by substantial evidence, the petition is denied and the proceeding dismissed.

 

1465 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wyndham Realty Co. v. New York State Div. of Housing & Community Renewal


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


139 Misc. 2d 418; 527 N.Y.S.2d 698; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 171



April 7, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord sought review of a ruling of the Department of Housing and Community Renewal (New York), that declined to stay the effect of respondent agency's order that decreased the amount of legal regulated rent for landlord's premises. Furthermore, the petitioner's action sought a stay of the respondent's order in order to maintain the status quo until his petition for administrative review was considered by respondent.


OVERVIEW: The court found that the landlord's application was encompassed by N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 63 rather than, as the landlord asserted, N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78. If an injunction were issued, the payment of a higher rent by the tenants pending determination of the petition for administrative review would be just as burdensome as the landlord's collection of a lower rent if no injunction issued. The court concluded that the landlord did not demonstrate any exigent circumstances that removed the matter from the general rule of administrative finality in N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7801. Furthermore, the order to show cause directed that service be made upon the affected tenants; however, the landlord neglected to file an affidavit of service, and it was not certain that the tenants were parties to the proceeding. Moreover the agency was empowered to grant the requested stay upon such notice to the affected parties and reasonable opportunity to be heard, as it deemed appropriate. Therefore, there was no necessity for judicial intervention to effect a stay under the terms proposed.


OUTCOME: The court denied the landlord's request for an injunction that stayed enforcement of the agency's order that decreased the amount of legal regulated rent for the landlord's premises.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Administrative Law -- Stay of Administrative Proceedings -- Basis for Judicial Intervention

A petition seeking to enjoin the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal from enforcing an order decreasing the amount of legal regulated rent petitioner could collect is dismissed; the pendency of an application before an administrative agency is not an "action" within the contemplation of CPLR article 63 and mandamus to review ( CPLR art 78) will not lie inasmuch as there has been no final agency determination. Although a party may seek review of an order of the type complained of if 90 days have passed following submission of a request for an agency review, the instant proceeding was brought prior to the expiration of such time period. Moreover, petitioner is unable to establish that the injury it might sustain if the injunctive relief is not granted is more burdensome than the harm which its tenants might sustain if the relief were granted, since, if successful, petitioner can be fully recompensed by monetary damages; nor has petitioner demonstrated the likelihood that it will ultimately prevail on the merits in light of the factual nature of the dispute concerning whether petitioner  [***2] decreased services to its tenants. Petitioner has demonstrated no basis to remove the proceeding from the rule of administrative finality, and given the power of the agency to stay its own rulings, petitioner should look to that body for the relief it seeks.

 

1466 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Property Clerk, New York City Police Dep't v. Covell


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


139 Misc. 2d 707; 528 N.Y.S.2d 299; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 245



April 6, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Since the complaint fails to allege facts sufficient to establish that defendant permitted or suffered her car to be used by her daughter as the instrumentality of a crime, the motion to dismiss pursuant to CPLR 3211 (a) (7) is granted with leave to replead in accordance with the foregoing.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The New York City Police Department Property Clerk (property clerk) brought a forfeiture action pursuant to New York City Administrative Code § 14-140 against defendant property owner. The property owner moved to dismiss the complaint on the grounds that the property clerk lacked the authority pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(3) to bring the action in his own name, and the complaint failed to state a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The property owner's daughter and another individual were arrested and charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance and unlawful possession of marihuana. The daughter was in the property owner's car at the time of the arrest. The car was seized by the police as the instrumentality of criminal activity and delivered into the custody of the property clerk, who was designated by the New York City Corporation Counsel to bring forfeiture actions. The court held that dismissal of the complaint pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(3) was unwarranted because the property clerk was authorized to bring the action. The court dismissed the complaint for failure to state a cause of action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(7). The property clerk failed to allege that the property owner knew that her car was being used for an unlawful purpose and permitted or suffered the car to be used for the unlawful purpose.


OUTCOME: The court granted the property owner's motion to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action, but granted the property clerk leave to replead.


HEADNOTES

Forfeitures and Penalties -- Forfeiture of Proceeds of Crime

The Property Clerk of the New York City Police Department, pursuant to the authority delegated to him by the Corporation Counsel (NY City Charter § 392 [a]; § 394 [c]) is authorized to bring a forfeiture action to declare the rights of the parties to property seized as the instrumentality of criminal activity (Administrative Code of City of New York § 14-140). To state a viable cause of action for forfeiture, the Property Clerk must allege not only that the property seized was used in the commission of a crime, but also that a defendant owner, not present when the alleged crime took place, had knowledge that the property was to be used for unlawful purposes (see, McClendon v Rosetti, 369 F Supp 1391). Accordingly, since the complaint fails to allege facts sufficient to establish that defendant permitted or suffered her car to  [***2] be used by her daughter as the instrumentality of the crime of unlawful possession of marihuana, the complaint is dismissed with leave to replead.

 

1467 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Merksamer


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Village of North Hills, Nassau County


139 Misc. 2d 987; 529 N.Y.S.2d 941; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 281



April 1, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants tow truck drivers filed a consolidation motion to dismiss appearance tickets and informations against them in the justice court (New York) on the grounds that the ordinance requiring licenses, North Hills, New York, North Hill Code ch. 161, §§ 3 and 15, was unconstitutional as written and as applied.


OVERVIEW: The tow truck drivers received appearance tickets for assisting disabled vehicles in the town without a license pursuant to North Hills, New York, North Hills Code ch. 161, §§ 3, 15. The drivers filed motions in the justice court to dismiss the tickets as unconstitutional as written and as applied. The justice court denied the motion to declare the ordinance unconstitutional on its face, and denied without prejudice the motion to declare it unconstitutional as applied subject to renewal after the trial. The justice court ordered the parties to proceed to trial. The justice court determined that, although a court of limited jurisdiction, it could hear the motions because N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.35(1)(c) conferred jurisdiction to determine whether the law defining the offense in an information was unconstitutional, that the constitutionality of the act as applied could not be determined absence the more complete record of a trial, that the constitutionality of the ordinance as written should be determined under the rebuttable presumption of constitutionality, and that the justice court found that the act was a reasonable and valid exercise of legislative police power.


OUTCOME: The justice court denied the tow truck drivers motion to declare the ordinance unconstitutional on its face and denied without prejudice the motion to declare the ordinance unconstitutional as applied on a motion to renewal after the trial. The court ordered the parties to proceed to trial.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- Jurisdiction -- Declaration of Statute's Constitutionality by Village Court

1. A Village Court has jurisdiction to pass on the constitutionality of a local ordinance regulating the towing industry where defendants' challenges to the ordinance were made in the context of a criminal proceeding and as a defense to informations charging them with unlicensed towing, with the court treating the challenges as motions to dismiss on constitutional grounds; indeed, CPL 170.35 (1) (c) expressly confers jurisdiction to determine whether the law defining the offense charged in an information is unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, and CPL 170.30 (1) (a) expressly provides that a local criminal court may, upon defendant's motion, dismiss an information upon the ground that it is defective within the meaning of CPL 170.35.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Factual Record

2. Inasmuch as it is elementary that constitutional issues should not be decided on the basis of an inadequate factual record, it would be inappropriate and premature to determine the constitutionality, as applied, of a local ordinance regulating the towing industry in the absence of a more complete  [***2] record after a plenary trial where the factual contentions of the parties may be fully heard.

Municipal Corporations -- Regulation of Towing Industry -- Constitutionality of Ordinance

3. A local ordinance regulating the towing industry is not facially invalid where defendants have failed to meet their burden of establishing unconstitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt in their criminal prosecution arising out of their towing motor vehicles without a license, since the ordinance represents a reasonable and valid exercise of legislative police power. The ordinance clearly represents a considered effort by the local legislature to enact procedures intended to safeguard the public from fraud, exorbitant rates, and other tow car abuses, as well as to assure, within reason, that disabled vehicles are promptly removed from highways so as not to impede the free flow of traffic through the municipality; as such, the legislation bears a rational relationship to valid legislative findings and is not arbitrary, capricious or unreasonable in the means which the municipality has adopted to effectuate the purposes sought to be attained by its enactment.

Municipal Corporations -- Regulation  [***3] of Towing Industry -- Effect on Interstate Commerce

4. A local ordinance regulating the towing industry and requiring licenses of tow car owners and drivers is not an unconstitutional impingement on interstate commerce, notwithstanding the fact that the ordinance is enforced on an interstate highway, since the court is unaware of any Federal enactment which so occupies the towing business in interstate highways as to exclude the right of the municipality to enact licensing requirements and appropriate regulations in the public interest.

Municipal Corporations -- Regulation of Towing Industry -- Tower's Response to Motorist's Call

5. A local ordinance regulating the towing industry is not unconstitutionally overbroad owing to the fact that it purports to regulate a business which does not solicit within the boundaries of the locality, and the reliance by defendants, who are being criminally prosecuted for towing without a license, on the fact that they were merely responding to a motorist's call is misplaced, since they are not charged with violating the antisoliciting provision of the ordinance; moreover, defendants overlook that portion of the ordinance which permits the  [***4] towing of a vehicle involved in an accident or becomes disabled so long as a signed authorization is obtained from the motorist, irrespective of whether the motorist called the tow car owner or vice versa, it being sufficient that a tow owner may lawfully tow a disabled vehicle so long as a written authorization has been obtained.

Municipal Corporations -- Regulation of Towing Industry -- Effect on Right to Contract

6. A local ordinance regulating the towing industry does not unconstitutionally impinge upon the right of tow car owners to contract where it does not appear that defendants, who are being criminally prosecuted for towing without a license, are the persons who actually contract with the motorists since they claim to be merely tow car drivers, not owners; moreover, the right to contract is not absolute and where a legislative finding of a substantive evil threatening the safety and welfare of the public is predicated on a rational basis and is reasonably appropriated to curb that evil, the rights of individuals to contract must give way to the State's right to superimpose its police powers in the public interest. It is noteworthy that defendants concede that it is  [***5] a legitimate concern of the locality to require licensing of tow car owners and operators to prevent fraud.

Municipal Corporations -- Regulation of Towing Industry -- Duplicate Licensing

7. In a criminal prosecution for operating a tow car without a license in violation of a local ordinance regulating the towing industry, defendants' contention that the ordinance in question duplicates other similar local ordinances which also require licensing, thereby requiring defendants to obtain duplicatory licenses from every locality in which they operate, is not an argument of constitutional dimension and is better addressed to the elected officials of those municipalities which have enacted tow car laws.

 

1468 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Field v. Cronshaw


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Nassau County


139 Misc. 2d 470; 527 N.Y.S.2d 165; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 170



March 31, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Intervenor stepfather sought leave to intervene in a custody/visitation action between petitioner father and respondent mother. He claimed that he had a right to intervene because the court's decision could have a financial impact on him and because he would be slandered in the custody proceedings and he had a right to cross-examine those witnesses testifying against him.


OVERVIEW: The father brought suit against the mother to obtain custody of the parties' minor child. The mother sought an order allowing her husband, the stepfather, to represent her in the action. The court denied that motion and the stepfather then sought to intervene in the action. He claimed that the court's determination might affect the life-style and manner in which he and the mother raise the child and could have a financial impact upon him as he provided support for the child over and above that provided by the father. He further claimed that he would be slandered and his religious beliefs put on trial and that he should be permitted to intervene so that he could cross-examine witnesses who testify against him. The court denied his motion to intervene, finding that he did not assert a legal interest which formed a basis for intervention. The stepfather's asserted rights were identical to those of respondent. Further, he would not be bound by entry of the judgment in the proceedings and, if custody was awarded to the father, such determination would not affect the stepfather's legal rights or cause any obligation to be imposed upon him.


OUTCOME: The court found that the stepfather did not assert a legal basis for his intervention in the custody suit between the mother and the father and denied the stepfather's motion to intervene.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parties -- Intervention -- Intervention by Stepfather in Custody Proceeding

1. In a custody and visitation proceeding between the subject child's natural parents, an application by the child's stepfather to intervene pursuant to CPLR 1012 (a)(2) is denied. The proposed intervenor asserts no legal interest which forms a basis for intervention; he does not seek custody or visitation; his asserted interests and rights are identical to those of his wife, the respondent mother, and he sets forth no claim or defense divergent or independent of his wife's claims and defenses. Further, the proposed intervenor will not be bound by entry of judgment in this proceeding as the judgment will in no manner affect his legal rights or impose any legal duty or obligation upon him. Moreover, insofar as the stepfather seeks to intervene in order to represent his wife's interest before the court, a grant of permission to intervene would violate CPLR 321, which authorizes a person to appear only in person or by duly licensed attorney.

Courts -- Sanctions -- Vexatious Litigation Practice

2. In a custody and visitation proceeding between the subject child's natural parents, where an application  [***2] by the child's stepfather, the respondent mother's husband, to intervene was denied, a cross motion by petitioner father to impose sanctions against respondent on the ground that the application to intervene was the 14th pretrial motion filed by respondent and was intended to harass petitioner is denied. Since the application was brought by respondent's husband, sanctions will not be imposed on respondent.

 

1469 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hylton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Nassau County


139 Misc. 2d 645; 529 N.Y.S.2d 412; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 241



March 25, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant's motion is denied except to the extent specifically granted herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed an omnibus motion to inspection the grand jury minutes, to dismiss an indictment and to preclude the use of any statements allegedly made by defendant. Defendant claimed that he was deprived of due process when the district attorney refused to allow defendant's witness to testify before the grand jury unless they executed waivers of immunity, pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law 190.50.


OVERVIEW: Defendant moved for dismissal of indictment by reason of the unconstitutionality of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 190.50(4), as applied to N.Y. Const., art. I, § 6, on the ground that defendant was deprived of due process as a result of the district attorney's refusal to allow defendant's witnesses to testify before the grand jury unless they executed waivers of immunity pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 190.45. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment on the ground of unconstitutionality of § 190.50(4). The court held that even if the potential testimony of the two witnesses could be considered mitigating or exculpatory, such evidence did not have to be presented at the grand jury stage. Due process was not violated by a failure to present such evidence to grand jury. The court also denied defendant's motion to preclude the use of defendant's statements at trial because the district attorney had served timely notice on defendant of an intent to use the wiretap evidence. Notice on date of the arraignment on the indictment strictly complied with the 15-day requirement of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 710.30.


OUTCOME: Motion for inspection of grand jury minutes was granted to extent that court had examined them; court was satisfied that evidence presented to grand jury was proper and legally sufficient to support crimes charged in indictment or any lesser included offenses. Defendant's motion for dismissal of indictment was denied. Defendant's motion for an order precluding the district attorney from using the statements of defendant at trial was denied.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury -- Right to Appear before Grand Jury -- Demand that Defendant's Witnesses Waive Immunity

1. The discretionary power of the District Attorney to demand that defendant's witnesses waive their immunity before giving evidence to the Grand Jury ( CPL 190.50 [4]) does not violate due process by impairing or interfering with the investigatory power of the Grand Jury since the standard of fundamental fairness, requiring that the Grand Jury be "well informed concerning the circumstances of the case before it" and that the prosecutor meet an obligation of "fair dealing to the accused and candor to the courts" to see that "justice is done", is not violated by a failure to present potentially "mitigating" or "exculpatory" evidence at the Grand Jury stage. CPL 190.50 (4) tends to further the Grand Jury's investigatory/accusatory function by protecting against the unwise, unwarranted and uninformed conferring of immunity by the Grand Jury on suspect persons. Since a Grand Jury proceeding is in no sense adversarial, the fact that a reasonable and salutary limitation is placed on a defendant's access to  [***2] the Grand Jury does not violate the concept of due process.

Crimes -- Disclosure -- Notice of Intention to Offer Evidence

2. CPL 710.30 (2), which precludes the People from using the statements of the defendant at trial unless notice of such intention is served upon the defendant within 15 days "after arraignment and before trial", does not require that such notice be served within 15 days after the defendant's initial arraignment on the felony complaint, but rather the "arraignment" contemplated by the statute is the arraignment on the triable accusatory instrument, i.e., the indictment.

 

1470 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Capitello


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Suffolk County


139 Misc. 2d 618; 528 N.Y.S.2d 263; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 229



March 15, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The case is on the Trial Calendar for March 21, 1988.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, charged with crimes of use of a child in a sexual performance, endangering the welfare of a child, and sexual abuse, moved for a bill of particulars, severance of counts, and dismissal of three counts of the indictment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, charged with crimes of use of a child in sexual performance, endangering welfare of a child, and sexual abuse moved for bill of particulars, severance of counts, and dismissal of three counts of indictment. Court held that defendant was entitled to bill of particulars where acts which constituted the crime were varied and was entitled to bill of particulars concerning the nature of any deviate sexual intercourse involved in a charge. The court held that defendant was entitled to severance of charges where the offenses were not based on the same act or criminal transactions and where, under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 200.20(2), defendant demonstrated either that counts were not properly joinable or that discretionary severance was warranted. Therefore, court severed counts which would be established by pictures of nude child from remaining counts which would depend on testimony of children because there was substantial likelihood jury would be unable to consider separately proofs as they related to each charge. Court held N.Y. Penal Law § 263.05, use of a child in sexual performance, was not unconstitutionally vague because statute employed language familiar in criminal law.


OUTCOME: Court granted defendant's motions in part and denied in part. Defendant was entitled to bill of particulars concerning the nature of any deviate sexual intercourse involved in a charge. Defendant entitled to severance of charges where the offenses were not based on the same act or criminal transactions and where defendant demonstrated either that counts were not properly joinable or that discretionary severance was warranted.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Use of Child in Sexual Performance -- Severance -- Bill of Particulars

1. The first three counts of the indictment charging defendant with the use of a child in a sexual performance (Penal Law § 263.05) and endangering the welfare of a child based upon defendant's possession of nude photographs of a seven-year-old boy must be severed from the other charges against defendant of sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of two other children in view of the substantial difference in the type and quality of the evidence ( CPL 200.20 [3]). The first three counts will be established by pictures of a nude male whereas the remaining counts will depend on the testimony of the children and defendant has indicated a need to testify as to those counts. Under these circumstances, there is a substantial likelihood that the jury would be unable to consider separately the proof as it relates to each offense. The People need not specify the number of times defendant allegedly touched the penis of one of the victims since the allegation in the indictment that defendant touched the victim on numerous occasions throughout a specified  [***2] period of time is sufficient and any additional information is evidentiary in nature and not the proper subject matter of a bill of particulars. In addition, the request for particulars concerning the "exact location" in which the crimes charged in counts 4-9 occurred is satisfied by the allegation that the acts occurred while defendant was employed as a school bus driver and took place while on school premises or on route to and from the elementary school.

Crimes -- Use of Child in Sexual Performance

2. The statute proscribing "the use of a child in a sexual performance" (Penal Law § 263.05), which includes a "photograph" or "sexual conduct" that may consist of a number of activities such as the "lewd exhibition of the genitals" (Penal Law § 263.00), is not unconstitutionally vague or overbroad. Child pornography is not entitled to First Amendment protection even where the material is not obscene under constitutional standards and States have greater leeway in the regulation of pornographic depicting of children. Accordingly, the evidence before the Grand Jury consisting of nude photographs of a seven-year-old boy are sufficient to support the charges against defendant of  [***3] use of a child in a sexual performance and endangering the welfare of a child.

 

1471 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Doe v. Roe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


139 Misc. 2d 209; 526 N.Y.S.2d 718; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 66



March 14, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, maternal grandparents, brought a action against respondent father for custody two minor children. The maternal grandparents sought to compel the father to submit to a compulsory test for Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).


OVERVIEW: The maternal grandparents argued that if the father had AIDS his life expectancy would be minimal, which was a consideration in awarding custody, and that the court would want to consider whether the father was facing a death-threatening illness and was suicidal or homicidal. The father refused to voluntarily submit to a blood test. The court denied the maternal grandparents' motion. The court concluded that no compelling interest had been shown for involuntary testing. There was no claim, nor could there be on the available medical evidence, that the children would be in danger from living with the father if he were seropositive. A court-appointed expert psychiatrist testified that (1) even if the father were suffering from AIDS and had a shortened life span, it would not justify removing the children from their long-term custodial parent, (2) assuming that the father actually suffered from AIDS, his knowledge of the disease would create no danger to him or to the children, and (3) he saw no evidence of any suicidal ideation.


OUTCOME: The court denied the maternal grandparent's motion, insofar as it sought an involuntary blood test from the father.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Disclosure -- Physical Examination -- Involuntary Test for Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome in Custody Proceeding

Based on the special characteristics and dangers of testing for Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS), including the lack of absolute reliability, the threat to civil liberties, potential ostracization and psychic harm, and based upon the strong public policy of confidentiality and the prohibition against conducting any AIDS test in the absence of a signed consent form (see, 10 NYCRR 58-1.1), a showing of compelling need, as opposed to the more lenient test of relevancy and materiality, must be met before an involuntary AIDS test may be ordered in a civil case pursuant to CPLR 3121. Accordingly, respondent father, the long-term custodian of two minor children, may not be ordered to undergo an AIDS test in the custody proceeding since petitioners, the maternal grandparents, have not shown a compelling need for involuntary AIDS testing or even that such information is relevant and material to the custody question in view of the expert psychiatric evidence that even if respondent were suffering from AIDS and had a shortened life span, this fact would not [***2] justify removing the children from their long-term custodial parent nor would respondent's knowledge of the disease create any danger to him or the children.

 

1472 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gary M.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Kings County


138 Misc. 2d 1081; 526 N.Y.S.2d 986; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 137



March 10, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The trial court held that defendant had discriminated in the use of peremptory challenges based upon race. The jury was then discharged, because of the length of time in conducting proceeding, and because several jurors had already been discharged and returned to the jury pool. At the time of the discharge of the jurors, there were seven blacks and three whites on the panel.


OVERVIEW: The court considered the credibility of two white police officers who stated they saw defendant in possession of guns. Defendant and civilian witness claimed that the guns were not in defendant's possession. At issue was whether defendant, as a minority, could use peremptory challenges to discriminate against majority jurors and whether Batson applied. Other issues before the court were whether the government was entitled to a trial by jury composed of fair cross-section of community, whether defendant's exercise of peremptory challenges constituted "state action, whether white potential jurors constituted "cognizable" groups, and whether the state had standing to object to discrimination against juror. Court found those cases adopting "possibility" of obtaining fair cross-section of community rule in U.S. Const. amend. VI were compelling and would ultimately be adopted. The court ruled that Batson applied. The underlying premise of Batson was prosecutorial racially motivated use of peremptory challenges violated Equal Protection Clause of U.S. Const. amend. XIV. The court held that there was sufficient state action for standing and that the New York constitution was violated.


OUTCOME: The Batson case applied to defendant's peremptory challenges and defendant was held to have utilized his peremptory challenges in a racially discriminatory method in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and the New York constitution.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of Jury -- Use of Peremptory Challenges in Racially Discriminatory Manner

A minority defendant's racially discriminatory use of peremptory challenges to systematically exclude white jurors violates both the State and Federal constitutional right to a jury trial, which includes a right to a "possibility" of obtaining a fair cross section of the community at the petit jury level. Racially motivated use of peremptory challenges is violative of equal protection since "State action" is involved in the discrimination in that the State supplies the tools (peremptory challenges), the place (court-room), the object (juror), the setting (criminal action) and enforces the discrimination (discharge of juror). The District Attorney, as representative of the State and as an agent for the excluded juror, has standing to contest defendant's discriminatory use of peremptory challenges as an injury to the community, to the jury system and to the law as an institution. Alternatively, the State has standing to assert the equal protection claims of the excluded jurors under the doctrine of third-party standing. In addition, since a citizen has a "civil right" to serve [***2] on a petit jury (see, Civil Rights Law § 13; Judiciary Law § 500), defendant's use of peremptory challenges in a racially discriminatory manner violates the constitutional provision that no person "be subjected to any discrimination in his civil rights * * * because of race" (NY Const, art I, § 11).

 

1473 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Holtzman v. Supreme Court of State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


139 Misc. 2d 109; 526 N.Y.S.2d 892; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 64



March 7, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant justices moved to dismiss plaintiff district attorney's request for a declaration that the federal and state constitutions prohibited defense counsel from exercising race-based peremptory challenges, that the justices could not grant peremptory challenges without making further inquiry when it was shown, prima facie, that defense counsel's peremptories were race-based, and that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 270.25(1) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The justices claimed that the district attorney lacked standing to bring the action in her own right or as a representative of prospective excluded jurors and that, if she had standing, the conduct complained of was not state action. The court granted the motion to dismiss. The court held that the district attorney did not have standing as a representative of excluded potential jurors because such jurors had standing to seek declaratory relief on their own behalf. The court held that the district attorney had standing to bring the action in her own right because standing should only be denied where there was clear legislative intent negating review or lack of injury in fact. The court held that the Fourteenth Amendment and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11 both required state action. Peremptory challenges by defense counsel under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 270.25(1) did not involve state action because the state could not require or compel defense counsel to exercise peremptory challenges, much less require them to exercise their peremptory challenges in a racially motivated manner. Defense counsel was not acting under color of state law when he represented a defendant in a criminal proceeding.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the district attorney's request for a judgment declaring that the federal and state constitutions prohibited criminal defendants from using race-based peremptory challenges and that the justices could not enforce defense counsel's peremptory challenges in criminal trials, without further inquiry, upon a prima facie showing that they were based on race.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Available

1. A declaratory judgment is the proper vehicle to test the validity of CPL 270.25 (1) to the extent that that statute authorizes defense counsel to make racially motivated peremptory challenges to prospective jurors, where no real questions of fact have been raised insofar as the six cases relied upon by plaintiff District Attorney are concerned, since declaratory relief is usually deemed proper to test the constitutionality of a statute; moreover, without accepting plaintiff's allegations that the exercise of race-based peremptories is widespread, plaintiff has adequately demonstrated that the issue has already arisen in several other cases, that it is an issue potentially far-reaching in scope, and that it is likely to arise again -- all of which are factors tending to favor entertaining the instant application.

Parties -- Standing -- District Attorney as Representative of Prospective Jurors Excluded Through Use of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges

2. In a declaratory judgment action seeking to test the constitutionality of CPL 270.25 (1) insofar as that statute authorizes defense counsel to make racially motivated peremptory  [***2] challenges to prospective jurors, plaintiff District Attorney does not have standing to sue as a representative of those prospective jurors who have been excluded as a result of such peremptory challenges, since it cannot be said that conferring standing on the District Attorney is necessary to circumvent an "impenetrable barrier" to judicial scrutiny of the statute, in light of the fact that standing has been granted by the United States Supreme Court to black citizens of Alabama who asserted that they were being systematically excluded from jury service ( Carter v Jury Commn., 396 U.S. 320).

Parties -- Standing -- Challenge to Constitutionality of Statute Permitting Race-Based Peremptory Challenges -- District Attorney as Plaintiff

3. In a declaratory judgment action seeking to test the constitutionality of CPL 270.25 (1) insofar as that statute authorizes defense counsel to make racially motivated peremptory challenges to prospective jurors, plaintiff District Attorney has standing to sue in her own right and in her official capacity in light of the more liberalized attitude toward recognition of standing to litigate and the lack of any clear legislative intent to negate  [***3] review; it should be noted that a District Attorney has been held to be within the "zone of interest" of, and therefore had standing to challenge, a plan promulgated by the Chief Administrator of the Courts for the rotation of Judges (see, Matter of Morgenthau v Cooke, 56 NY2d 24).

Jury -- Selection of Jury -- Constitutionality of Statute Authorizing Race-Based Peremptory Challenges -- State Action

4. The contention that CPL 270.25 (1) is unconstitutional to the extent that it permits defense counsel to issue race-based peremptory challenges to prospective jurors must be rejected since there has been no showing that the conduct in question amounts to "State action", which is a necessary predicate to the invocation of constitutional protections; the statute permits but does not compel the exercise of race-based peremptory challenges in any case, and the State cannot be held responsible for the conduct complained of merely because its Judges are required to grant the peremptory challenges once they are exercised. Moreover, in no sense can defense counsel be said to be "State actors", and there has been no allegation that any conspiracy existed between the Judges and defense  [***4] counsel such that the latter could be said to be acting "under color of" State law by virtue of joint participation in the challenged conduct.

Jury -- Selection of Jury -- Constitutionality of Statute Authorizing Race-Based Peremptory Challenges -- State Action

5. The contention that CPL 270.25 (1) is unconstitutional to the extent that it permits defense counsel to issue race-based peremptory challenges to prospective jurors must be rejected since there has been no showing that the conduct in question amounts to "State action"; although NY Constitution, article I, § 11 provides that nobody "shall be subjected to any discrimination * * * by any other person", that provision is no broader in coverage than the Federal provision, is not self-executing, and pertains only to those civil rights already denominated as such in the Constitution itself, in the Civil Rights Law, or in other statutes. To the extent that Civil Rights Law § 13 prohibits the disqualification of jurors on account of race, that prohibition applies to claims against public officials, usually Commissioners of Jurors, engaged in systematic and intentional discrimination in the manner in which an entire panel of  [***5] prospective jurors is selected.

 

1474 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Kilcommons v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


138 Misc. 2d 815; 525 N.Y.S.2d 145; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 200



February 26, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendants' motion and cross motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint are granted and plaintiff's application for the same relief is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, state and city officials and administrators of employee retirement systems, filed a motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint of plaintiff widow, in her suit seeking to be included in the payment of increased benefits provided by N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 43(I); the widow also moved for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: A widow filed suit against state and city officials, contending that her deceased husband, a member of the state employees retirement system at the time of his death, should be included in the payment of increased benefits codified at N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 43(i), which became effective several months after her husband's death. All parties moved for summary judgment. Previously, the decedent had been denied service credit for a period of employment with the city and with the city police department. The widow attempted to file an election provided for in § 43(i) for transfer of the decedent's "police time" for additional retirement credit. The application was rejected on the stated grounds that §43 (i) had application only to members, not beneficiaries, and she filed suit. The court granted the officials' motion and denied that of the widow. It held that the unambiguous language of § 43(i) defining the parameters for eligibility, and the rule that remedial legislation should not be given retroactive effect in the absence of clear legislative intent, required that the widow's claim be denied.


OUTCOME: The court granted the state and city officials' motion for summary judgment and denied the widow's motion.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Retirement and Pension Benefits -- Transfer of Members between Systems

 Retirement and Social Security Law § 43 (i), effective August 3, 1984, which allowed certain members of the New York State Employees' Retirement System (NYSERS) who had been transferred to that system from the New York City Employees' Retirement System (NYCERS) to transfer service credit from another retirement system such as the Police Pension Fund to NYSERS notwithstanding the failure to have made a timely election to make such a transfer, is not applicable to plaintiff, whose husband died six months prior to the effective date of the statute while still on active service as a court officer, so as to allow plaintiff to file for transfer of her husband's "police time" for additional retirement credit, since plaintiff's claim is clearly excluded by the unambiguous language of the statute and a remedial statute should not be given retroactive effect in the absence of clear legislative indication, particularly where such application [***2] would work mischief upon claims already finalized (plaintiff having been paid the full death benefit of $ 291,363.08 on Apr. 24, 1984). To make the election provided by the statute, an applicant must have been a member of NYSERS between August 4, 1984 and March 31, 1985, filed the appropriate papers making the election and deposited or begun to deposit with NYSERS any contributions withdrawn from pre-NYCERS retirement systems with interest and there is no indication that the statute was specifically intended to benefit plaintiff's decedent and 34 others whose claims to include "police time" credit had previously been rejected (see, Matter of Burns v Regan, 87 AD2d 944, appeals dismissed 57 NY2d 954).

 

1475 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Burdick v. Afrimet-Indussa, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Onondaga County


138 Misc. 2d 598; 525 N.Y.S.2d 542; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 154



February 18, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendants' motions for summary judgment dismissing the complaints in their respective actions are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant cobalt manufacturers filed motions for summary judgment dismissing the complaints in separate actions filed by plaintiffs, two workers in the tungsten-carbide industry, asserting causes of action for negligence, strict liability, implied warranty, and loss of consortium.


OVERVIEW: The workers alleged that they were exposed to cobalt, cobalt dust, and fumes containing cobalt, which caused them to develop cobalt-related lung disease and that the cobalt manufacturers caused the injury. The manufacturers filed a motion for summary judgment on the grounds that the dismissal of a prior similar action barred the maintenance of the instant actions under the doctrine of res judicata and that the revival statute relating to toxic torts litigation, 1986 N.Y. Laws 682, § 4 did not revive workers' claims against the manufacturers. The manufacturers also asserted that the revival statute was unconstitutional. The court denied the manufacturers' motions for summary judgment. The court held that the legislature was aware of the common usage of the term "tungsten-carbide" when it enacted the revival statute. The court held that purpose of the statute regarding the tungsten-carbide workers was to revive their claims and that the statute had to be interpreted to advance the remedy sought to be provided. The statute did not violate the Fourteenth Amendment because there was a legitimate state interest in the health, safety, and welfare of society.


OUTCOME: The manufacturers' motions for summary judgment dismissing the complaints in the workers' respective actions were denied.


HEADNOTES

Torts -- Exposure to Toxic Materials -- Revival of Time-Barred Claims

The revival of actions provision of the 1986 toxic torts legislation (L 1986, ch 682) revives plaintiff's previously time-barred actions against defendants, manufacturers and suppliers of cobalt and cobalt-containing materials utilized during the cemented tungsten-carbide manufacturing process, for injury caused by plaintiff's exposure to cobalt while employed in the tungsten-carbide industry resulting in his developing cobalt-related lung disease (hard metals disease), notwithstanding the fact that the statute only revives actions for injuries "caused by the latent effects of exposure to * * * tungsten-carbide", a compound of elements which contains no cobalt, since "tungsten-carbide" as used in the statute was intended as a broad, all-inclusive synonym for the hard metals manufacturing process. The Legislature was aware that the finished hard metal product manufactured at the plant where plaintiff was employed is commonly referred to as "tungsten-carbide" and that the manufacturing process is commonly [***2] known as the tungsten-carbide manufacturing process. The clear purpose of the revival statute vis-a-vis the tungsten-carbide workers was to revive their claims and the statute must be read to advance the remedy sought to be provided. The 1984 dismissal of plaintiff's actions on Statute of Limitations grounds, even though final and on the merits, is not an adjudication of rights that bars plaintiff from prosecuting the current actions pursuant to a right newly conferred by statute. In addition, the revival statute does not violate the dictates of due process since the State has a legitimate interest in preferring plaintiff's privilege to litigate over defendants' protection from stale claims.

 

1476 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Tocco


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County


138 Misc. 2d 510; 525 N.Y.S.2d 137; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 50



February 5, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff State of New York charged defendant with arson in the second degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 150.15 and reckless endangerment in the first degree under N.Y. Penal Law. § 120.25.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with arson and reckless endangerment after he allegedly set a fire in an apartment in which he resided with his ex-wife. The court sought to determine whether defendant's severe intoxication negated the intent element required to substantiate the crime of arson in the second degree, and if not, whether he could still could be liable for the lesser included offense. The court found that defendant set the fires following an argument with his ex-wife. Defendant contended that he was incapable of formulating the requisite intent necessary for arson. The court held that voluntary intoxication was not a defense to criminal charges, but it could be offered to negative an element of the crime. While intoxication could negative the mens rea in a crime regarding specific intent, it could not negative the lower culpable mental state required in crimes of recklessness. The court determined that mens rea for arson in the second degree was negated by the intoxication; however, arson in the fourth degree, as well as reckless endangerment, only required a reckless mental state. Therefore, defendant was found guilty of arson in the fourth degree and reckless endangerment.


OUTCOME: Defendant was found not guilty of arson in the second degree because he lacked the specific intent to damage a building. However, defendant was guilty of arson in the fourth degree as he recklessly damaged a building. Defendant was found guilty of reckless endangerment in the first degree. Defendant voluntarily commenced a reckless course of action, the natural causes of which were intended.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Effect of Intoxication upon Liability -- Reckless Mental State

Intoxication will negative the specific intent required in some crimes (Penal Law § 15.25), but will not act as even a partial defense in general intent crimes such as those requiring a mental state of recklessness (Penal Law § 15.05 [3]). Moreover, even though the law may evolve as new medical research on the nature of alcoholism becomes available, alcoholism is not, according to the prevailing view, accepted as a defense to any crime. Accordingly, defendant, a chronic alcoholic who set fire to the apartment in which he resided with his ex-wife and children while he was intoxicated, is not guilty of arson in the second degree (Penal Law § 150.15) since he lacked the specific intent to damage a building, but defendant is guilty of the lesser included offense of arson in the fourth degree, which is defined as "recklessly [damaging] a building * * * by intentionally starting a fire" (Penal Law § 150.05 [1]), and also of reckless endangerment in the first degree (Penal Law § 120.25) since his act of voluntarily imbibing the first alcoholic beverage that led to criminal conduct constituted recklessness per se.

 

1477 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Owens v. Ivey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Rochester


138 Misc. 2d 671; 525 N.Y.S.2d 508; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 151



February 5, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The complaint is dismissed, with prejudice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, the mother of an injured child, brought suit against defendant, the mother of the child who inflicted the injury, seeking damages for her child's injuries and loss of personal property during a fight pursuant to the New York Parental Liability Act, N.Y. Gen. Oblig. Law § 3-112.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff was the mother of a child who was injured and suffered the loss of personal property in a fight with defendant's child. Plaintiff brought suit against defendant seeking damages pursuant to the New York Parental Liability Act, N.Y. Gen. Oblig. Law § 3-112. The court noted that § 3-112 fixed an unconditional monetary liability on all nongovernment parents or guardians, natural or legal, for the malicious and destructive acts of their children, between the ages of 10 and 18, who were in their custody and unemancipated at the time of the damage. Liability was limited to $ 2,500. The court found that § 3-112 violated U.S. Const. art. I, § 10, because it was, in substantial intent, and in practical effect, a bill of attainder. Although the court acknowledged that a rational basis existed for parental vicarious liability statutes, it found that § 3-112 was nevertheless unconstitutional because it based liability solely on the parent-child relationship. The court dismissed the complaint with prejudice.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the complaint with prejudice because it found that the parental liability statute upon which the complaint was grounded was an unconstitutional bill of attainder because it based liability solely on the parent-child relationship.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child -- Liability of Parent for Act of Child -- Parental Liability Act -- Bill of Attainder

New York's Parental Liability Act (General Obligations Law § 3-112), which imposes an unconditional monetary liability on all nongovernmental parents or guardians, natural or legal, for the malicious and destructive acts of their children, between the ages of 10 and 18, who are in their custody and unemancipated at the time of the damage, is, in substantial intent and practical effect, an unconstitutional bill of attainder (US Const, art I, § 10) in that the fines and other limited monetary penalties constitute traditional punishment, the levying of financial penalties promotes punitive purposes generally and the legislative motive in enactment was both recriminatory and punitive rather than regulatory or compensatory. If the Legislature had stipulated any other predicate for liability other than the relationship of a parent and child set forth in the statute, such as lack of supervision or negligence or willful behavior of any sort, the constitutional issue of a bill of attainder would not be present. Accordingly, a small claims [***2] action brought by the mother of a 17 year old against the mother of another 17-year-old girl for injuries and loss of personal property plaintiff's daughter suffered during a fight with defendant's daughter is dismissed with prejudice.

 

1478 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Long Island Lighting Co. v. Long Island Power Auth.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Nassau County


138 Misc. 2d 745; 525 N.Y.S.2d 497; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 163



February 4, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a publicly owned power company, sought to dismiss an action by plaintiffs, an investor-owned utility company and one of its shareholders, that challenged the constitutionality of the Long Island Power Authority Act (act), 1986 N.Y. Laws 517, and sought to enjoin defendants from implementing the act. Plaintiffs also sued as taxpayers pursuant to N.Y. State Fin. Law § 123-b (1).


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs filed state and federal actions to challenge the constitutionality of the act, which would allow defendants to acquire the investor-owned utility company's stock or assets. The court denied plaintiffs' request for preliminary injunctive relief as premature because defendants had not yet implemented a tender offer. Thus, there was no present danger of irreparable harm to justify the preliminary injunction. The court granted defendants' motion to dismiss because the act did not violate either N.Y. Const. art. I, §§ 6 or 11, or the corresponding due process and equal protection provisions of the United States Constitution. The court adopted the reasoning used by the federal district court to conclude that the act was constitutional because the state and federal provisions were substantially similar. The act did not violate substantive due process because it bore a rational relationship to a legitimate state interest. The act did violate the equal protection clause because it was social and economic legislation that neither classified on the basis of a suspect class nor impaired a fundamental right, and was rationally related to the achievement of a legitimate state purpose.


OUTCOME: The court denied plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction. The court entered a declaration that the act was constitutional and further declared that plaintiffs were not entitled to relief under a state finance law.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Injunctions -- Preliminary Injunction

1. In an action challenging the validity of the Long Island Power Authority Act (Public Authorities Law, art 5, tit 1-A), which established a public authority for the purpose of acquiring the assets and business of the Long Island Lighting Company, plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction restraining defendants from taking any actions to implement the act is denied. Defendants have taken no steps which would indicate the imminence of a tender offer so as to create a basis for urgent intervention by the court and a present danger of irreparable harm has not been demonstrated.

Judgments -- Collateral Estoppel -- Judicial Estoppel

2. In an action by plaintiffs, the Long Island Lighting Company (LILCO) and one of its shareholders, challenging on State constitutional grounds the validity of the Long Island Power Authority Act (LIPA Act [Public Authorities Law, art 5, tit 1-A]), which established a public authority for the purpose of acquiring the assets and business of LILCO, application of principles of collateral estoppel based upon a Federal action instituted by LILCO wherein the LIPA Act was sustained under the Federal Constitution [***2] is not appropriate. State courts are not bound by Federal decisions in cases in which a statute is tested against the provisions of the Federal Constitution. In view of LILCO's previous successful contention in a State court action that the State, in enacting the LIPA Act, has preempted the subject area of legislation, the doctrine of judicial estoppel might be utilized to dismiss the complaint since, having once invoked the LIPA Act for its own benefit, LILCO may not now attack its constitutionality; however, since plaintiff shareholder was not a party in the previous State court action, the court will determine the matter upon its merits rather than invoke the estoppel doctrine against LILCO alone.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Establishment of Public Authority to Acquire Long Island Lighting Company

3. The Long Island Power Authority Act (LIPA Act [Public Authorities Law, art 5, tit 1-A]), which established a public authority for the purpose of acquiring the assets and business of the Long Island Lighting Company (LILCO), is a valid enactment as measured by the substantive due process and equal protection requirements of the New York and Federal Constitutions.  [***3] The LIPA Act withstands scrutiny under the rational basis test of substantive due process jurisprudence; the act is reasonable in relation to its subject and adopted in the interests of the community. Regarding equal protection analysis, while the act singles out LILCO, such classification is closely related and in fact necessary to the achievement of the statute's aims, which include assuring that dependable and affordable sources of energy exist for residents and industry in LILCO's service area. Statutes which constitute social and economic legislation that neither classify on the basis of a suspect class nor impair a fundamental right must be upheld if the challenged classification is rationally related to achievement of a legitimate State purpose.

State -- Unlawful Disbursement of State Funds -- Citizen-Taxpayer Action

4. In an action challenging the validity of the Long Island Power Authority Act (LIPA Act [Public Authorities Law, art 5, tit 1-A]), which established a public authority for the purpose of acquiring the assets and business of the Long Island Lighting Company, plaintiffs, as taxpayers, are not entitled to relief under State Finance Law § 123-b, since the [***4] LIPA Act has been found constitutional and it has not, therefore, been demonstrated that the disbursements anticipated to be made in the implementation of the LIPA Act would be unlawful.

 

1479 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Neuman v. Cornwall Cent. School Dist.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


138 Misc. 2d 429; 524 N.Y.S.2d 1005; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 42



February 2, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the instant motion is denied, the cross motion is granted, the complaint is dismissed, and the temporary restraining order contained in the order to show cause dated January 7, 1988 is hereby rescinded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff voter challenged the action of defendant school board to put a proposition relating to the improvement of schools to a vote in a special meeting after the voters recently defeated the proposition.


OVERVIEW: The school district submitted to voters a proposition calling for the reconstruction of existing school buildings and the general improvement of the entire district-wide school grounds. That proposition was defeated. Thereafter, the school district called a special meeting to be taken on two propositions: 1) the reconstruction of existing school buildings and reconstruction and enlargement of service roads, playgrounds, sidewalks, and curbing including ramps for the handicapped; and (2) if the first proposition was approved, general improvements of the entire district-wide school grounds to include expansion of parking areas. The voter challenged the school board's attempt to put the same propositions to a vote. The court denied the relief sought, finding that although the vote proposed for the special meeting related to the same improvement program, the two resolutions to be presented at the special meeting were more specific than the prior one and offered the voters a singular opportunity to approve certain of the funds requested in the original vote, while disapproving others.


OUTCOME: The court denied the voter's petition challenging the school board authority to call a special meeting to vote on two propositions that were similar to a proposition recently disapproved by voters, dismissed the complaint, and rescinded the temporary restraining order contained in the order to show cause.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Jurisdiction

1. Supreme Court has jurisdiction to entertain an action by plaintiff in which it is claimed that defendant School District's proposed vote on a proposition calling for reconstruction of existing school buildings and, if approved, on a second proposition calling for general improvements to the district's school grounds is unconstitutional on the ground that a proposition calling for reconstruction of existing school buildings and general improvement of the district's school grounds had been defeated several months earlier.

Schools -- Vote on School Budget

2. The complaint is dismissed in an action wherein plaintiff challenges as unconstitutional defendant School District's proposed vote on a proposition calling for reconstruction of existing school buildings and, if approved, on a second proposition calling for general improvements to the district's school grounds on the ground that a proposition calling for reconstruction of existing school [***2] buildings and general improvement of the district's school grounds had been defeated several months earlier.
