Although concededly related to the same improvement program, the two propositions to be presented are more specific than the prior one and offer the voters a singular opportunity to approve certain of the funds requested in the original vote, while disapproving others. In any event, there is no violation of plaintiff's constitutional rights.

 

1480 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Chrysler Motors Corp. v. Schachner


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Rockland County


138 Misc. 2d 501; 525 N.Y.S.2d 127; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 46



February 1, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In respondent car owner's suit for a replacement car after repairs failed to cure his car's defects, petitioner car dealer moved to vacate an arbitration award, claiming that the arbitrator exceeded his authority and that New York's Lemon Law, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 198-a, was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The car owner sued the car dealer for a replacement car under New York's Lemon Law, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law §198-a(f), after repairs failed to cure his car's defects. The dealer moved to vacate an arbitration award. The owner cross-moved for a change of venue, to confirm the award, and for attorney's fees. As the car dealer questioned the law's constitutionality, the state attorney-general was granted leave to intervene as an additional party respondent. The court denied the car dealer's motion to vacate the award and granted the owner's cross motion to confirm the award, without costs. The warranty agreement was made after the effective date of New York's Lemon Law, and was clearly within its ambit. The arbitrator's determination was not so irrational as to require vacatur of his award. The court denied the car owner's cross motion for attorney's fees. There was nothing in the statute to indicate that the right to recover attorney's fees extended to a party who demanded arbitration. The court denied the car owner's cross motion to change the venue. The car dealer designated the county as its principal office in the state. Therefore, venue was properly placed in the county.


OUTCOME: The court denied the car dealer's motion to vacate the award and granted the car owner's cross motion to confirm the award because a warranty agreement was made after the effective date of the Lemon Law and was clearly within its ambit, and because the arbitrator's determination was not so irrational as to require vacatur of his award.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Compulsory Arbitration

The compulsory arbitration provision of the new car Lemon Law (General Business Law § 198-a [k]), effective January 1, 1987, which grants the consumer the option of submitting any dispute under the law to an independent arbitrator, as opposed to the previously existing manufacturer's arbitration program, does not unconstitutionally impair the contract obligations of petitioner car manufacturer when retroactively applied to the sale of a car on August 10, 1984, since the Lemon Law as a whole became effective 11 months before the vehicle was purchased and the provision for compulsory arbitration merely gives a consumer an additional remedy with which to enforce rights under the sale agreement. Where a statute merely alters a remedy available to a party, retroactive application of the statute will not violate the Contract Clause (US Const, art I, § 10) since, absent language indicating a contrary intent, a remedial or procedural statute will ordinarily be applied to past transactions, accrued actions, pending actions and future actions, in the interest of spreading its benefits as widely as possible. Accordingly,  [***2] the arbitrator's award to respondent is confirmed since the arbitrator's determination that respondent, as president of the corporation which took title to the vehicle, qualified as a consumer under the Lemon Law has a rational basis nor were the other determinations as to the reasonable number of attempts to repair the alleged clutch problem and the substantial impairment of the value of the vehicle so irrational as to require vacatur of the award; however, respondent is not entitled to attorney's fees since there is nothing in the statute to indicate that the right to recover attorney's fees extends to a party who demands arbitration.

 

1481 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Parise


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Monroe County


137 Misc. 2d 1098; 523 N.Y.S.2d 962; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 10



January 11, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for an order prohibiting photography of his trial by the state for second degree manslaughter. The media's motion to provide audio-visual coverage of the trial was also pending.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with second-degree manslaughter based on an incident in which was alleged that a victim's death resulted from a "pit bull terrier" dog attacking and biting him. Defendant contended that the media's application to photograph the trial constituted the unauthorized practice of law, that the enabling act of N.Y. Jud. Law § 218 violated separation of powers, and that enabling act and regulations passed pursuant to it violated his First and Fourteenth Amendment rights. The court denied defendant's motion and granted that of the media, concluding that the media was not practicing law by filing a request to engage in audio-visual coverage regarding events in court. Rather, the media practiced its trade of delivering news to the public. As to the constitutional claims, § 218 did not violate separation of power because it was permissive in nature. Media coverage of trials was not compelled. Finally, media coverage was not prohibited by another constitutional provision.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to prohibit the photography of his criminal trial. The media's motion was granted.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Right to Public Trial -- Media Coverage of Court Proceedings

Defendant's motion to prohibit media coverage of proceedings in his prosecution for manslaughter in the second degree is denied. Applications by the news media to report judicial proceedings do not constitute the unauthorized practice of law. Judiciary Law § 218, which authorizes presiding Trial Judges to permit audio-visual coverage of court proceedings, does not violate the separation of powers doctrine. Finally, the Federal Constitution does not prohibit broadcasting of a criminal trial over the objections of the defendant.

 

1482 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bredero Vast Goed, N. v. v. Tax Com. of New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Albany County


138 Misc. 2d 27; 523 N.Y.S.2d 754; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 8



January 7, 1988 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The petition for an order directing the Tax Commission to refund taxes paid under protest is denied, and the petition is dismissed, all without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayers appealed a determination from respondent tax commission denying their petition for an order directing the tax commission to refund taxes paid under protest.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers paid taxes on a real property transfer, pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law § 31(B), under protest. The tax commission denied the taxpayers petition requesting a refund of taxes paid under protest. The taxpayers filed a petition for an order directing the tax commission to refund taxes paid under protest. The taxpayers claimed that the transaction was not subject to tax by reason of the "grandfather" clause contained in N.Y. Tax Law § 1443(6). The taxpayers' petition for an order directing the tax commission to refund taxes paid under protest was denied, and the petition was dismissed. The court held that the acquisition of a controlling interest in any entity with an interest in real property was a transaction subject to the gains tax. Further, the court held that the tax commissioner's determination was rational and was given deference; there was a substantial nexus with the state to permit the application of the tax without discriminating against interstate commerce, and § 31(B) was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied the taxpayers petition for an order directing the tax commission to refund taxes paid under protest, and dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Real Property Transfer Gains Tax -- Exemptions

1. The Real Property Transfer Gains Tax (Tax Law art 31-B) applies to the sale of stock of a corporation that owns an interest in a partnership which owns real property. The acquisition of a controlling interest in any entity with an interest in real property is, by statute, a transaction subject to the gains tax, and a tiered entity transfer is a transaction subject to tax (20 NYCRR 590.51). Nor is the transaction exempt by reason of the "grandfather" clause contained in section 1443 (6) of the Tax Law. The interpretation of the Tax Commission that there was no "written contract" executed before the effective date of article 31-B, and that the resolutions of petitioners' boards of directors authorizing the sale of stock did not constitute contracts with the purchaser, is not irrational and must be given deference.

Constitutional Law -- Commerce Clause -- Due Process of Law -- Gains Tax on Real Property Transfer

2. The application of article 31-B of the Tax Law  [***2] to the sale of stock of a corporation that owns an interest in a partnership which owns real property is not unconstitutional as a violation of the Due Process and Commerce Clauses of the US Constitution. Stock in a New York corporation was sold to another New York corporation, and the actual transfer occurred in New York State. There is substantial nexus with New York State to permit the application of the tax without discriminating against interstate commerce.

 

1483 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Sistenstein v. Manufacturers Hanover Financial Services, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Broome County


138 Misc. 2d 140; 523 N.Y.S.2d 400; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 5



January 6, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner borrower raised issues of noncompliance with N.Y. Pers. Prop. Law § 46 et seq. in the cancellation of wage assignment action against respondent assignee.


OVERVIEW: The borrower sought cancellation of a wage assignment in an action involving the lender. The court held that N.Y. Pers. Prop. Law § 48(1) imposed upon respondent as assignee the burden of proving the validity of the assignment on the application to vacate including any and all defenses to the assignment, of which proper notice was necessarily a part. The court held that the borrower was not sent, nor did she receive, the notice required by § 48 (1), as a result of which the assignment filed both with the Tioga County Clerk and the employer was a nullity. The borrower was entitled both to its cancellation as of record and with the employer and return from the assignee of the wages paid thereunder, with interest from the date of each wage payment.


OUTCOME: The court ordered cancellation of a wage assignment and return of wages in an action involving the borrower.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Creditors' Suits -- Wage Assignment -- Notice to Assignor

In a proceeding to cancel a wage assignment (Personal Property Law § 47-e), when a husband and wife are coborrowers and each executes a separate wage assignment, the notice required to be given each of them pursuant to Personal Property Law § 48 (1) is ineffective as against a contesting assignor unless sent separately and individually to that assignor by certified mail; accordingly, a notice acknowledged as to its receipt only by one spouse is in fact "undelivered" as to the other spouse, thereby requiring that the alternate notice means provided in the statute be realized by the assignee to assure that the assignor is advised of the pending wage assignment.

 

1484 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Tri-State Pub. Co., Div. of Ottaway Newspapers, Inc. v. Port Jervis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


138 Misc. 2d 147; 523 N.Y.S.2d 954; 1988 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 4



January 4, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner newspaper sought to inspect the death certificate of an individual in the possession of respondent city in order to determine whether the individual had died of the disease Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome, commonly known as AIDS. After the city and the state denied the request based on N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 4174(1)(a), the newspaper filed suit.


OVERVIEW: The newspaper alleged that death from such AIDS in the community was a matter of "grave public concern." In granting the newspaper's request for a copy of the death certificate, the court first determined that in order to insure the maximum public access to government records, full disclosure was compelled unless the city could demonstrate that the requested records fell within 1 of 8 categories of exemptions provided in the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL), which, were to be narrowly construed. In determining that the issuance of the death certificate did not constitute an invasion of privacy, the court held that there was no expressed exemptions in the FOIL which granted to a decedent's personal representative, or to the next-of-kin or survivors of a decedent, the right on decedent's behalf to prevent disclosure of decedent's death certificate. Where rights of personal privacy were involved the exercise of the rights were limited to the living and could not be asserted by others after decedent's death. The court concluded that the city had not met its burden of proof that the certificate was exempted from disclosure.


OUTCOME: The court granted the newspaper's petition and ordered the city to issue the newspaper a copy of the death certificate.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Disclosure -- Freedom of Information Law -- Death Certificate

Respondent City of Port Jervis improperly denied the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request of petitioner newspaper publisher to inspect the death certificate of a person suspected of having died from Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) on the ground that the request was not "necessary or required for judicial or other proper purposes" (Public Health Law § 4174 [1] [a]), since the death certificate is not exempt from FOIL disclosure as "an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy" or as an item "specifically exempted" from disclosure by State statute (Public Officers Law § 87 [2]). The protection against unwarranted invasion of privacy is limited to the living and may not be asserted by others after the decedent's death while Public Health Law § 4174 does not establish a clear legislative intent to exempt death certificates from disclosure. Once petitioner's FOIL appeal was denied by the city's governing body, it was entitled to seek judicial review (Public Officers Law § 89 [4] [a], [b]) and was not required to pursue administrative review within the Department of Health. Accordingly, since AIDS is a matter [***2] of great public concern, petitioner has a legitimate and specific public purpose in seeking to gather and publish information concerning a possible case of AIDS in the locality served by its newspaper and it is thus entitled to access to the death certificate.

 

1485 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Martin B.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


138 Misc. 2d 685; 525 N.Y.S.2d 469; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2816



December 24, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Movant Commissioner of the New York State Office of Mental Health (commissioner) filed a motion for an order pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 330.20 extending the order of conditions subject to which the criminal defendant was discharged from inpatient treatment for the ensuing five years. Respondent counsel, on behalf of defendant, liminally opposed the motion, arguing such an extension under § 330.20(1)(o) violated the Constitution.


OVERVIEW: The trial court accepted defendant's plea that he was not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect, determined that defendant had neither a dangerous mental disorder nor was mentally ill, and entered an order of conditions pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 330.20(1)(o) that required defendant to comply with a treatment plan which included screening and in-patient treatment for five years. The commissioner filed his motion upon the expiration of that five year term. The court liminally considered the counsel's constitutional objections and entered an order rejecting them. Section 330.20(1)(o) provided that, for good cause shown, the order of conditions could be extended for an additional five year period. The commissioner or the prosecuting district attorney could apply for the extension. Section 300.20(17) ensured that a defendant's liberty interests would be protected and provided adequate procedural and substantive safeguards. Section 330.20 balanced the public's safety interests with a defendant's liberty interests and did not violate the Equal Protection Clause. Nor was § 330.20 void for vagueness as it provided standards to be applied by courts.


OUTCOME: The court entered an order that liminally rejected counsel's objections to the commissioner's motion to resettle and extend the defendant's order of conditions for an additional five years.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Insanity -- Five-Year Extension of "Order of Conditions"

The provision of the Insanity Defense Reform Act of 1980 authorizing the court to renew the initial five-year "order of conditions", directing a defendant found not responsible by reason of mental disease or defect to comply with a "prescribed treatment plan" for an additional five-year period "for good cause shown" ( CPL 330.20 [1] [o]), does not constitute such an impermissible discrimination against nonresponsibility acquittees as to deny equal protection since provision of a longer period of supervision after custody in the case of nonresponsibility acquittees is not inconsistent with the constitutional mandate that no one be retained in custody by reason of mental disease or defect absent a finding of mental illness and dangerousness to self or others. The function of the order of conditions is to provide a safeguard to the public that is peculiar to nonresponsibility acquittees and it is less restrictive than and provides an alternative safeguard to custody under an order even in the case where the order of conditions permits transfer to a nonsecure or private facility. The statute is not "void for [***2] vagueness" since the requirement of "good cause" imposes a burden of justification on the applicant in the context of the over-all statutory scheme which provides for continuing hearings until discharge with a spectrum of carefully limited types of custody: the commitment and retention orders, the furlough order, the transfer order and recommitment order.

 

1486 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Seawall Associates v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


138 Misc. 2d 96; 523 N.Y.S.2d 353; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2780



November 23, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff owners brought an action challenging the constitutionality of defendant city's legislation prohibiting the conversion, alteration, or demolition of privately owned buildings containing single-room occupancy (SRO) units. The owners sought declaratory and injunctive relief.


OVERVIEW: Previous legislation attempting to prohibit the conversion or alteration of privately owned SRO buildings had been found unconstitutional. In response, the city enacted new legislation, which differed from the previous legislation by the addition of a cash buy-out provision, the obligation of SRO owners to create replacement housing, and the addition of a hardship escape provision. The court held that the exemptions added to the law did not alleviate the constitutional infirmities found in its predecessor legislation. The law still contained an antiwarehousing provision forcing owners to make these units habitable and to rent them to bona fide tenants, which was previously held to be unconstitutional. Moreover, the buy-out and replacement exemptions required the owners to pay exorbitant fees in order to escape the regulation, thereby constituting an excessive financial burden on the owners. The court found that the law placed an unfair and uncompensated burden on one class of property owners to subsidize a low-income housing program administered by the city and denied the owners use of their properly without compensation in violation of the due process and takings clauses.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment for the owners.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Preservation of Single-Room Occupancy Buildings -- Unconstitutional "Taking" without Due Process of Law

The buy-out, replacement and hardship exemptions contained in the new single-room occupancy (SRO) legislation (Administrative Code of City of New York § 27-198.2) fail to alleviate the constitutional infirmities in the previously invalidated SRO law, prohibiting the conversion, alteration of demolition of privately owned SRO buildings and placing an affirmative obligation on SRO owners to renovate their buildings (see, 134 Misc 2d 187), since the exemptions are tantamount to extortion and place an unfair and uncompensated burden on one class of property owners in violation of the due process rights of SRO owners. The limited statutory cash buyout, in the amount of $ 45,000 per unit an SRO owner must pay to the New York City Development Fund in order to withdraw an SRO building from the moratorium, extracts an exorbitant price that can prevent SRO owners from recovering the use of their property. The hardship exemption, which provides for a total or partial reduction in the amount of the cash buyout or of the number of dwelling units to be [***2] replaced if the Commissioner determines that there is no reasonable rate of return (defined as 8.5% of the property's assessed value as an SRO building) unless the property is altered or converted to another use, is inherently confiscatory and violative of due process because of the total disregard of reasonable "investment backed" expectations on the part of SRO owners. In addition, the SRO regulatory scheme constitutes an unconstitutional taking for which just compensation must be made. Although the SRO legislation may be an innovative and well-intentioned attempt to lessen the growth of the homeless population in the City of New York, the city cannot constitutionally force a single segment of property owners to bear a public burden without just compensation.

 

1487 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Levitz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Nassau County


137 Misc. 2d 591; 521 N.Y.S.2d 977; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2628



November 16, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed pre-trial motions in their criminal trial seeking a declaration that N.Y. Penal Law § 263.15 was unconstitutional, inspection of the minutes of the grand jury, controversion of a search warrant, suppression of evidence, suppression of statements, and a copy of the State's debriefing statements.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged by the State under N.Y. Penal Law § 263.15 with promoting a sexual performance by a child. Evidence was seized pursuant to a search warrant. Defendants filed pre-trial motions and alleged that § 263.15 was unconstitutional. Defendants sought to inspect the grand jury minutes, controversion of search warrants, suppression of the evidence seized, suppression of statements, and a copy of the State's debriefing statements. The court found that § 263.15 was not unconstitutional as overbroad, vague, or as applied to the case. The state had a compelling interest in safeguarding minors, and the distribution of sexually explicit photographs of minors was related to the sexual abuse of children. An in camera inspection of the grand jury minutes was ordered. The court ordered a hearing to determine whether police conduct in searching and seizing defendants' home was so outrageous as to warrant suppression of items seized, and to ascertain the effect of misrepresentations made in an affidavit for a warrant. A hearing was granted on the motion to suppress statements, and defendants were provided with a summary of the State's debriefing statements.


OUTCOME: The court granted and denied defendants' motions in part and held that a state statute was not unconstitutional, an in camera inspection of the grand jury minutes was required, hearings were to be held concerning police conduct and misrepresentations in a search warrant and suppression of statements, and defendants were entitled to the State's debriefing statements.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Promoting Sexual Performance by Child -- Noncommercial Exchange of Materials

1. Defendants, who allegedly engaged in the noncommercial exchange, through the mail, of material featuring persons under the age of 16 in various stages of undress and engaged in sexual acts, may constitutionally be charged with violating Penal Law § 263.15, promoting a sexual performance by a child. The definition of "promote" contained in Penal Law § 263.00 (5) dispels any notion that section 263.15 is devoted exclusively to "commercial" exploitation. In view of the State's compelling interest in safeguarding the physical and psychological well-being of minors, the State is not proscribed from protecting its legitimate State interest through restricting the promotion of sexually exploitive material as defined in the statute; it is not solely the commercial use which creates the harm to the child, but the record of the child's conduct exacerbated by the circulation, which is within the State's legitimate interests to protect through proscribing that conduct. Accordingly, Penal Law § 263.15 as applied in this case is constitutional pursuant to the New York and Federal Constitutions.

 [***2] Crimes -- Search Warrant

2. A search warrant permitting the search and seizure of certain items at the purported residence of defendants, who were charged with promoting a sexual performance of a child in connection with the exchange, through the mail, of material featuring persons under the age of 16 in various stages of undress and engaged in sexual acts was properly issued. Although defendants argue that the police officer's supporting affidavit does not establish the probable cause necessary to search those premises, there is no compelling reason on the face of the document to disturb the findings of the issuing Judge. The particularity requirement of the Fourth Amendment to the US Constitution is satisfied by the warrant and the affidavit coupled with the accompanying exhibits provides sufficient probable cause that obscene materials would be found on the premises. Finally, a hearing is ordered to determine whether the conduct of the police in searching the house and seizing items not subject to the warrant was so outrageous as to warrant suppression of all the items seized in the search; to determine whether searches made of a safe in one of the defendants' houses and [***3] of certain post-office boxes were consented to or otherwise authorized by the warrant; and as to the effect of certain misrepresentations in the supporting affidavit on the finding of probable cause.

 

1488 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Med. Malpractice Ins. Ass'n v. Superintendent of Ins.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


137 Misc. 2d 785; 520 N.Y.S.2d 501; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2715



October 9, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Based on the foregoing analysis, the court concludes that the report of the Referee should not be accepted, and that the determination of the Superintendent should be set aside.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner medical malpractice insurance association instituted proceedings under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 in order to annul the determination of respondent superintendent of insurance, which established premium rates for professional liability insurance for physicians and surgeon for three policy years. The association also sought a judgment, which would compel the superintendent to establish proper rates for those years.


OVERVIEW: The association was established by the legislature to provide medical malpractice insurance. The superintendent established both primary and two levels of excess premium rates for professional liability insurance for physicians and surgeons for two policy years. The association claimed that the superintendent's determination for those years and, by amendment to their petition, for a third policy year, was arbitrary and capricious, that it violated lawful procedure, and that violated provisions of both the federal and state constitutions. The association also sought to compel the superintendent to establish proper premium rates for those three policy years, in compliance with various provisions of the N.Y. Ins. Law. Upon review, the court concluded that the report of the referee should not be accepted and that the determination of the superintendent should be set aside because there was no proper actuarial basis, or other basis before the superintendent, which could serve as a foundation for his determination.


OUTCOME: The court held that the superintendent's determination concerning premium medical malpractice rate for three policy years should be set aside.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- Malpractice Insurance -- Rates Set by Superintendent of Insurance

The determination of the Superintendent of Insurance setting rates for medical malpractice insurers shall be set aside where there was no proper actuarial basis for the determination; the determination rested upon various "scenarios" which depended upon future results which themselves rested on a speculative foundation with no basis in past experience. Moreover, the direction in legislation passed to deal with the medical malpractice insurance crises (see, L 1986, ch 266, § 40) that a surcharge, which might be imposed in the policy year 1989 and could continue indefinitely in order to cover any projected deficiencies incurred by the insurers, shall be deemed to be income for the purposes of Insurance Law § 2303 was not intended to override the direction in Insurance Law § 5505 that rates fixed by the Superintendent were to be actuarially sound, self-supporting, and based on reasonable standards, since it would [***2] be impermissible for the Legislature to reduce soaring malpractice insurance rates by permitting the Superintendent to fix rates which did not allow a reasonable rate of return to insurers. Further, it appears that the insurers' solvency is impaired by the rates set (see, Insurance Law § 1309 [a]).

 

1489 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Carpentry Perfectionists, Ltd. v. Patterson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Nassau County


137 Misc. 2d 189; 520 N.Y.S.2d 128; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2668



October 7, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff contractor moved for an order recalling the court's order, reinstating the complaint, and striking defendant customers' first and third affirmative defenses. The court had dismissed the contractor's complaint sua sponte for failure to comply with the pleading requirements of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3015(e).


OVERVIEW: The contractor entered into a contract with the customers for home improvements, and it filed suit against them for nonpayment. The court sua sponte dismissed the complaint for the contractor's failure to plead, as required by N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3015(e), that it was currently licensed in the county. The contractor moved for an order recalling the court's dismissal of the complaint. In reargument, the contractor informed the court that it was licensed at the time the cause of action arose, although its license had been revoked after a formal hearing prior to the commencement of the action. The court granted the motion, reinstated the complaint, and struck the customer's first and third affirmative defenses. The court held that it was not the intent of the legislature to preclude a plaintiff from suing under these circumstances. If a contractor was properly licensed at the time he performed the work, he had an immediate right to maintain an action for payment for services rendered. He, therefore, could not subsequently lose this right if the work was completed prior to the termination or revocation of his license.


OUTCOME: The court granted the contractor's motion, recalled its original order, and reinstated the nonpayment complaint against the customers. The court also struck the customers' first and third affirmative defenses.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Consumer Protection -- Home Renovation

Plaintiff home improvement contractor who is licensed to do business at the time he performs the work has an immediate right to maintain an action against defendant consumer for payment for services rendered. He therefore cannot subsequently lose this right if his license has been revoked prior to the time the action was commenced. CPLR 3015 (e), which in requiring a contractor to plead that he is duly licensed, further provides for him to obtain a license after commencement of the action and then amend his complaint, does not refer to a contractor who formerly held a valid license. Revocation of a contractor's license does not necessarily mean that all of the contractor's work was inferior. He is still entitled to payment for services that were rendered in a workmanlike manner. It would be an unconstitutional deprivation of property if a contractor were forced to lose claims which had accrued because his license was revoked.

 

1490 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Birnbaum v. State


Claim No. 63695


Court of Claims of New York


138 Misc. 2d 402; 524 N.Y.S.2d 958; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2800



October 2, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: At the time of his death, decedent was the state-licensed operator of a nursing home. Claimants, representatives of decedent's estate, sought to shut down the unprofitable operation, but defendant state obtained a temporary restraining order and appointment of receivers to force the nursing home to remain open. Money claims were pursued against the state, including a claim for legal and accounting fees.


OVERVIEW: The court previously concluded that the state's insistence upon running the nursing home constituted a de facto taking for which the state was obligated to compensate claimants. At issue was whether claimants were entitled to recover their accounting and legal expenses and whether those expenses were fair and reasonable. The court entered judgment for claimants, concluding that they were entitled to the full amount of legal and accounting fees sought. First, the court held that constitutionally required just compensation generally did not include legal and associated expenses incurred in fixing the value of property taken by eminent domain. Nevertheless, N.Y. Em. Dom. Proc. Law § 702(C) provided a statutory exception that allowed payment of such expenses here. The state's de facto rather than de jure taking forced claimants to establish both that a taking had been effected and the value of the property taken. Valuation expenses could not be separated in this complex litigation. Second, reading Ct. Cl. Act § 27 to prohibit the award of expenses described in N.Y. Em. Dom. Proc. Law § 702 was utterly inconsistent with the purposes of the New York Eminent Domain Procedure Law.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment for claimants in their action to recover legal and accounting fees incurred by them in asserting that a de facto taking had occurred when the state forced them to continue to run a nursing home formerly operated by decedent. The court held that claimants were entitled to the full amount of legal and accounting fees sought.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] State -- Court of Claims -- Jurisdiction over Claims Arising from Acquisition of Real Property

1. The Court of Claims is the appropriate forum in which to adjudicate an application by a condemnee for reimbursement for legal and accounting expenses it incurred in establishing a de facto taking by the State of its property, notwithstanding the fact that most of the fees charged were incurred for matters handled in Supreme Court, since the Court of Claims possesses jurisdiction over money claims against the State; moreover, EDPL 501 (A) confers on the Court of Claims "exclusive jurisdiction to hear and determine all claims arising from the acquisition of real property by or in the name of the people of the state of New York".

Eminent Domain -- De Facto Appropriation -- Legal and Accounting Expenses

2. Recovery of a condemnee's legal and accounting expenses attributable to establishing a de facto taking of its property by the State is authorized by EDPL 702 (C) and may be sought in the Court of Claims, notwithstanding the fact that Court of Claims Act § 27 limits recovery of such expenses to those provided in EDPL 701, since reading section 27 to prohibit the award [***2] of expenses described in EDPL 702 is utterly inconsistent with the purposes of the over-all scheme of the Eminent Domain Procedure Law, which is to provide the exclusive procedure by which property shall be acquired by exercise of the power of eminent domain in the State; significantly, unlike other sections of the EDPL, EDPL 701 and 702 make no distinction between proceedings in the Court of Claims and those in Supreme Court with respect to the awards of expert witness' fees, attorneys' fees and other costs, and the logical import of those provisions is that both were intended to apply equally to condemnation proceedings irrespective of whether jurisdiction over such proceedings lay in the Court of Claims or Supreme Court. Moreover, EDPL 705 provides that the provisions of the EDPL shall be controlling notwithstanding any inconsistent provisions of any general or special law.

Eminent Domain -- De Facto Appropriation -- Interest on Award for Legal and Accounting Expenses

3. In a condemnation action, claimants are entitled to interest on an award of attorney's fees and accounting expenses where they had to establish a de facto taking by the State, because the State deprived [***3] them of possession and enjoyment of their property (see, CPLR 5001 [a]), and inasmuch as claimants are seeking to recover fees already paid or incurred, it is the date upon which they rendered payment which should govern with respect to the computation of interest, rather than the date on which the services were completed or billed. Although EDPL 702 is directed at compensation for legal expenses incurred incident to establishing the existence of a de facto taking and not at the expenses of establishing the value of the property taken, the nature of the instant claim and the complex issues connected with it made it virtually impossible to separate out the "de facto" expenses from the "valuation" expenses.

 

1491 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York State Soc. of Obstetricians & Gynecologists, Inc. v. Corcoran


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


138 Misc. 2d 591; 525 N.Y.S.2d 457; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2807



October 1, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, New York State Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (Society) and its president, filed a motion under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, which challenged Regulation 124, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 11, § 152, promulgated by respondent Superintendent of the Insurance Department of the State of New York (Superintendent) as unconstitutional. The Superintendent cross-moved to dismiss the petition.


OVERVIEW: The legislature required the Superintendent to promulgate a regulation that established a physician professional liability insurance merit rating plan as part of the Medical Malpractice Reform Act, which reflected an individual physician's experience with respect to incidents or occurrences of alleged medical malpractice and that would be reasonable, not unfairly discriminatory, or violative of public policy. The Superintendent promulgated a final regulation that established the plan, which the Society and its president challenged. The Superintendent filed a cross-motion to dismiss the petition. The court denied the cross-motion by holding that the Society's action was not premature because, although its claim failed to comport with the N.Y. Ins. Law § 2343 on grounds that the regulation unfairly discriminated, the proceeding was converted to an action for declaratory judgment, and N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 was an inappropriate vehicle in which to advance the claims. The court also held that the Society did not fail to state a cause of action because it alleged that the regulation unfairly burdened certain doctors with a greater share of the total cost of insurance premiums.


OUTCOME: The court denied the Superintendent's cross-motion to dismiss the Society and its president's petition which challenged the regulation promulgated by the Superintendent as unconstitutional. The Superintendent was directed to serve an answer to the Society and its president's complaint.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Declaratory Judgments -- Conversion of Article 78 Proceeding to Declaratory Judgment Action -- Challenge to Physicians Professional Liability Insurance Merit Rating Plan

1. A CPLR article 78 proceeding brought by a not-for-profit corporation representing certain physicians and its president challenging regulation 124 (11 NYCRR part 152), which establishes a physicians professional liability insurance merit rating plan reflecting an individual physician's or surgeon's experience with respect to incidents or occurrences of alleged medical malpractice, as confiscatory, violative of due process, a denial of equal protection of the laws, arbitrary and capricious and discriminatory, is converted to an action for a declaratory judgment.

Insurance -- Malpractice Insurance -- Physicians Professional Liability Insurance Merit Rating Plan

2. Plaintiff's challenge to regulation 124 (11 NYCRR part 152), which establishes a physicians professional liability insurance merit rating plan reflecting an individual physician's or surgeon's experience with respect to incidents or occurrences of alleged medical malpractice, is not rendered premature or moot by the fact that the regulation [***2] permits periodic adjustment of those factors specified for assigning points to generate surcharges; the regulation has been in effect for over one year and plaintiffs' attacks on the regulation are directed at its face, not as applied to individual physicians. Plaintiffs' claims that the regulation permits a confiscatory taking of property by establishing a period of review of chargeable losses which exceeds the limits of reasonable retroactivity and that it arbitrarily and capriciously discriminates among doctors in terms of dollar amounts charged per premium surcharge because it fails to distinguish between the risks faced by physicians practicing different medical specialties state a valid cause of action for confiscatory taking and violation of substantive due process. Further, in light of the apparent unequal treatment of doctors with similar experience records and the current lack of an articulated reason for the disparity, it cannot be concluded that, as a matter of law, plaintiffs have failed to state a cause of action for arbitrary and capricious discrimination under the regulation. Accordingly, a cross motion by respondent Superintendent of Insurance to dismiss is denied [***3] and respondent is directed to serve an answer to the complaint.

 

1492 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rich


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


137 Misc. 2d 474; 520 N.Y.S.2d 911; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2604



September 22, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss his indictment for third-degree rape and endangering the welfare of an incompetent person, arguing that the indictment was illegally obtained by use of videotaped testimony and that N.Y. Penal Law §§ 25.00(2) and 130.10 unconstitutionally required him to prove an element of the crimes with which he was charged.


OVERVIEW: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss an indictment charging him with third-degree rape and endangering the welfare of an incompetent person. The prosecutor had obtained the indictment by showing the grand jury a videotape of the victim's statement because the victim was a "special witness" pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 190.32, i.e., a person more than 12 years old who was likely to suffer severe emotional or mental stress if required to testify in person. The court held that even though the state's application to present the victim as a special witness was factually deficient, the victim qualified as a special witness based upon the court's observation of her demeanor in the videotape. Furthermore, the age of the victim, more than 16, did not preclude her from illustrating what happened by using anatomically correct dolls; N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 60.44 was liberally construed to apply to impaired victims of all ages. Requiring defendant to prove that he had no knowledge of the victim's inability to consent to sex did not unconstitutionally shift to him the burden of proving the elements of the crimes. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment, holding that it was legally obtained under New York law by the prosecutor's showing the grand jury videotaped testimony from a mentally impaired "special witness," by allowing her to describe her assault by using anatomically correct dolls, and by requiring defendant to prove his affirmative defense of lack of knowledge of the witness's inability to consent to sex.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Use of Videotaped Statement of Special Witness in Grand Jury Proceeding

1. In the prosecution of defendant for rape in the third degree and endangering the welfare of an incompetent person, the use of the victim's videotaped statement in the Grand Jury proceeding pursuant to CPL 190.32 was not unconstitutional on the ground that it abrogated the Grand Jury's power to hear and examine all the evidence (NY Const, art I, § 6). The Legislature expressly stated in CPL 190.30 that CPL 190.32 could not be construed to limit the Grand Jury's power to subpoena any person it believes possesses knowledge or information of the crimes it is investigating. Further, it appears that the Grand Jury accepted the videotaped statement as sufficient, and the Assistant District Attorney conducting the examination on tape and presenting the case to the Grand Jury said nothing to indicate that this particular witness' testimony should be given any special consideration or credence because of the manner in which her testimony was presented.

Grand Jury -- Special Witness -- Sufficiency of Application -- Severe Emotional or Mental Stress

2.  [***2] In the prosecution of defendant for rape in the third degree and endangering the welfare of an incompetent person, the District Attorney's treatment of the victim as a "special witness" pursuant to CPL 190.32 for purposes of presenting her videotaped testimony to the Grand Jury is affirmed. Although the People's ex parte application to have the victim determined a special witness under CPL 190.32 is inadequate insofar as it lacks sufficient sworn allegations of fact supporting the allegations that the victim would suffer severe emotional or mental stress if required to testify, the victim's status can be affirmed through the court's review of the victim's videotaped statement. To reverse the order granting special witness status to the victim because of the insufficiency of the People's factual allegations as to emotional or mental stress would serve no useful purpose in light of the court's ability to observe her testimony firsthand.

Grand Jury -- Evidence -- Use of Anatomically and Racially Correct Dolls by Witness over Age of 16

3. A motion by defendant to dismiss the indictment charging him with rape in the third degree and endangering the welfare of an incompetent [***3] person on the grounds that the victim's use of anatomically correct dolls during her Grand Jury testimony was unauthorized under CPL 60.44 because the victim was over 16 years of age, and was neither helpful nor appropriate and prejudiced defendant because the dolls reflected the different races of the victim and the defendant, is denied. Although CPL 60.44 refers specifically to the use of anatomically correct dolls by persons under 16 years of age, it does not preclude the use of such dolls by persons 16 years of age and older. Further, the use of racially correct dolls would only serve to provide a more accurate description of the alleged crime for the grand jurors and greater aid to the victim as she testified.

Crimes -- Rape -- Affirmative Defense of Ignorance of Lack of Capacity to Consent -- Burden of Proof -- Due Process of Law

4. In the prosecution of defendant for rape in the third degree and endangering the welfare of an incompetent, the affirmative defense in Penal Law § 130.10 does not violate defendant's right to due process under the State and Federal Constitutions because it places the burden of proof on defendant regarding the issue of the victim's capacity [***4] to consent. The allegation that defendant had no knowledge of the victim's inability to consent is an issue separate and apart from the elements of rape in the third degree which the People must still prove beyond a reasonable doubt; further, it would be unfair to have the People attempt to prove a negative, particularly when the information is within defendant's own knowledge. Moreover, the statute is not unconstitutional as applied to the particular defendant in this case.

 

1493 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Savastano v. Nurnberg


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Queens County


139 Misc. 2d 593; 529 N.Y.S.2d 403; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2831



September 16, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, advocate for the mentally ill and three mentally ill patients, brought an action against defendants, hospital director of psychiatry and state commissioner of mental health, and sought a declaration that N.Y. Mental Hygiene Law § 29.11 and N.Y. Comp. Codes. R. & Regs. tit. 14, § 517.4 were violative of mentally ill patients' rights under the Due Process Clauses of the United States and New York Constitutions.


OVERVIEW: The advocate and patients challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Mental Hygiene Law § 29.11 and N.Y. Comp. Codes. R. & Regs. tit. 14, § 517.4, claiming they violated the rights of mentally ill patients under U.S. Const. amend. XIV and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6. The challenged laws permitted the transfer of involuntarily committed mentally ill patients from acute-care facilities to long-term facilities, over objection, and without a prior judicial hearing as to the need for such transfer. The court determined that the laws were unconstitutional, finding that an involuntarily committed patient did not forfeit all constitutional protections as the result of such commitment. The court held that due process protection attached to the decision to transfer mentally ill patients from acute care to long term care facilities because the transfer represented a major change in the condition and duration of confinement and should only be imposed after a determination that long-term confinement was warranted. The court concluded that a judicial hearing had to be held prior to the transfer if such a hearing was required to protect the interests of mentally ill patients.


OUTCOME: The court found that the challenged laws were in violation of mentally ill patients' due process rights.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Mental Health -- Transfer of Patients

The transfer of involuntarily committed mentally ill patients from an acute-care facility to a long-term facility, over objection and without prior judicial hearing as to the need for such transfer (Mental Hygiene Law § 29.11; 14 NYCRR 517.4), is violative of the rights of mentally ill patients to due process of law since the transfer represents a major change in the condition and duration of confinement and is normally imposed only when it is determined that an individual is in need of intermediate or long-term confinement. The mere fact that the transfer might be motivated by the desire or necessity to alleviate overcrowding to meet the demand for inpatient treatment in acute-care psychiatric facilities is a conflict which prevents the director of the transferring facility from deciding the issues in an unbiased and impartial manner. While the aim of the statute and regulations is to utilize the limited resources for treatment of the mentally ill in the most expeditious manner so that a treatment in an acute-care facility is limited to those individuals who will most benefit, expediency, efficiency and costs in terms of time and effort [***2] are not paramount governmental interests where due process protections are involved.

 

1494 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Allen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


136 Misc. 2d 963; 519 N.Y.S.2d 527; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2556



September 15, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was indicted for violating N.Y. Tax Law § 1802(a) based on his failure to file personal income tax returns for three consecutive years. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the indictment on the ground that the State's reference to the years of his non-filing prior to the effective date of § 1802(a) violated the restriction against ex post facto laws of U.S. Const. art. I, § 9, cl. 3 and U.S. Const. art. I, § 10, cl. 1.


OVERVIEW: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the indictment that charged him with violating § 1802(a) for failing to file personal income tax returns for three consecutive years. Defendant argued that his non-filing of personal income tax returns for the two years prior to the enactment of § 1802(a) could not be used to meet the three year requirement of § 1802(a) because it violated the constitutional restriction against ex post facto laws. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment because the violation of § 1802(a) was not committed until defendant failed to file the personal income tax return for the third year. The crime that defendant was charged with was defined in terms of three separate components that spanned a three year period and the effective date of § 1802(a) preceded the date on which the crime of three sequential non-filings was executed by defendant. The court concluded that there was no constitutional infirmity by the State's application of the prior years' non-filings because defendant had fair notice that his conduct would produce criminal penalties.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Failure to File State Tax Returns for Three Consecutive Years -- Ex Post Facto Law

 Tax Law § 1802 (a), effective November 1, 1985, which makes it a class E felony to fail to file State tax returns for three consecutive years, is not an unconstitutional ex post facto law as applied to defendant because of the incorporation of 1983 and 1984 nonfilings as part of the offense since the statute does not increase punishment for failure to file 1983 and 1984 tax returns but, rather, it simply toughens the penalty for the 1985 nonfiling, exclusively in the context of two immediate and sequential prior omissions where there is outstanding tax liability. While the criminal activity technically began in 1983 when nonfiling was punishable as a misdemeanor, the crime was not in fact committed within the meaning of section 1802 (a) until April 15, 1986 when the third filing was due and, as such, this is not a case where the defendant is being subjected to a greater penalty for committing a crime which was consummated before the increased penalty was enacted. Defendant had fair notice, well before his 1985 return [***2] was due, of which conduct would produce criminal penalties and what those penalties were.

 

1495 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York v. 629 Ltd. Partnership


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


136 Misc. 2d 1072; 519 N.Y.S.2d 779; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2534



September 14, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff mortgagee, a city, sought an order appointing a receiver during the pendency of the foreclosure action of the premises owned by defendant mortgagor authorizing the receiver to expend moneys necessary to properly repair, run, and maintain the premises. The mortgagor opposed the appointment of a receiver claiming that a sale of the building was imminent and that N.Y. Mult. Dwell. Law § 302-b was unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: The building in question was primarily occupied by low-income tenants. The condition of the apartments and common hallways was deplorable. The mortgagor was in default, and a foreclosure action had been commenced. The purpose of § 302-b was to permit and encourage mortgagees of multiple dwellings to remove violations, which the mortgagor had failed to correct. In order to accomplish the purpose of the legislature and keep the housing stock free of hazardous violations, mortgagees had to be allowed to add the moneys advanced for such purposes to the mortgage lien. Nor was there any problem with regard to vagueness as to what repairs with respect to the property could be made by the receiver. The court appointed a receiver and reviewed his or her acts. Such legislation, which was reasonably calculated to provide better living conditions, namely, ones not hazardous to life, health, or safety, was in the best interest of the public welfare. Protecting the public welfare was a proper concern of government. Therefore, § 302-b was constitutional. The mortgagee correctly sought a receiver to protect its lien and for the welfare of the tenants. The court granted the motion.


OUTCOME: The court granted the mortgagee's motion for the appointment of a receiver during the pendency of the foreclosure action against the mortgagor.


HEADNOTES

Receivers -- Multiple Dwellings -- Removal of Violations by Mortgagee

Multiple Dwelling Law § 302-b (1), which provides that a Receiver appointed during foreclosure proceedings may expend funds advanced by the mortgagee "necessary for the operation of such multiple dwelling and for the making of repairs therein necessary to remove conditions constituting violations" is not unconstitutionally vague since the repairs made by the Receiver are subject to review by the court. Furthermore, the additional provision that the sums advanced "shall be added to the amount of the lien of such mortgagee" is not an unconstitutional deprivation of property without due process of law since the statute properly addresses a proper concern of government of protecting the public welfare by providing better living conditions. In order to accomplish the purpose of the statute and keep the housing stock free of hazardous violations, mortgagees must be allowed to add the moneys advanced to remove violations to the mortgage lien.

 

1496 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Sullivan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Queens County


137 Misc. 2d 909; 522 N.Y.S.2d 758; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2735



September 14, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged in a multicount indictment of being the mastermind of a "chop-chop" and of violating N.Y. Penal Law § 170.70 based on the removal of safety stickers. Defendant filed a motion for the inspection of the Grand Jury minutes and the dismissal of counts of the indictment concerning the violations of § 170.70 stemming from the removal of the safety stickers.


OVERVIEW: Defendant filed a motion to inspect the Grand Jury minutes and for the dismissal of several counts in the indictment on the ground that the evidence was inadequate to support the indictment. Defendant argued that he did not violate § 170.70 by removing the safety stickers from vehicles because the safety stickers were not vehicle identification numbers since they were not permanently affixed to the vehicles. Defendant further contended that he was required to remove the safety stickers from "non-component" parts, such as the automobile doors, prior to the resale of the vehicles. The State argued that the safety stickers were vehicle identification numbers and that defendant's removal of the stickers violated § 170.70. The court dismissed the criminal charges against defendant that related to his removal of the safety stickers because the stickers were not vehicle identification numbers since they not stamped or embossed as required by § 170.70, and the did not require vehicle identification numbers since they were not major component parts.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the counts in the indictment concerning the removal of the safety stickers.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Possession of Vehicle Identification Number -- "Chop-Shop" Operation

Defendant, a licensed automobile dismantler, is charged with masterminding a "chop-shop" operation in that he allegedly possessed numerous automobile doors with no vehicle identification number (VIN) stickers attached, in violation of Penal Law § 170.70. A person cannot possess a vehicle part with the VIN removed (Penal Law § 170.70 [2]). However, the statute requires that a VIN be "stamped or embossed" and that the only sanctioned VIN locations be on the major component parts, to wit, the nose, the frame, the engine, the transmission, and in one secret location chosen by the manufacturer, usually located under a wheel well or back seat of the automobile. Thus, automobile doors are not major component parts, nor were they stamped or embossed. Furthermore, the alleged VINs were contained within Federal safety pollution stickers which defendant had an implied duty to remove from noncomponent parts prior to resale pursuant to motor vehicle regulations. Therefore, dismissal of challenged counts of the indictment is granted.

 

1497 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Association of Messenger Services, Inc. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


136 Misc. 2d 869; 519 N.Y.S.2d 506; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2523



September 8, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs sought preliminary injunctions against the enforcement by defendants, New York City and the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Transportation, of the Commissioner's order barring bicycles from designated city streets during certain hours. Defendants sought to dismiss plaintiffs' action.


OVERVIEW: Defendants issued a press release announcing a ban on bicycles on certain streets during designated hours. Thereafter, the Commissioner promulgated an order formally banning bicycles in the designated areas at the designated times. Plaintiffs brought suit to enjoin enforcement of the order. The court found that the order was invalid because it was not enacted in the form of a regulation, with publication and notice as mandated by the city charter. Although N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1642 provided that the Commissioner could regulate traffic by an "order," he was still required to comply with the provisions of the city charter requiring that a prohibition be adopted by promulgation of a regulation and the publication and notice requirements. Further, the order regulated conduct affecting a significant segment of the population and, even though the public was informally notified of the ban approximately a month before the effective date of the order, legal enactment thereof required its formal adoption as a regulation.


OUTCOME: The court concluded that the order barring bicycles from designated streets at designated times was improperly promulgated, granted plaintiffs summary judgment declaring the order to be invalid, and entered a permanent injunction barring enforcement of the order. It dismissed defendants' cross motions to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Regulation of Traffic Safety -- Ban on Bicycles in Midtown Manhattan

An order of the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Transportation barring bicycles from designated midtown Manhattan streets during certain hours by the mere posting of signs is invalid since the Commissioner may regulate traffic in this manner only through the enactment of formal rules and regulations (NY City Charter § 2903 [b] [1]) and the ban on bicycles was not enacted in the form of a regulation with the mandated publication and notice (NY City Charter § 1105). The Commissioner's authority to implement traffic control "without the necessity of filing and publication" (NY City Charter § 2903 [b] [2]) is limited to the Commissioner's discretion as to where, how and in what manner the necessary traffic signs are to be posted to inform the public of prohibited conduct and other restrictions properly promulgated and does not authorize the Commissioner to establish rules of conduct merely by putting up signs to that effect.

 

1498 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Goodwin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Criminal Term, Nassau County


136 Misc. 2d 657; 519 N.Y.S.2d 189; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2453



August 21, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For these reasons, defendant's motion to suppress is denied and this court holds that the search was a legal search limited to that which was necessary for discovery of weapons which might be used to harm the officers or others nearby.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss a loitering charge under N.Y. Penal Law § 240.35 [7], on the grounds that the statute was unconstitutional on its face and as applied, and moved to suppress a hypodermic syringe, alleging that it was the fruit of an illegal search.


OVERVIEW: The court denied motions by defendant to dismiss a loitering charge and to suppress a hypodermic syringe. Defendant had been arrested in a lower level waiting room of a railroad station. The court found that although the legislature did not draft N.Y. Penal Law § 240.35 (7) in a manner worthy of high praise for their eloquent craftsmanship, and although its "satisfactory explanation" provision did raise constitutional uncertainty, the court was constrained to conclude that defendant had failed to discharge its burden of proving the statute's constitutional invalidity beyond a reasonable doubt. The statute merely prohibited loitering at a specific location and was, therefore, sustainable. Accordingly, defendant's motion to dismiss the loitering charge on the grounds that it was unconstitutional was denied. Defendant's motion to suppress was denied as the court found the search was a legal search limited to that which was necessary for discovery of weapons which might have been used to harm the officers or others nearby.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motions were denied as the loitering statute was not unconstitutional and the search which produced a syringe was a legal search limited to that which was necessary for the discovery of weapons.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Loitering -- Sleeping in Transportation Facility -- Seizure of Hypodermic Instrument

Defendant has failed to prove that Penal Law § 240.35 (7), which provides that a person is guilty of loitering when he "[loiters] or remains in any transportation facility or is found sleeping therein, and is unable to give a satisfactory explanation of his presence", is unconstitutionally vague since there is a reasonable relationship between the welfare of the public-at-large, and the concern and efforts of the Legislature to insure the safety of the many patrons who utilize transportation facilities which often serve as the setting of violent crimes. In addition, a hypodermic instrument (Penal Law § 220.45) was lawfully seized from defendant's pocket by police officers who awoke defendant to determine why he was sleeping on a bench in a waiting room of the Freeport railroad station since defendant's actions in placing his hand in his sweatshirt [***2] pocket and then refusing to remove his hand stating "I have something I'm not supposed to have in my pocket" gave rise to a reasonable suspicion that the officers were in danger of physical injury and thereby justified a limited legal search of defendant's pocket for a weapon.

 

1499 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Dillon v. Bialostok


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Nassau County


136 Misc. 2d 695; 519 N.Y.S.2d 186; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2484



August 14, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff claiming authority moved for an order confirming the ex parte order of attachment by the County Court (New York). Defendant opposed the confirmation of the order of attachment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant had criminal charges against him. The claiming authority, the district attorney, moved for an order confirming the criminal court's order of attachment. The court found that the claiming authority had established: (1) a substantial probability of success; (2) that failure to confirm the ex parte order might have resulted in the property being destroyed, removed, or otherwise unavailable for forfeiture; and (3) that the need to preserve assets outweighed the hardship suffered by the defendant. The court rejected defendant's argument that he was in need of access to the attached funds to meet his living expenses, finding that he still had access to some funds and the use of much of his property. The court found no factual basis for the assertion that the seizure deprived defendant of his right to counsel. However, the court found that the order granting attachment might have been invalid, as the claiming authority had not complied with N.Y. C.P.L.R. 1318(2). Defendant had not indicated his willingness to give an undertaking in an amount equal to the value of the property sought to be discharged; thus, his motion for a discharge of attachment was denied.


OUTCOME: The claiming authority's motion for an order confirming the attachment was granted subject to the timely submission of proof of filing. Defendant's cross motion for a discharge of attachment was denied.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Forfeitures and Penalties -- Forfeiture of Proceeds of Crime -- Provisional Remedies

The ex parte order of attachment of defendant's property is confirmed subject to the timely submission of proof of the filing of the complaint ( CPLR 1318 [2]) since the claiming authority, by submission of affirmations, affidavits and exhibits, including excerpts from the transcripts of intercepted communications not excluded from evidence, has established a substantial probability of success on the issue of forfeiture and that failure to confirm the order may result in the property being destroyed, removed from the jurisdiction of the court or otherwise unavailable for forfeiture ( CPLR 1312 [3] [a]). Defendant has not shown that the seizure of his property effectively deprives him of his constitutional right to counsel since he can apply to the court for release of his funds pro tanto nor has he shown that the forfeiture statute is unconstitutional by requiring him to give up his Fifth Amendment right to silence in order to exercise his due process right to be heard. Due to the clandestine nature of the underlying criminal charges, the proceeds cannot be determined with absolute [***2] certainty at this preliminary stage but the claiming authority has made a just and reasonable estimate of proceeds. County Court has jurisdiction over the civil forfeiture action notwithstanding its $ 25,000 jurisdictional limit (see, CPLR 1310 [7]; CPL 10.10). Since the forfeiture statute provides little guidance to the parties and courts faced with the task of interpreting and applying its often obscure provisions, the Legislature should clarify the statute to allow uniform application in all civil forfeiture actions.

 

1500 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


George v. Goldrick


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Rockland County


136 Misc. 2d 258; 518 N.Y.S.2d 582; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2420



July 27, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, petitioners' application is denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner brought a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, in the nature of mandamus, initiated to compel respondents to eliminate alleged overcrowded conditions at a county jail.


OVERVIEW: The instant court dismissed the petitioner's cause of action alleging jail overcrowding, because the allegations raised did not amount to excessive conditions of confinement that resulted in punishment. The court granted the application for class certification by petitioner and the intervening petitioners, because all of the prerequisites set forth in N.Y. C.P.L.R. 901 had been satisfied. Petitioners alleged that that the population of the county jail was allowed to exceed the maximum prisoner capacity in contravention of the applicable rules and regulations. Respondents contended that the allegations of overcrowding did not amount to a U.S. Const. amend. VIII violation of the petitioners' rights. The court held that while the overcrowding may have been harsh and uncomfortable, that did not make it cruel and unusual and therefore unconstitutional. Accordingly, there was no cruel and inhuman punishment against petitioners and the court dismissed their cause of action.


OUTCOME: The instant court dismissed the petitioner's cause of action alleging jail overcrowding, on the grounds that the allegations raised did not amount to excessive conditions of confinement that resulted in punishment in violation of the U.S. Const. amend. VIII of the United States Constitution.


HEADNOTES

Parties -- Intervention

1. In a proceeding to compel respondents to eliminate alleged overcrowded conditions at a county jail brought by an inmate at the jail who is no longer incarcerated there, petitioner's application to serve an amended petition naming five individuals who are or were inmates of the jail as intervening copetitioners, is granted. The intervenors are in the same situation which has given rise to petitioner's claim, and allowing intervention will not prejudice the rights of any party to the action.

Actions -- Class Actions

2. In a proceeding to compel respondents to eliminate alleged overcrowded conditions at a county jail, an application for class certification is granted. The five prerequisites for a class action contained in CPLR 901 have been satisfied, and it is irrelevant that petitioner is no longer incarcerated in the jail and that the five intervening petitioners have also been released or transferred elsewhere; the general conditions of incarceration complained of may persist, and the matter is not rendered moot.

Actions -- Conversion of One Form of Action  [***2] to Another

3. A proceeding pursuant to CPLR article 78 in the nature of mandamus seeking to compel respondents to eliminate alleged overcrowded conditions at a county jail is deemed a declaratory judgment action. It does not appear that petitioners' case lies in mandamus, but rather primarily seeks a declaration whether Federal and State constitutional rights of due process and to be free from cruel and unusual punishment have been violated.

Prisons and Prisoners -- Overcrowding in County Jail

4. In a proceeding seeking to compel respondents to eliminate alleged overcrowded conditions at a county jail, causes of action have not been stated. Overcrowding, in and of itself, is not a violation of the 8th Amendment prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment, for those persons incarcerated upon conviction for crimes. The allegations do not indicate barbarous physical punishment or the unnecessary and wanton infliction of pain and the imposition of penalties grossly disproportionate to the severity of the crimes. For those held in prison awaiting trial, overcrowding, in and of itself, is also not a deprivation of Federal due process rights. To the extent that petitioners [***3] allege that the jail population has been allowed to exceed the maximum capacity promulgated by the Commission of Correction, enforcement of these standards is a matter for the commission and not the courts; a court may intervene only if there are violations of constitutional dimension. Transfer of certain inmates to other county jails in the State is also not a violation of constitutional rights. Finally, enforcement of the mandate contained in CPL 430.20 (1) that defendants sentenced to terms of imprisonment must be forthwith committed to the custody of the appropriate public servant is not for the court except if it finds violations of a constitutional dimension.

 

1501 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Tigue v. E.R. Squibb & Sons, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


136 Misc. 2d 467; 518 N.Y.S.2d 891; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2473



July 16, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendants' motions for summary judgment dismissing the complaint are denied, and the matter is set down for trial on September 30, 1987.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant pharmaceutical companies moved for summary judgment dismissing plaintiffs' complaint based upon the conceded inability of plaintiffs to identify the particular manufacturer of the drug diethylstilbestrol (DES) to which they were allegedly exposed.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs sought to recover for injuries allegedly sustained by their prenatal exposure to their mothers' ingestion of diethylstilbestrol (DES). Although they could not identify the particular manufacturer of the DES they were exposed to, plaintiffs pursued various tort and collective liability theories. The companies moved for summary judgment because they claimed that the right to recover on collective, nonidentification, or concerted action theories of liability had not been established. The court denied the companies' consolidated motions for summary judgment. The court adopted the concerted action theory of recovery for DES cases and determined that plaintiffs could proceed on their clearly stated and viable cause of action for DES collective liability through concert by agreement or substantial assistance. Plaintiffs' inability to identify the actual DES manufacturer was not fatal. The court declined to rule on the applicability of the liability theories that were raised in response to the companies' motions, denied the companies' claims of exculpation, and rejected the companies' constitutional challenges on due process, equal protection, preemption, and commerce grounds.


OUTCOME: The court denied the companies' motions for summary judgment dismissing the complaint in the plaintiffs' personal injury case, and set the case for trial.


HEADNOTES

Products Liability -- Concerted Action -- Pharmaceutical Manufacturers
