In the absence of a definitive ruling by the Court of Appeals, collective, nonidentification or concerted action theories of liability in cases involving injuries caused by prenatal exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES), a synthetic hormone manufactured or marketed by between 94 and 300 pharmaceutical companies from 1947 to 1971, are viable in the First Department (see, Bichler v Lilly & Co., 79 AD2d 317, affd 55 NY2d 571) and, therefore, the inability of plaintiffs to identify the particular manufacturer of the DES taken by the mothers of the injured women in each case does not require dismissal of the actions. A finding of concert by conscious parallelism or substantial assistance may be supported based upon the formation of identical chemical standards for DES in pregnancy, the marketing of the drug without prior testing on pregnant mice and the drug companies' reliance upon the same studies in supplemental new drug applications filed with [***2] the Food and Drug Administration. A collective liability theory under which liability may be imposed upon drug companies without product identification is not violative of due process or equal protection since liability may properly be premised upon the tortious behavior of each defendant that resulted in a harmful product being placed on the market. In addition, the imposition of liability without product identification is not preempted by Federal law, which is primarily designed to control product safety and efficacy, nor would such liability place an unconstitutional burden on interstate commerce.

 

1502 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hymowitz v. Eli Lilly & Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


136 Misc. 2d 482; 518 N.Y.S.2d 996; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2476



July 16, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendants' cross motions for summary judgment dismissing the complaint as barred by the Statute of Limitations are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff woman filed a pharmaceutical product liability action against defendant drug manufacturers alleging that she developed cancer as a result of prenatal exposure to a synthetic estrogen taken by her mother. The action was brought under the provisions of the tort revival statute, 1986 N.Y. Laws ch. 682, § 4, because the action was barred by the statute of limitations, N.Y. C.P.L.R. 208, 214.


OVERVIEW: The cancerous condition that the woman claimed was the result of prenatal exposure to a synthetic estrogen taken by her mother appeared four years after she was barred from commencing an action by the statute of limitations. She filed a pharmaceutical product liability action against the drug manufacturers under the tort revival statute, and the court denied the drug manufacturers' motions for summary judgment and granted the woman's motion to strike the affirmative defenses challenging the constitutionality of the revival statute. The court conducted a rational basis review of the statute for both the drug manufacturers' due process and equal protections claims and concluded that the legislature acted within permissible objectives relating to health, safety, and welfare by reviving causes of action based upon the latent effects of exposure to certain toxic substances. The court found that the legislation and the challenged classifications within it passed muster under the rational basis test or even under the more demanding intermediate standard because it could not be said that the legislature acted unreasonably in selecting the substances for special treatment.


OUTCOME: The court granted the woman's motion to strike the drug manufacturers' affirmative defenses challenging the constitutionality of the tort revival statute in her pharmaceutical product liability action and denied the drug manufacturers' motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions -- Revival of Time-Barred Claims -- Exposure to Toxic Substances

The revival portion of the 1986 tort reform legislation, which provides that actions seeking damages for personal injury, property damage or death caused by the latent effects of exposure to five toxic substances (diethylstilbestrol [DES], asbestos, tungsten-carbide, chlordane, and polyvinylchloride) that were time barred or dismissed as of the July 30, 1986 effective date of the statute, may be instituted within one year from the statute's effective date (L 1986, ch 682, § 4), is not violative of due process since there is a reasonable connection between the revival statute and the promotion of the legitimate State objective of remedying the defects or inequities under the prior exposure-based Statute of Limitations so as to provide a forum for innocent victims who might otherwise be denied legal recourse before becoming aware of their injuries. In addition, limiting the revival statute to five chosen substances and their manufacturers is not violative of equal [***2] protection as an underinclusive random penalty without scientific basis since the statutory classification is reasonably based upon the perceived realities of the latent effects of exposure to the five substances, the existence of an identifiable group affected and the resulting ability to predict with some accuracy the economic costs of revival.

 

1503 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Fulvio


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Bronx County


136 Misc. 2d 334; 517 N.Y.S.2d 1008; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2460



June 22, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss the charge of attempting to violate General Business Law § 518 is granted, the conviction thereon is set aside and dismissed and the defendant is discharged.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Subsequent to his conviction for violation of N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 518 by the government, defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charge.


OVERVIEW: A customer had attempted to purchase gasoline at defendant's establishment with a credit card. A dispute arose when the clerk and defendant told the customer that the gas purchase was higher because he wanted to pay by credit card, and that the price on the sign was the discounted price for cash purchases. The customer swore out a complaint and defendant was arrested. Defendant argued that § 518 was unconstitutional. The court agreed, granted the motion to dismiss, and set aside defendant's conviction. In doing so, the court held that the very distinction made by the government, namely, that the statute prohibited a vendor from charging a surcharge for credit card usage, but would not have interfered with that same vendor establishing the higher price for credit card sales and then allowing a comparable discount for cash purchases, required that the statute be invalidated on due process grounds, at least as applied in the case.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to dismiss the charge was granted, the conviction thereon was set aside and dismissed, and defendant was discharged.


HEADNOTES

Consumer Protection -- Consumer Credit -- Credit Card Surcharge

General Business Law § 518, which prohibits vendors from imposing a surcharge for credit card usage but permits merchants to have two-tier pricing systems for "cash discounts", is unconstitutional as violative of substantive due process as applied to defendant, a gas station operator convicted of attempting to charge a credit card customer a "credit price" 5 cents more per gallon than the price posted on the top of the pump, since the statute, by permitting a price differential so long as that differential is characterized as a discount for payment by cash and not as an additional charge for payment by use of a credit card, creates a distinction without a difference that impermissibly allows the same conduct to be labeled as lawful or unlawful on the basis of semantics only. The statute is not saved by the semantic gyration of claiming that it contemplates the establishment of a "regular price" for a product, that a "discount [***2] for cash" from that "regular price" is permitted and that it is only the "surcharge", or additional charge for use of a credit card which is prohibited since there is at the "gas" pump a legally permissible "cash price" and a legally permissible "credit price". It is intolerable that a gas station operator careless enough to describe the higher price in terms which amount to the "credit price" having been derived from adding a charge to the lower price faces the prospect of criminal conviction and possible imprisonment. Accordingly, defendant's conviction is set aside and he is discharged.

 

1504 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Keyes


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Albany County


135 Misc. 2d 993; 517 N.Y.S.2d 696; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2348



June 17, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss an indictment against his for violating N.Y. Penal Law § 263.15 by promoting a sexual performance by a child.


OVERVIEW: The State alleged that defendant, while knowing its character and content, procured certain magazines through the mail that contained photographs depicting children under the age of 16 engaged in sexual conduct. Defendant argued that the photographs were for his own private use and thus were not proscribed by N.Y. Penal Law § 263.15, which prohibited the promoting of a sexual performance by a child. The court dismissed the indictment for failure on its face to state a crime under § 263.15. Because the term "procure" was susceptible to two or more meanings, the court was required to determine the intention of the legislature. The court found that there was no suggestion in the legislative history, and no language in the statute, that § 263.15 was intended to punish the customer of a sexual performance for his own private use. The court also found that the term "procure" had to be construed consistently with the other terms in the statute, all of which prohibited conduct relating to the creation and distribution of the prohibited performance. Thus, the statute was not intended to punish the ultimate consumer.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the indictment.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Promoting Sexual Performance by Child

An indictment charging defendant with violating Penal Law § 263.15 by procuring through the mail certain magazines containing photographs of children under the age of 16 which depicted them performing deviate sexual acts must be dismissed since section 263.15, which provides that "[A] person is guilty of promoting a sexual performance by a child when, knowing the character and content thereof, he produces, directs, or promotes any performance which includes sexual conduct by a child less than sixteen years of age", was intended to punish the creator and distributor of the prohibited performance, not the ultimate consumer.

 

1505 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Merriweather


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Nassau County


135 Misc. 2d 998; 516 N.Y.S.2d 893; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2349



June 12, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In view of the aforesaid, the defendant's motion is, in all respects, denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss an information charging him with violating N.Y. Educ. Law § 6513, unauthorized use of a professional title, for using the title "architect" without having a license as required by N.Y. Educ. Law § 7302.


OVERVIEW: Defendant used the title "architect" on an American Institute of Architects "Abbreviated Form of Agreement Between Owner and Contractor" involving the construction of a one-story addition to an owner's house. Defendant was not licensed to practice architecture in the State. He claimed that the violations as charged against him were unconstitutionally vague and incapable of enforcement. The court held that N.Y. Educ. Law § 7300 et seq., the statutes regulating the practice of architecture, were constitutionally sound. There was a legitimate exercise of police power in regulating the practice of architecture. N.Y. Educ. Law §§ 6513(1), 7301, and 7302 directed a person with reasonable specificity toward the conduct to be prohibited. Defendant has failed to demonstrate the invalidity of §§ 6513(1), 7301, and 7302 beyond a reasonable doubt. It was the legislature's intent to prohibit the activity defendant allegedly committed. Sections 6513(1), 7301, and 7302 protect the public from unlicensed professional architects.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the information filed against him.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Unauthorized Use of Professional Title

In a criminal prosecution wherein defendant was charged with violating section 6513 (1) of the Education Law by his unauthorized use of a professional title, to wit, "architect", defendant's motion to dismiss the information on the grounds that the statutes proscribing such conduct (Education Law § 6513 [1]; § 7302) are unconstitutionally vague is denied. There exists a legitimate exercise of police power in regulating the practice of architecture, and the statutes, with clarity and certainty, direct a person with reasonable specificity toward the conduct to be prohibited. Defendant failed to demonstrate the invalidity of the statutes beyond a reasonable doubt; Education Law § 7300 et seq., the statutes regulating the practice of architecture, are constitutionally sound.

 

1506 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Davis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Syracuse


135 Misc. 2d 841; 516 N.Y.S.2d 890; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2318



June 11, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] On its own motion, the court dismisses the charge of petit larceny for insufficiency.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought dismissal of the accusatory instrument charging him with possession of an imitation controlled substance under N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 3383(2) on the ground of insufficiency. Defendant also contended that the statute was unconstitutional as being overbroad and vague.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that § 3383 was unconstitutional because it was uncertain as to what persons came within its scope or how guilt was to be ascertained. Moreover, he contended insufficiency of the accusatory instrument because there were no facts alleged that demonstrated intent to sell an imitation controlled substance. Upon review, the court found that under § 3383, the prosecution failed to establish that defendant had an intent to sell as such the charge of larceny was insufficient on its face. The court went on to hold that § 3383 was constitutional in not being vague or overbroad.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the charge of petit larceny for insufficiency.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Controlled Substances -- Possession of Imitation Controlled Substances

The statute proscribing possession of an imitation controlled substance (Public Health Law § 3383) is not unconstitutionally vague or overbroad since the statute contains the element of intent and refers to the clear Penal Law definition of "controlled substance". However, an accusatory instrument charging defendant with possession of an imitation controlled substance, for possessing a white powdery substance "packaged exactly as * * * cocaine is packaged for street sale" is dismissed for insufficiency ( CPL 100.40) in the absence of a recitation of the complainant's experience or background that would explain his basis for knowing "pony pak" paper, how it is folded and how the package is one for street sale. In addition, the petit larceny charge (Penal Law § 155.25) based upon defendant's alleged acceptance of $ 10 from a police officer for a substance purported to be marihuana is likewise dismissed for insufficiency since there is no factual allegation that the substance purchased from defendant was [***2] not worth the $ 10 paid.

 

1507 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Brentwood Union Free School Dist. v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Suffolk County


135 Misc. 2d 1105; 517 N.Y.S.2d 996; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2361



June 10, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff school district filed a declaratory judgment action against defendants, state officials and a school district, challenging the officials' modification of the school district's tax base, which caused a reduction in the school district's state aid to education. The members of the board of education had sought to intervene, the school district and the officials had sought summary judgment, and the officials had sought a change of venue.


OVERVIEW: In consideration of the challenge to the addresses reported by a certain school district, the state officials, which determined the amount of "state aid to education" to a district on the combined total gross adjusted income of the residents of each district, added the addresses to the school district's tax base, substantially reducing its state aid. The district sought a declaratory and summary judgment against the officials alleging that the school district was not given an opportunity to review the additions to its tax base and that the officials had no power under 1984 N.Y. Laws 889 to unilaterally reduce its state aid, and the officials sought a change of venue and summary judgment. The court held that: (1) a declaratory judgment action under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 213 was the appropriate vehicle to challenge the implementation of the statute; (2) the action was filed within the six-year statute of limitations period; and (3) while 1984 N.Y. Laws 889 was constitutional, the officials' implementation thereof and the revision of the school aid formula was a denial of their rights because they were inconsistent therewith in not providing the district with an appellate review thereof.


OUTCOME: The court granted the school district's summary judgment motion, ordered the officials to reimburse the school district accordingly, and enjoined the officials from employing the proposed modified system to calculate the state aid to the school district.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Schools -- State Aid to Local School Districts -- State Aid Formula Based on Adjusted Gross Income of School District Residents

The manner in which the State defendants, the Commissioner of Education, the Commissioner of the Department of Taxation and Finance and the Director of the Budget, implemented legislation creating an Interagency Task Force "to conduct a study of alternatives for the establishment of a statewide address match and income verification system * * * with respect to improving and modifying the data used in distributing school aid to local school districts" (L 1984, ch 889 [State aid to local school districts being based in part on the combined adjusted gross income of school district residents]) is arbitrary and unfair as applied to plaintiff. Defendants deprived plaintiff and other school districts of their rights by selecting certain identified school districts to participate in the pilot program and then proceeding to change the entire State aid formula, accepting at face value the challenges of the identified districts, without any outside verification or appeal by the districts affected, thereby diminishing the State aid to neighboring school districts.  [***2] The addresses challenged by a neighboring school district and added to plaintiff's tax base increased plaintiff's adjusted gross income by more than $ 76 million resulting in a diminution in State aid of $ 771,584 for the 1985-1986 school year. Since a declaratory judgment action, rather than an article 78 proceeding, is the proper vehicle to challenge defendants' implementation of the statute, the proceeding commenced one year after plaintiff received its initial reduced State aid payment is timely and venue need not be moved to Albany County. Plaintiff has standing to object to the State's implementation of the law as being at odds with the statutory language and, in addition, injunctive relief is the only method available to plaintiff to prevent defendants, without specific direction from the Legislature, from reducing its aid in the future.

 

1508 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Multari


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


135 Misc. 2d 913; 517 N.Y.S.2d 374; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2334



June 9, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment modified, by reducing the fine imposed on defendants Multari to the sum of $ 2,750; by reducing the fine imposed on the defendant Jasmine See to the sum of $ 750; and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed their convictions and sentences for violations of a local zoning ordinance from the Albany Police Court (New York).


OVERVIEW: Three defendants appealed from their convictions and sentences for zoning ordinance violations. The ordinance regulated the number of unrelated people who could live together. The court modified the judgments and affirmed as so modified. The court found that the city had a legitimate purpose in establishing occupancy limitations, including preservation of the character of traditional single-family neighborhoods, reduction of parking and traffic problems, control of population density, and prevention of noise and disturbance, among others. The definition of "family" in Albany, N.Y., Code § 27-160 included those that were the functional equivalent of a traditional family and did not require the existence of blood, marriage, or adoption, placed no restriction on the number of unrelated children who could reside together, and allowed up to three unrelated adults to live together, so it passed muster. The portion of the ordinance providing for cumulative penalties, and pursuant to which defendants were sentenced, was invalid. Accordingly, the fines imposed on defendants for cumulative violations were reduced.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgments against the three defendants by reducing the fines imposed on them and otherwise affirmed their convictions for violating the local zoning ordinance.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Grouper Law

The Grouper Law of the City of Albany which, for purposes of the zoning ordinance, defines "family" as "[one] or more persons occupying a premises and living together as a single housekeeping unit, subject to a limit of not more than three unrelated persons 18 years of age or over" does not unconstitutionally exclude or restrict living arrangements that are "the functional equivalent of a traditional family", such as a "group home", consisting of one or more surrogate parents and a number of foster children, living together as a permanent-like surrogate family (see, McMinn v Town of Oyster Bay, 66 NY2d 544). In addition, the definition of "family" in the zoning ordinance is rationally related to the legitimate governmental ends sought to be achieved by the ordinance of reducing parking and traffic problems, controlling population density, preventing noise and disturbance and preserving the character of traditional single-family [***2] neighborhoods. However, the portion of the ordinance providing for cumulative penalties is invalid since imposition of cumulative fines or penalties for a single but continuing violation of a zoning ordinance is not permitted and the fine imposed on the defendants sentenced under such provision is reduced from $ 12,500 to $ 2,750. In addition, since the remaining defendant could not be convicted of continuing violations not specifically charged in the informations, the fine imposed on her is reduced to $ 750.

 

1509 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Kutas v. State


Claim No. 72617


Court of Claims of New York


135 Misc. 2d 1044; 517 N.Y.S.2d 857; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2355



June 9, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant retiree and defendant state filed motions for summary judgment in the claimant's action under N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 74(d) for retirement benefits. The state contended that the court lacked jurisdiction based on N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78.


OVERVIEW: The state hired the claimant as a clerk when he was 73 years old. The claimant misrepresented his age as 57, believing that the state would not hire him if the state knew that he was over 70. Retirement was mandatory at 70. After working for 10 years the claimant applied for retirement benefits. The state denied the application because retirement would have been mandatory as soon as the claimant joined the state if he had told the truth, and no benefits would have been paid. The claimant had also filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding, however he had not perfected his appeal from a decision against him. The court granted the state's motion. The statutory/contractual scheme was in place when the claimant fabricated his way into a state job and it became part of his constitutionally protected contractual pension rights when he started working. There was no change in these rights and, thus, they could not be said to have been unconstitutionally diminished. Further, the comptroller had exclusive authority to determine applications for any form of retirement and a final determination was subject to review only as provided in art. 78. Thus, the court lacked jurisdiction.


OUTCOME: The court denied the claimant's motion for summary judgment and granted the state's cross motion for summary judgment of the claimant's action for retirement benefits.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- Jurisdiction -- Contract Claim of Former State Employee for Retirement Benefits

Claimant was hired by the State Department of Motor Vehicles in 1971, having misrepresented his age as 57 when in fact he was 71 years old, and subsequently applied for retirement benefits in 1981, which were denied, after a hearing, by the Comptroller. Claimant's contract claim for retirement benefits, filed in the Court of Claims, should be dismissed, and the State's motion for summary judgment granted, since the subject claim is wholly within the purview of the Retirement and Social Security Law and hence wholly outside the subject matter jurisdiction of the Court of Claims. Disputes involving retirement benefits should be judicially determined through the procedural vehicle of a CPLR article 78 proceeding in Supreme Court (Retirement and Social Security Law § 74 [b], [d]), where all aspects of claimant's would-be contract claim can be presented.

 

1510 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Cier Industries Co. v. New York State Div. of Housing & Community Renewal


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


135 Misc. 2d 1003; 517 N.Y.S.2d 660; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2350



May 29, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, petitioners Cier Industries and Sharp and Lufkin are denied their requested relief and the petitions are dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner owner filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceedings as a challenge to respondent housing authority's decision, which denied the owner's application for an alternative hardship.


OVERVIEW: The owner converted his building to condominium ownership. Thereafter, he filed applied for but was denied consideration of any alternative hardship relief. The housing authority concluded that alternative hardship relief was only available to building owners. The housing authority contended that the economic position of owners of rent-stabilized apartments in condominium and cooperative buildings was not reflective of the building's total income and expenses. The owner argued that the Rent Stabilization Law (statute), Administrative Code of City of New York § YY51-1.0 et seq., renum. § 26-501 et seq., was misconstrued by the housing authority and that the statute was not limited to owners of buildings. The owner contend that if read in the context of the entire sentence, the words "owners of buildings" meant something else. Therefore, the owner asserted that the housing authority's decision to exclude cooperative and condominium owners from obtaining rent increases from their respective tenants was arbitrary and capricious. The court denied the owner's petition, holding that only owners of building, under the statute were entitled to apply for alternative hardship relief.


OUTCOME: The court denied the owner's petition which sought review of the housing authority's denial of his application for alternative hardship relief.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Alternative "Hardship" Rent Increase

The owners of unsold rent-stabilized apartments in cooperative and condominium buildings are not entitled to any "hardship" rental increases available under the Rent Stabilization Law to owners who were not able to maintain an annual gross rental income for the building which exceeded the annual operating expenses by a sum equal to at least 5% of the gross rents ( Administrative Code of City of New York § 26-511 [c] [6-a]). The determination of respondent State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the agency responsible for administering the rent laws, that alternative "hardship" rental increases are available only to owners of buildings and should not be measured on an ad hoc unit-by-unit basis because the economic positions of owners of rent-stabilized apartments in condominium and cooperative buildings is not reflective of the building's total income and expenses, is consistent with the original purpose for enacting the law of assisting owners with rent [***2] levels which were not sufficient to enable owners to pay the operating expenses of the building. The fact that petitioners have a negative cash flow with regard to the subject individual units does not make the law confiscatory and unconstitutional as applied to them given the presumption that a legislative enactment in furtherance of police power is constitutional and the fact that operating at an economic loss is not necessarily per se unconstitutional in the field of rent regulation.

 

1511 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Esther C. v. Ambach


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Albany County


135 Misc. 2d 446; 515 N.Y.S.2d 997; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2243



May 15, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner parents filed a motion for an order awarding them attorneys' fees and costs pursuant to the Education for the Handicapped Act (EHA), 20 U.S.C.S. §1415(e)(4), against respondents, an education commissioner and others.


OVERVIEW: The parents challenged an interpretation of a state education law by the commissioner that they claimed denied their handicapped children the placement they were entitled to under the Education for the Handicapped Act (EHA). The court held for the parents, who then filed a motion for attorneys' fees and costs under the EHA, 20 U.S.C.S. § 1415(e)(4)(B). The court granted the motion and rejected respondents' claim that this was not the type of action in which fees were allowed under the EHA. The court noted that 20 U.S.C.S. § 1415(e) authorized an action to challenge a final administrative determination by an education commissioner following an appeal to him by a party aggrieved by a determination of a local educational agency in an administrative hearing. The court stated that the action attacked by the parents involved an action taken by the commissioner, rather than an appeal of an action taken by a local agency. The court found that this distinction did not require the denial of the parents' motion. Despite some procedural irregularities, the action qualified as one under the EHA. The court also noted that a broad construction of the EHA required granting the motion.


OUTCOME: The court granted the parents' motion for an order awarding them attorneys' fees and costs against respondents.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Schools -- Education of Handicapped Children -- Counsel Fees

In a proceeding brought by parents of handicapped children, successfully challenging a determination of the Commissioner of Education terminating the educational placement of their children, petitioners' motion for attorneys' fees and disbursements pursuant to 20 USC § 1415 (e) (4) (B) (Education for the Handicapped Act [EHA]) is granted. The litigation, which deals with the claim that the Commissioner's erroneous interpretation of Education Law § 4407 (2) denied four handicapped children the placement they were entitled to under EHA and Education Law article 89, is an action or proceeding under 20 USC § 1415. Awarding attorneys' fees does not constitute a violation of the impairment of Contract Clause of the Federal Constitution (US Const, art I, § 10). The amount requested is reasonable, and the number of hours expended by petitioners' counsel is reasonable in view of the quality of the legal work and the result obtained.

 

1512 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Familo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Oswego, Oswego County


135 Misc. 2d 623; 516 N.Y.S.2d 416; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2278



May 15, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the proper interpretation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1224(c)(1), the violation of which he was charged for abandoning his vehicle.


OVERVIEW: Section 1224 stated that a vehicle was deemed to be abandoned if it was left unattended for more than 48 hours after the parking of the vehicle became illegal if left on a portion of a highway or public place on which parking was legally permitted. Defendant raised the issue as to the proper interpretation of the statute. In dismissing the charge against defendant, the court held that there was no evidence that the parking of the vehicle had become illegal. The court concluded that the statute was subject to different interpretations, which required its construction in favor of defendant. The court concluded that a vehicle had to be parked at least 48 hours in a spot after the parking had become illegal before the vehicle could be considered abandoned. Since there was no evidence that defendant's vehicle was illegal, the charge was dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the charge of abandoning a vehicle against defendant.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor Vehicles -- Abandoned Vehicle

A charge that defendant violated Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1224, which provides that a motor vehicle shall be deemed to be an abandoned vehicle if left unattended for more than 48 hours, after the parking of such vehicle shall have become illegal, if left on a portion of a highway or public place on which parking is legally permitted, is dismissed, since there is no proof that defendant's vehicle was ever parked illegally. The statute should be construed to mean that if a vehicle is left on a public highway in which parking is legally permitted at the time the vehicle is parked, but subsequently the parking becomes illegal and the vehicle is parked in such area for 48 hours after the parking first became illegal, the violation of abandoned vehicle would have been committed. That interpretation should be given conflicting portions of a penal statute which best protects the right of a person charged with an offense.

 

1513 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Sabree v. Parking Violations Bureau


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Monroe County


135 Misc. 2d 514; 516 N.Y.S.2d 155; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2257



May 14, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the decision of the lower court granting damages in the amount of $ 35 to the plaintiff on the grounds that the city's towing statute was unconstitutional is reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city sought review of the judgment of the Small Claims Court of the City of Rochester (New York), which awarded direct, consequential, and punitive damages to plaintiff vehicle owner in her action against the city parking violations bureau.


OVERVIEW: The vehicle owner received citations for an unregistered and uninspected motor vehicle. Her vehicle was towed and she had to pay to retrieve it. She filed a small claims action against the city's parking violations bureau. The small claims court awarded her direct damages for the amount that she paid to retrieve her vehicle from the impound lot, consequential and punitive damages. On appeal, the court reversed finding that there was no evidence upon which the small claims court could have assessed consequential damages. The court reversed the order for punitive damages finding that punitive damages could not be assessed against a municipality or any of its bureaus. The court found that the city ordinance authorizing the impoundment of the vehicle was constitutional because it provided for notice after towing and prompt judicial review.


OUTCOME: The court reversed.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Parking Violations

A judgment awarding plaintiff direct, consequential and punitive damages after her parked car was issued traffic tickets for being an unregistered and uninspected motor vehicle and after the vehicle was towed is reversed. There is no evidence upon which the court could have assessed consequential damages. Punitive damages may not be assessed against a municipality or any of its bureaus, including defendant Parking Violations Bureau. Finally, the ordinance authorizing the city's action provides for both notice after towing and a prompt judicial review, and was thus improperly declared unconstitutional; the ordinance provides sufficient procedural guidelines to insure due process.

 

1514 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Walker


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County


135 Misc. 2d 370; 515 N.Y.S.2d 700; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2229



April 23, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant's assigned counsel submitted vouchers with respect to his representation of defendant, who was indigent. Defendant was charged with a count of murder in the second degree. The defense was vigorous and resulted in a complete acquittal.


OVERVIEW: The trial of defendant was lengthy. Defense counsel submitted vouchers for over 255 hours for in-court time and 137 hours for out-of-court time, for a total of $ 13,490. Under N.Y. County Law art. 18-B, § 722-b, however, compensation was limited to a total of $ 1,200. The court found that the length of the trial was, in large part, because of the lengthy and unabated applications made by defense counsel. Furthermore, the overwhelming majority of the challenges and applications were, if not frivolous, "throw-away" applications. The court found that the statute did not define the "extraordinary circumstances" in which additional compensation was to be awarded, above and beyond the statutory $ 1,200. In addition, the cases deciding the issue were in conflict. Therefore, the court made a list of relevant factors, including, but not limited to: the complexity of the issues, the seriousness of the charges, the extent to which counsel was compelled to expend additional hours due to circumstances beyond his control, and the extent to which additional time was unnecessarily expended. Applying those factors, the court limited the compensation to the statutory limit.


OUTCOME: The court limited defense counsel's entitlement to compensation for representing the indigent defendant to the maximum permitted by the relevant statute.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Attorney and Client -- Compensation -- Assigned Attorney's Fee for Legal Representation

Upon application by assigned counsel pursuant to County Law § 722-b for compensation beyond the statutory limit of $ 1,200 with respect to his representation of an indigent defendant, the court is to consider the complexity of the issues, the seriousness of the charges, the extent to which counsel was compelled to expend additional hours due to circumstances beyond his control, the extent to which additional time was unnecessarily and unreasonably expended, the fact that participating attorneys are aware that the limited fees provided fall short of full compensation for their services, and, to a lesser extent, actual hours expended, results achieved, experience and stature of counsel at the Bar, and the cost of such services if provided by private counsel. Accordingly, upon assigned counsel's claim for 255.5 hours expended in court and 137 hours expended out of court, for a total of $ 13,490, compensation is limited to the maximum permitted by law, plus a reasonable supplement to compensate counsel for extra time spent beyond his control; to grant the compensation request would do violence [***2] to the purpose of the law and would shock the conscience of the court. Although counsel's defense was vigorous and resulted in a complete acquittal of the charges against defendant, which included murder in the second degree, counsel engaged in numerous tactics which resulted in a waste of valuable court time.

 

1515 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Capozzi v. New York State Dep't of Social Services


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Oswego County


137 Misc. 2d 193; 520 N.Y.S.2d 471; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2669



April 22, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Submit judgment, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner grandmother filed an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 against respondent State and County Departments of Social Service to obtain a judgment annulling the departments' determinations that the grandmother was no longer eligible to receive Aid to Dependent Children benefits on behalf of her grandchild.


OVERVIEW: The grandmother filed a petition to annul the departments' decisions denying her eligibility to receive Aid to Dependent Children benefits on behalf of her grandchild. The court dismissed the petition. The court found that the decisions were based on N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 131-c, which was revised to meet requirements pressed on the states by the federal Aid to Dependent Children program. The revised law and regulations required consideration of the grandmother's income when determining the need for eligibility of her grandchild. Under this statute, the court stated that the grandmother's income had to be considered because her daughter, the child's mother, was a minor and resided with the child in the grandmother's household. The court rejected the grandmother's argument that the revised statute violated the federal equal protection clause. The disparate treatment accorded persons in the grandmother's position did not offend the U.S. Constitution because there was a rational basis for the classification. The court found that the New York statute was enacted based on a federal study that a grandparent's income was a legitimate consideration in this type of situation.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the grandmother's petition to annul the departments' determinations that she was ineligible to receive aid on behalf of her grandchild.


HEADNOTES

Social Services -- Aid to Dependent Children

A petition seeking to annul determinations that petitioner was no longer eligible to receive Aid to Dependent Children benefits on behalf of her grandchild is dismissed. As required by Federal law, Social Services Law § 131-c and 18 NYCRR 352.14 (a) (2) and 352.18 have been amended to require consideration of petitioner's income when determining the eligibility of petitioner's grandchild, since petitioner's daughter, the child's mother, is a minor and resides with the child in the same household as petitioner. Petitioner's equal protection challenge to the statute and regulations must fail because it is not irrational to consider the income of a grandparent under such circumstances. Nor is there any violation of NY Constitution, article XVII, § 1.

 

1516 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Goldberg v. Corcoran


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Queens County


136 Misc. 2d 213; 518 N.Y.S.2d 81; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2413



April 16, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss plaintiff physician and fictitious person's complaint, which sought a judgment to declare N.Y. Ins. Law § 5108 unconstitutional, for failure to state a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The physician alleged that his rights to due process and equal protection had been violated by virtue of N.Y. Ins. Law § 5108. Defendant moved to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action. The court granted defendant's motion and held that encompassed within the police power of the state was the power of the state to regulate medical fees. The court determined that as an exercise of the police power, a statute regulating medical fees was valid when it was enacted for the promotion of the health, comfort, safety, and welfare of the people and when the means adopted to secure that end were reasonable. The court found that § 5108 was enacted to contain the cost of no-fault insurance premiums and to end the practice of significantly higher health care charges for auto accident victims than for persons not suffering auto injuries. The court held that there was nothing irrational in the state's saying that doctors had to follow the rule set forth in § 5108. Thus, the physician failed to state a cause of action in his complaint.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the physician's complaint, which sought to declare an insurance statute that regulated medical fees unconstitutional, for failure to state a cause of action and dismissed the physician's complaint.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parties -- Fictitious Plaintiff -- Class Representative

1. In a declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of a statute, the complaint is dismissed insofar as it is asserted by the fictitious plaintiff "John Doe", who purportedly represents a class of individuals, since there must be a real plaintiff in every action, and to maintain a civil action it is necessary that plaintiff be a person in law, an entity which the law of the forum can recognize as capable of possessing and asserting a right of action. The naming of "John Doe" as a plaintiff appeared to be an attempt by the real individual plaintiff to represent a class of which he is not a member, and the purpose of the class action statute ( CPLR art 9) may not be subverted by simply naming a fictitious "John Doe" as a plaintiff, since the court has no jurisdiction to litigate issue for people not before it who are supposedly represented by a fictitious plaintiff.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Regulation of Fees -- Patients Involved in No-Fault Automobile Accidents

2. Insurance Law § 5108, which limits the fees physicians may charge to patients involved in no-fault automobile accidents, was [***2] enacted to contain the cost of no-fault insurance premiums and to end the practice of significantly higher health care charges for auto accident victims than for persons not suffering auto injuries; it cannot be said that there is no real and substantial relation between the limitations on the privilege to practice medicine imposed by section 5108 and the ends sought to be attained by the Legislature. Inasmuch as there is nothing irrational about New York State saying that doctors, whose practice is already regulated pursuant to the State's police powers, must follow the rule set forth in the statute, plaintiff has failed to state a cause of action in this declaratory judgment action seeking to declare the statute unconstitutional, and defendant's motion to dismiss the complaint shall be granted.

 

1517 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Board of Education v. Cohalan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Suffolk County


135 Misc. 2d 358; 515 N.Y.S.2d 691; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2227



April 9, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff school district filed a motion for summary judgment, and defendant lawmakers filed a cross-motion for summary judgment in the school district's action challenging a local law that restricted smoking by the public in a meeting place.


OVERVIEW: The lawmakers enacted a local ordinance that prohibited smoking by the public in a meeting place, which was in a school building. The school district brought an action challenging the ordinance and filed a motion for summary judgment. The lawmakers filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, which was granted by the court. The court noted that the ordinance made no attempt to regulate activities within the context of education. The court found that the ordinance was not related to the maintenance, support, or administration of the educational system as provided by N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 11(1)(c). The court held that Suffolk County, N.Y., Local Law No. 12-84, was consistent with and supplemental to N.Y. Educ. Law § 409 because § 409 applied primarily to the safety and education of pupils and the local ordinance made no attempt to regulate student activity or interfere with the school district's educational function. The court further held that § 409 did not preempt Suffolk County, N.Y., Local Law No. 12-84. The court noted that school buildings were not within the category of institutions addressed by N.Y. Pub. Health Law art 13-E, § 1399-o.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment in favor of the lawmakers.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- No-Smoking Ordinance -- State Preemption

A county ordinance which prohibits smoking by the public in a meeting place is not an unconstitutional usurpation of the State's role in education by virtue of the fact that under the ordinance smoking would be prohibited in public school buildings used as meeting places, since the ordinance makes no attempt to regulate the educational function of the school system nor does it attempt to regulate the structure, maintenance or administration of schools. The ordinance does not offend Education Law § 409, which applies primarily to the safety and education of pupils with respect to the construction of school buildings and is not intended to govern all matters concerning public health in school buildings, nor 8 NYCRR part 155, which addresses smoking in the context of fire prevention. Moreover, the ordinance does not run afoul of Public Health Law § 1399-o, which prohibits smoking in specified areas open for public use, since a school building is not available to the public as a meeting place during regular business hours, and, therefore, should not be considered among the areas the Legislature [***2] sought to exclude from the smoking prohibition.

 

1518 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Crystal H.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


135 Misc. 2d 265; 514 N.Y.S.2d 865; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2210



April 9, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In conjunction with a child protective proceeding, respondent father requested that the court order psychiatric examinations of the subject children's mother, grandparents and any aunts and uncles who were living in or visiting the children's home within three months of the time the children were allegedly abused. Petitioner Commissioner of Social Services claimed that the court was without power to order the requested examinations.


OVERVIEW: The court made a finding that three-year-old twin girls were abused based on proof that one twin was sexually abused by respondent father. The children were in the custody of their mother, who lived with her parents at the time of the abuse. After the fact finding, all counsel agreed that respondent and the children should be evaluated by a court-appointed psychiatrist, but respondent also requested that the court order psychiatric examinations of the children's mother, grandparents and other relatives who were visiting the home within three months of the time the abuse took place. Petitioner Commissioner of Social Services claimed that the court lacked the authority to order the additional evaluations. The court held that under Fam. Ct. Act § 251, member-of-household custodians were only custodians, and thus subject to court ordered evaluations when they were alleged to have harmed the subject child. Since no allegations had been made against the relatives, the court declined to order their evaluations. The court ordered the mother's examination, even absent allegations of harm, because the court's need for the information outweighed any intrusion imposed on the mother.


OUTCOME: The court held in favor of petitioner Commissioner of Social Services and declined to order the psychiatric evaluations of the grandparents or other relatives in response to respondent father's request because no allegations of abuse had been made against them. The court did order the children's mother undergo an examination even absent allegations of harm because the court's need for the information outweighed any imposition on the mother.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parent and Child -- Abused or Neglected Child -- Psychiatric Examinations

The Family Court may order the psychiatric examination of the nonrespondent parent in preparation for the dispositional phase of a child protective proceeding (see, Family Ct Act §§ 251, 1012 [a]), notwithstanding the fact that no allegations of abuse or neglect have been filed against the nonrespondent parent. Psychiatric examinations of the grandparents, aunts, and uncles of the subject children of this proceeding, however, cannot be compelled even though these individuals visit or reside from time to time with the children since there has been no allegation that these individuals have harmed the subject children (see, Family Ct Act § 1012 [g]).

 

1519 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Doherty


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, New York County


136 Misc. 2d 164; 518 N.Y.S.2d 78; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2402



March 17, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant's motion for a hearing with respect to the suppression of identification testimony is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant requested a hearing on his motion to suppress a police officer's identification of defendant, arguing that the identification of him as the person who committed the crime was unduly suggestive.


OVERVIEW: The court denied the defendant's motion for a hearing to suppress the police officer's identification of defendant. Defendant argued that the officer's confirmatory identification in which the officer told the arresting police officers that defendant was the man who committed the crime was unduly suggestive. The court held that the court had the power to summarily deny a motion to suppress if the motion did not argue a proper ground for suppression. Furthermore, the court held that the method of identification by the police officer was permitted. Therefore, the court held that defendant did not argue a proper ground for suppression and denied defendant's motion for a hearing to suppress the identification testimony.


OUTCOME: The court summarily denied the defendant's motion for a hearing on defendant's motion to suppress.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Identification of Defendant -- Confirmation by Undercover Officer

A motion by a defendant indicted for criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree in connection with the sale of heroin to a police officer, for a hearing with respect to suppression of identification testimony by the officer is denied. Although CPL 710.60 (3) now provides that the court may summarily deny a motion to suppress if the motion papers do not allege a proper ground or if the sworn allegations of fact do not as a matter of law support the ground alleged, except where the motion is based upon the ground specified in CPL 710.20 (6), which concerns suppression of identification testimony which would be inadmissible due to an improperly made previous identification of defendant, the officer made his confirmation of defendant's identification at a showup at the scene five minutes after his purchase, and such a confirmation is not an identification within CPL 710.20 (6). The 1986 amendment should not generate hearings where the viewing consisted of an undercover officer's [***2] confirmation that the right person had been arrested.

 

1520 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Airborne Freight Corp. v. New York State Dep't of Taxation & Fin.


RJI NO. 01-86-001367


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


134 Misc. 2d 602; 511 N.Y.S.2d 993; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2839



February 4, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff transportation companies moved for summary judgment to declare that N.Y. Tax Law § 184(1) was unconstitutional as it sought to tax the gross receipts of air express transportation companies and air freight forwarders. The transportation companies sought to permanently enjoin defendants, New York State Department of Taxation and New York State Tax Commissioners (taxing authorities), from assessing, imposing, or collecting the tax.


OVERVIEW: In compliance with the Transportation Gross Receipts Tax, N.Y. Tax Law § 184, one of the transportation companies filed a New York State Franchise Tax Report for 1981 and paid the $ 40,095 tax under protest and filed a claim for a refund. The transportation companies shipped under air waybills and were regulated by the Civil Aeronautics Board which issued operating authorizations for the transportation companies to engage in business as air freight forwarders. The taxing authorities alleged that N.Y. Tax Law § 184 was constitutional and that the Federal Aviation Act, 49 U.S.C.S. § 1513, and the Supremacy Clause of United States Constitution did not prevent the taxing authorities from imposing taxes on New York gross receipts of freight forwarders. The court granted summary judgment to the transportation companies and held that the tax was a gross receipts tax imposed on the sale of air transport services and that 49 U.S.C.S. § 1513 prohibited New York from taxing directly or indirectly the sale of air transportation or the gross receipts derived therefrom. The transportation companies' activities were the sale of air transportation as defined in 49 U.S.C.S. § 1513.


OUTCOME: The court granted the transportation companies' motion for summary judgment and found that the gross receipts tax on air express transportation and air freight forwarders' operations was unconstitutional. The court denied the motion of the taxing authorities for summary judgment.

 

1521 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Moreau v. County of Saratoga


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Saratoga County


134 Misc. 2d 380; 510 N.Y.S.2d 990; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2038



January 16, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a town and its board, sought a declaratory judgment to declare a resolution of defendant county to be null and void, to declare N.Y. Tax Law § 1262(c) unconstitutional to the extent that it provided for the allocation of county sales and use taxes by agreement between the county and its cities, and to permanently enjoin the state comptroller from approving the agreements. Defendant State filed a motion to dismiss the action.


OVERVIEW: The essential complaint of plaintiffs was that the town was not getting an appropriate share of the sales tax revenues raised by the applicable provisions of the § 1262(c) and that they had standing to challenge the law and its application. The State moved to dismiss on the ground that plaintiffs lacked standing and that they failed to join necessary parties. The court dismissed plaintiffs' action. The court found the State's ground of dismissal for failure to join necessary parties to be without merit. However, the court found that, with respect to sales taxes, only the counties and cites had the power to tax not the towns. The court noted that the taxing authorities decided which formula would be used to disperse the funds accumulated and that the town had no say in the process or a property right. Thus, the court ruled that the town could not under the Jeter exception claim to having standing to protect or collect its sales tax funds.


OUTCOME: The court granted the State's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Standing of Town to Challenge Allocation of Sales Tax Revenues

The Town of Moreau lacks standing to challenge a resolution of the Saratoga County Board of Supervisors apportioning sales tax revenues to cities, towns and villages within the county as agreed upon by the county and its cities subject to the approval of the State Comptroller as authorized by statute instead of an allocation based upon population (Tax Law § 1262 [c]) since the general rule is that a political subdivision of the State has no standing to challenge the acts of the Legislature and the town has not demonstrated an exception to the general rule regarding the standing of a local governmental unit to challenge the enforceability of a State statute which directly affects the tax funds of the local government inasmuch as the towns of a county are not empowered to impose sales taxes. Likewise, the town is not being deprived of its home rule power to levy, collect and administer local taxes (NY Const, art IX, § 2 [c] [ii] [8]) as to afford it standing since the town has never been empowered by the State to levy, collect or administer sales taxes. In addition, the Town Supervisor,  [***2] as Town Treasurer, has no standing to demand sales tax funds or to challenge the formula for deciding the amount to be allocated.

 

1522 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Fulvio


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Bronx County


135 Misc. 2d 93; 514 N.Y.S.2d 594; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2183



January 16, 1987 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendant's motion for an order dismissing the charge of General Business Law § 518 pursuant to the Constitutions of the United States and the State of New York is hereby denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved the court for an order dismissing charges against him under N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 518, pursuant to the United States Constitution and the State of New York Constitution in that the statute was void for vagueness, preempted by federal statute, and was an unconstitutional selective enforcement.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that the charge of violating N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 518 should have been dismissed. Defendant was accused of imposing a five cents per gallon charge over the cash price of gasoline purchased at his station. Defendant argued that the statute was void for vagueness, preempted by federal statute, and was an unconstitutional selective enforcement. The court denied defendant's motion and found that the provision at issue gave fair warning as to what conduct was prohibited and was not impermissibly vague, indefinite or uncertain. The court held that the statute need not have deferred to the complementary federal legislation, and found that the federal legislation did not conflict with § 518. Finally, the court found that defendant's bare assertion that he was singled out for enforcement while all other oil dealers were ignored failed to set forth any facts that supported the contention that his prosecution resulted from any conscious discrimination, nor that the prosecution had been initiated by any evil intention.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion for an order dismissing the charge.


HEADNOTES

Consumer Protection -- Consumer Credit -- Credit Card Surcharge

General Business Law § 518, which proscribes the imposition of a credit card surcharge, is not unconstitutionally vague, indefinite or uncertain even though the term "surcharge" is not precisely defined by the statute since the term retains its everyday, commonsense meaning and, therefore, defendant, a gas station operator charged with attempting to impose a five-cent per gallon charge over the cash price when complainant tried to use his credit card to purchase gasoline, had fair warning as to what conduct was prohibited. Defendant's contention that the charge for gasoline in excess of the cash price was a cash discount and not a surcharge should be raised at trial. General Business Law § 518 is not preempted by a similar surcharge prohibition contained in the Federal Truth in Lending Act (15 USC § 1666f [a] [2]) since the State statute is designed to complement the Federal act and the corresponding provision [***2] in the Federal act is neither too pervasive nor dominant nor in conflict with the State statute. Defendant's bare assertion that he was singled out for enforcement while all other oil dealers were ignored is insufficient to demonstrate an unconstitutional selective enforcement.

 

1523 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wittenberg v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


134 Misc. 2d 363; 511 N.Y.S.2d 492; 1987 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2036



January 15, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owners filed an action against defendants, city and city officials, to contest the validity of a city ordinance that imposed a per unit retroactive fee on the owners of rent stabilized multiple dwellings. The property owners filed a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Nearly two years after the state passed a law allowing municipalities to impose fees to recover the administrative costs of rent regulation, the city passed an ordinance imposing such a fee and then amended it to make it retroactive for two years. The property owners filed an action contesting the legality of the ordinance. The court ruled in favor of the property owners and found that the ordinance was unconstitutional and violated the enabling statute. The retroactive fee violated due process because the avowed reason for the fee, which was to increase general revenues to prevent a future anticipated shortfall rather than to defray past costs, was not a proper public purpose, the attempt to recapture funds from the previous two years was inherently unreasonable, and the property owner's had an expectation that they would not be required to pay a fee for those two years. The ordinance violated equal protection because it required property owners who purchased property since the ordinance was enacted to pay the fee even though they had not been owners during that time. Finally, the ordinance violated the enabling statute because the statute only allowed for prospective fees.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment in favor of the property owners in their action against defendants to contest the legality of a city ordinance imposing a retroactive fee on owners of rent controlled property.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Retroactive Annual Fee from Owners of Rent-Stabilized Buildings

A 1986 local law of the City of New York which assesses a $ 10 per unit annual fee on the owners of rent-stabilized multiple dwellings retroactive to April 1, 1984 (Administrative Code of City of New York § YY51-6.0.7 [c]) in an effort to increase the general revenues of the city to prevent a future anticipated shortfall of funds is unconstitutional as violative of due process since retrospective application unfairly frustrates the owners' expectations of prospective application in view of the city's failure to act promptly after enactment of the statute enabling it to impose such a $ 10 fee to defray the costs of administration of rent regulation (Omnibus Housing Act, L 1983, ch 403, § 3, McKinney's Uncons Laws of NY § 8628), the city's initial enactment in December 1985 of only a prospective annual fee and the fact that the enabling statute speaks in prospective terms. Moreover, the attempt to recapture funds more than two years prior to the enactment of the law is inherently unreasonable. The local law is also violative of equal protection since it discriminates [***2] against owners who purchased rent-stabilized multiple dwellings since December 1985 who would then be liable for fees for a period of time when they were not owners of the property. Lastly, the local law is invalid for conflicting with its enabling legislation regarding retrospective application and the utilization of funds for purposes other than to defray the costs of rent stabilization on a year-to-year basis.

 

1524 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Seawall Associates v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


134 Misc. 2d 187; 510 N.Y.S.2d 435; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3085



December 22, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landowners requested that the court invalidate N.Y. City, N.Y., Local Law No. 22 in a case against defendant city regarding local requirements for landowners to provide single room occupancy dwellings.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff landowners challenged the validity of N.Y. City, N.Y., Local Law No. 22 in a case against defendant city. The ordinance provided that plaintiffs were required to meet certain guidelines in providing single room occupancy (SRO) dwellings. The court held that the provisions of the law which imposed the affirmative obligations on plaintiffs to rehabilitate all vacant SRO units and to rent them to bona fide tenants was declared invalid. Defendants were enjoined from enforcing those provisions. The court found that the regulations imposed an unreasonable and arbitrary scheme and frustrated plaintiffs' property rights without due process of law. The court did not accept that the ordinance was invalid because of inconsistency with N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 248 because that provision was not applicable to plaintiffs' buildings which were class B dwellings.


OUTCOME: The court invalidated a local law passed by defendant city which imposed affirmative obligations on plaintiff landowners to rehabilitate single room occupancy dwellings. The court found that the ordinance frustrated plaintiffs' property rights without due process of law.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Preservation of Single Room Occupancy Multiple Dwellings -- Unconstitutional "Taking" Without Due Process of Law

A local law enacted by the City of New York, which, in an effort to preserve and maintain single room occupancy (SRO) multiple dwellings as relatively inexpensive housing for persons of low and moderate incomes, the elderly and individuals suffering from some form of physical or mental disability, imposes a moratorium on the demolition of SRO buildings, imposes affirmative obligations on the owners of buildings containing SRO units to maintain the units in habitable conditions and to renovate any vacant units to make them habitable (Local Laws, 1986, No. 22 of City of New York), is unconstitutional since the provisions of the law impose an onerous and uncompensated burden on the properties regulated so as to deprive or frustrate the owners' property rights without due process of law. The local law is not unconstitutional as inconsistent with and preempted by State law since the entire field of rental accommodations is not preempted by State law and any inconsistent State laws regarding vacancy and demolition are special State laws affecting [***2] only New York City and the City Council may enact special laws in furtherance of its police power which conflict with other special laws. The local law does not violate the "Urstadt Law" (L 1971, ch 372) since that law only prohibits more stringent or restrictive local regulation of the rents that landlords could charge and does not apply to the broader regulatory scheme to preserve SRO units. Although the notice of the public hearing on the local law was not initially published in the City Record as required (Municipal Home Rule § 20 [5]), the subsequent reenactment of the law following a public hearing with the requisite notice renders plaintiff's challenge to the law on this ground moot. Since plaintiffs are not residents of the community which may be affected by the provisions of the local law and have only an economic interest, they lack standing to challenge the law for failure to comply with environmental requirements. Accordingly, since a violation of constitutional due process rights constitutes irreparable injury, defendants are enjoined from enforcing those provisions of the local law which impose the affirmative obligations on plaintiffs to rehabilitate all vacant [***3] SRO units and to rent them to bona fide tenants.

 

1525 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People by Abrams v. Ford Motor Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


133 Misc. 2d 828; 510 N.Y.S.2d 425; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2988



December 19, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner Attorney-General initiated a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 63(12), which alleged that respondent automobile manufacturer engaged in persistent fraudulent conduct in violation of N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 198(a) (Lemon Law). The automobile manufacturer moved to dismiss the attorney general's petition, and the court treated the motion to dismiss as a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The automobile manufacturer charged its customers the first $ 100 for repairs made under its extended powertrain warranty when the vehicle's odometer had between 12,000 and 18,000 miles. The attorney general successfully sought to enjoin the practice as violative of the Lemon Law. The court noted that the legislative purpose behind the Lemon Law was to give consumers greater redress for defects in a new car than were afforded by the manufacturers' express limited warranties. The court rejected the automobile manufacturer's position that the $ 100 payment was a permissible condition precedent to the warranty. The court determined that the Lemon Law did not violate U.S. Const. art. I, § 8 as an unreasonable burden on interstate commerce. The court held that the Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act (Act) did not preempt state laws providing a remedy to a consumer, and that any claim that the Act was a burden on interstate commerce would have to be raised in a federal court. Because the automobile manufacturer had not intentionally engaged in consumer fraud, the court held that the appropriate remedy was a prospective enforcement of the provisions of the Lemon Law as interpreted in its decision.


OUTCOME: The court granted the attorney general's petition which requested a permanent injunction against the automobile manufacturer. The court granted summary judgment to the attorney general and converted a portion of the proceeding to a declaratory judgment action.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor Vehicles -- Warranties -- "Lemon Law"

1. General Business Law § 198-a (Lemon Law) requires that during the first 18,000 miles or two years of operation, whichever occurs first, an automobile manufacturer must repair all defects covered by its express warranty free of charge. Although section 198-a (3) allows the manufacturer to attach conditions precedent to its express warranty obligation, respondent manufacturer's requirement that its customers pay the first $ 100 for warranty repair work performed between 12,000 and 18,000 miles as a condition precedent to enforcement of its obligation under its extended powertrain limited warranty is unenforceable. As such, the petition of the Attorney-General which seeks to permanently enjoin respondent from requiring its customers to pay the $ 100 service charge for obtaining warranty repair work on the automobile's powertrain is granted.

Constitutional Law -- Commerce Clause -- "Lemon Law"

2. General Business Law § 198-a (Lemon Law) does not impose an unreasonable burden upon the flow of interstate commerce in violation of the United States Constitution (art I, § 8). It does not directly regulate or discriminate [***2] against interstate commerce. Nor does it favor New York residents or businesses at the expense of sister States. Although it may be advisable for the Federal Government to establish one uniform law, in its stead, the State may act to protect its consumers.

Statutes -- Federal Preemption -- "Lemon Law"

3. Although the Magnuson-Moss Act (15 USC §§ 2301-2312), which requires a manufacturer to fully disclose the terms of a warranty it is voluntarily giving, does prohibit a State law that would regulate the contents of or performance under a written warranty complying with the disclosure requirements of the Federal act, it does not preempt or prevent the enactment of a State law which provides a remedy to a consumer. Accordingly, since General Business Law § 198-a (Lemon Law) does not require that respondent manufacturer make any disclosure in its warranty booklet but merely provides an additional remedy to State consumers, it is not preempted by the Magnuson-Moss Act.

Consumer Protection -- Deceptive Acts and Practices -- Remedies

4. Since respondent manufacturer has not intentionally engaged in consumer fraud by requiring that its customers pay a $ 100 service [***3] charge for warranty repair work in violation of General Business Law § 198-a (Lemon Law), an award of $ 2,000 in statutory costs to petitioner is not appropriate (see, CPLR 8303 [a] [6]). Likewise, retroactive reimbursement to the consumers that have paid the $ 100 charge is not appropriate. Requiring respondent to locate and repay such consumers would be at a cost ultimately to be borne by future new car purchasers. Prospective enforcement of the provisions of General Business Law § 198-a will best serve the interest of all New York consumers.

 

1526 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Robert Z.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Nassau County


134 Misc. 2d 555; 511 N.Y.S.2d 473; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3125



December 19, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] That portion of the defendant's motion seeking a trial severance is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant brought a motion for an order granting him a separate trial from his codefendants. Defendant was indicted for the crime of assault in the third degree, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 120.00, a class A misdemeanor. Defendant contended that he was entitled to mandatory youthful offender treatment pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.20(1)(b).


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that he should have been granted a single judge, nonpublic trial apart from his "adult" codefendants. The State contended that he was entitled to mandatory youth offender status because he was before a superior court. The court reasoned that courts which had found constitutional the statutory classification of youths who were required to receive the youthful offender benefit did so on the basis of the rationality of a distinction grounded on the gravity of the crime originally charged in an accusatory instrument. The court concluded that the rational basis so found did not exist in this case. The court held that defendant had never been charged with a felony, there was therefore no preliminary investigation basis and no probable cause for a belief that defendant's activities were felonious. The court reasoned that there had never been a serious crime charged. The court concluded that the only distinction between defendant and those accused misdemeanants for whom youthful offender treatment was mandatory was the forum in which the charge was pending. Therefore, the court held that there was no basis, rational or otherwise, for treating defendant differently.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion for a severance.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- Youthful Offenders -- Mandatory Treatment
