New York's youthful offender statutes deny defendant equal protection of law and are thus unconstitutional as applied to him to the extent that defendant, an otherwise eligible youth charged in an indictment with a class A misdemeanor of assault in the third degree who would be entitled to mandatory youthful offender treatment if his case were pending in a local criminal court ( CPL 720.20 [1] [b]), is only eligible for discretionary youthful offender treatment solely because the prosecution is proceeding by way of indictment in a superior court rather than by information ( CPL 720.20 [1] [a]). While the seriousness of the original charge and interests of judicial economy provide rational bases for different classifications for youthful offender treatment, unfettered prosecutorial discretion does not provide a rational basis to treat defendant differently than other youths "similarly situated". Defendant is in that classification of persons for whom youthful offender treatment is mandatory based on the gravity of the charge originally [***2] brought and he is thus entitled to mandatory youthful offender treatment even though his case is pending in a superior court. Accordingly, defendant is granted a severance of his trial from that of his adult codefendants and is entitled to a nonpublic trial ( CPL 720.15 [2]) but cannot be deprived of his right to a jury trial (see, CPL 260.10, 320.10).

 

1527 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Craft


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Rochester


134 Misc. 2d 121; 509 N.Y.S.2d 1005; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3068



December 15, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants brought a motion to dismiss the information charging them with violating N.Y. Penal Law § 245.01, which imposed criminal sanctions on women for exposing their breasts below the top of the areola, in a public place.


OVERVIEW: Defendants participated in a demonstration at a public park, where they removed their shirts and uncovered their chests to protest what they viewed as sexist and repressive laws which permitted men, but not women, to appear with bare chests in public places. Defendants contend that the differential treatment of men's and women's breasts constituted sex discrimination in violation of equal protection of the laws. The court held that although the State could not regulate private conduct, it could enforce standards as to public conduct, where, as here, a fundamental right was not involved. Defendants further contended that the statute was unconstitutional as applied to their conduct because they were engaged in expressive conduct. The court agreed, holding that expressive conduct was entitled to the protective shield of the First Amendment. The court reasoned that defendants' conduct was intended to convey a very particularized message and was overwhelmingly imbued with communicative elements. The court reasoned that defendants conduct did not foreclose the use of the park, was not a repeated occurrence, and did not frustrate the purpose of the penal statute.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Exposure of Person -- Exposure of Female Breasts in Public Place

 Penal Law § 245.01, which imposes criminal sanctions on women for exposing their breasts below the top of the areola in a public place, is constitutional since community standards regard the female breast, and not the male breast, as an intimate part of the human body and the statute's gender distinction is substantially related to the legitimate governmental objective of protecting the public from invasions of its sensibilities. The statute's objective merely reflects current community standards as to what constitutes nudity and is not improperly based on stereotyped notions of the female breasts as objects for sexual pleasure nor does the right to control one's personal appearance encompass a fundamental right to appear nude in public. Defendants, who removed their shirts and uncovered their breasts in a public park within the City of Rochester to protest what they view as sexist and repressive laws which permit men, but not women, to appear with bare chests in public, have no standing to challenge the statute as being void for vagueness since their conduct was clearly proscribed by the statute.  [***2] However, the statute is unconstitutional as applied to defendants' conduct in the circumstances of this case since they were engaged in constitutionally protected expressive conduct in that, not only was the removal of their shirts intended to convey a very particularized message about women's control over their own bodies and about the sexism of gender-specific public exposure laws, but there was also a great likelihood that the message would be understood by those who viewed it. Defendants' conduct did not frustrate the objective of the statute since the demonstration was a one-time occurrence that was carried out in a secluded part of the park so as not to offend or surprise anyone.

 

1528 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


O'Connor v. Maine-Endwell Cent. School Dist.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Broome County


133 Misc. 2d 1126; 509 N.Y.S.2d 472; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3043



December 11, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The denial of defendant's motion to dismiss should not be disturbed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In light of an appellate court decision holding that N.Y. Educ. Law § 3813(2-b), requiring that any action against a school district be commenced within one year after the cause of action arose, be given retrospective effect, the school district sought review of the denial of its motion to dismiss the plaintiff's action.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff argued that rather than the one-year limitations period contained in § 3813(2-b), his action was subject to the six-year limitations period applicable to contract actions. The court agreed and affirmed the denial of the school district's motion, explaining that in the absence of a clear showing of legislative intent, statutory modifications of period of limitations were given prospective application. The court explained that in order to pass constitutional muster, legislation retroactively shortening a period of limitations had to provide a party with a reasonable time to commence an action. Reviewing the date of accrual of plaintiff's cause of action, the court noted that his action would have been immediately barred upon the effective date of the one-year limitations contained in § 3813(2-b) and as such, opined that the application of § 3813(2-b) to plaintiff's action would be unconstitutional. The court explained that statutes of limitation were not open to discretionary change by the courts and that N.Y. C.P.L.R. 201 expressly prohibited the courts from extending the time limited by law for the commencement of an action.


OUTCOME: The court declined to disturb the denial of the school district's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions -- Action against School District -- Retroactive Effect of One-Year Statute of Limitations

 Education Law § 3813 (2-b), effective July 31, 1981, which requires that any action against a school district be commenced within one year from the time the cause of action arose, cannot, consistent with constitutional requirements, be applied retrospectively to bar plaintiff's action since legislation retroactively shortening a period of limitations must provide a party with a reasonable time to commence an action in order to pass constitutional muster and retrospective application of the statute would have immediately barred plaintiff's action upon the statute's effective date (cf. McGuirk v City School Dist., 116 AD2d 363). The court has no authority to construe the statute so as to extend the time for causes of action accruing before the effective date of the statute to one year from the effective date. Accordingly, since it would be unconstitutional to apply the one-year limitations period to plaintiff's claim, the action is still subject to the six-year limitations period applicable [***2] to contract actions generally ( CPLR 213 [2]).

 

1529 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Steele v. State Bd. of Equalization & Assessment


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Fulton County


134 Misc. 2d 820; 513 N.Y.S.2d 71; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3133



October 31, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a tax assessor, sought a declaration against defendant New York State Board of Equalization & Assessment that N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 310(5) and (10) and the regulations enacted thereunder, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, pt. 188 were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The tax assessor was elected to his office by a township. However, he failed to comply with the certification requirements for knowledge and skills required under N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 310 within a year after his election. Approximately two years after his election, the Board held a hearing to determine whether he had complied with the training requirements under N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 310(10) and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, pt. 188. The hearing officer held that the tax assessor had not met the requirements and recommended that the Board declare that his office was vacant. The Board accepted the finding and the recommendation. As such, the tax assessor filed his action to declare that the statutory requirements were unconstitutional. The court held that N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 310(5) and (10) and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, pt. 188 were not unconstitutional because the qualifications for the office of assessor established under N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 310 had a rational basis. The court found that it was imperative that the tax assessor was familiar with the various assessment theories and procedures in order to play his pivotal role in the taxation process.


OUTCOME: The court held in favor of the Board.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Statute Prescribing Qualifications for Office of Assessor

 RPTL 310 (5) and (10) and the regulations enacted thereunder ( 9 NYCRR part 188), pursuant to which the State Board of Equalization and Assessment may, after a hearing, declare vacant the office of an assessor elected after November 1, 1982, who is not certified as having met the prescribed educational and training requirements within one year following the commencement of his term, are constitutional. When the Legislature establishes a public office, it may prescribe qualifications for holding that office as long as the qualifications have a rational basis. Since an assessor plays a pivotal role in the taxation process, it is imperative that he be familiar with the various assessment theories and procedures and, thus, the qualifications for the office of assessor established in RPTL 310 have a rational basis.

 

1530 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bacon


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Second District, Nassau County


133 Misc. 2d 771; 508 N.Y.S.2d 138; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2947



October 23, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with operating a day care center business on premises zoned "B" for "one family residence use" in violation of Building Zone Ordinance of the Town of Hempstead, N.Y., article 7, § 63.


OVERVIEW: Defendant conducted baby-sitting services for five or six young children in her home and was charged with violating a local zoning ordinance. At the close of defendant's case, she filed a motion to dismiss the information on grounds that her use of the premises was a permitted use as a "nursery," that her use was a proper accessory use of the premises for teaching purposes, and that the zoning ordinance was preempted by N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 390. The court dismissed the information and held that defendant could not be convicted of violating the ordinance because a family day care home was a permitted use of residentially zoned property in view of the state's public policy favoring home day care. An ordinance prohibiting use of residentially zoned single-family dwellings for day care had no reasonable or substantial relation to the public health, welfare, and safety of the people of the town and could thwart state interest. Because the ordinance did not expressly prohibit family day care as an accessory use of a residentially zoned "B" premises, the court found family day care a permissible accessory use.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the information that charged defendant with violating the ordinance.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Home Day Care

Defendant, a certified day care provider (Social Services Law § 390 et seq.; 18 NYCRR part 417 et seq.) conducting baby-sitting services for five or six young children in her home, cannot be convicted of illegally operating a day care center business on premises zoned for single-family residence use in violation of the zoning ordinance of the Town of Hempstead since a family day care home is a permissible use of a residentially zoned property in view of the public policy of the State favoring home day care for children to alleviate the acute shortage of quality day care facilities. An ordinance prohibiting use of residentially zoned single-family dwellings for day care bears no reasonable or substantial relation to the public health, welfare and safety of the people of the Town of Hempstead and might totally thwart the State law and policy regarding day care services. In addition, since the ordinance does not expressly prohibit family day care as an accessory use of a single-family dwelling and such use does not alter or conflict with the residential character of the district, family day care is deemed a permissible [***2] accessory use under the ordinance.

 

1531 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People of N.Y. v. Kavanauch


DOCKET NOS. 3005678; 3005679; 3009696; 3009697


DISTRICT COURT OF NEW YORK, FIRST DISTRICT, SUFFOLK COUNTY


1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2741



October 15, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with violating several regulations made pursuant to N.Y. Transp. Law § 14-F regarding the transportation of hazardous materials. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charges based on an alleged deficiency in the charging instruments and on the ground that the statute was unconstitutional or otherwise invalid.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with violating several regulations made pursuant to N.Y. Transp. Law § 14-F regarding the transportation of hazardous materials. The charging documents accused him of several violations of regulations that were adopted in N.Y. Comp. Codes R. tit. 17, § 507.4. Defendant claimed the documents were invalid because they did not contain sufficient facts that established each element of the offenses. Defendant also argued that the statute under which he was charged was unconstitutional. The court rejected defendant's arguments. The court first found that the use of a simplified information to charge defendant under N.Y. Transp. Law § 14-F was sufficient. The court then noted that the legislative enactment, which was presumed to be valid, was constitutional because N.Y. Const. art III, § 16 applied to statutes and not to rules and regulations. The court further pointed out that the statutory framework of the transportation law was clear and left no discretion for arbitrary or discriminatory enforcement. The regulations adopted did not amount to an unconstitutional delegation of authority in violation of N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1 or N.Y. Const. art. IV, § 8.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss.

 

1532 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kavanaugh


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Suffolk County


133 Misc. 2d 689; 507 N.Y.S.2d 952; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2929



October 15, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the defendant's motion to dismiss is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant truck driver filed a motion to dismiss the simplified information filed against him by the state for his violations of N.Y. Transp. Law § 14-F. He argued that the information was legally insufficient and that the statute, which regulated transportation of hazardous materials, violated the state constitution in several respects.


OVERVIEW: The state charged a truck driver with violating N.Y. Transp. Law § 14-f. The truck driver's motion to dismiss argued that the simplified informations were insufficient; it also argued that the statute was preempted by federal law and violated the state constitution. The court, noting that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 100.10(2)(a) permitted simplified informations for traffic infractions and misdemeanors, summarily held that the informations were sufficient. The court cited the Federal Hazardous Materials Transportation Act, 49 U.S.C.S. § 1801 et seq., which by its terms preempted inconsistent state laws. The Act provided the basis for N.Y. Transp. Law § 14-f, which solved the preemption issue by incorporating the federal regulations, and by requiring the state's transportation commissioner to make rules no less protective of public safety than those of the federal act. Incorporation of the federal act by reference did not violate N.Y. Const. art. III, § 16. The authority to make administrative rules did not contravene N.Y. Const. art. III, § I . The rules became effective when they were published, under N.Y. Const. art. IV, § 8 and N.Y. Exec. Law § 102. The motion to dismiss was denied.


OUTCOME: The court held that the simplified information, which had been adopted by state law, was adequate for traffic violations, including those under the state's transportation act. The court also held that the act's rules and regulations were not preempted by federal law, were constitutionally enacted and enforced, and had been published for public access. The court denied the truck driver's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Transportation of Hazardous Materials -- Simplified Traffic Information

1. A simplified traffic information is a sufficient accusatory instrument to charge violations of the Transportation Law involving the transportation of hazardous materials such as improper placarding, operating with improper shipping papers, operating with defective steering and insufficient air pressure ( Transportation Law § 14-f; 17 NYCRR 507.4) since the simplified traffic information can be used to accommodate offenses found in statutes other than the Vehicle and Traffic Law that relate to traffic.

Motor Vehicles -- Transportation of Hazardous Materials -- Adoption of Federal Regulations by Reference into State Regulations

2. Regulations of the Department of Transportation ( 17 NYCRR 507.4) promulgated pursuant to Transportation Law § 14-f, which prohibit the transportation of hazardous materials in violation of the Federal regulations under the Federal Hazardous Materials Transportation Act (49 USC § 1801 et seq.; 49 CFR parts 171-179, 390-397) specifically incorporated by reference into the State regulations,  [***2] are valid since the Commissioner of Transportation is empowered to adopt by reference the Federal regulations and need not develop an entirely new set of rules and regulations nor are the regulations unconstitutionally vague since the statutory framework is clear and positive and leaves no discretion for arbitrary or discriminatory enforcement. The regulations were properly promulgated since the applicable Federal regulations were filed with the Department of State as is required when Federal regulations are adopted by reference in State regulations and there is no further requirement that the Federal regulations also be published.

 

1533 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Friends of Yelverton, Inc. v. 163rd Street Improv. Council, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, Bronx County


135 Misc. 2d 275; 514 N.Y.S.2d 841; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3142



October 10, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner school filed a summary proceeding against respondents, city and building operator, to be restored to possession of the space it formerly utilized in a building owned by the city and operated by a contractor of the Human Resources Agency (HRA) under the federal neighborhood facilities program. The city had changed the locks and filed a plenary trespass action against the school as a result of nonpayment.


OVERVIEW: After the school's occupancy agreement expired, the city and the building operator allowed it to remain in the building as a holdover tenant. However, when the school was late in paying its rent, the city locked the school out of the building. The court held that the city's self-help measure of locking out the school constituted an illegal forcible entry and detainer. There was no justification for it either in fact or law. The city's action deprived the school of its licensee rights unilaterally without resort to legal process. The city could have instituted a holdover proceeding based on the expiration of the occupancy agreement and its asserted claim of illegality. It could have had the building operator use the stipulation in the nonpay summary proceeding and the school's default under it to obtain a warrant of eviction. Thus, in the absence of an extraordinary situation, the city's self-help eviction of the school without judicial sanction of any substantial property interest was illegal.


OUTCOME: The court restored the case to the calendar for a hearing on the school's damages for forcible entry and detainer.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Landlord and Tenant -- Wrongful Eviction -- Licensee

1. The City of New York, as landlord, illegally locked petitioner out of a city-owned building rather than resort to any of several legal processes available to it; the city could have instituted a holdover proceeding based on the expiration of the occupancy agreement and its asserted claim of illegality, or it could have used a stipulation in a prior nonpayment proceeding and petitioner's default thereunder to obtain a warrant of eviction. Petitioner, which had occupied the premises for 2 1/2 years, was at least a licensee which had the right to run a school on the premises and the city's action deprived petitioner of its rights without resort to due process; the fact that petitioner may have no defense to the city's claims does not justify the self-help employed by the city. Moreover, Real Property Law § 231 (1), which permits a landlord to use self-help if a tenant is using the premises for illegal purposes, should not be used in situations not involving Penal Law violations directly related to the premises such as prostitution, gambling or narcotics, or in the absence of urgent need; and the illegalities alleged, i.e.,  [***2] petitioner's failure to secure various bureaucratic imprimaturs, do not justify precipitous action.

Landlord and Tenant -- Wrongful Eviction -- Remedy

2. Although a landlord acted illegally in locking out petitioner from the premises it had occupied, that does not mean that possession of the premises must be returned to petitioner, who was at best a licensee whose alleged written right to use the premises had expired, thereby terminating whatever holdover rights it might have enjoyed, since a court need not order a wrongfully evicted party back to possession where the return would be futile; it makes no sense to restore petitioner to possession only to order its eviction in the near future. Accordingly, inasmuch as the landlord's forcible entry and detainer remain, the matter shall be restored to the calendar for a hearing on petitioner's damages.

 

1534 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Thomas


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


134 Misc. 2d 649; 512 N.Y.S.2d 618; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3128



October 9, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant who was charged with fraud in the sale of securities filed a motion for an order dismissing on the ground that the attorney-general did not have the authority to obtain the indictment. Defendant also sought to dismiss the remaining counts of the indictment because the attorney-general could only pursue the additional crimes in connection with the prosecution of fraud count.


OVERVIEW: Defendant had sold and offered artwork for sale. He argued that the transactions did not involve a security. The court denied his motion to dismiss, holding that defendant's transaction involved an investment contract and, therefore, involved a security within the meaning of the Martin Act, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law art. 23-A. Defendants distributed brochures which characterized prospective purchasers as investors, and they made statements leading the purchasers to expect large profits. The artworks were bought because purchasers believed defendants' representations regarding their profitability. The investments were made into a common enterprise by the purchasers' reliance on defendants' knowledge and expertise to select the artworks and in determining how long to retain them. Defendants solicited and encouraged such reliance through their urgings, recommendations, and promises of rapid appreciation. Thus, the efficiency of defendants' efforts were tied to the fortunes of all the investors. Finally, the buy-back and guaranteed profit programs extended by defendants demonstrated that purchasers' profits were to be derived from the efforts of the promoters or a third person.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss his indictment for fraud in the sale of securities.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Consumer Protection -- Fraudulent Practices in Respect to Securities -- Sale of Artworks

The Attorney-General, who is empowered under the Martin Act to prosecute persons involved in the fraudulent offer and sale of securities (General Business Law § 352-c [6]; § 358), may properly prosecute defendant for engaging in an allegedly fraudulent scheme involving the offer and sale of artworks since the transaction entailed an investment contract security within the meaning of the Martin Act whereby persons were solicited to invest money in a common enterprise and were led to expect profits substantially from the efforts of the promoter or a third party. The common enterprise was created by the purchasers' reliance on the knowledge and expertise of the sellers to select artworks purchased and in determining how long to retain them. Such reliance was solicited and encouraged through promises of rapid appreciation and, thus, the efficiency of defendant's efforts were tied to the fortunes of all the investors. Finally, the buy-back and guaranteed profit programs demonstrate that purchasers' profits were to be derived from the efforts of the promoter or a third person.

 

1535 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ballard


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


133 Misc. 2d 584; 507 N.Y.S.2d 572; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2913



September 15, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For all of the foregoing reasons that count of the indictment charging the three defendants with possession of the weapon recovered from the trunk is hereby dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants made a motion to dismiss an indictment charging defendants with criminal possession of a weapon recovered in the locked trunk of an automobile.


OVERVIEW: An informant informed the police that defendants and others planned to commit an armed robbery at a store on an unspecified date. The informant stated that defendants were casing the store. The police observed defendants walking back and forth near the store and arrested them. A car in defendants' possession was impounded and the police broke open the trunk and recovered a gun. A charge of attempted robbery was dismissed. Defendants made a motion seeking dismissal of a charge of criminal possession of a weapon. The court granted the motion to dismiss, holding that no fact finder could reasonably infer dominion or control over the trunk and its contents by any of the defendants. To prove a criminal possession of a weapon charge there must first be evidence of possession, whether actual or constructive, personal or accessorial.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendants' motion to dismiss the criminal possession of a weapon charge.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Possession of Weapon -- Constructive Possession Through Dominion and Control

Evidence that the recent occupants of a rented car knew that a gun was in the locked trunk and planned to use it in an armed robbery does not provide the necessary connection between defendants and the weapon that is necessary to demonstrate dominion and control over the weapon so as to sustain a charge of criminal possession of a weapon where neither the trunk nor the ignition key was recovered and there is no evidence whatever that any of the three defendants had access to the trunk. In order to sustain a constructive possession charge through dominion and control, there must be clear evidence of the defendant's direct access to and/or control over the contraband at that point when possession is alleged and, in the absence of any evidence that the gun recovered from the locked trunk was imminently available, there is no reasonable basis for concluding that any of the three defendants exercised dominion and control over [***2] the weapon. It is irrelevant that the Grand Jury was not instructed with regard to Penal Law § 265.15 (3), which provides that a gun recovered from an automobile is presumptive evidence of its possession by all persons occupying the vehicle at the time the weapon is found since it is for the fact finder to determine whether the simultaneous presence of the defendant and the gun in the car, together with any other relevant evidence, signifies constructive possession beyond a reasonable doubt.

 

1536 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kramer


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


133 Misc. 2d 239; 507 N.Y.S.2d 122; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2854



September 10, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged his conviction for conspiracy, insurance fraud, grand larceny, offering false instruments for filing, bribing a witness, criminal solicitation, and violating N.Y. Judiciary Law § 482 (prohibiting attorneys from employing lay persons to solicit or procure legal business).


OVERVIEW: Before the jury retired on Saturday night, the court ruled in limine that it would respond to any jury requests for information during its Sunday deliberations. Defendant objected arguing that the court's ruling violated N.Y. Judiciary Law § 5. The court overruled the objection. The court found that by permitting courts to receive verdicts and discharge juries on Sunday, and by authorizing adjournments to Sunday in cases already "committed to a jury", the legislature had implicitly recognized that juries could also be deliberating on Sundays. The court reasoned that where the jury was anxious to continue its deliberations without interruption, and needed information to enable it to do so, the law should be interpreted so as to make this possible. Thus, the court ruled a prompt answer to the jury's inquiry was called for.


OUTCOME: The court ruled that the responding to the jury's requests during its Sunday Deliberation was not proper.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- Judicial Proceedings on Sunday -- Responses to Jury's Requests during Sunday Deliberations

The court's response to the jury's request for a rereading of certain testimony during its Sunday deliberations is not violative of the statutory prohibition against a court being open or transacting "any business on Sunday except to receive a verdict or discharge a jury" (Judiciary Law § 5) since jury requests for information are integral to jury deliberations and must be responded to ( CPL 310.30) and the Legislature has implicitly recognized that juries may also be deliberating on Sundays by permitting courts to receive verdicts and discharge juries on Sunday and by authorizing adjournments to Sunday in cases already "committed to a jury" such as this one. Where the jury is anxious to continue its deliberation without interruption and needs information to enable it to do so, the law should be liberally interpreted so as to make this possible and, thus, a prompt answer to the jury's inquiry was called for.

 

1537 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Forward v. Webster Cent. School Dist.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


133 Misc. 2d 480; 506 N.Y.S.2d 528; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2884



August 27, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Submit order accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayers, individually and as representatives of an alleged class, brought a suit against defendants, a town and others, for a declaratory judgment to obtain a refund of a school tax that they had paid based on unconstitutional legislation. The court granted the town's motion to dismiss the case. The town then sought a declaratory judgment that it did not need to refund the taxes. Both parties filed motions for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: A levy statute employed by the town was found to be unconstitutional in an underlying suit. The town subsequently passed another curative piece of legislation. After the school taxes were levied the curative legislation was also found to be unconstitutional. The town had adopted a dual rate tax structure, which resulted in the taxpayers bearing a higher proportion of the school tax burden than did similarly situated owners of residential properties based on geographic location. This violated the Equal Protection Clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions. The court denied the town's motion to dismiss the suit but found that the taxpayers were not entitled to a refund. Even though the taxes under N.Y. Real. Prop. Tax Law art. 19-A were declared unconstitutional, that conclusion did not require a tax refund to the taxpayers. No refund was necessary where the time frame between the two pieces of legislation was a matter of months, such that little else could be done; the legislature had a good faith belief the statute would be found to be constitutional; the taxing unit relied upon the derived revenues; an undue burden would be imposed on the taxing unit; and no fraud was present.


OUTCOME: The court denied the town's motion to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action, denied the school district's motion for summary judgment for failure of the complaint to state a claim, granted the taxpayers' motion to declare the school tax levy unconstitutional, and granted the school district's motion to declare that a tax refund was not obligatory.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Assessment -- Homestead Dual Tax Rates -- Refunds

Although the dual tax rate classification for homestead and nonhomestead property adopted by defendant Town of Webster and used by defendant Webster Central School District (School District) for the September 1985 school tax levy in reliance on Real Property Tax Law article 19-A is unconstitutional, since the imposition of unequal tax burdens on similar properties solely by reason of geographic location results in invidious discrimination (see, Foss v City of Rochester, 65 NY2d 247; Xerox Corp. v Town of Webster, 131 Misc 2d 817), plaintiffs, residents of the Town of Penfield within the School District, are not entitled to a refund for the school taxes they paid without protest since they did not preserve their rights. Retroactive tax refunds are inappropriate since the School District relied upon the invalidated legislation in preparation of its budget and it cannot be said that defendants were put on notice of the unconstitutionality of article 19-A prior to the mailing of the tax bills on September 4, 1985 (the tax bills having been sent out between the enactment of art [***2] 19-A on Aug. 2, 1985 and the declaration of unconstitutionality affirmed by the Court of Appeals on Nov. 20, 1985 [see, 66 NY2d 872]).

 

1538 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Mead v. Fairbrother


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Broome County


133 Misc. 2d 378; 506 N.Y.S.2d 514; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2868



August 22, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding, petitioners, a seller and a buyer of property, sought in the alternative, to annul the denial by respondent Town Board of the Town of Vestal (New York) of an application for a special permit pursuant to an ordinance and for an order granting the permit, or for remand to the Town Board for continuation of an earlier public hearing with full participation by petitioners.


OVERVIEW: A buyer applied for a required special permit and submitted a statement of landowners in support of the application at the public hearing, as required by Vestal, N.Y., Town of Vestal Zoning Code § 44-XI-10. At that hearing the sufficiency of the number of the signatory landowners was raised. The issue was then shelved for another meeting until the issue of the signatures could be resolved. The number of proper signatures was determined by counting owners of contiguous pieces of land only once. The buyer was told that the issue would not be raised at the next meeting so he did not attend. The issue was discussed and the application was denied. The court held that the counting of the signatures was improper. The court found that the consent provision of § 44-XI-10 required the buyer, as an applicant, to submit to the Town Board approval statements from the owners of 50% of real property within 500 feet of the subject premises to satisfy the condition precedent of the Zoning Code, such percentage to be determined in land area terms, rather than number of owners. The court retained jurisdiction over the other contested issues until the application's validity could be determined.


OUTCOME: The court remanded the action to the Town Board for a determination to be made within 45 days after entry of this order as to whether approval from the owners of 50 percent of the land area within 500 feet of the subject property were received for the public hearing, and whether it had received such approvals as of the other dates. The court retained jurisdiction over the parties in relation to the issues raised.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Landowners' Consents to Special Permit

A provision in a zoning ordinance of the Town of Vestal requiring an applicant for a special permit to submit approval statements from owners of 50% of the real property located within 500 feet of the subject premises is constitutional under prior judicial precedent (see, Matter of Sibarco Stas. v Town Bd., 24 NY2d 900). However, the interpretation of the town affording a single vote to the owner of each parcel which is separately assessed on the tax map and treating contiguous parcels with the same owner as a single unified parcel entitling that owner to a single vote but granting a single owner of noncontiguous parcels within the concerned land area a vote for each noncontiguous parcel is improper since such a one-man, one-vote doctrine disfavors owners of large single parcels as well as contiguous parcels in the counting process while favoring owners of small or noncontiguous parcels and conflicts with the purpose of the consent provision of protecting surrounding properties and is contrary to the "fundamental rule that zoning deals basically with land use and not with the person who owns or occupies [***2] it". Utilizing land area as the basic measure of consent affords approval in terms of a definite and measurable concept and fulfills the apparent purpose of the consent provision.

 

1539 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Culhane v. Sullivan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


133 Misc. 2d 181; 506 N.Y.S.2d 620; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2846



August 20, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner sought a writ of habeas corpus pursuant to a judgment of conviction for felony murder under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25(3). Petitioner was sentenced to a term of 25 years to life. Petitioner's ultimate conviction, after three trials, was affirmed on in a direct appeal.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner and two other prisoners attempted to escape while being transported. One officer and one prisoner died in the attempt. Petitioner contended that his judgment of conviction was illegal and a nullity because the indictment failed to allege a cognizable crime under the law in effect at the time. The court disagreed. The court found that the provisions of the New York Penal Law, which enumerated crimes, had to be construed according to the fair import of their terms to promote justice and effect the objects of the law. Even though the laws prior to petitioner's conviction classified an attempted escape as a class A misdemeanor rather than a felony, such attempt could serve as a predicate "felony" for purposes of applying the felony murder statute for petitioner's crime. Nowhere under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25 (1965), the revised murder statute, did the statute indicate that the predicate for murder had to be a felony. An attempted escape from custody was such an inherently dangerous act, not only to the escapee but to his captors and the public in general, that the crime properly and constitutionally might serve as a predicate for the crime of murder under § 125.25 (3).


OUTCOME: The court entered a judgment for the State and dismissed the petition for a writ of habeas corpus.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Murder -- Attempted Escape as Predicate for "Felony" Murder

Petitioner was lawfully convicted of "felony" murder (Penal Law § 125.25 [3]) in 1975 for his involvement along with two other prisoners in the death of a Deputy Sheriff during an attempted escape in 1968 even though, at the time of petitioner's crime, attempted escape in the second degree was a class A misdemeanor (Penal Law § 110.05), since attempted escape from custody is such an inherently dangerous act not only to the escapee but to his captors and the public in general that such properly and constitutionally may serve as a predicate for the crime of "felony" murder. The inclusion of attempted escape in the second degree as a specifically enumerated predicate to the "felony" murder statute cannot be disregarded as an inadvertent drafting mistake since, historically, it has been the underlying conduct involved in the substantive crime and not its classification as a misdemeanor and/or felony which serves a predicate for operation of the murder statute. If a mistake was made, it was in the Legislature's failure to remember that under the revised Penal Law of 1967 all attempts at felonies were not [***2] necessarily "felonies" as they had been in the past and not in the inclusion of attempted escape as a predicate crime of potential violence justifying a "felony" murder charge. Since petitioner is incarcerated in a correctional facility in Westchester County, the writ of habeas corpus is properly brought in Westchester County ( CPLR 7002 [b]) rather than in Ulster County where petitioner's trial was held.

 

1540 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Richardson on behalf of Willis v. Clark


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Monroe County


132 Misc. 2d 986; 506 N.Y.S.2d 257; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2816



August 4, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner director of social services filed written objections to that portion of an order of the hearing examiner, Monroe County (New York), which awarded respondent putative father counsel fees under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 536.


OVERVIEW: On review, the court determined that since to grant respondent's motion to dismiss based on his blood test exclusion would determine the issue of paternity, the hearing examiner should have transferred the proceeding to a judge for a ruling on that motion. Further, although the law allowed for fathers who successfully filed paternity actions to be paid attorney's fees, there was no provision for alleged fathers who were excluded from paternity to recover fees. As a result, neither the hearing officer nor a judge was authorized to award respondent attorney's fees.


OUTCOME: The court granted respondent's motion to dismiss because respondent was excluded as father and petitioner consented to dismissal of the paternity action. To the extent that the hearing examiner may have also lost jurisdiction over respondent's application for counsel fees, the court denied the application de novo.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Children Born out of Wedlock -- Paternity Proceeding -- Counsel Fees

In a paternity proceeding wherein respondent was excluded as the biological father by blood tests, there is no authority for an award of counsel fees, since Family Court Act § 536 provides that once an order of filiation is made, the court may allow counsel fees to the attorney for the prevailing party. The statute is not unconstitutionally "sex-based" since a male petitioner who is found to be the father may apply for an award of counsel fees against a respondent mother, and whether a counsel fee award should be available to a respondent who defeats an application for an order of filiation is a matter for the Legislature; further, the statute mandates that a party's ability to pay be considered on an application for counsel fees. Finally, the court, sua sponte, vacates the hearing examiner's order dismissing the proceeding, and makes its own order granting respondent's motion to dismiss, since Family Court Act § 439 (a) specifically enjoins hearing examiners from hearing, determining and granting any relief with respect to "issues of contested paternity * * * which shall be referred to a judge"; to [***2] grant respondent's motion to dismiss based on his blood test exclusion would determine the issue of paternity, and the hearing examiner should have transferred the proceeding to a Judge for a ruling on that motion.

 

1541 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Baby Girl L.J.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Nassau County


132 Misc. 2d 972; 505 N.Y.S.2d 813; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2814



July 31, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: This case was before the court for approval of an adoption in which the adoptive child was born to a surrogate mother and for a determination of whether the payment to the surrogate mother violated New York statutes.


OVERVIEW: In this case the parties entered into a surrogate parenting agreement prior to the conception of the child. Pursuant to the agreement, the surrogate mother was to be artificially inseminated, with the donor being the adoptive father, and she would receive a fee for bearing the child. The court approved the adoption, finding that it was in the best interests of the child to be raised by the biological father and his spouse. The court also held that the payment to the surrogate mother could be made, finding that it was for the legislature to determine if such payments should be disallowed. In so doing, the court stated that the surrogate parenting situation was not contemplated by the New York legislature when it enacted N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 374(b), which prohibited payments in connection with an adoption. Finally, the court approved the attorney's fees requested based on the difficulties involved in this type of adoption.


OUTCOME: The court approved the adoption, the payment to the surrogate mother, and the attorney's fees requested.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Adoption -- Surrogate Parenting Agreement -- Validity of Agreement and Payment to Surrogate Mother

In a private placement adoption proceeding wherein the adoptive child was born to a surrogate mother who was artificially inseminated with the adopting father as the donor, petitioners, the natural father and his wife, may adopt the child, pursuant to the surrogate parenting agreement entered into prior to the child's conception. It would be in the best interests of the child to approve the adoption and no other alternative, such as denying the adoption for the purpose of discouraging such procedures, is appropriate here. Although surrogate parenting was not contemplated when the Legislature enacted Social Services Law § 374 (6) prohibiting payments in connection with an adoption, current legislation does not expressly foreclose the use of surrogate mothers or the paying of compensation to them under parenting agreements, and as with any contractual arrangement, the court will determine whether there has been any overreaching, unfair advantage, fraud, undue influence, or excessive payments. It is for the Legislature to determine whether statutory provisions should be enacted [***2] to allow or disallow such payments and the practice of surrogate parenting. Here, payment of $ 10,000 to the surrogate mother, as per the agreement, may be made. Finally, petitioners' attorney is entitled to a fee of $ 3,500, the amount requested in the attorney's affidavit of services.

 

1542 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Babigan v. Wachtler


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


133 Misc. 2d 111; 506 N.Y.S.2d 506; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2976



July 25, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, plaintiff's motion is denied, and the defendants' cross motion and defendant/intervenor's cross motion are granted on the ground that CCA 110 (f) is constitutional as a matter of law.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff applicant, defendant individuals, and intervenor state attorney general sought rulings on their cross motions for summary judgment in the applicant's suit for declaratory judgment declaring N.Y. City Civ. Ct. Act § 110(f) unconstitutional, and injunctive relief enjoining further appointment of Housing Judges pursuant to it.


OVERVIEW: The applicant brought a declaratory judgment action to declare N.Y. City Civ. Ct. Act § 110(f) unconstitutional, and for injunctive relief enjoining further appointment of housing judges pursuant to it. The applicant, defendants, and the state attorney general filed cross motions for summary judgment. The court denied the applicant's motion, and granted defendants' and the state attorney general's motions. The court held that N.Y. City Civ. Ct. Act § 110(f) was constitutional as a matter of law. The court held that housing judges acted as referees, in effect officers of the court, to assist a trial court in the performance of its judicial functions, and the appointment of such officers by a member of the judiciary did not violate the doctrine of the separation of powers.


OUTCOME: The court denied the applicant's motion for summary judgment, and granted defendants' and the state attorney general's motions for summary judgment in the applicant's suit for declaratory and injunctive relief.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- New York City Civil Court -- Appointment of Housing Judges

CCA 110 (f), which provides for the appointment of Housing Judges of the New York City Civil Court by the Administrative Judge rather than by the executive branch as would be the case with full-fledged Civil Court Judges, is not unconstitutional as violative of the doctrine of separation of powers since Housing Judges remain essentially Referees, officers of the court appointed to assist it in the performance of its judicial function, and appointment of such officers by a member of the judiciary has been explicitly endorsed by the courts. The change in terminology in the statute from "hearing officer" to Housing Judge, a "duly constituted judicial officer", was only designed to invest Housing Judges with as much authority and dignity as possible in order to improve the stature and effectiveness of the entire court and was not meant to confer any additional jurisdiction or powers on Housing Judges.

 

1543 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Silvestri


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


132 Misc. 2d 1015; 506 N.Y.S.2d 251; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2823



July 16, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For all of the above reasons, the motion of the People to revoke defendant's bail and remand him is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People made a motion to revoke bail and remand defendant to jail based on allegations that defendant, while out on bail, assaulted two women in two separate incidents.


OVERVIEW: The People's motion to revoke bail and remand defendant to jail was denied. The People's motion was based on allegations that defendant, while out on bail, assaulted two women in two separate incidents. The court denied the motion holding that the People failed to meet N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 530.60. The court held that the requirements of the statutory provision authorizing the court to revoke a bail order if the court had reasonable cause to believe defendant committed one or more specified class A or violent felony offenses was not met, because defendant was not indicted on either of the two alleged incidents nor were complaints filed against him. The court continued and held that since the revocation of bail could only last until there were no felony charges or class A or violent felony charges against defendant, such revocation could not exist at all since no such charges were ever made. Lastly, the court held that its inherent power to revoke bail could not be invoked in the case at bar because there were no allegations of witness tampering or any other reason and the court was obliged to proceed pursuant to the statute.


OUTCOME: The court denied the People's motion to revoke defendant's bail because the People failed to show reasonable cause to believe that defendant committed one or more specified class A or violent felony offenses.


HEADNOTES

Bail -- Revocation

A motion pursuant to CPL 530.60 to revoke defendant's bail based on allegations in the Assistant District Attorney's affirmation that defendant, while out on bail, assaulted two women in two separate incidents is denied. Pursuant to CPL 530.60 (2) (a), no hearsay evidence would be admissible on the required bail revocation hearing; thus, since the People produced no witnesses for the hearing and relied solely on the allegations in said affirmation, the motion must be denied. Since no charges have been brought against defendant of any sort charging him with a felony or any other crime with regard to the incidents alleged by the People, the statutory requirements authorizing the court to revoke bail if the court has reasonable cause to believe the defendant committed one or more specified class A or violent felony offenses have not been met. Further, pursuant to CPL 530.60 (2) (b), revocation of bail could only last until there are no felony charges or class A violent felony charges against defendant and, thus, revocation could not exist at all [***2] since no such charges were ever made.

 

1544 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Brokopp v. Sturz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


133 Misc. 2d 273; 505 N.Y.S.2d 528; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2895



July 15, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner tenants sought an order directing defendant planning commission to accept and approve their application for a determination of loft occupancy, commonly referred to as a "grandfathering" application, after the planning commission rejected the application as untimely. The tenants challenged the application deadlines of the zoning resolutions passed to implement the Loft Law, N.Y. Mult. Dwell Law art. 7-C.


OVERVIEW: The tenants filed a grandfathering application after the Loft Law was passed to provide legalization of lofts as dwellings. Their application was rejected as untimely. They sought an order compelling the planning commission to accept and approve their application. The court determined that the deadlines for filing the application were not properly adopted and directed the planning commission to accept the application as timely filed. The notice published by the planning commission prior to adoption of the resolution did not meet the 10-day publication requirement as the 10th publication was made on the day of the hearing and, by definition, was not published prior to the date of the hearing. Further, the notice itself was insufficient because it contained typographical errors and there were omissions. In addition, under the Loft Law the burden of filing applications designed to legalize loft residence was on the landlord and not the tenants. As such, the tenants were not adequately notified that under the proposed zoning amendments they were required to take affirmative steps to obtain rights that they thought had been guaranteed under the Loft Law.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment to the tenants, declaring the challenged deadlines for the filing of the application to be unenforceable and directing the planning commission to accept the tenants' application as timely filed.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Landlord and Tenant -- Loft Law -- Deadline on Filing "Grandfathering" Applications

An amendment to a New York City zoning resolution which imposed a June 1983 deadline on filing "grandfathering" applications by loft tenants seeking to "legalize" their residential occupancy in areas zoned for manufacturing use was improperly promulgated since the notice of the proposed amendment was not published in the City Record for the requisite 10 days prior to the meeting of the City Planning Commission (NY City Charter § 200 [a] [1]) and, in addition, the notice failed to adequately notify loft tenants that their recently acquired and highly publicized rights under the newly passed Loft Law (Multiple Dwelling Law art 7-C) were about to be abridged by the imposition of a time limit to file "grandfathering" applications and that they were now required to take some affirmative action to obtain rights which they thought had been guaranteed under the Loft Law. Accordingly, the cumulative effect of the defects in notice render the time limits unenforceable, and plaintiffs' "grandfathering" application is deemed timely filed under the broader language of the Loft Law.

 

1545 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Joselyn D. v. Oscar O.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


132 Misc. 2d 964; 505 N.Y.S.2d 791; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2813



July 15, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court was a paternity action between petitioner mother and respondent deceased father.


OVERVIEW: The paternity action was brought after the birth of the child and more than two months after the death of the putative father. The mother and putative father were not married. The court found that N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 518, which seemingly required the paternity petition to abate on the death of the putative father, was violative of equal protection because it did not provide that a paternity petition would abate on the death of the mother. Determining that the legislature would prefer a gender-neutral interpretation of the statute rather than to strike it in its entirety, the court held that consistent with N.Y. Stat. Law § 150(c), § 518 should be read to give it constitutional validity. The court's gender neutral reading of § 518 thus defeated abatement and a finding of paternity was made based on clear and convincing evidence, which included the mother's testimony respecting the inception, duration, and frequency of her exclusive sexual relationship with the putative father, his actions and positive comments made during her pregnancy, and the testimony by the putative father's sister that he told her that he was the father of the mother's unborn child.


OUTCOME: The court ordered that the action for paternity could be brought notwithstanding the death of the putative father prior to the action's commencement.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Children Born out of Wedlock -- Paternity Proceeding -- Abatement of Proceeding upon Death of Putative Father

Family Court Act § 518, which provides that the right to bring a paternity proceeding does not abate if the mother dies, thereby compelling the conclusion under rules of statutory construction that the Legislature intended to preclude the survival of paternity actions after the death of the father, must be read in a gender-neutral way so as to include fathers in order to save the statute from being violative of equal protection since the gender-based classification is not substantially related to achieving the important governmental objective of the statute to accord equal treatment to marital and nonmarital children by expanding the opportunity to obtain orders of filiation. The statute should be read to extend the benefits to the previously disfavored class of fathers rather than being struck down in its entirety since the Legislature, had it foreseen the court's conclusion as to underinclusiveness, would have opted for a gender-neutral statute in view of the unremitting expansion of the rights of nonmarital children. Accordingly, petitioner mother may bring a [***2] paternity proceeding notwithstanding the death of the putative father prior to the child's birth.

 

1546 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Abrams


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


134 Misc. 2d 841; 512 N.Y.S.2d 962; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3134; 86-2 U.S. Tax Cas. (CCH) P9560



July 8, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent United States Treasury moved to dismiss petitioner state attorney's petition, which was filed for the right of escheat to the unclaimed federal income tax returns of the state's residents.


OVERVIEW: Respondent, United States Treasury, sought to have petitioner state attorney general's petition dismissed as a matter of law. Respondent argued that petitioner did not have the right of escheat to the unclaimed federal income tax refunds of the state's residents and invoked the doctrine of sovereign immunity. The court denied respondent's motion to dismiss because it found that the United States was a mere stakeholder and not a contesting party to the case. The court determined that as a nominal party, the United States' immunity from the case without its consent was not in issue. The state, as the ultimate owner of the tax refunds was found to be, in effect, the ultimate heir. The court ordered respondent to answer the petition.


OUTCOME: The court denied respondent United States Treasury's motion to dismiss petitioner state attorney general's petition because respondents' sovereign immunity was not in issue and the court ordered respondent to answer the petition.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- Law of the Case

1. The doctrine of law of the case does not preclude the New York State Supreme Court from determining whether it has subject matter jurisdiction of a proceeding to determine whether the State of New York or the Federal Government is entitled to the unclaimed Federal income tax refunds of New York State residents, despite a prior decision in the matter by the United States District Court, which, upon a motion by the Secretary of the Treasury of the United States to remove the case to Federal court and to dismiss on grounds of sovereign immunity, held that there was no Federal jurisdiction because the Secretary of the Treasury was no more than a stakeholder with no claim of right to the funds in question, and remanded the matter to State court. In deciding that the State court should retain jurisdiction, the Federal Judge necessarily decided that the United States was amenable to suit brought by the State in the State court. Nevertheless, the Federal court decision was not subject to appeal and, thus, whether or not that decision was ill-considered, made on the basis of an incomplete record or was in error, the State court will make its own determination [***2] as to whether it has subject matter jurisdiction with respect to unclaimed Federal tax refunds.

United States -- Immunity from Suit -- Proceeding by State to Determine Entitlement to Unclaimed Federal Tax Refunds of State Residents under Escheat Statute

2. In a proceeding pursuant to Abandoned Property Law § 1217 to determine whether the State of New York or the United States Government is entitled to the unclaimed Federal income tax refunds of New York State residents, a motion by respondent Secretary of the Treasury of the United States to dismiss the petition on the ground of sovereign immunity is denied. Although there is no Federal right of escheat, even as to abandoned property in the hands of the Federal Government, the Federal Government may act pursuant to US Constitution article VI to defeat State escheat statutes, but the Government has not acted affirmatively to prevent the escheat of Federal tax refunds. Further, since entitlement to the refunds has been determined and the funds are held custodially by the United States pending transfer to the beneficial owner, the United States is a mere stakeholder whose immunity from suit without its consent is not an [***3] issue and the State can make the definitive determination as to the devolution of title to the funds; moreover, the State, in asserting the right of escheat, stands in the shoes of the rightful claimants, and is entitled to reclaim the funds as abandoned property.

Abandoned Property -- Escheat to State of Unclaimed Federal Tax Refunds of State Residents -- Effect of State's Failure to File Claim for Refund

3. A proceeding in the State Supreme Court pursuant to Abandoned Property Law § 1217 to determine whether the State of New York or the Federal Government is entitled to the unclaimed Federal income tax refunds of New York State residents will not be dismissed on the ground that the right to the refunds has not been finally determined. A State seeking escheat of abandoned claims for refunds need not itself file a claim for refund with the Internal Revenue Service -- such a claim has already been determined. Further, even if the Government becomes entitled to subsequently arising offsets against the refunds, they can be handled administratively on an individual basis, and would not bar an adjudication of title to the refunds. Moreover, the State has stipulated that [***4] it will reimburse the Government for any moneys paid over by the Government to taxpayers who claim their refunds after the Government has turned over the unclaimed tax refunds to the State.

United States -- Immunity from Suit -- Proceeding by State to Determine Entitlement to Unclaimed Federal Tax Refunds of State Residents Under Escheat Statute -- Interference with Public Administration -- Imposition of Expense on Public Treasury

4. A proceeding in State Supreme Court pursuant to Abandoned Property Law § 1217 to determine whether the State of New York or the United States Government is entitled to the unclaimed Federal income tax refunds of New York State residents will not be dismissed as a matter of law on the motion of respondent Secretary of the Treasury of the United States on the ground that the State court cannot enter an order which would interfere with public administration or expend itself on the public treasury. The practical and pragmatic difficulties which might ensue from requiring the Government to examine its tax records and determine the amount of money due the State pursuant to the escheat statute, including whatever expenditure of funds may be entailed,  [***5] are factual considerations which cannot at the outset stand as a bar to the State's seeking to assert its rights.

 

1547 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wolkoff v. Church of St. Rita


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Richmond County


132 Misc. 2d 464; 505 N.Y.S.2d 327; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2719



July 2, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff buyer, in two separate proceedings, commenced an action seeking an injunction barring the sale of certain property to a party other than itself, specific performance, and other damages against defendant church. Plaintiff also filed a motion for an evidentiary hearing under N.Y. Not-for-Profit-Corp. Law § 511 on the application for leave to sell real property by defendant pursuant to N.Y. Relig. Corp. Law § 12.


OVERVIEW: The church, offering a lot of land for sale, entered into a contract with the buyer, and when the church petitioned for leave to sell the property pursuant to N.Y. Relig. Corp. law § 12 and N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law § 511, the court's independent appraiser determined the fair market value was 80 percent over the contract price. The court held that the contract price was inadequate consideration and issued an order denying the petition to sell. The buyer commenced an action seeking an injunction barring the sale of to a party other than itself, specific performance, and damages and also filed a motion for an evidentiary hearing under § 511. On review, the court held that the contract was specifically made subject to the approval of a supreme court justice pursuant to § 12 and that the stipulated arbitrator had the discretion to approve or deny the agreement. The court held that it had not arbitrarily withheld its approval, that the buyer had a meaningful opportunity to be heard, and that due process was satisfied. The court granted the church's cross-motion to dismiss the complaint under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(7) and denied the buyer's motion for rehearing.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant church's cross-motion to dismiss plaintiff buyer's claim seeking an injunction barring the sale of property, specific performance, and damages, and the court denied plaintiff's motion for an evidentiary hearing.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Religious Corporations and Associations -- Judicial Approval of Sale of Property

Plaintiff, whose contract for the purchase of land owned by defendant church was disapproved after a hearing due to inadequate consideration, was not entitled to notice of the hearing since plaintiff was not a properly interested person under Not-For-Profit Corporation Law § 511 (b) which permits only an interested person to appear at a hearing and "show cause why the application should not be granted". Neither Religious Corporations Law § 12 nor Not-For-Profit Corporation Law § 511, which require judicial approval before a religious corporation can sell or mortgage any of its property, violated plaintiff's due process by denying him the opportunity to participate in the special proceeding affecting his contract rights since the contract was expressly conditioned upon the approval of a Supreme Court Justice who was a stipulated arbitrator. Plaintiff is not entitled to a rehearing to produce evidence that the consideration was adequate at the time the sale was negotiated in September 1984 since the contract price is insufficient as of the contract date in April 1985 based on three appraisals [***2] of the property and a rehearing would not afford the court an opportunity to review evidence which it has not already considered.

 

1548 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Caruso v. Ward


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


133 Misc. 2d 544; 506 N.Y.S.2d 789; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2908; 2 I.E.R. Cas. (BNA) 238



July 1, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff police union filed an action in the Supreme Court of New York, New York County, against defendants, the police commissioner, police department (Department) and the city (referred to collectively as defendants), in which the union sought a determination that an interim Department order which required random drug testing for police officers assigned to a certain bureau was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The Department order at issue required current and future members of the Department's Organized Crime Control Bureau (OCCB) to consent and submit to future random drug testing. Previously, all Department members were subject to testing where there was a "reasonable belief" that the suspect officer was using drugs. The union objected only to the proposed order, which eliminated the "reasonable belief" requirement for OCCB members. The union claimed the proposed order violated OCCB members' constitutional rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments. The court found the intrusive drug tests constituted Fourth Amendment searches, and found the Department failed to demonstrate or to document that drug use presented a discernible problem or danger sufficient to warrant the constitutional intrusion occasioned by standardless drug testing of the approximately 1,200 members of the OCCB. Thus, because the proposed order failed to meet the requirements of reasonableness under the Fourth Amendment, the court found the proposed order unconstitutional. The court provided, however, that defendants could have continued to test officers upon a reasonable suspicion basis.


OUTCOME: The court found that the Department's drug testing order violated the Fourth Amendment guarantee against unreasonable searches because the random and standardless searches of certain union members was not justified.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Searches and Seizures -- Compulsory Random Urine Drug Testing for Police Officers -- Reasonable Suspicion Standard for Drug Testing

An order issued by the New York City Police Department (Department) requiring current and future members of the Department's Organized Crime Control Bureau (OCCB) to consent and submit to periodic random urine drug testing as a condition of continued assignment to the OCCB is unconstitutional since compulsory employee urine testing constitutes a search subject to 4th Amendment constraints and respondents have failed to demonstrate or to document that drug use presents a discernible problem or danger sufficient to warrant the constitutional intrusion occasioned by standardless drug testing of the approximately 1,200 members of the OCCB nor is the requirement that present and future members of OCCB execute consent to such testing a reasonable condition for their assignment or continued assignment to OCCB. The present reasonable belief or suspicion standard for drug testing coupled with greater vigilance, drug education and other less intrusive methods is flexible enough to afford the full measure of constitutional protections without posing a barrier [***2] to the exercise of the Department's legitimate right to seek out drug use by its employees. Accordingly, respondents are enjoined from implementing the order but may continue drug testing as part of the application process for assignment to OCCB.

 

1549 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kaufman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Oswego, Oswego County


132 Misc. 2d 530; 504 N.Y.S.2d 361; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2729



June 26, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant made a motion to dismiss the misdemeanor charge of selling or providing alcohol to a minor in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 260.20.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's motion to dismiss the charge of selling or providing alcohol to a minor in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 260.20 was denied. Defendant asserted that as an individual under 21, he could not be convicted of providing alcohol to another under 21. The court rejected defendant's argument. The court held that § 260.20(4) provided that a person was guilty of unlawfully dealing with a child when he gave or sold or caused to be given or sold any alcoholic beverage to a person less than 21 years old. According to the court, the fact no age limitation was set forth for § 260.20 implied a definite purpose on the part of the legislature to proscribe the commission of a violation of § 260.20(4) by any person over the age of 16, the legal age a juvenile could be held accountable for his conduct.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the misdemeanor charge against him.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Unlawfully Dealing with Child -- Giving Beer to Person under 21

Defendant, age 20, can be convicted of unlawfully dealing with a child for giving a cup of draft beer to another 20 year old (Penal Law § 260.20 [4]) since the absence of any age limitation in the statute implies a definite legislative intent to proscribe the commission of a violation of the statute by any person over the age of 16. The statute is constitutional since there is a valid societal purpose to be served in allowing the conviction of an offender under the age of 21 for violation of a statute designed to protect persons under the age of 21 and it is not unconstitutional to punish minors under a statute designed to protect them since society can legally and constitutionally "protect" minors against themselves by penal legislation. The equities of a given case can be addressed by means of pretrial motions such as an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal or a dismissal in the interest of justice.

 

1550 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Garcia


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


132 Misc. 2d 350; 503 N.Y.S.2d 972; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2694



June 19, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to suppress certain physical evidence as being unlawfully seized. The motion was referred to a judicial hearing officer for an evidentiary hearing and a report. Defendant had been charged with the criminal sale of marihuana in the fourth degree, possession of marihuana in the fifth degree, and possession of a controlled substance in the seventh degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 221.40, 221.10, 220.03, respectively.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested in an undercover buy and bust operation. Defendant contended that it was unconstitutional to refer his pretrial motion to suppress to a judicial hearing officer. He also asserted that there was no probable cause for his arrest. The court held, as a matter of law, that the applicable statutes regarding the position of judicial hearing officer were constitutional. The court affirmed the report of the judicial judge and denied defendant's motion to suppress. The court found, inter alia, that (1) the statute creating the position of judicial hearing officer did not violate any provisions of the New York State Constitution, such that the State legislature could, by statute, provide for references by judges to judicial hearing officers in some cases; (2) the arresting officer could apprehend defendant based upon a radio transmission from an undercover member of the police force where probable cause existed for the arrest; and (3) probable cause was determined from, inter alia, the specific description of the suspect given in the transmission; the officer's experience, training, and expertise; and the circumstances of the time and place.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the findings of the judicial hearing officer and denied defendant's motion to suppress the property seized.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Judges -- Judicial Hearing Officer -- Pretrial Suppression Hearing

1. The statute authorizing retired Judges to serve as judicial hearing officers to hear and determine in a pretrial motion setting even in the absence of consent of all parties (L 1983, ch 840) is constitutional and the reference of a pretrial suppression hearing to such a judicial hearing officer to file a report with the Judge making the assignment setting forth findings of fact and conclusions of law ( CPL 255.20) does not violate a defendant's constitutional rights. Defendant has failed to overcome the strong presumption that the legislation regarding the position of judicial hearing is valid.

Crimes -- Arrest -- Probable Cause -- Radio Description of Drug Seller

2.
