The arresting officer had probable cause to arrest defendant for selling marihuana during a buy and bust operation in a drug-prone area where defendant fit the specific description of a drug seller transmitted via radio by an undercover officer who made the buy five minutes before the arrest. Accordingly, the drugs and prerecorded buy money were lawfully seized from defendant's person during a search incident to a lawful arrest.

 

1551 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Christie


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


133 Misc. 2d 468; 505 N.Y.S.2d 310; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2883



June 18, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Since it does not appear that any person was specifically designated to testify on behalf of the corporation before the Grand Jury, discovery is denied as to such statements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant corporation sought dismissal on equal protection grounds of the charges against it for conspiracy to falsify business records and the falsification of business records for the purpose of concealing commission of the crime of offering false sales tax returns and sought discovery of the statements made to law enforcement officials and the grand jury by unindicted employees of the corporation.


OVERVIEW: The corporation and its owners were charged with conspiracy to falsify business records and falsification of business records, each for the purpose of concealing the offering of false sales tax returns for filing in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §§ §105.05 (1), 175.10, and 175.35, respectively. The corporation filed a motion to dismiss, alleging violations of equal protection under U.S. Const. amend. XIV and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11. The corporation claimed that a state program unconstitutionally allowed tax amnesty for those not under investigation or indictment for tax violations but did not allow it for those under investigation or indictment. The court denied the motion, finding the amnesty program was a permissible exemption from a penal statute for the legitimate purpose of collecting overdue state revenues while at the same time pursuing prosecution of those whose violations had already been detected. The corporation sought discovery of statements made by its unindicted employees to law enforcement officers or the grand jury but the court limited the scope of such discovery to those employees specifically authorized by the corporation to make statements on its behalf.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion to dismiss the indictment against the corporation for violation of its equal protection rights and limited the scope of its request for discovery to those employees of the corporation who were specifically authorized by it to make statements on behalf of the corporation to law enforcement officials or the grand jury.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Tax Amnesty Program -- Exclusion of Tax Liabilities under Criminal Investigation

1. Defendants, charged with engaging in a scheme to avoid sales tax on the retail sale of luxury furs by the false use of out-of-State addresses purported to be the shipping destination of furs actually sold and carried from the defendant corporation's premises, are not denied equal protection of the law by their exclusion from the benefits of the State's tax amnesty program (L 1985, ch 66) under which taxpayers, including corporations, who had incurred tax liabilities prior to January 1, 1985 could avoid all "civil, administrative or criminal action" by paying in full all taxes and interest during the period November 1, 1985 through January 31, 1986 except for those taxpayers like defendants, whose tax liabilities were under criminal investigation as of the effective date of the amnesty program (defendants having paid almost $ 90,000 in sales tax and interest in Dec. 1985 in an attempt to qualify for tax [***2] amnesty) since the statutory classification excluding tax liabilities under criminal investigation bears a rational relation to both the revenue raising and punitive purposes of the tax laws. Since, in respect to revenue raising, the Legislature did all that was necessary to induce the disclosure of previous nonpayments and since that purpose is legitimate and the means were reasonably tailored to suit the purpose, the Legislature was not required to do more and, thus, the statutory classification of those eligible for amnesty is not underinclusive.

Crimes -- Disclosure -- Statements of Nondefendant Employees of Defendant Corporation

2. Defendants, charged with engaging in a scheme to avoid sales tax on the retail sale of luxury furs by the false use of out-of-State addresses purported to be the shipping destination of furs actually sold and carried from the defendant corporation's premises, are not entitled to disclosure of statements made by nondefendant employees of the defendant corporation to law enforcement authorities and to the Grand Jury ( CPL 240.20 [1] [a], [b]) since only those statements made by employees who were expressly authorized by the corporation [***3] to speak on its behalf regarding possible violations of the tax laws are discoverable and defendants have failed to show that any such person was specifically designated to speak on behalf of the corporation. To allow greater discovery would permit corporate defendants to obtain statements and testimony of witnesses otherwise unavailable to other defendants and would present the danger of intimidation and of testimony by current employees of the corporation tailored to preserve their jobs rather than to serve the ends of truthfulness.

 

1552 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Mauro v. Kiley


Index No. 270/86


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


131 Misc. 2d 912; 503 N.Y.S.2d 680; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2427



May 28, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners public transit union filed a writ of prohibition and sought declaratory relief against respondents public transit board to invalidate a collective bargaining settlement that was imposed upon the union after an impasse was reached in negotiations.


OVERVIEW: Members of a public transit union worked almost two years without a contract. A public employment relations board appointed a fact-finding board to aid in resolving the impasse in negotiations, but the public transit board refused to accept the recommendations. The public transit board imposed upon the union a collective bargaining settlement. The union filed a writ of prohibition seeking declaratory relief against the public transit board seeking to have the imposition of the collective bargaining settlement upon the union invalidated. The court denied the union's writ holding that the Fair Employment Act, N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 209(3)(e), permitted public entity boards to take whatever steps it deemed appropriate to resolve a labor dispute, despite contrary fact finder recommendations. The public transit board qualified as a legislative body under N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 209.


OUTCOME: The court denied the public transit union's writ of prohibition.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Civil Service -- Public Employees' Fair Employment Act -- Imposition of Contract by "Legislative Body" upon Impasse

The Board of the Triborough Bridge & Tunnel Authority-Metropolitan Transportation Authority has the right and power to impose a collective bargaining agreement upon petitioner's membership when an impasse is reached in labor negotiations since the Board, and not the State Legislature, is the "legislative body of the government involved" (the respondent authorities) authorized to resolve deadlocked negotiations (Civil Service Law § 209 [3] [e]). Respondents did precisely what the Fair Employment Act allows them to do in rejecting the findings of fact and recomendations of the fact finder and then imposing a new labor contract and petitioner has not presented any evidence of arbitrariness or abuse of discretion beyond bald conclusory assertions that respondents have acted in bad faith and will adopt the same hard-nosed attitude when the present agreement expires. It is up to the State Legislature and not the court to "right the wrong" alleged by petitioner of a "dictated contract".

 

1553 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Fells


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Town of Rhinebeck, Dutchess County


133 Misc. 2d 341; 505 N.Y.S.2d 751; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2864



May 27, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendants' motion to dismiss is granted as to the information before this court alleging a violation on July 25, 1985 and on November 16, 1985 and is denied as to the violation of July 10, 1985.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant landowners sought dismissal of three informations filed by plaintiff town alleging violations of the zoning ordinance on the grounds that they were jurisdictionally defective under N.Y. Town Law § 267 and that the ordinance was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The town's zoning officer notified the landowners that the permanent placement of a caboose on their property would violate the ordinance and issued a citation, which the landowners stated they would appeal. The officer then filed an order to remedy a violation. The landowners filed a permit application but it was denied and they appealed. The denial was upheld on appeal but two further orders to remedy were issued while the appeal was pending. The orders were the bases of the three informations. The court held that the orders issued while appeals were pending were jurisdictionally defective because N.Y. Town Law § 267(4) operated as an automatic stay of any proceedings with respect to the matter on appeal. However, the landowners' statement of an intent to appeal the citation was not effective to activate the automatic stay. The omission of a specific reference to a caboose in the ordinance's definitions of building and structure did not render it unconstitutionally vague and ambiguous because the definitions gave citizens reasonable notice of the need for a permit before moving any building, including certain named wheeled buildings, onto their property.


OUTCOME: The court granted the landowners' dismissal motion with respect to two informations and denied it as to the third.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Building Permit to Move "Caboose" onto Premises

A zoning ordinance of the Town of Rhinebeck which prohibits the movement of any building without a building permit is not unconstitutionally vague as applied to defendants' prosecution for moving a "caboose" onto their premises for use as an office without a permit since the definition of "building" in the ordinance includes wheeled units such as a "dining car", "mobile home", "lunch wagon" or "similar structure" and, thus, provides reasonable notice that a "caboose" would require a permit. Likewise, the fact that the ordinance does not expressly prohibit the erection of a "caboose" on real property does not prevent defendants' prosecution for violating the ordinance since a "caboose" is clearly a type of wheeled unit that falls within the ambit of the concept of a structure and/or building. Defendants are not entitled to a jury trial in the misdemeanor zoning case in view of the six-month limitation [***2] of jail time and a maximum $ 1,000 fine. However, since an automatic stay "of all proceedings" was in effect from July 25, 1985 when defendants filed an appeal of the denial of a permit with the town code enforcement officer and the Zoning Board of Appeals until November 18, 1985 when the Board's decision was filed with the town clerk (Town Law § 267 [4]), defendants cannot be charged with violating the ordinance during that time period but the information alleging a violation on July 10, 1985 is valid.

 

1554 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Gans


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, New York County


134 Misc. 2d 426; 511 N.Y.S.2d 458; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3117



May 19, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent illegitimate child filed a motion for summary judgment in an action brought by petitioner trustee for construction of a will regarding whether or not a child born out of wedlock to the son of the testatrix was entitled to inherit under the class of individuals referred to as "issue" in testatrix's will.


OVERVIEW: The decedent set up a trust for her son in her will. Upon the death of her son, the trust continued for the life of his widow, and the remaining was to be distributed to her son's issue, per stirpes. The son had three issue of his marriage, two of which predeceased the widow, and was the father of respondent, who was born out of wedlock. The trustee brought an action seeking construction of the will and respondent filed a motion for summary judgment, arguing that he was entitled to benefit from the estate because he was included in the term "issue." The court agreed with respondent. The court held that the word "issue" should be construed to refer to legitimate and illegitimate descendants alike in the absence of an express qualification by the testatrix. Therefore, respondent was entitled to recover under the will.


OUTCOME: The court granted respondent's motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Wills -- Construction -- Inclusion of Out-of-Wedlock Children within Bequest to "Issue"

The term "issue" in a 1930 will which left the remainder of trust principal to the "issue" of testatrix' son includes a child born out of wedlock to the son in 1948 and is not limited to only the "lawful issue" of the son since a 1951 decision of the Appellate Division ( Matter of Hoffman, 53 AD2d 55; see also, Matter of Best, 66 NY2d 151), which held that the term "issue" in a will, standing alone, "should be construed to refer to legitimate and illegitimate descendants alike in the absence of an express qualification by the testatrix" so as not to promote discrimination based upon an unconstitutional classification under "expanding concepts" of equal protection, is not limited to wills executed after 1951. In addition, any presumption of exclusion is overcome by testatrix' lack of concern for bloodlines as evidenced by the inclusion of a power of appointment which permitted testatrix' daughter to appoint trust principal to her husband.

 

1555 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Burnside Coal & Oil Co. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


131 Misc. 2d 149; 502 N.Y.S.2d 622; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2482



May 5, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Settle order granting plaintiff's motion for summary judgment on the complaint and dismissing the counterclaims and denying the defendant city's cross motion for summary judgment.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff vendor, an oil company, filed an action against defendant buyer, the City of New York, to require the buyer to pay gross receipt taxes on all petroleum products passed through by the vendor. Both parties filed motions for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The vendor was awarded a contract to provide fuel oil to the buyer. The court found that N.Y. Tax Law § 13-A was applicable and that there was a clear intent to allow payment by the buyer of the gross receipts tax. The contract was, by its own terms, an adjustable price contract with continuous changes in the price to reflect the market price. The market price was necessarily reflected in the inclusion of the new gross receipts tax. The contract had to be interpreted to allow amendation of the price to include the applicable gross receipts tax. The court granted summary judgment in favor of the vendor.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment in favor of the vendor in the vendor's action to require the buyer to pay gross receipts tax under a public contract for fuel oil.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Gross Receipts Tax on Petroleum Products -- Applicability to Municipal Corporations

Pursuant to the gross receipts tax on petroleum products imposed by Tax Law article 13-A (L 1983, ch 400, § 8, eff July 1, 1983), the City of New York was obligated to pay that tax when demanded by a supplier of petroleum products, since an exemption which would have relieved the city from the tax was removed on July 1, 1983, while the contract was awarded to the supplier on July 6, 1983, and the contract clearly intended to allow payment by the city if the tax was applicable; although the city presented evidence that amendment of the gross receipts law to remove the exemption was contemplated prior to the award of the contract, it would have been wholly improper for any bidder to have submitted a bid based on news reports of pending legislation. Moreover, postbid negotiations are permitted with the lowest responsible bidder in the context of price changes, and the instant contract was, by its own [***2] terms, an adjustable price contract with continuous changes in the price to reflect the market price, which would necessarily reflect the inclusion of the new gross receipts tax.

 

1556 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


O'Quinn v. New York State Bd. of Parole


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


132 Misc. 2d 92; 503 N.Y.S.2d 483; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2643



May 5, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner parolee brought an action against respondent New York State Board of Parole, challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Exec. Law §259-i(3)(d)(iii), which denied a parolee who had been convicted of a new felony to a timely final parole revocation hearing.


OVERVIEW: By operation of law, N.Y. Exec. Law § 259-i revoked petitioner's parole on a finding of a subsequent conviction, aborting any right to a final hearing. Petitioner claimed that totally denying a parolee a final hearing at any time before revocation was violative of the federal requirements of due process. The court disagreed, finding that (1) a parolee's right to liberty was rendered within the protection of the 14th Amendment; (2) the purpose of a final hearing was to review any contested relevant facts and consider whether the facts as determined warrant revocation, not to create a new forum in which a parolee could relitigate issues that were previously determined against him; (3) inherent in a new felony conviction was the fact that petitioner's parole violation was sustained; and (4) no risk of prejudice resulted from the elimination of a final parole revocation hearing because there was no purpose to that hearing.


OUTCOME: The court upheld the constitutionality of the statute that revoked petitioner's parole by operation of law.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parole -- Revocation -- Final Revocation Hearing

 Executive Law § 259-i (3) (d) (iii), which denies a parolee who has been convicted of a new felony a timely final parole revocation hearing, is constitutional; the purpose of a final hearing is to afford the opportunity to review any contested relevant facts and consider whether the facts as determined warrant revocation, not to create a new forum in which a parolee may relitigate issues that have previously been determined against him as in the situation presented when the revocation is based on conviction of another crime. Inherent in a new felony conviction is the fact that a parole violation was sustained, and, therefore, no risk of prejudice results from the elimination of a final parole revocation hearing in that there would be no purpose to that hearing.

 

1557 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Smithson v. Ilion Housing Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Herkimer County


134 Misc. 2d 400; 510 N.Y.S.2d 788; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3114



April 29, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Therefore, the petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner employee filed N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding to restrain respondent housing authority commissioners from carrying out a resolution terminating the employee.


OVERVIEW: The employee was discharged from his position as executive director of the housing authority. There was no hearing, and no specific reasons were given for his dismissal. The employee argued that the attempts to remove him were illegal because he was a public officer, and that the reasons behind the action were unconstitutional. One of the grounds that formed the basis for the employee's removal was the fact that the employee had brought a lawsuit against one of the commissioners, charging him with defamation. The court held that if the employee felt aggrieved by a member of the board, his proper remedy was to approach the board and seek its support. If he was not successful, then his position became untenable since he was required to serve at the board's pleasure. The court held that to go outside the board and seek redress in the courts could constitute a form of coercion to intimidate a board member and restrain him from performing his duties. Because the employee had no fundamental constitutional right to, nor did State law authorize, continued employment, he had shown no prohibited interference with his access to the courts.


OUTCOME: The petition was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Master and Servant -- Wrongful Discharge

Petitioner's discharge as executive director of the Ilion Housing Authority for bringing a defamation action against one of the commissioners of the Authority arising from statements made by the commissioner with reference to petitioner's performance of his official duties is not constitutionally impermissible since petitioner has no fundamental constitutional right, nor is there any State law authorizing continued public employment and he has thus shown no prohibited interference with his access to the courts.

 

1558 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Xerox Corp. v. Webster


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


131 Misc. 2d 817; 502 N.Y.S.2d 379; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2411



April 22, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the foregoing reasons, the School District's motion for summary judgment is, therefore, denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant school district filed a motion for summary judgment on its cross claim for indemnification against defendant town to recover from the town an amount of tax revenue it lost as a result of a judgment granted to plaintiff company.


OVERVIEW: The town adopted a dual tax rate structure and the company commenced an action to challenge the constitutionality of the local law. The court granted the company's motion for partial summary judgment and ruled that the use of dual tax rates was unconstitutional as applied, and enjoined the town and the school district from attempting to collect school taxes in excess of the amount that would be payable if a uniform rate of taxation were applied. The school district filed a motion for summary judgment on its cross claims against the town for contribution and indemnification to recover the lost revenues. The court denied the school district's motion. The court held that civil liability could not arise from the enactment of legislation, even where such legislation was subsequently held to be unconstitutional. The court refused to apply the finding of unconstitutionality retroactively, to impose liability for the town's reliance on a then presumptively valid state law when it adopted the tax rates, or to charge the town with advance notice of constitutional infirmity.


OUTCOME: The court denied the school district's motion for summary judgment against the town.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Assessment -- Homestead Dual Tax Rates -- Indemnification for Loss of School Tax Revenues

The Town of Webster (Town) is not obligated to indemnify the Webster Central School District (School District) under the theory of implied indemnification for a loss in school tax revenue resulting from the Town's adoption of homestead dual tax rates and the certification of such rates to the School District (Real Property Tax Law arts 19, 19-A) where the use of dual tax rates by the Town was held unconstitutional as applied to plaintiff Xerox Corporation since the mere enactment of legislation is a governmental function which cannot serve as a basis for imposing civil liability, even where such legislation is subsequently held to be unconstitutional. Since the acts of the Town upon which the School District's indemnification claim is based occurred before there was notice of constitutional infirmity (see, Foss v City of Rochester, 65 NY2d 247), the finding of unconstitutionality cannot be applied retroactively to impose liability for the Town's reliance on a then presumptively [***2] valid State law.

 

1559 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hawkins v. Coughlin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Queens County


132 Misc. 2d 45; 503 N.Y.S.2d 476; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2634



April 22, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petition is denied and the proceeding is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding, petitioner sought to annual a determination of respondent New York Department of Correctional Services denying his application for a sentence credit pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 70.30(3) and sought an order directing the granting of such a credit.


OVERVIEW: After serving over three years for robbery and while on probation, petitioner was arrested for and pleaded guilty to the crime of sodomy in the first degree. He was sentenced as a second felony offender. As a result of a new case, it was determined that petitioner's robbery conviction had been unconstitutionally obtained. The indictment was dismissed and the sentence vacated. He was then resentenced on the sodomy conviction as a first felony offender. Petitioner requested that the time for which he was incarcerated as a result of the dismissed robbery charge be credited against the prison term he was serving on the sodomy conviction. Upon review, the court determined that § 70.30(3) did not apply. Petitioner had been convicted, sentenced, and served time on the first charge prior to his arrest on the second charge. There was no sentence left to be imposed on the first charge on which he would have been entitled to a credit but for the dismissal of the charge. The dismissal contemplated by § 70.30(3) pertained to the dismissal of the matter prior to the imposition of any sentence as contrasted with a dismissal after appeal.


OUTCOME: The court denied the petition and dismissed the proceeding.


HEADNOTES

Prisons and Prisoners -- Jail Time Credit

In 1975, petitioner was convicted of robbery and he was paroled in 1978 after serving 3 1/2 years. While on parole from the robbery conviction, petitioner was convicted of sodomy and sentenced in 1981 as a second felony offender. In 1985, the robbery conviction was held to have been unconstitutionally obtained by a Federal court and the indictment was dismissed. Petitioner's proceeding to annul a determination of the State Department of Correctional Services denying his application pursuant to Penal Law § 70.30 (3) for a sentence credit for time served on the robbery conviction against his sentence for the sodomy conviction should be dismissed, since that statute contemplates a situation in which a party has been in custody due to a charge but has not yet been convicted or sentenced on that charge when a second charge is lodged against him. Here, petitioner had been convicted, sentenced and served time on the first charge prior to his arrest on the second charge, and there was no sentence left to be imposed on the first charge on which he would have been [***2] entitled to a credit but for the dismissal of the charge.

 

1560 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Two Associates v. Brown


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


131 Misc. 2d 986; 502 N.Y.S.2d 604; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2605



April 21, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Settle order providing for tender of vacancy lease with appropriate rent increase.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landlord sought to evict defendant surviving "gay life partner" of decedent on the basis that decedent was the only named tenant on the lease. Defendant claimed that he was entitled to a renewal lease or a vacancy lease based on recent court interpretation of the Rent Stabilization Law, N.Y., Admin. Code. § YY51-1.0 et seq. Both parties moved for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant surviving "gay life partner" argued he was entitled to a renewal lease or a vacancy lease based on recent interpretation of the Rent Stabilization Law, N.Y., Admin. Code. § YY51-1.0 et seq. Because the decedent was the only named tenant on the lease, plaintiff landlord sought to evict defendant. The court granted summary judgment to plaintiff. Defendant later moved to renew and reargued the decision on the basis of a subsequent Emergency Operational Bulletin issued by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which stated that a host of relatives living in the house were deemed to be family members and gave vacancy lease rights to those relatives. The court granted defendant's motion, holding that a gay life partner had the same right as a family member to a vacancy lease under § YY51-1.0 et seq. and that defendant was entitled to remain in the apartment. The court held that there was no rational reason for separate classification of defendant. Exclusion of defendant, who had provided care and love to decedent through illness and death, as a family member, would be an arbitrary way to define family. The court denied summary judgment to plaintiff.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment for defendant surviving "gay life partner" and held that he was entitled to a vacancy lease with appropriate rent increase although decedent was the only tenant named on the lease. The court held that defendant had the same right as a family member to a vacancy lease under the Rent Stabilization Law and was therefore entitled to remain in the apartment. Plaintiff landlord's summary judgment motion was denied.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Vacancy Lease for Surviving "Gay Life Partner" of Rent-Stabilized Tenant

Defendant, the surviving "gay life partner" of the named tenant of a rent-stabilized apartment, who lived with the named tenant for seven years and cared for him during his final illness, although not entitled to be treated as a surviving spouse for purposes of being entitled to a lease renewal as an "immediate" family member, is nonetheless deemed to be a family member entitled to a vacancy lease pursuant to an Emergency Bulletin issued by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal in response to the decision in Sullivan v Brevard Assoc. (66 NY2d 489) requiring a landlord to offer a "non-immediate" family member who has continuously resided in the dwelling of a primary resident the right to a vacancy lease. Interpreting the Bulletin so as not to include defendant as a family member would tender it unconstitutional in that there is no reason to exclude persons in defendant's situation from being classified as a family member, when, in fact, the relationship was [***2] much closer than that of most family members, and it would be inconsistent with the purpose of the Bulletin to prevent "wholesale [evictions] * * * regardless of * * * circumstances" to exclude a person in defendant's position.

 

1561 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Harley Rendezvous, Inc. v. Duanesburg Zoning Bd. of Appeals


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Schenectady County


131 Misc. 2d 1060; 502 N.Y.S.2d 599; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2617



April 18, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner sponsor filed an action against respondent zoning board in the Supreme Court for Schenectady County (New York), after the zoning board requested that the sponsor file a draft environmental impact report pertaining to its motorcycle fair and exposition. The sponsor sought a ruling from the court that it did not have to prepare such a report.


OVERVIEW: The sponsor claimed the requirement was imposed to hinder the sponsor's ability to obtain a permit. The court pointed out that 6 N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 617.2 gave the zoning board the authority to act as the lead agency. The court also noted that the Town Environmental Quality Ordinance was not overbroad because it was specifically qualified to remain consistent with 6 N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 617. The sponsor also contended that its fair was a Type II list, which did not require an environmental review at all because it was a minor temporary use of the land having negligible or no permanent effect on the environment. The court rejected this argument and pointed out that a temporary use was not necessarily minor. The court also agreed that the zoning board identified the relevant areas of concern and took a "hard look" at them and made a "reasoned elaboration" of the basis for its determination. The court also found no support in the record that the zoning board had acted in bad faith or was guilty of a conflict of interest.


OUTCOME: The court granted the zoning board's motion to dismiss the sponsor's petition to prohibit the zoning board from requiring the sponsor to prepare and submit an environmental impact statement.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Motorcycle Rally

The Town of Duanesburg Zoning Board of Appeals properly designated itself as the lead agency to undertake environmental review of petitioner's project even though the town environmental quality review ordinance provides that responsibility "for environmental review * * * shall be designated to the appropriate * * * boards by resolution of the Town Board" since town ordinance is contrary to the State Environmental Quality Review Act and the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder which authorize the lead agency designation without action by the Town Board (6 NYCRR 617.2 [r]). Petitioner's plan to hold a fair and exposition for motorcycle enthusiasts is not exempt from environmental review as a minor temporary use of land "having negligible or no permanent effect on the environment" (6 NYCRR 617.13 [d] [19]) since a three-day event which concentrates as many as 10,000 participants onto a 115-acre site within a town of only 5,000 cannot be classified as minor. Accordingly, the Zoning Board properly determined that the proposed action may have a significant effect on the environment requiring [***2] a draft environmental impact statement based upon a "hard look" at the evidence before it concerning noise, dust, ground water contamination, parking, traffic congestion, access of emergency vehicles to the site and adverse impact on the character of the community.

 

1562 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Arnot-Ogden Memorial Hospital v. Axelrod


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Chemung County


131 Misc. 2d 779; 502 N.Y.S.2d 372; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2575



April 17, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff nonprofit hospital brought an action against defendant, the Commissioner of Health of the State of New York, challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2807-a(9), which provided for the creation of a statewide bad debt and charity care pool funded by an assessment upon the actual Medicare revenues realized by hospitals in New York.


OVERVIEW: Under § 2807-a(9), assessed monies were distributed to fund certain hospitals' losses for bad debt and charity care. The court held that § 2807-a(9) conflicted with Medicare legislation in two ways. First, Medicare payments were already adjusted for certain disproportionate share hospitals, in effect making provision for their bad debt and charity care problems. Thus the state legislation frustrated the clear intent of Congress to deal with the problem by its own scheme of allocation of Medicare revenues. Secondly, Medicare legislation, specifically 42 U.S.C.S. § 1395x(v)(1)(A) and 42 C.F.R. § 405.420(d), explicitly provided that there would be no cross subsidization in determining reasonable cost. This goal was frustrated by N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2807-a(9), which redirected Medicare revenues to service bad debt and charity care revenue shortfall created by non-Medicare patients. Thus, the subject legislation was constitutionally infirm. The court awarded attorney's fees pursuant to 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983, because there was a presumption that the prevailing party should ordinarily recover such fee and there were no special circumstances which militated against such an award.


OUTCOME: The court found that the subject legislation, which provided for the creation of a bad debt and charity care pool fund, was unconstitutional. The court also awarded attorney's fees to the nonprofit hospital.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Health -- Medicare Reimbursement Rates -- Reallocation of Medicare Revenues for Bad Debt and Charity Care Purposes

Public Health Law § 2807-a (9), which provides for the creation of a Statewide bad debt and charity care pool funded by an assessment upon the actual Medicare revenues which are realized by the hospitals in the State, is constitutionally infirm since the State plan is preempted by the comprehensive Federal scheme of allocation of Medicare revenues which deals with bad debt and charity care problems by providing for exceptions and adjustments to the reimbursement rates "to take into account the special needs * * * of public and other hospitals that serve a significantly disproportionate number of patients who have low income or are entitled to benefits under part A of this title" (42 USC § 1395ww [d] [5] [C] [i]). In addition, even if the Medicare legislation does not preempt the State's power to reallocate Medicare revenues for bad debt and charity care purposes, the State plan totally frustrates the Federal goal that there be no cross subsidization in determining reasonable cost (42 USC § 1395x [v] [1] [A]; 42 CFR 405.420 [d]) by redirecting [***2] a percentage of Medicare revenues to service the bad debt and charity care revenue shortfall created, to a large extent, by non-Medicare patients.

 

1563 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Coe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, New York County


131 Misc. 2d 807; 501 N.Y.S.2d 997; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2578



April 14, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss is denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: At the conclusion of trial, defendant, a registered nurse, made a motion for a dismissal of the two-count indictment by which she was charged with willful violation of health laws, in violation of N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 12b, for allegedly falsifying business records and participating in an act of physical abuse against a patient in the geriatric center where she worked.


OVERVIEW: A search for missing money led defendant to force a patient to submit to a search, with a security officer banging a chair down in front of the patient and restraining him. Five minutes after the security officer and defendant left, the patient was found collapsed onto a chair and gasping for breath. Noting this, and the resuscitative efforts, defendant wholly failed to mention in the medical records the preceding incident. In her motion to dismiss the indictment, defendant argued that such incidents were commonplace and inevitable, and further that such searches frequently occurred. Nevertheless, the court denied defendant's motion to dismiss and held that the state had proven facts sufficient to show that defendant knowingly violated, inter alia, the Patients' Bill of Rights, N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2803-d(7), by searching an 86-year old man, over his objections, and omitting the search from the records. Moreover, the court held that wilful violations included those consciously and deliberately done and did not require the element of malice. Finally, the court reasoned that even if such searches were commonplace, that fact would not validate the otherwise illegal procedure.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment against her in its entirety.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Violation of Health Laws

1. The evidence was sufficient to find that defendant, a registered nurse at a geriatric center, willfully violated health laws (Public Health Law § 12-b) in that she violated Public Health Law § 2803-d and regulations enacted pursuant thereto and falsified business records in the first degree (Penal Law § 715.10), where defendant attempted to search an 86-year-old resident of the center over his stated objections in an attempt to locate two $ 5 bills that were allegedly missing; Public Health Law § 2803-d (7) describes acts of physical abuse, neglect or mistreatment of such residents or patients, and 10 NYCRR 81.1 defines "abuse" as "inappropriate physical contact with a patient or resident of a residential health care facility", and "mistreatment" is defined as "inappropriate use of physical * * * restraints on * * * a patient or resident of a residential health care facility". Defendant's failure to state any of the facts relating to the search of the resident in his records constitutes falsification of business records; although the statute, which requires an expressed intent to [***2] defraud, does not set forth the target of such attempt, intent to defraud anyone is sufficient.

Health -- Violation of Health Laws -- Constitutionality of Statute Defining Offense

2. Public Health Law § 12-b, which provides that any willful Public Health Law violation is a crime, is not unconstitutionally vague. That the statute incorporates or makes reference to other legislative enactments or regulations promulgated by State agencies is neither impermissible nor exceptional, and the Legislature has not left to any other body the determination of which violations shall be criminal and which shall not.

 

1564 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Slavik


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Broome County


131 Misc. 2d 795; 501 N.Y.S.2d 992; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2577



April 14, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Following defendant's conviction for criminal possession of stolen property in the first degree, plaintiff, the People of the State of New York (people), filed an information alleging a prior felony conviction. The court issued an opinion regarding defendant's claim that the prior conviction was obtained in violation of his constitutional rights.


OVERVIEW: With respect to the prior conviction, defendant claimed that his attorney had a conflict of interest and, therefore, that the conviction was obtained in violation of his right under U.S. Const. VI and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6 to the effective assistance of counsel. The people contended that defendant could obtain relief under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.21 only upon a finding that his federal constitutional rights were violated. The people also claimed that federal law was controlling and that defendant bore the burden thereunder of demonstrating that his attorney had an actual conflict of interest. Defendant claimed that a violation of his rights under the state constitution was sufficient to warrant relief under § 400.21. In the alternative, defendant claimed that if federal law was controlling, the prosecution bore the burden of showing that he was not prejudiced. The court held that defendant could obtain relief under § 400.21 upon a finding that his rights under either the state or the federal constitution had been violated. Further, the court found that defendant bore the burden of showing that a conflict of interest, or at least the distinct possibility thereof, existed.


OUTCOME: The court held that if a hearing was required to resolve defendant's claim regarding his prior conviction, defendant would have the burden of proof in showing that he was denied the effective assistance of counsel. The court further determined that if defendant was successful, he was entitled to relief.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Proof of Prior Convictions -- Effective Assistance of Counsel

A defendant who has been convicted of a felony and who asserts that a prior felony conviction was obtained in deprivation of his right to effective assistance of counsel by virtue of counsel's joint representation of defendant and his codefendant son, has, once the People have demonstrated the existence of the prior conviction, the burden of proof in demonstrating that he was denied the effective assistance of counsel in the earlier criminal matter, and if he successfully shows that the predicate felony conviction was obtained in violation of his rights under either the State or Federal Constitution, then he shall be entitled to relief; the People's position, that defendant's relief from second felony offender status must be based on a violation of his US Constitution 6th Amendment rights, would allow such postverdict issues to be decided under the State Constitution if brought under CPL 440.10 but not if raised under CPL 400.21, a result which would be both illogical and unjust.

 

1565 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kleeman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


131 Misc. 2d 762; 501 N.Y.S.2d 576; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2572



April 9, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Two defendants and a co-defendant were indicted for the crimes of assault in the second degree and assault in the third degree. In addition co-defendant was separately indicted for the crime of reckless endangerment in the second degree. Defendants and co-defendant filed a motion to suppress oral, written, and audio statements.


OVERVIEW: Defendants and co-defendant, three off-duty police officers, arrested a civilian for assault following a physical confrontation. Statements were made by defendants and co-defendant that no shots were fired, even though witnesses reported hearing gunshots. It was not until co-defendant submitted his weapons fire report that the police department was told that co-defendant had fired a gun. The court granted in part the motion to suppress certain statements. The court found, inter alia, that (1) oral statements made on the way to a hospital prior to the weapons report were not suppressible because all the parties were free to leave and could not have reasonably believed themselves in custody or the target of an investigation, such that Miranda warnings were required; (2) the written police forms prepared at the precinct and submitted prior to the administration of constitutional warnings were not suppressible because they were part of standard police procedure; and (3) the audiotaped statements defendants made following the constitutional and statutory warnings were suppressed because the statements were involuntary where they were procured pursuant to a grant of immunity.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to suppress with regard to the audiotaped statements made by defendants but was denied as to the written statements and the oral statements made on the way to the hospital.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Confession -- Statements Obtained from Police Officers under Threat of Departmental Dismissal

Oral statements made by defendants, three police officers involved in an off-duty physical confrontation with a civilian, to police officers arriving on the scene in response to a report that shots had been fired, should not be suppressed since the initial questions put to defendants were legitimate, on-the-scene noncustodial investigative questioning of the arresting officers for which Miranda warnings were not required. Likewise, written statements contained in official police forms submitted by defendants prior to the administration of constitutional warnings before defendants were considered targets of a "criminal" investigation were part of an internal police investigation for which Miranda warnings were not required, but written statements contained in firearm discharge/assault reports submitted many days after defendants had become the targets of an ongoing criminal investigation must be suppressed for all purposes as involuntary. Audiotaped statements of defendants made under threat of departmental dismissal following the administration of constitutional [***2] warnings may not be used by the People for impeachment purposes should defendants testify at trial since defendants' decision to make audiotaped statements under threat of departmental charges and their possible dismissal from the police force cannot be construed as anything but involuntary and such coerced statements fall outside the ambit of Harris v New York (401 U.S. 222) which otherwise permits the use of suppressed statements on cross-examination to impeach a defendant's credibility.

 

1566 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Oshry


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Town of Clarkstown, Rockland County


131 Misc. 2d 888; 502 N.Y.S.2d 590; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2591



April 3, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] This court cannot say, as a matter of law, that this picture does not appeal to prurient interest and, accordingly, denies the motion with respect to this exhibit.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state sought dismissal of an action charging defendant with public display of offensive sexual material under N.Y. Penal Law § 245.11 on the grounds that the offensive materials did not fall within the proscription of the statute as a matter of law.


OVERVIEW: Charges were pending against defendant for a public display of offensive sexual material under N.Y. Penal Law § 245.11. The state sought to dismiss the charges, but its motion was opposed by an organization for decency. That group contended that pictures subject to public display were sexually explicit and violative of the statute prohibiting the unrestricted public display of sexually offensive material as defined in N.Y. Penal Law § 245.10. Defendant contended the information was defective. The court did not agree with defendant, as every defect in an accusatory instrument was not jurisdictional. Insufficiency in factual allegations was not deemed a jurisdictional defect. While the state claimed that the disputed material did not, as a matter of law, predominately appeal to prurient interest in sex, the court disagreed. As the court concluded that it could not say, as a matter of law, that the exhibit in issue did not appeal to prurient interests, it denied the motion to dismiss the charges.


OUTCOME: The court denied the state's motion to dismiss because it could not find, as a matter of law, that the disputed exhibit did not appeal to the prurient interest.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Public Display of Offensive Sexual Material

The display in a suburban mall "toy store" of glossy technicolor cards featuring close-up nude shots of rear views of females, fetchingly posed with messages inside some of the cards, does not, as a matter of law, constitute the unlawful display of sexually offensive material in a place accessible to members of the public (Penal Law § 245.11), the purpose of the statute being to protect minors and other members of the public against viewing pornography which might be thrust upon them indiscriminately in public places, since the determination of the Court of Appeals that the display of a life-size photograph of a nude female in a prone position with her buttocks exposed and clearly visible outside of a movie theatre in the center of Broadway does not fall within the proscription of the statute as a matter of law (see, People v Lou Bern Broadway, 32 NY2d 816) compels a like ruling that the display of cards merely depicting rear "nudity" falls outside the [***2] proscription of the statute. While the statute may be viewed as a public display restriction on sexually explicit nonobscene materials that need not be analyzed within the framework of conventional obscenity criteria, the court cannot rewrite the statute to incorporate local community standards or ignore the sweeping authoritative language of the Court of Appeals and a more tightly drawn statute incorporating defined "harmful to minors" criteria with enumerated "alternative adult access" would be desirable. However, a card which depicts a man fondling the bare buttocks of a female is erotic, and since it cannot be said as a matter of law that this card does not appeal to prurient interest, the charge is not dismissed as to this card.

 

1567 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Russo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Suffolk County


131 Misc. 2d 677; 501 N.Y.S.2d 276; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2532



March 28, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendants' joint motion is denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants jointly moved to dismiss the indictment against them on the grounds that the indictment failed to allege the commission of any crime and that the application of N.Y. Penal Law § 165.07 to the acts alleged in the indictment violated defendants' right to due process.


OVERVIEW: Defendants had been indicted for the unlawful use of secret scientific material, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 165.70. Defendants moved to dismiss the indictment, contending that the indictment did not allege the commission of any crime and that application N.Y. Penal Law § 165.07 to the acts alleged was a violation of defendants' due process rights. The court rejected defendants' argument that the indictment failed to state a crime, noting that § 165.07 did criminalize unlawful use of criminal software. The court found that a "computer program" was included within the definition of secret scientific material under N.Y. Penal Law § 155.00, which consequently made the electronic reproduction of the software a prohibited offense under N.Y. Penal Law § 165.07. The court denied the motions, finding that the purpose of § 165.07 was clear and that it gave unequivocal warning to defendants of the offenses prohibited and what was required of them.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' joint motion to dismiss the indictment, finding that the indictment had alleged the commission of a crime where electronic reproduction of computer programs was a prohibited offense under the statute and that defendants' due process rights were not violated. The statute's purpose was clear as to what offenses were prohibited and what was required of each offense.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Unlawful Use of Secret Scientific Material -- Computer Program

1. Defendants' motion to dismiss, on the ground that it failed to allege the commission of any crime, an indictment charging them with unlawful use of secret scientific material in violation of Penal Law § 165.07, arising out of their tangible reproduction of a hospital's computer program which they old to another hospital, shall be denied since a computer program is a "scientific or technical process, invention, or formula" (Penal Law § 155.00 [6]), the unlawful use of which is prohibited by section 165.07; because a computer program is the result of time and effort spent by trained people, because such training requires study associated with specialized knowledge, and because the program directs a computer to perform prescribed procedures and operations on data to produce a desired result, the resulting program can be described as a "scientific process". Provisions of the Penal Law must be construed according to the fair import of their terms to promote justice and effect the objects of the law (Penal Law § 5.00), and hypertechnical [***2] or strained interpretations of the Penal Law are to be eschewed.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Warning of Prohibited Conduct

2. Penal Law § 165.07, which prohibits the unlawful use of secret scientific material, is not constitutionally defective for failing to warn what conduct is prohibited, since a reading of the statute makes its purpose clear and gives unequivocal warning to citizens of the rule to be obeyed; although the Legislature gave "secret scientific material" an elastic, rather than a specific, definition, that does not mean that the statute is constitutionally defective, since the "root of the vagueness doctrine is a rough idea of fairness", and "impossible standards are not required."

 

1568 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bonded Concrete, Inc. v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


131 Misc. 2d 567; 500 N.Y.S.2d 927; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2562



March 27, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The petition is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, concrete company and others, brought an action to invalidate 1985 N.Y. Laws chs. 549, 929, on the grounds that they were irrational, illegal and unconstitutional. Petitioners contended that State or municipally owned vehicles were being treated by respondents, the State and others, as exempt from the statutory amendments' vehicle size, weight and related limitations, and from the fine and penalty provisions of the statutes.


OVERVIEW: Petitioners contended that the New York State Department of Transportation rules and regulations promulgated under the two statutory amendments went considerably further than the statutes themselves, without legal authority. In denying the petition, the court stated that a strong presumption existed in favor of the constitutionality of the legislative enactment. It was incumbent upon the petitioners to rebut the constitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt. There was a wholly rational and reasonable basis for the legislation. 1985 N.Y. Laws chs. 549, 929 carefully regulated the maximum gross weight of trucks allowed to travel the roads and bridges of the State and allowed for varying weights, depending on the wheel configurations, length of the truck and geographic area in which the truck will travel. Greater weights were allowed in the "downstate" area because restrictive weight limitations caused a disproportionately greater increase in travel time and construction costs downstate due to the greater traffic congestion in that area. The legislation reflected a rational policy designed to preserve the State's highways and bridges with minimal increases in construction costs.


OUTCOME: The court denied the petition to invalidate the statutes regulating the gross vehicle weight limits for trucks, tractor trailers, and semi-trailers on the State's highway system.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Truck Weight Restrictions -- Two-Region System of Permits

Amendments to the Vehicle and Traffic Law (L 1985, chs 549, 929) establishing a two-region system of permits for trucks, tractor trailers and semitrailers, allowing greater weights in the downstate area because restrictive weight limitations cause a disproportionately greater increase in travel time and construction costs in the downstate area due to greater traffic congestion, are not unconstitutional since the legislation imposing less severe restrictions in the downstate area reflects a rational policy designed to preserve the highways and bridges of the State with minimal increases in construction costs.

 

1569 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Chandler v. Coughlin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


131 Misc. 2d 442; 500 N.Y.S.2d 628; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2516



March 20, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmate filed suit against respondent, prison official, challenging the structure of temporary release committees established pursuant to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 7, § 1900.2(a).


OVERVIEW: The inmate filed an application to participate in the temporary release program which was denied. Thereafter she filed the instant action challenging the propriety of having parole officers serve on the release committees. The prison official sought to dismiss the petition on the grounds that the petition was time-barred, the inmate failed to exhaust her administrative remedies, and the petition failed to state a cause of action. The court found that the contention that the action was time-barred was without merit. The inmate challenged the prison official's ability to appoint parole officers to the release committees rather than the denial of her application to participate in the temporary release program. Accordingly, the six-year statute of limitations of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 213(1) applied and the action was timely. Moreover, because the inmate's claim was a constitutional challenge, she could maintain the action without first exhausting administrative remedies. The court held that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 7, § 1900.2(a), was unconstitutional insofar as the prison official construed that statute as authorizing the appointment of parole officers to temporary release committees.


OUTCOME: The court rendered judgment in favor of the inmate in her action against the prison official challenging the structure of temporary release committees and held that a state statute was unconstitutional to the extent that the prison official used it to authorize the appointment of parole officers to temporary release committees.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Actions -- Conversion of One Form of Action to Another

1. A proceeding commenced pursuant to CPLR article 78, in which petitioner challenged the constitutionality of the structure of temporary release committees established under 7 NYCRR 1900.2, should be one for declaratory judgment, and, thus, pursuant to CPLR 103 (c), the matter shall be converted to a declaratory judgment.

Limitation of Actions -- What Statute Governs -- Temporary Release Committees

2. An action challenging the ability of the Commissioner of the Department of Corrections to appoint parole officers to temporary release committees pursuant to 7 NYCRR 1900.2 tests the constitutionality of the Commissioner's regulation rather than the determination of petitioner's individual application for release, and, as such, the six-year Statute of Limitations of CPLR 213 (1) applies rather than the four-month limitation period of CPLR 217, since the constitutional challenge to the regulation could not be properly reviewed in an article 78 proceeding.

Administrative Law -- Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies -- Constitutional Challenge to Regulation

3. An action to challenge the constitutionality [***2] of a regulation whereby parole officers may be appointed to temporary release committees established by the Department of Corrections is not a review of petitioner's individual temporary release determination and may be maintained without first exhausting administrative remedies; moreover, it was apparent that petitioner did pursue the appropriate grievance appeal of the disposition of her request for release through final determination by the Commissioner of Correction.

Prisons and Prisoners -- Temporary Release Committees -- Appointment of Parole Officers to Committees

4. Parole officers may not be appointed to serve on temporary release committees established by the Department of Corrections (see, 7 NYCRR 1900.2 [a]); Correction Law § 852 (5) specifically directed the Department to contract with the Division of Parole for parole officers' services in the supervision of inmates participating in the temporary release programs, and through the aforementioned regulation, the Commissioner of Correctional Services has expanded the function of parole officers such that they are involved in the preliminary consideration of inmates' applications for the program. There [***3] is no authority empowering the Commissioner to expand the duties of parole officers within the temporary release programs beyond those specifically established by the Legislature, and although the eligibility of an inmate for participation in the program is related to his or her eligibility for parole or conditional release, that is an insufficient basis for the Commissioner of the Department of Corrections to utilize the services of parole officers beyond the limitations prescribed by the Legislature in the aforementioned statute.

 

1570 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Haefner v. Apcoa Parking, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Rochester


130 Misc. 2d 203; 500 N.Y.S.2d 605; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2409



March 7, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Two separate small claims cases came before the court for consideration. In each case, plaintiff individual sought to recover for the allegedly wrongful seizure of his vehicle and the subsequent assessment against him of towing and storage charges.


OVERVIEW: In the first case, the individual was an airline employee who was authorized to park his car in a designated area of an airport parking lot for a limited period of time. Upon his return from work duties that called him away for several days, he found that defendant parking concessionaire had towed his vehicle to another location and assessed towing and storage charges against him. In the second case, city police affixed to the individual's legally parked vehicle two parking violation summonses charging that the car was uninspected and that its registration from another state had expired. Defendant parking violations bureau subsequently towed the vehicle to the city pound. In each case, a municipality authorized, either by a contract and regulations or an ordinance, the seizure of the individual's vehicle without notice or consent and without judicial supervision. Moreover, absent in each case was any police power interest of the given municipality. The court held that the purported municipal authorizations for the seizures were unconstitutional because they lacked due process of law. The court then awarded direct, consequential, and punitive damages to each individual.


OUTCOME: The court awarded compensatory and punitive damages to each individual.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor Vehicles -- Parking Violations -- Removal of Car without Notice to Owner

Regulations of a private concessionaire adopted pursuant to a parking contract with a municipal airport permitting the concessionaire to remove cars parked beyond the specified time limits and tow and store said cars elsewhere at the expense of the owner are unconstitutional as a deprivation of property without due process of law, as is an ordinance permitting the seizure and removal without notice of any vehicle found standing or parked in violation of any law or ordinance; there are no provisions for notice to the vehicle owner, either before or after the seizure, nor for an application to any judicial officer prior to the seizure and relocation of the vehicle, and before imposition of towing and storage charges. The taker of the property has no interest or lien in the vehicle, there is no police power interest, and there is no risk to public health, safety or welfare; there is no important general public interest, there is no demonstrated need for prompt action, and neither the regulations nor the ordinance establish any standards of judgment. A municipality cannot exercise an unconstitutional [***2] grant of authority nor can it delegate it to others, and accordingly, the parking concessionaire and the Parking Violations Bureau are liable in damages to plaintiffs for the wrongful seizure of their property; plaintiffs are entitled to recover the moneys paid for towing and storage, damages for loss of use of the vehicle, and punitive damages.

 

1571 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Macellaro


Indictment Nos. 85-00856, 85-0923


County Court of New York, Westchester County


131 Misc. 2d 383; 500 N.Y.S.2d 595; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2397



March 4, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged under consolidated indictments of unlawful dealing in hazardous wastes, disposing of hazardous wastes without authorization, transporting hazardous wastes without a permit, and reckless endangerment. Defendant brought a motion to dismiss on the basis that the regulations listing and identifying hazardous wastes had not been validly enacted and were not actually in effect on the date the charges crimes allegedly occurred.


OVERVIEW: Defendant alleged that the regulations identifying hazardous waste were not validly promulgated because on the day the alleged crimes occurred, these regulations had not been submitted to the State Environmental Board for review and approval as required by N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law §§ 3-030, 5-0107(2). Relying on N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-0903(3), the People argued that only amendments to regulations had to be submitted to the Board for approval. Upon weighing the rules of statutory construction, the court found insufficient support for the position advanced by the People to the effect that § 27-0903 ought to be read as being in conflict with, or as superseding, or as an exception to, N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law §§ 3-0301, 5-0107(2). Recognizing the statutory preference to harmonize, the court read these sections compatibly and jointly, as requiring both the initial environmental regulation and any subsequent amendment thereto to be submitted to the Board for approval. Moreover, the requirements of State Administrative Procedure Act mandated approval of regulations by the Board before the regulations could become effective.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the counts contained in the indictment charging the defendant with unlawfully dealing, disposing, and transporting hazardous waste.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Environmental Conservation -- Hazardous Waste -- Approval of Hazardous Waste Regulations by State Environmental Board

 ECL 27-0903 should not be read as being in conflict with, or as superseding, or as an exception to ECL 3-0301 and 5-0107 (2); thus, both an initial environmental regulation and any subsequent amendment thereto must be submitted to the State Environmental Board for approval; further, assuming that enactment of hazardous waste regulations must first satisfy the requirements of the State Administrative Procedure Act, then compliance with the State Administrative Procedure Act would mandate compliance with regulations such as ECL 3-0301 and 5-0107 (2), which call for approval of the regulations by a designated body before such regulations can become effective. Accordingly, indictments against defendant arising out of his alleged deposit of two drums containing hazardous waste, identified in 6 NYCRR 371.3, on April 11, 1985 are dismissed; inasmuch as the regulations were not submitted to the State Environmental Board and approved until April 29, 1985, they had not been validly enacted as of the date of the crimes charged.

 

1572 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


233 East 86th Street Corp. v. Park East Apartments, Inc.


Index No. 25965/85, No. 80


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


131 Misc. 2d 242; 499 N.Y.S.2d 853; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2391



February 27, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion for a preliminary injunction is, therefore, denied and the stay is dissolved 10 days after service of a duly entered copy of this order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action for damages and a declaration that its lease with defendant condominium cooperative ("cooperative") was valid, plaintiff condominium plan sponsor ("sponsor") sought a preliminary injunction.


OVERVIEW: While the sponsor controlled the cooperative, it caused a condominium plan to be executed by both parties. The plan conveyed a reconstructed building to the cooperative and granted the sponsor a lease of the ground floor for $ 5,000 per year for up to 95 years, at the sponsor's option. After the conveyance, the cooperative declared the lease terminated under the Condominium and Cooperative Abuse Relief Act of 1980, 15 U.S.C.S. § 3601 et seq. On the sponsor's request for a preliminary injunction, the court held that 1) the condominium building did not lose its character from the reconstruction, so the Act applied, so the cooperative was likely to prevail on the merits, 2) the Act satisfied due process requirements because it was reasonably related to the legitimate congressional goals, 3) the sponsor's potential harm was not irreparable because its potential loss of rental income was compensable in dollars, and 3) the equities balanced in favor of the cooperative because of the long potential term of the lease and the low rental rate.


OUTCOME: The court denied the sponsor's request for a preliminary injunction.


HEADNOTES

Condominiums and Cooperatives -- Condominium and Cooperative Abuse Relief Act of 1980 -- Termination of Long-Term, "Sweet Heart Deals" by Unit Owners

The Condominium and Cooperative Abuse Relief Act of 1980 (15 USC § 3601 et seq. [Condominium Act]), which enables cooperative and condominium unit owners, by a two-thirds vote, to terminate certain long-term "sweet heart deals" entered into between the cooperative or condominium corporation and the sponsor, is not unconstitutional since the statute is a socioeconomic regulation of the marketplace rather than the governmental benefit, entitlement deprivation or other action to which procedural due process attaches and the regulation of private contracts is reasonably related to the legitimate congressional goals in an area of national importance. Plaintiff, the sponsor of the plan for cooperative conversion of the subject premises, is not entitled to injunctive relief tolling the termination of a long-term commercial lease by the cooperative corporation pursuant to the [***2] Condominium Act since plaintiff has not established the likelihood of success on the merits in view of the fact that it controlled the cooperative corporation at the time the lease with a potential duration of 95 years was executed nor has it demonstrated irreparable harm or that the premises is a totally new building to which the statute should not apply. Since plaintiff has no right to cure, the "Yellowstone doctrine" which allows injunctive relief in landlord-tenant matters without regard to the likelihood of success on the merits in order to protect a tenant's leasehold is inapplicable.

 

1573 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Byrnes v. County of Monroe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Monroe County


131 Misc. 2d 129; 499 N.Y.S.2d 350; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2480



February 18, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The judgment of the Rochester City Court by decision, dated June 10, 1985, is affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant county challenged a judgment of the Rochester City Court (New York), which awarded respondent attorney compensation in excess of the statutory limits based on extraordinary circumstances. The attorney was assigned as counsel to defendant in a criminal matter. The city court relied on N.Y. County Law § 722-b in making the award. The county argued that the city court had to have the approval of the supervising judge to make such an award.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. County Law § 722-b provided that attorney compensation (other than appeals) and reimbursement was fixed by the court where judgment of conviction or acquittal or order of dismissal was entered and in extraordinary circumstances the trial court was allowed to provide for compensation in excess of the limits set by statute. The Rules of the Appellate Division, Fourth Department, N.Y. Comp. Code R. & Regs. tit. 22, § 1022.12, required the supervising judge of the criminal courts to approve any request for compensation greater than that statutorily allowed under N.Y. County Law § 722-b. The court found that the statute and rule could not have been reconciled and were contradictory on their face. The court affirmed the city court's attorney compensation award and held that the Appellate Division could not make rules and regulations governing the administration of the courts that were contradictory to statutes enacted by the New York State Legislature. N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 30 granted the courts power only to adopt rules and regulations that were consistent with the general practice and procedure as provided by statute or general rules.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the city court's award of attorney compensation in excess of the limits set by statute.


HEADNOTES

Attorney and Client -- Compensation -- Assigned Counsel for Criminal Defendants -- Excess Award

In a criminal prosecution, the City Court may grant awards of counsel fees in excess of the statutory limits pursuant to County Law § 722-b without the approval of the Supervising Judge as called for by Rules of the Appellate Division, Fourth Department (22 NYCRR 1022.12), and such rules are void and unconstitutional where they conflict with County Law § 722-b. The Appellate Division may not make rules and regulations governing the administration of the courts which are contradictory to statutes enacted by the State Legislature.

 

1574 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Dumain v. Carey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


131 Misc. 2d 221; 499 N.Y.S.2d 334; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2488



February 13, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In view of this determination, plaintiffs' motion to serve an amended complaint and defendants' cross motion to serve an amended answer are denied as moot.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, the Governor of the State of New York and related others, and plaintiff school board members filed a motion and cross motion for summary judgment. The members also filed a motion for leave to serve a supplemental complaint. Defendants filed a cross motion for leave to serve an amended answer. The members had filed an action against defendants under N.Y. State Fin. Law art. 7-A for injunctive relief and a declaratory judgment.


OVERVIEW: The members commenced an action against defendants for injunctive relief and a judgment declaring that N.Y. Educ. Law § 3602 was unconstitutional and contrary to statute to the extent that it provided for formulas in the calculation of state aid to school districts predicated upon inaccurate data not subject to verification and that they were entitled to retroactive and continuing adjustment of state aid provided to them upon the basis of such inaccurate data. The court found that defendants' use of the data gathering mechanism promulgated under N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 20, § 2000.2 was arbitrary and capricious to the extent that it was applied to administer distribution of any state aid funds to the school district under N.Y. Educ. Law § 3602 and that the members were entitled to adjustments of prior disbursements. The court directed defendants to make all necessary adjustments to the disbursements and denied all other requested relief. The court held in part that the legislature had the authority to provide for school aid through a formula predicated upon the wealth of each school district.


OUTCOME: The court found that defendants' use of the data gathering mechanism was arbitrary and capricious to the extent that it was applied to administer distribution of any state aid funds to the school district and that the members were entitled to adjustments of prior disbursements. The court directed defendants to make all necessary adjustments to the disbursements and denied all other requested relief.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- State Aid -- Inaccurate Formula
