In a taxpayers' action seeking an adjustment of State aid given to a school district, where the aid was disbursed pursuant to an inaccurate formula, defendant State officials' use of the data gathering mechanism promulgated under 20 NYCRR 2000.2 was arbitrary and capricious to the extent that it was applied to administer distribution of any State aid funds to plaintiff school district pursuant to Education Law § 3602, and plaintiffs are entitled to adjustments of all disbursements made for the school years 1980-1981 through 1984-1985 to the extent that said disbursements were predicated upon any formula utilizing said data gathering mechanism; Laws of 1984 (ch 889), being a statute designed to remedy the situation produced by the failure of the bureaucracy to discharge the legislative mandate to produce a State aid formula based upon the wealth of each school district, which failure resulted from taxpayers inaccurately designating on their State tax returns the school district [***2] in which they lived, shall not be construed to limit the application of retroactive relief, since in the absence of a clear showing that it is to be afforded prospective application only, remedial statutes are to be liberally construed to carry out the reforms intended.

 

1575 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Rauscher v. Boonville


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Oneida County


131 Misc. 2d 264; 499 N.Y.S.2d 832; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2494



January 27, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff private garbage collectors operated within defendant village and refused to pay a licensing fee. They were charged for violating Village of Boonville, N.Y., Local Laws No. 1, §§ 4.0-4.5 (1985) and were fined $ 500 for each violation. The collectors brought a motion to strike down the local law, and granted a temporary injunction. The matter was before the court for determination.


OVERVIEW: Under a village ordinance any collector of waste operating in the village was required to be licensed and as a license fee was charged the sum of $ 45 per ton for trash collected. The stated purpose of the local law was to promote the public health and safety, and to spread the cost of garbage and refuse disposal to fund a village transfer site. The law further required garbage haulers to obtain a permit and to pay a fee for the permit based on tonnage collected, but the fee was unrelated to the costs of licensing, inspecting, or regulating the pickup and hauling of garbage and refuse. Indeed, it had been admitted that the fees were to pay for the village transfer station costs. Thus, as the fee was unrelated to the cost of licensing, it was constitutionally defective. No mechanisms were provided by the law as to trash disposal, and the licensing law contained only arbitrary fees unrelated to where or how haulers disposed of trash. Therefore, the law was not reasonably related to the purpose intended. It was the opinion of the court that the local law was unreasonable and arbitrary and, thus, an unconstitutional use of the village police power.


OUTCOME: The trash hauler permit and fee provisions of the village licensing law were stricken as unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Licensing of Trash Collectors

Local Laws, 1985, No. 1 of the Village of Boonville, insofar as it requires garbage and trash haulers to obtain a permit and to pay a fee for said permit based on tonnage of garbage collected in the village, is unreasonable and arbitrary and thus an unconstitutional use of the village police power, since the fees are not related to the cost associated with licensing but rather are to pay for village transfer station costs. The law is simply a revenue measure, imposed without any relationship to controlling solid waste disposal, and arbitrarily distinguishes between a hauler who has to pay even if it does not use the village trash facility, and an individual who pays a fee only if he disposes of his trash at the transfer facility.

 

1576 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Flinn


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Erie County


130 Misc. 2d 877; 497 N.Y.S.2d 994; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2443



January 13, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The order appealed from should be and is affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state appealed an order of the City Court of Buffalo (New York), which found Buffalo, N.Y., City Ordinances ch. IX, § 24, unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested by a City of Buffalo police officer and charged with disorderly conduct in violation of Buffalo, N.Y., City Ordinances ch. IX, § 24, and resisting arrest in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §205.30. Under the city ordinance, "disorderly conduct" meant refusing to obey a reasonable order or request of a police officer. Defendant was charged with refusing to leave the area of an ambulance when requested several times by the officer. Defendant moved to dismiss the information upon his contention that the ordinance was unconstitutional on its face. The trial court determined that the ordinance was unconstitutionally vague and dismissed both of the charges. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that, by failing to specifically define the nature of the prohibited conduct, the ordinance permitted police officers to both make and enforce the law. The officer's subjective determination of what was unreasonable determined the law. The court held that the failure to properly describe the prohibited conduct rendered the ordinance unconstitutionally vague.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the trial court, which ruled a city ordinance for disorderly conduct was unconstitutionally vague, and dismissed the charges brought against defendant.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Resisting Officer in Discharge of Duty -- Ordinance Void for Vagueness

An order of the Buffalo City Court holding that an ordinance of the City of Buffalo is unconstitutionally vague and dismissing charges brought pursuant to its violation is affirmed since the statute, which mandates obedience to the reasonable orders of a police officer in the discharge of his regular duty, while not vague in the sense that it requires obedience to reasonable requests and orders, is constitutionally defective in that the police officer must determine what is proper or improper by reference to his own concept of reasonability rather than by reference to a particular legislatively established standard of behavior; the language of the ordinance makes no attempt to define or limit the words "reasonable order or request" conferring virtually unrestrained authority upon the police, lending itself to discriminatory and harsh enforcement, and additionally does not require that one intentionally or willfully refuse to obey an order and therefore may punish an inadvertent noncompliance.

 People v Flinn, 126 Misc 2d 570, affirmed.

 

1577 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Amsterdam v. Goldstick


Index No. HP 12048/85


Civil Court of the City of New York, New York County


131 Misc. 2d 131; 499 N.Y.S.2d 568; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2386



January 6, 1986 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] After reargument the court adheres to its original determination.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent managing agent for a multiple dwelling, an out-of-state resident, filed a motion for "reargument" in which he challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. City Admin. Code § D26-41.03(a)(3) after a determination by the trial court that he was in violation of the statute, which required managing agents of multiple dwellings to have a business office in the city.


OVERVIEW: Respondent managing agent for a multiple dwelling, an out-of-state resident, filed a motion, denominated as one for "reargument," in which he challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. City Admin. Code § D26-41.03(a)(3) because it deprived him of his right to earn a livelihood. The statute required managing agents of multiple dwellings to have a business office in the city. The managing agent argued that the statute violated the Privileges and Immunities Clause of the United States Constitution and the analogous provision of the state constitution. The trial court had already determined that the managing agent did not meet the requirements of the statute. While noting that the proper procedure after a trial but before a judgment was signed was to move for a new trial rather than for reargument, the trial court granted the motion to reargue. Upon an analysis of the constitutional issue, the trial court held that the statute was constitutional. The trial court held that it was not an unreasonable burden to require that persons who used the city as the place to earn a living must conduct their business in the city and, parenthetically, pay city taxes.


OUTCOME: Because the issues presented went to the constitutional heart of the statute and because there were numerous pending cases that involved the same provision, the trial court granted the motion for reargument, even though a motion for a new trial would have been the proper procedure after a trial. After determining that the statute was a reasonable one and that it was constitutional, the trial court adhered to its original determination.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Managing Agent of New York City Multiple Dwelling -- Office within City

The statute that the managing agent of a multiple dwelling in New York City either reside in the city or maintain a bona fide office in the city for the conduct of business as a managing agent (Administrative Code of City of New York § D26-41.03 [a] [3]) is not violative of the "privileges and immunities" clause of the Federal Constitution (U.S. Const, art IV, § 2), which was "intended to create a national economic union" and extends unique protection to nonresidents who wish to engage in their chosen occupation and earn a livelihood within the State on an equal basis with residents, since, although serving as a managing agent is a substantial economic right, the limited discrimination restricting nonresidents who can serve as managing agents to those who maintain a bona fide office in the city bears a substantial relation to the legitimate State objective of making agents available to the tenants whose apartments they manage and the governmental officials responsible for their regulation. It is not an unreasonable [***2] burden to place on persons who seek to use the city as the place to earn a living that they actually use the city for the conduct of their business and pay city taxes. Although respondent, having lost on a nonconstitutional factual defense at trial, would not ordinarily be permitted to raise a constitutional defense on a motion to reargue, the merits of the constitutional issue will be reached since there are numerous pending cases in which respondent's status as a managing agent is in issue.

 

1578 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York v. New St. Mark's Baths


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


130 Misc. 2d 911; 497 N.Y.S.2d 979; 1986 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2444



January 6, 1986 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff's sought injunctive relief in its nuisance action to close defendant's bathhouse as a risk to public health, and defendants filed a cross motion to dismiss for violating due process rights of privacy and association.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs sought preliminary injunctive relief in its action pursuant to the state administrative and penal codes to close defendant's bathhouse as a public nuisance citing health risks following several on site inspections in which high risk sexual activity was taking place on a continuous and regular basis. Defendants brought a cross motion to dismiss the complaint on the grounds that the action violated defendant's due process rights to privacy and freedom of association. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss, because plaintiffs showed a compelling state interest in preserving the health of the population, that closure was the most reasonable and least intrusive remedy available, and plaintiff could exercise its police power because the impact on defendant' due process rights to entertainment or gratification were tangential to the risk to public health.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to dismiss was denied and plaintiffs were granted a preliminary injunction in their nuisance action to close defendant's bathhouse, because plaintiffs showed a compelling interest in preserving public health, and that closure was the most reasonable remedy available.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Health -- State Sanitary Code -- Closure of Bath House Where "High Risk Sexual Activity" Takes Place

Plaintiffs, the health authorities of the City of New York, are granted a preliminary injunction closing defendants' bath house as a public nuisance (Administrative Code of City of New York § C16-2.0 et seq.) in view of the proof that "high risk sexual activity" connected with the transmission of the deadly disease known as AIDS (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) has been taking place at the bath house on a continuous and regular basis (10 NYCRR 24-2.1). Plaintiffs have demonstrated a compelling State interest in acting to preserve the health of the population that takes precedence over any constitutional rights of privacy and free association and the remedy adopted by plaintiffs is the least intrusive reasonably available. Defendants' constitutional rights will not be adversely affected by closure of the bath house in any event since the privacy protection of sexual activity conducted in a private home does not extend to commercial establishments simply because they provide an opportunity for intimate behavior or sexual release and the State police power will be upheld [***2] over claims of constitutional rights of association where the nature of the assemblage is not for the advancement of beliefs and ideas but predominantly either for entertainment or gratification. The city's Nuisance Abatement Law is not unconstitutionally vague and there is ample proof that defendants' staff had actual knowledge of the "high risk sexual activity" upon the premises within the meaning of the statute and chose to condone it.

 

1579 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hollander v. City of New York


Index No. 7813/81


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3068



December 24, 1985 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a former owner of realty, filed a motion to amend his complaint in his action against defendant city to challenge a foreclosure. The city moved for an order dismissing the owner's complaint.


OVERVIEW: The owner challenged an in rem foreclosure proceeding that was based on the owner's failure to pay taxes. He moved to amend his complaint to plead the unconstitutionality of statutes that provided for service upon a defaulting owner of a notice of foreclosure by ordinary mail. The court held that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code §§ D17-6.0c, D17-11.0 were constitutional, that proper service was made upon the owner, and the court had jurisdiction over the owner to render an in rem judgment of foreclosure against him. Where the names and addresses of those affected by a proceeding were available, the reasons disappeared for resort to means less likely than the mails to apprise them of its pendency. Due process principles were not violated by service by publication plus a mailing by ordinary mail to the interested party's designated address.


OUTCOME: The court denied the owner's motion to amend and granted the city's motion to dismiss.

 

1580 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hollander v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


130 Misc. 2d 1039; 498 N.Y.S.2d 953; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3288



December 18, 1985 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In view of the foregoing, this court considers defendant's further ground for dismissal of plaintiff's complaint under the doctrine of res judicata to be moot.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff former owner filed a motion to amend his complaint against defendant City of New York, New York to plead the unconstitutionality of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code §§ D17-6.0(c), D17-11.0 and to add the present owner of the property as a party in order to cancel its title ownership. The City filed a cross motion to dismiss the complaint for lack of merit and also on the ground of res judicata.


OVERVIEW: The former owner's property was the subject of an in rem tax foreclosure proceeding instituted by the City because of the former owner's nonpayment of realty taxes. The former owner filed the action to try and cancel the present owner's ownership and restore the property to it. The former owner filed a motion to amend the complaint. The court denied the motion and dismissed the complaint. The court determined that it was appropriate to address the merits of the action. The court concluded that although advertising along was not constitutionally adequate notice of a pending foreclosure sale, advertising plus mailing, as provided by New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § D17-6.0(c) was adequate. The court held that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code §§ D17-6.0(c), D17-11.0 were constitutional. The court determined that the former owner was properly served with notice of the foreclosure proceeding.


OUTCOME: The court denied the former owner's motion to amend the complaint and granted the City's cross motion to dismiss the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Tax Liens, Tax Sales and Tax Titles -- Notice of Foreclosure Sale Sent by Ordinary Mail

New York City's in rem tax foreclosure statute, which provides for the service upon a defaulting owner of a notice of foreclosure by ordinary mail (Administrative Code of City of New York § D17-6.0 [c]), is constitutional since the United States Supreme Court, in ruling the notice provisions of an Indiana tax foreclosure statute unconstitutional (see, Mennonite Bd. of Missions v Adams, 462 U.S. 791), did not require that notice of an in rem tax foreclosure proceeding be sent to persons having an interest in the realty being foreclosed by certified as opposed to ordinary mail but, rather, the court intended to approve the use of the ordinary mail.

 

1581 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Lori M.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, RICHMOND COUNTY


130 Misc. 2d 493; 496 N.Y.S.2d 940; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3225



December 18, 1985 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the reasons set forth herein, the petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mother filed a petition alleging that respondent daughter was a person in need of supervision pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 712(a).


OVERVIEW: After her 15-year-old daughter engaged in a homosexual relationship with a 21-year-old woman, a mother filed a petition alleging that her daughter was a person in need of supervision (PINS) pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 712(a). The court dismissed the petition, holding that the daughter had asserted her constitutional right to privacy in matters concerning her sexual orientation and that state action could not be used to infringe on those rights absent a significant state interest that was not present in the case of an adult. The court found that there was no such interest presented. The court also held that the daughter had shown great maturity and had continued to be a well-behaved child. Finally, the court held that although it would not adjudicate the daughter as a PINS, it would admonish her to cease her relationship with the 21-year-old because such relationship was violative of N.Y. Penal Law § 130.40.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed a mother's petition alleging that her daughter was a person in need of supervision.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- Persons in Need of Supervision

The petition is dismissed in a proceeding in which petitioner mother alleges that her 15-year-old daughter is a person in need of supervision due to her association with a 21-year-old lesbian; a mature child's right to make her own decision regarding abortion and contraception is constitutionally protected from parental and/or State interference, and where a child demonstrates sufficient maturity, her sexual orientation and choices in pursuit thereof must be held to be similarly protected. Respondent is admonished to avoid engaging in any conduct violative of the Penal Law, and referral is made for petitioner and respondent to Family Court Services for counseling.

 

1582 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rivera


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


130 Misc. 2d 326; 496 N.Y.S.2d 669; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3195



December 13, 1985 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, in a parole violation proceeding before the trial court (New York), contended that a revocable sentence imposed on defendant was illegal and unconstitutional, and that the resentence imposed was in violation of the statutory provisions authorizing revocable sentences.


OVERVIEW: Defendant pled guilty to grand larceny, and was sentenced to 16 weeks of imprisonment and a five-year term of probation. Defendant subsequently violated the terms of his probation, and the court revoked his sentence, and sentenced defendant to 30 days imprisonment and probation for five years. Defendant contended that the second sentence imposed was illegal and unconstitutional, and the resentence was in violation of the statutory provisions authorizing revocable sentences. The court held that when defendant was resentenced to 30 days in prison and probation, the imposition of probation was not allowable at that time. As a matter of law, as the prior sentence of probation was revoked by the resentencing of defendant to 30 days in jail, there was no longer a probationary term pending against defendant. The court concluded, therefore, that defendant was discharged from probation.


OUTCOME: The court discharged defendant from probation on the ground that when defendant was resentenced to 30 days in prison and probation, the imposition of probation was not allowable at that time.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Sentence

A defendant sentenced to 16 weekends of imprisonment and a five-year term of probation, whose sentence was vacated because he had missed several weekends of imprisonment, was improperly resentenced to 30 days in prison and a five-year term of probation; at the time defendant's original revocable sentence was vacated Penal Law § 60.01 did not permit the subsequent imposition of another sentence of probation, and accordingly, defendant is discharged from probation.

 

1583 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Molero


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


130 Misc. 2d 330; 496 N.Y.S.2d 671; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3196



December 13, 1985 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a hearing on a violation of probation, under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 410.70(1), the State applied for an order revoking defendant's sentence of probation after he pled guilty in another court to the crime of attempted criminal possession of a controlled substance, seventh degree. Defendant was sentenced originally to three years probation, which he was serving when he was arrested for the crime to which he pled guilty.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was sentenced to probation. While on probation, he was arrested and pled guilty to the crime of attempted criminal possession of a controlled substance. The State sought to revoke defendant's probation. The court adjourned the hearing. At the hearing, defendant claimed he was not advised by his counsel that pleading guilty would violate his sentence of probation. The court found that, under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.30, defendant could move to set aside the conviction that followed his guilty plea only in the court that entered the judgment. The court determined that, under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 410.70(2), it could adjourn the hearing to allow defendant time to prepare for the hearing, which involved applying to the other court to set aside the conviction.


OUTCOME: The court adjourned the hearing on defendant's probation violation for a few weeks. The court directed defense counsel to move forthwith in the other court for the relief defendant sought.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Sentence -- Probation

At a hearing to revoke a sentence of probation on the ground that the defendant was convicted in another county of a crime after he was placed on probation, the defendant may not challenge that conviction on the ground that it was unconstitutionally obtained; a motion to set aside a conviction obtained in violation of a defendant's constitutional rights must be made in the court in which the judgment was rendered, and defendant's application for an adjournment for the purpose of challenging that conviction is granted.

 

1584 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


McVann v. Myers


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Yonkers, Westchester County


131 Misc. 2d 167; 497 N.Y.S.2d 819; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3297



December 12, 1985 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord sought a judgment and warrant of eviction against respondent tenant. The tenant moved for dismissal of the proceeding on the ground that the apartment was subject to the Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974 (ETPA), L 1974, ch. 576, § 4, and that the landlord failed to comply with certain jurisdictional notice requirements thereunder.


OVERVIEW: The landlord contended that the apartment was not subject to ETPA control because the legislature did not intend that the ETPA apply to a landlord owning a single co-op unit, application of the ETPA to the landlord would be unfair and cause extreme hardship, and N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 352-eee (5) superseded the ETPA. The court disagreed. There was no specific exclusion for cooperative apartment owners in the city's declaration of emergency, enacted in order to be protected under the ETPA, or in the ETPA itself. That the landlord owned only one co-op was immaterial because the ETPA only exempted buildings containing fewer than six units. The court construed the ETPA to apply to nonprofessional landlords because the ETPA covered housing accommodations not types of ownership. The ETPA was constitutional. Any hardships resulting to the landlord from enforcement of the ETPA were superceded by the public policy considerations during an acute housing shortage. The ETPA did not contain an exception for rental apartments in cooperatives and condominiums, and the existence of such an exception in § 352-eee did not supercede the ETPA.


OUTCOME: The tenant's motion to dismiss was granted.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Cooperative Apartment Owners Subject to Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974

An apartment in a multiple dwelling in the City of Yonkers previously subject to the Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974 (L 1974, ch 516, § 4 [ETPA]) and the regulations promulgated thereto when petitioner resided in the apartment as a tenant remained subject to the ETPA following the cooperative conversion of the building and petitioner's purchase of his apartment and subsequent rental to respondent since cooperative apartment owners are not specifically excluded by the ETPA or by the city's declaration of housing emergency and it thus cannot be said that the Legislature did not intend for the ETPA to apply to a "nonprofessional" or "mini" landlord who owns a single co-op unit. Emergency Tenant Protection Regulations § 35 (3) (h) (9 NYCRR 2502.5 [c] [8]) is not unconstitutional since the city's view that the potential exists for tenants of cooperative apartment owners "being charged excessive and unwarranted rents and rent increases" is reasonable in view of the city's housing situation and the position of the State Division of Housing and [***2] Community Renewal that the cooperative market should be regulated by enforcement of the ETPA and its regulations is not irrational or unreasonable. General Business Law § 352-eee, which governs cooperative conversions in Westchester County, does not supersede the ETPA since ETPA § 5 does not contain an exception for cooperatives and condominiums. Accordingly, unless and until the ETPA and the declaration of emergency are amended to create an exception for individual cooperative apartment owners, any personal hardship that petitioner may suffer as a result of enforcement of the ETPA must yield to the policy considerations of government regulation of housing accommodations during an acute housing shortage.

 

1585 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Pattberg v. Pattberg


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


130 Misc. 2d 893; 497 N.Y.S.2d 251; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3281



December 4, 1985 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant ex-wife filed a motion for an order staying a hearing on the modification of plaintiff ex-husband's support obligations pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 248 pending a determination as to the constitutionality and enforceability of the statute.


OVERVIEW: The court reviewed § 248 and determined that it was constitutional. However, the court noted that alimony or maintenance should be based on economic rather than moral factors and urged the legislature to remedy what it termed a very unpopular and unnecessary law. Section 248 provided that a court could modify an ex-husband's support obligations to the ex-wife upon proof that the ex-wife was habitually living with another man and holding herself out as his wife. The court held that the right to cohabit and assert a status as a married individual was not a fundamental right and such cohabiting persons were not a suspect class triggering a review under the "strict scrutiny" doctrine. The court found that , in the absence of a fundamental interest or a suspect class, the statute was simply required to be a rational means to a legitimate state objective. Based on the legislative history, the objective of the statute was to rectify a situation where an ex-wife was receiving alimony while she was being accepted by society as another man's wife. The court found the statute passed the rational basis test as well.


OUTCOME: The court determined that the statute was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Husband and Wife -- Support -- Anticohabitation Provision

New York's anticohabitation, termination-of-alimony statute (Domestic Relations Law § 248) which provides that the court may modify or annul previously ordered support "upon application of the husband on notice, upon proof that the wife is habitually living with another man and holding herself out as his wife", is constitutional under any of three standards for determining the validity of a statute on equal protection grounds. The right to cohabit and assert a status as a married individual is not a fundamental right and such cohabiting persons are not a suspect class triggering a review of the statute under the "strict scrutiny" doctrine and, therefore, any constitutional challenge on this basis must fail. Likewise, given the discretionary language of the statute, the absence of total termination of support in each individual case and the fact that the statute serves as a rational means to a legitimate State objective, a constitutional challenge to the statute on the basis of the "rational basis" standard must also fail. The fact that the New York statute has been construed as gender neutral, and speaks in discretionary [***2] and nonfatal terms thereby placing less of a burden on ex-spouses wishing to continue to receive alimony or maintenance in such situations than do other States, combined with the closer fit between statutory means and ends, is sufficient to shift the equal protection balance in favor of the State, and, accordingly, the statute is constitutional even under the third "balancing of factors" standard of review.

 

1586 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bloomfield


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Town of Rhinebeck, Dutchess County


130 Misc. 2d 151; 495 N.Y.S.2d 133; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3154



November 4, 1985 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The defendant is therefore guilty of the above-stated charge.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with having violated the motorcycle helmet law, N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 381(6).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was issued a uniform traffic summons for not wearing a helmet while he was riding a motorcycle. At trial, the arresting officer testified that defendant's helmet had been worn "cowboy style," meaning that it was sitting on the back of the head and resting on the top of defendant's shoulders. Defendant contended that he had been wearing a helmet within the meaning of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 381(6). The court disagreed. A helmet was defined in N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 15, § 54.2(a) as a device primarily intended to protect the upper part of the wearer's head against a blow. The blow could have been from the wearer's head striking the pavement or, more commonly, from the wearer being struck with rocks or other road debris. The court pointed out that in order to achieve its intended purpose, the helmet had to have been worn so that it covered the entire parietal and temporal bones and most of the frontal and occipital bones of the skull. A helmet that was worn "cowboy style" did not satisfy the requirements of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 381(6).


OUTCOME: Defendant was found guilty of having violated the motorcycle helmet law.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Motorcycle Helmet Law -- Wearing Helmet "Cowboy Style"

Wearing a motorcycle helmet "cowboy style", that is having the helmet sitting on the back of the head and resting on the top of the motorcyclist's shoulders leaving the better part of the head exposed, is equivalent to not wearing a helmet at all and is thus violative of the motorcycle helmet law which makes it unlawful for a person to operate or ride upon a motorcycle without a proper protective helmet (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 381 [6]); the purpose of the helmet is to protect the entire head from injury (see, 15 NYCRR 54.2) from loose stones, tree branches, or other objects or circumstances causing injury, and while the helmet and face shield do not assure the safety of a motorcyclist against injury, they do lessen the chance of injury to an important part of the human body; accordingly, defendant is guilty of operating his motorcycle without a helmet.

 

1587 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wells v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Steuben County


130 Misc. 2d 113; 495 N.Y.S.2d 591; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3147



October 30, 1985 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The court finds that the New York State mandatory "Seat Belt Law" is a valid constitutional exercise of legislative power and, therefore, grants the motion for summary judgment.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff driver filed an action against defendant State of New York, alleging that the "seat belt law," N.Y. Veh. Code § 1229-c, exceeded constitutional limits. The state filed a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The driver was issued a traffic citation in the City of Corning, New York, for failure to wear his seat belt while operating a motor vehicle. The driver then brought a declaratory action against the state, alleging that the seat belt law was unconstitutional. The driver alleged that the state legislature might have had improper motives in passing the bill. The state filed a motion for summary judgment, and the court granted the motion. The court found that the statute was constitutional, and noted that a court could not inquire into the motives of the legislature. Every legislative enactment carried with it a presumption that there existed the necessary factual support for its provisions, and the driver's mere conjecture was not enough to overcome the presumption. The court found that the statute was a valid exercise of constitutional power and that there had been an 18 percent reduction in occupant fatalities during the first six months after the seat belt law was passed.


OUTCOME: The court granted the state's motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Judgments -- Summary Judgment -- Constitutionality of Statute -- Legislative Intent

1. In a declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutional validity of Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1229-c, which requires motorists to wear seat belts while operating a car, plaintiff motorist's argument that summary judgment must be denied inasmuch as there exist factual issues concerning the Legislature's intent in passing the statute, shall be rejected since plaintiff uses conjuncture and surmise to pose questions as to the individual intents of the lawmakers and a court may not inquire into the motives of the State Legislature; the fact that similar legislation had been introduced but failed to pass on many occasions does not persuade the court that it may explore the area of legislative intent. In the instant matter, there is no factual issue before the court which would preclude entertaining defendant's motion for summary judgment, since the Legislature is presumed to have investigated and found the [***2] necessary facts. Moreover, judicial inquiry into legislative intent is only appropriate as an aid to statutory interpretation and then only when the statute in question is so ambiguous that its applicability to a particular circumstance is in doubt.

Motor Vehicles -- Seat Belt Law -- Constitutionality of Statute

2. In determining whether a law compelling motorists to use seat belts (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1229-c) advances the State's interest in protecting the health, safety and welfare of its citizens pursuant to the police power, an appropriate test is whether it bears a reasonable and rational relationship to the purpose for which the law was enacted, and numerous studies have shown that the use of seat belts significantly lowers not only mortality rates but the severity of injuries. The State has a compelling interest in saving lives and promoting the welfare of its citizenry, and fewer highway injuries lessen the economic burden on the rest of society by reducing hospitalization and rehabilitation costs, along with keeping productive members of society productive, such that plaintiff's arguments concerning his personal autonomy and the infringement on his right [***3] to make his own decision as to the use of seat belts are insufficient to invalidate a law designed to reduce a "mounting carnage" which has "reached proportions of a public disaster."

Motor Vehicles -- Seat Belt Law -- Constitutionality of Statute -- Justiciable Question

3. In a declaratory judgment action brought by plaintiff seeking to invalidate Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1229-c, which requires the use of seat belts in automobiles, plaintiff's argument that seat belts are dangerous must be rejected where no probative evidence was submitted to support that contention; the issue as to whether a seat belt is the perfect remedy is a policy question not subject to justiciable consideration.

Motor Vehicles -- Seat Belt Law -- Constitutionality of Statute -- Equal Protection

4. Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1229-c, which mandates the use of seat belts in automobiles, does not run afoul of the equal protection clause by exempting rear seat passengers over a certain age in privately owned vehicles, taxis, liveries, tractors, trucks with a certain maximum gross weight, and buses other than school buses, since the classifications created by the statute are not based on [***4] race, alienage, age or nationality and, therefore, the strict scrutiny test is not indicated to determine whether the statute promotes a compelling governmental interest; needed is a "rational basis" test to determine if the varied treatment rests on grounds wholly irrelevant to the achievement of the State's objective, and when a State regulates a problem, it is not under any obligation to regulate all phases of it or every class or acts or actors involved in it. Accordingly, in light of the evidence that seat belts promote the public health and safety, and in deference to the principles of judicial restraint and separation of powers, the "Seat Belt Law" bears a rational relationship to the goals to be advanced and is, therefore, a valid exercise of legislative power.

 

1588 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Michael v. Communications Workers of America


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


130 Misc. 2d 424; 495 N.Y.S.2d 569; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3213



October 25, 1985 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, the New York City Department of Finance and commissioner (finance department), sought leave to renew and reargue the court's denial of summary judgment and for declaratory relief it had requested in its amended complaint. The court's original order granted defendant union's cross motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Stenographer members of the union and employees of the finance department transcribed finance department hearings and sold those transcripts to the parties involved or their attorneys. This practice had been on going for 30 years. The finance department unilaterally stopped the practice and prohibited the stenographers from selling the transcripts. The union filed suit against the finance department. The issues were resolved in favor of the union. One and one-half years later the finance department sought leave to renew and reargue the matter. The court granted only the city's motion for reargument. The court found that the finance department, as a governmental agency, lacked standing to assert the Freedom of Information Law, N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 84(6) et seq., as a petitioning sword rather than an exemption shield. The court held that the sale of the transcripts by the stenographers was deemed additional salary for 30 years and supported contractual consideration and negated any violation of N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1. Additionally, the finance department was equitably estopped from unilaterally changing the practice.


OUTCOME: The court granted the finance department's motion for reargument and denied its motion for renewal. The court affirmed its prior decision that denied the finance department's motions for summary and declaratory judgments.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Sale of Transcripts of Agency Hearings

Employee stenographers, and not the employer New York City Finance Department, may sell and retain all monetary proceeds for municipal agency hearing transcripts since Finance's past 30-year practice of allowing stenographers to charge and collect fees for the sale of transcripts taken at all formal hearings, using Finance's equipment and materials, except for the stenographers' own machines, is a term of employment contractually protected under the city's collective bargaining agreements. The Finance Department, as a governmental agency, cannot be merged with the "public" as a petitioner under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL; Public Officers Law § 84 et seq.) and, therefore, lacks legal standing to assert a right of access to governmental records and to claim that its responsibility under FOIL to insure access gives it the power to sell the transcripts to the taxpayers. Allowing stenographers to sell transcripts is not an unconstitutional gift of public funds (NY Const, art VIII, § 1) since Finance's participation in the 30-year practice makes it inescapable that the fees from the sale of transcripts [***2] were not merely additional income but part of consideration for the stenographer's salary frozen into the city's collective bargaining agreements and such fees in lieu of salary were a saving to the taxpayers that could not be changed unilaterally by Finance especially so soon after bargaining with the stenographers' union over compensation and fringe benefits.

 

1589 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Fossella v. Dinkins


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Richmond County


130 Misc. 2d 52; 494 N.Y.S.2d 1012; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3137



October 23, 1985 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner opponents sought to enjoin respondent Board of Estimates (board) from placing on the ballot at the next general election a referendum that would have amended the City of New York Charter to prohibit the voluntary transfer of property that would be used as a military facility.


OVERVIEW: Intervenor proponents obtained petitions which sought to place upon the ballot a referendum to amend the city charter. The referendum would effectively have prohibited the board from approving any disposition of, or expenditure for, any city-owned property so as to facilitate the development of a military facility designed to have nuclear weapons. The opponents argued that the referendum conflicted with the authority granted to Congress under U.S. Const. art. I, § 8 to provide for the common defense of the nation. The proponents argued the referendum merely prohibited the voluntary transfer of property and that the Federal Government could take any property by eminent domain proceedings. On remand from the appellate division, the court held that the proponents' petition to place the issue on the ballot passed judicial scrutiny and as such, the constitutionality of the proposed referendum was justiciable. The proposed referendum was unconstitutional because it was fashioned to hinder the effectuation of national security. The proposal did not in truth amend the charter but rather would have provided an unauthorized advisory opinion.


OUTCOME: The court granted the petition and issued the injunction.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Elections -- Referendum to Amend City Charter -- Prohibition against Use of City-Owned Property for Military Facility Storing Nuclear Weapons

A proposed referendum to amend New York City Charter § 67 so as to preclude the city from leasing, selling or consenting to the use of city-owned property for the development of any military facility at which nuclear weapons are to be deployed and thereby interfere with the efforts of the United States Navy to construct a homeport on Staten Island is unconstitutional (see also, 110 AD2d 227, 128 Misc 2d 822) since the city may not legislate, by referendum or otherwise, in such fashion as to hinder the effectuation of national security objectives and, even if the city has a legitimate interest in obtaining maximum compensation in return for its property, the proposed amendment has no rational relationship toward achieving this interest since the city will obtain fair and adequate compensation for any property condemned by the Federal Government; the proposed referendum is an impermissible advisory referendum which should not appear on the ballot since the referendum would not prevent the Navy from constructing a homeport under its [***2] eminent domain powers and would thus be nothing more than a public opinion poll which is an impermissible purpose for a referendum; the Referee's review of the petitions on the basis of an extrapolation of the petitions rather than upon a full line-by-line review was proper in view of the 35 volumes of petitions containing in excess of 100,000 signatures.

 

1590 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Moore


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


130 Misc. 2d 154; 495 N.Y.S.2d 564; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3155



October 23, 1985 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to set aside the verdict of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree, or in the alternative declare the law unconstitutional both on its face and as applied to him; and the state filed a motion for an order reinstating the verdict of guilty of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the third degree after the court granted defendant's motion to set aside that guilty verdict.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted, and following a Wade hearing, was found guilty by the jury before the court of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree, and two counts of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the third degree. Following motion papers, argument and submission, the court granted defendant's trial motion to set aside the jury's guilty verdicts as to the possession charge but denied setting aside the jury's guilty verdict on the sale charge. Defendant filed a motion for an order setting aside the verdict on the sale charge based on improper admission of evidence of an uncharged crime, or in the alternative, declaring N.Y. Penal Law §70.25 (2-a) unconstitutional both on its face and as applied to defendant. In addition, the state filed a motion for an order reinstating the verdict on the possession charge. The court denied both parties' motions. The court found that the state had failed to present evidence legally sufficient to support a guilty verdict as to possession, and that the state's case for the sale charge was strong and the proof of the uncharged crime was limited and not overly prejudicial.


OUTCOME: The court denied both the state's motion for an order reinstating the verdict of criminal possession of a controlled substance and defendant's motion to set aside the verdict of criminal sale of a controlled substance.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Verdict -- Setting Verdict Aside -- Testimonial Evidence of Uncharged Crime

1. Defendant's conviction of criminal sale of a controlled substance to an undercover police officer should not be set aside because the People were permitted to introduce on their direct case evidence of another uncharged drug transaction with an unknown male which occurred immediately prior to the drug sale to the undercover officer since the stages of the prior alleged crime were inextricably interwoven with the instant offense and such evidence was not intended to show defendant's criminal disposition nor was the testimonial evidence of the undercover officer as to another drug transaction so highly prejudicial so as to warrant reversal; in addition, the absence of curative instructions to the jury constituted harmless error in view of the overwhelming proof of defendant's guilt and the very brief and insignificant nature of the testimony regarding the uncharged crime and related references during summations.

Crimes -- Sentence -- Second Felony Offender -- Mandatory Consecutive Sentence

2. The enhanced sentencing scheme for second felony offenders, second violent felony offenders,  [***2] persistent felony offenders and persistent violent felony offenders which requires that defendant's sentence on his present drug sale conviction be imposed as consecutive with his present undischarged term of imprisonment for which he is on parole (Penal Law § 70.25 [2-a]) is not unconstitutional as violative of equal protection merely because the sentencing court has some limited flexibility to impose a concurrent sentence in the "interest of justice" upon a violent felony offender whose offense was committed while at liberty on bail or release on recognizance on a pending felony charge (Penal Law § 70.25 [2-b]) since there is a rational basis for treating the two classes of offenders differently in that the Legislature may have rationally concluded that a limited amount of sentencing discretion was appropriate in the presence of specific mitigating factors for statutory first-time violent felons, but that consecutive time without exception was appropriate for second or predicate felons, violent or not, who menace society on a continuing basis.

 

1591 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Weber


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Town of Amherst, Erie County


129 Misc. 2d 993; 494 N.Y.S.2d 960; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2892



October 14, 1985 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state charged defendant with an alleged violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law. § 1229-c(3), which claimed defendant had operated an automobile while not wearing a seat belt as required by law. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the information, contending that the statute in question was unconstitutional under the provisions of the United States Constitution.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that the mandatory seat belt law, N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law. § 1229-c (3), was unconstitutional because it exceeded the permissible scope of the exercise of the state's police power and it also created an impermissible classification that violated defendant's due process and equal protection rights under U.S. Const. amend, 14. Defendant also contended that the statute was unconstitutionally vague because an ordinary person had no way of knowing which safety belts were approved by state authorities. The court rejected defendant's arguments and determined the statute was constitutional and thus found defendant guilty of violating the statute. The court determined that the statute was a proper exercise of the state's police power and that it did not create an unconstitutional classification that deprived defendant of his right to due process and equal protection under the law. The court also noted that the void for vagueness challenge was not meritorious because no one had an inherent right to drive a car.


OUTCOME: The court found the mandatory seat belt law constitutional and determined that defendant had violated the statute. The court discharged defendant from any monetary obligation for the statutory violation.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- Validity of Mandatory Seat Belt Use Law

The mandatory seat belt use law (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1229-c [3]), which imposes a civil penalty upon the drivers of certain motor vehicles and their front-seat passengers over the age of 16 for failure, when driving on a public highway, to wear safety belts approved by the New York State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, constitutes a proper and constitutional exercise of the State's police power; fastening a seat belt can hardly be termed burdensome at all, and the benefits flowing from the use of seat belts may well be vast; preventing or reducing injuries to an unrestrained driver or occupant and others inside or out of the vehicle during an accident is a valid State interest; moreover, the classification created by the statute which exempts taxis, liveries, tractors and certain heavy trucks and buses other than school buses does not violate US Constitution 14th Amendment since the exemptions bear reasonable relation to the desired legislative purposes; further, the law is not invalid for vagueness in requiring use of a safety belt approved by the Commissioner; such provision makes for certainty.

 

1592 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Conyers v. New York State Div. of Parole


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


130 Misc. 2d 33; 494 N.Y.S.2d 818; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3133



October 11, 1985 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In accordance with the foregoing, the petition and writ are hereby dismissed and petitioner is remanded to the custody of respondents.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a habeas corpus proceeding, petitioner sought to be released on the grounds that N.Y. Exec. Law § 259-i(3)(d)(iii) was applied to him in violation of the ex post facto prohibition and on the basis that the statute itself violated his right to due process under the federal constitution.


OVERVIEW: The inmate as convicted and sentenced for felonies that were committed while on parole. The State notified the inmate that no final parole revocation hearing would be held. Rather, pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 259-i(3)(d)(iii), his parole would be revoked by operation of law. The court found that there was no merit to the inmate's contention that § 259-i(3)(d)(iii) was an ex post facto application of the law. The court found that the amendment to the Executive Law took effect on June 19, 1984, prior to the inmate's proposed delinquency date and prior to the issuance of the parole violation warrant. The inmate misconstrued the operable dates set forth in the statute. The inmate failed to show in what manner a final hearing. The inmate failed to sustain his burden of demonstrating that the statute was clearly unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The petition and writ were dismissed and petitioner was remanded to the custody of the State.


HEADNOTES

Parole -- Revocation -- New Felony Conviction

Executive Law § 259-i (3) (d) (iii) which provides that a parolee, convicted of a new felony committed while he was released on parole and serving an indeterminate sentence as a result of that new felony conviction, shall have his parole revoked by operation of law and that his next appearance before the Parole Board "shall be governed by the legal requirements of said new indeterminate sentence" is not violative of due process since no prejudice results from the elimination of a final parole revocation hearing in that where a parolee has been convicted of a crime committed while on parole, there is no question that he violated the conditions of his parole nor is there any question as to whether circumstances in mitigation of the new felony conviction might warrant vacatur of the parole warrant.

 

1593 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Furlong


Index No. CR5525/84


District Court of New York, First District, Nassau County


129 Misc. 2d 938; 494 N.Y.S.2d 653; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2852



October 10, 1985 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendant's motion to dismiss the simplified information is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court considered defendant's motion to dismiss the simplified information that charged him with having beer in his possession in a state park in violation of N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 415.2.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged by a simplified information with the offense of having beer in his possession in a state park in violation of N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 415.2. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the simplified information on the ground that the regulation was unconstitutional. The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the simplified information. The court held that defendant's dismissal motion was authorized by N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 170.30(1)(a) and 170.35(1)(c) as a means of challenging the constitutionality of the regulation. The court explained that any legislative enactment which was challenged on constitutional grounds was afforded a strong presumption of constitutionality, and the court would not set aside a statute as unconstitutional unless that result was inescapable. The court held that a law which placed a restriction upon an individual's freedom of action in the name of the police power had to bear some reasonable relation to the public good to be upheld as constitutional. The court concluded that the regulation criminalized conduct that a person of ordinary intelligence would not think was criminal.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the simplified information that charged him with having beer in his possession in a state park.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Regulation -- Open Container Law

1. A regulation of the Long Island State Park, Recreation and Historic Preservation Commission (9 NYCRR 415.2), which prohibits the possession of beer or other alcoholic beverages in the Jones Beach State Park without a permit or unless purchased in the park, is unconstitutional since it does not require an intent to consume such beverage in the park; by making the mere possession of a can of beer a criminal offense because it had been purchased outside the park rather than at the park, the regulation criminalizes conduct which a person of ordinary intelligence would not perceive as criminal. Even if the prohibition of possession of any alcoholic beverage, unless purchased from a park refreshment stand, was seen as intended to prevent public disorder and not merely to protect the economic interests of the refreshment concessions, the regulation's failure to prescribe the element of intent to consume such beverage in the park still renders it unconstitutional, and the court may not infer intent in order to salvage an otherwise [***2] invalid provision.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Regulation -- Means for Challenging

2. A dismissal motion is authorized by CPL 170.30 (1) (a) and 170.35 (1) (c) as a means for challenging the constitutionality of a statute under which a defendant is being prosecuted, but constitutional questions should not be reached unless there is a need for their determination to resolve the issue at hand and the question is squarely presented. Accordingly, in the prosecution of a defendant accused of possessing beer in a State park in violation of a park regulation, defendant's dismissal motion directly challenged the constitutionality of the regulation, thereby making a determination thereof both necessary and unavoidable.

 

1594 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Vitaliotis v. Mossesso


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, Queens County


130 Misc. 2d 141; 495 N.Y.S.2d 111; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3152



October 8, 1985 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord filed a summary holdover petition against defendant tenant after being issued a certificate of eviction for the personal use of a rent-controlled apartment by the landlord. Both the tenant's administrative appeal and his N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding were denied.


OVERVIEW: After being issued a certificate of eviction the landlord sought to gain possession of the apartment that the tenant had resided in for 20 years, by filing a summary holdover petition. The landlord contended that 1984 N.Y. Laws ch. 234, which amended New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § Y51-6.0(b)(1), the Emergency Housing Rent Control Law, 1946 N.Y. Laws ch. 274, § 5(20(a), and § 10(a) of the Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974, was not applicable because the exemptions it provided to tenants who resided in a premises for 20 years or more were relevant only during the pendency of the administrative proceeding and not once the issues were resolved, that the legislation interfered with his vested right, and that it violated the equal protection clause. The court held that the law imposed permissible and constitutionally acceptable restrictions on the right of the landlord to evict the tenant from the apartment because the certificate of eviction was not final until almost one year after the effective date of the new law, there was no constitutional right to evict a rent-controlled tenant, and the enactment of the law rested on a rational basis.


OUTCOME: The court rendered judgment in favor of the tenant and dismissed the landlord's summary holdover petition with prejudice.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Eviction of Long-Term Rent-Controlled Tenants on Grounds of Landlord's Personal Use

Recent amendments to Administrative Code of the City of New York § Y51-6.0 (b) (1), the Emergency Housing Rent Control Law and the Emergency Tenant Protection Act, which extend to rent-controlled tenants with 20 years in occupancy the same protection from eviction afforded elderly and disabled tenants when the landlord seeks to recover possession of the rent-controlled apartment on grounds of personal use (L 1984, ch 234, eff June 19, 1984), impose permissible and constitutionally acceptable restrictions on the right of landlords to evict a tenant from a rent-controlled apartment since the recognition that long-term tenants are particularly vulnerable to evictions by landlords who seek to remove apartments from their rent-controlled status in order to obtain higher rents is justified as resting on a rational basis and the fact that not all 20-year residents are in desperate straits does not justify striking the remedial law; respondent, whose 20th anniversary of residency in the subject premises occurred on May 18, 1985, is entitled to protection from [***2] eviction under the 1984 amendments even though petitioner landlord obtained an administrative eviction order in December 1983 since the eviction did not become final until respondent's article 78 proceeding challenging the eviction order was dismissed on June 7, 1985; petitioner never acquired any "vested" right to evict respondent since, at the time the law became effective, no final determination on the granting of the certificate had been made inasmuch as respondent was in the midst of an appeal from the initial determination of the Rent Commission.

 

1595 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Thompson v. Department of Environmental Conservation


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


130 Misc. 2d 123; 495 N.Y.S.2d 107; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3148



September 30, 1985 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the respondent is entitled to a judgment denying the relief requested in the petition and dismissing the petition.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, a contract vendee on a certain parcel of land, filed a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 for a judgment annulling a declaratory ruling by respondent, the Department of Environmental Conservation of the State of New York, which held that the Commissioner of the Department had authority pursuant to N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law art. 25 and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 6, part 661, to alter an inventory map at any time.


OVERVIEW: When the vendee filed an application for a tidal wetlands permit, the wetlands line on the official tidal wetlands inventory map was located in such a manner as to make it possible to construct a single family residence on the property. At the hearing, the Department argued that the tidal wetlands line should have been further landward, and the administrative law judge adjourned the hearing to allow the Commissioner to amend the inventory map. In response to the vendee's petition, the Department held that such an amendment was proper at any time, and that an applicant was subject to any duly revised boundaries. The vendee sought review, arguing that he had relied upon the tidal wetlands demarcation on the official map. The court held that although the statute did not expressly state that the Department could review the maps upon receipt of permit applications, clearly pursuant to N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 25-0201(6) the maps were subject to amendment, and the stated public policy was that the map amendment procedures should have been liberally construed to enable amendments to prevent destruction of tidal wetlands. Thus, the Department's decision was not unreasonable.


OUTCOME: The court denied the relief requested in the vendee's petition and dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Environmental Conservation -- Tidal Wetlands -- Amendment of Official Maps

Respondent State Department of Environmental Conservation, upon receipt of petitioner's tidal wetlands permit application to construct a single-family residence on property partially within a tidal wetlands area as shown on the filed official tidal wetlands map, has the power to amend the map so as to move the wetlands line further landward and thereby preclude construction of a single-family residence on the property since, although final tidal wetlands maps ( ECL 25-0201) are intended to do more than serve as a general notice that tidal wetlands are in the general area of a particular parcel, the purpose of the Tidal Wetlands Act of preventing the despoliation and destruction of tidal wetlands permits the Commissioner, after appropriate procedures, to "alter the classification of a wetland shown on [tidal wetlands maps] as may be necessary to conform such maps to actual on-site conditions" (6 NYCRR 661.27 [b] [1]); the fact that petitioner incurred expenses in reasonable [***2] reliance upon the filed map does not bar amendment of the map or establish a vested right upon which he may rely to bar a change in the demarcation of the tidal wetlands with respect to his property; the proceeding is not premature in view of respondent's declaratory ruling (State Administrative Procedure Act § 204) authorizing amendment of the tidal wetlands map at any time.

 

1596 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Harris


Docket No. 5N008749, Penal Law 245.01


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


129 Misc. 2d 577; 493 N.Y.S.2d 733; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2654



September 3, 1985 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Mr. Harris' motion to dismiss the charge against him based on the unconstitutionality of Penal Law § 245.01 is in all respects denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss the charge against him of exposure of a person, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 245.01, on the ground that the statute was so overbroad, vague and ambiguous as to violate his due process rights.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with indecent exposure in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 245.01. Defendant moved to dismiss the charge against him, alleging the criminal statute was so overbroad, vague and ambiguous as to violate his due process rights. The sole issue before the court was whether a reasonable man would have known that what defendant did was conduct proscribed by the statute. The court concluded that defendant, by deliberately exposing his naked penis to a male officer and to a female passenger on a train, committed the very acts which the statute had been legislated to condemn. The court concluded, therefore, that defendant could not complain that the statute was vague and overbroad.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the charge against him on the ground that defendant committed the very acts which the statute had been legislated to condemn and defendant could not complain that the statute was vague and overbroad.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Exposure

A motion by a defendant charged with exposure in violation of Penal Law § 245.01 to dismiss the charge on the ground that the statute is so overbroad, vague and ambiguous as to violate his constitutional right to due process of law is denied, defendant having been accused of deliberately exposing his naked penis to a male police officer and a female passenger on a subway train; the statute provides that a person is guilty of exposure if he appears in a public place in such a manner that the private or intimate parts of his body are unclothed or exposed, and a reasonable person would have known that what defendant did was conduct proscribed by the statute.

 

1597 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Usher v. Mobbs


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Tompkins County


129 Misc. 2d 529; 493 N.Y.S.2d 531; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3348



August 29, 1985 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowners commenced a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding in order to obtain a temporary restraining order preventing respondent commissioners from further widening of a roadway. The trial court (New York) granted the temporary restraining order and then modified so as to prohibit the commissioner only from widening the roadway on to the landowners' property.


OVERVIEW: The gravamen of the landowners' petition was that the commissioner was about to commit a trespass upon their property by widening the road; therefore the court held that the appropriate remedy was injunctive relief. According to the court, where a road had obtained its character as a public highway by user, its width was to be determined by the width of the improvement. However, the court held that where road had been laid out under a statute, it was the statute not the user that determined the width. Furthermore, the court held that intent in enacting N.Y. High Laws § 189 was to authorize the town superintendent to appropriate land that was actually in use, not land that was not in use. Therefore, the court held that the issue of whether the petition stated a cause of action depended upon the extent of the actual use of the road, which was a question of fact.


OUTCOME: The court denied the commissioner's motion to dismiss the landowners' action, which sought to enjoin the commissioner from widening a road.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Highways -- Town Highways by Use -- Width of Easement

Highway Law § 189, which provides that all lands used by the public as a highway for the period of 10 years or more "shall be a highway * * * and the town superintendent shall open all such highways to the width of at least three rods", does not create a town easement of three-rods width since the width of a road deemed a public highway by virtue of public use is determined by the width of the actual use of the road and physical features, safety or similar considerations may dictate other than a symmetrical opening of the road to three rods; the purpose of Highway Law § 189 is not to authorize the town superintendent to appropriate lands not actually in use as roads without the consent of the owner and to do otherwise would result in an unconstitutional taking of a real property without due process of law; accordingly, petitioner's article 78 proceeding to prevent the town from widening the roadway or shoulder in front of their property, which would result in the destruction of 24 trees, is converted to a plenary action seeking injunctive relief and since petitioners would be irreparably harmed if respondents widen the [***2] roadway any further, petitioners are granted a preliminary injunction pending a determination of the actual use made of the road for the prescriptive period provided they file an undertaking in the amount of $ 1,500.

 

1598 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hollstegge


Docket Nos. 623851, 72285-1


Justice Court of New York, Village of Ocean Beach, Suffolk County


129 Misc. 2d 580; 493 N.Y.S.2d 720; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2655



August 27, 1985 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Both motions are therefore denied and the cases shall be noticed for immediate trial.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, the manager of a discotheque and the individual in control of the volume level of music in the discotheque, were charged with violating Ocean Beach, N.Y., Code of Ordinances ch. 112. Both defendants moved pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. arts. 170 and 210 to dismiss the informations.


OVERVIEW: Defendants moved to dismiss the informations on the ground that Ocean Beach, N.Y., Code of Ordinances ch. 112 was unconstitutional, insufficient in law, and otherwise invalid. The court stated that the decisive question was whether the ordinance was so vague and impermissibly overbroad so as to vitiate its effectiveness. The court stated that N.Y. Village Law § 4-412 empowered the board of trustees of a village to enact local laws to protect its property and the safety, health, comfort, and general welfare of its inhabitants. A village was permitted to enact a noise ordinance. The court rejected defendants' argument that the ordinance in the case at bar was impermissibly vague. Ocean Beach, N.Y., Code of Ordinances § 112-5(A)(ii) was precise in defining unreasonable noise. Ocean Beach, N.Y., Code of Ordinances § 112-5(J) was even more specific in prohibiting any other excessive or unusually loud sound which either annoyed, disturbed, injured, or endangered the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of a reasonable person of normal sensitivities. The ordinance depended upon an objective standard to be applied and determined by the court before which cases were to be tried.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions and set the cases for immediate trial.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Village Ordinance Prohibiting Unreasonable Noise

Motions by defendants to dismiss informations charging them with violating a village ordinance prohibiting unreasonable noise, on the ground that the ordinance is unconstitutional are denied; the ordinance, which prohibits "excessive or unusually loud sound which either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of a reasonable person of normal sensitivities", is not unconstitutionally vague; its provisions clearly and expressly state what is prohibited and its enforcement depends upon an objective standard to be applied and determined by the court before which the cases are to be tried.

 

1599 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Asian American for Equality v. Koch


INDEX No. 22491/83, Motion Nos. 40; 203


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


129 Misc. 2d 67; 492 N.Y.S.2d 837; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3354



August 6, 1985 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendants' motion to dismiss the fourth cause of action is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city filed a motion to dismiss plaintiff Asian American group's declaratory action, which alleged that a zoning amendment was unconstitutional in that it was part of a master plan of neighborhood gentrification and planned shrinkage to exclude and displace low income Chinese persons from Chinatown in favor of a predominantly upper income population.


OVERVIEW: The challenged zoning amendment included an incentive program for an increase in the present density requirements for qualifying developers. The complaint alleged that the zoning amendment was not the product of a "well-considered plan" and that a developer was granted a permit under the zoning amendment to construct luxury dwellings, which would displace low-income housing in Chinatown. The city argued that the zoning amendment established a rational and balanced plan for the Chinatown area pursuant to the laws and the N.Y. Const., which did not require a specific form of land use regulation and did not ensure the construction of low and moderate income housing. The court denied the motion to dismiss as to the claims of exclusionary zoning and held that the Mount Laurel doctrine was applicable in New York. The court further held that the Asian American group adequately stated a cause of action under the Mount Laurel doctrine and also under the Berenson standard of a well considered plan. However, the court granted the dismissal as to the claim, seeking to enjoin the city from granting a developer any form of tax exemption that had not yet been applied for by the developer.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to dismiss as to the Asian American group's claim, seeking to enjoin the city from granting a developer any form of tax exemption. As to the other claims, the court denied the motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Motion to dismiss Complaint

1. In an action to challenge a zoning amendment on the grounds that it unconstitutionally failed to provide for low- and moderate-income housing, defendant municipality's motion to dismiss for failure to state a cause of action shall be denied since to succeed on the motion, defendant was required to show that even assuming all of the allegations of plaintiffs' verified complaint were true and viewed in a light most favorable to plaintiffs, the complaint set forth no basis upon which the amendment to the zoning resolution might be challenged; accordingly, inasmuch as plaintiffs have alleged causes of action cognizable under New Jersey law, which in the opinion of the court is applicable to New York since "it is now appropriate to adopt" such law, defendant's motion shall be denied.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Constitutional Mandate to Benefit Community

2.
