Zoning resolutions must be scrutinized in light of the needs of the community as a whole and once a priority community need has been identified, a developmental [***2] scheme which ignores or does not make reasonable provisions to meet that need violates the constitutional or statutory mandate to regulate for the health, safety and welfare of the community; similarly, any reasoning by a municipality must not conflict with the fundamental land use policies and development plans of the community. Moreover, the presumption of the validity and constitutionality attaching to municipal legislation is reputable, and when attacked, courts must examine the zoning and determine whether the constitutional requirements in both formulation and application have been satisfied, such that in determining whether a zoning resolution is designed to promote public health, safety and general welfare, and is a legitimate exercise of police power, the circumstances of each case must be examined.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Exclusionary Zoning

3. In an action to challenge a zoning amendment as being part of a plan of gentrification to specifically exclude monitory and low-income people from New York City's Chinatown, the proper scope of inquiry for analysis is that line of cases involving exclusionary zoning since, while the instant amendment is not [***3] exclusionary as classically defined, if, as alleged, it will result in displacement of Chinatown's low-income residents, then its effect is the same.

Courts -- Stare Decisis -- Decision of Appellate Division

4. While a decision of the Appellate Division, Second Department, is entitled to be accorded great respect and weight, that courts does not have appellate jurisdiction over the Supreme Court in New York County, and accordingly, its holding is not binding upon Supreme Court, New York County, based on principles of stare decisis. Therefore, Supreme Court may consider arguments presented in favor of and in opposition to the same issue presented to the Appellate Division and reach an independent determination.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Applicability of New Jersey Law

5. In an action challenging a zoning amendment on the ground that it fails to provide for low- and moderate-income housing in violation of the constitutional mandate to provide for the people's general welfare, and that such failure runs counter to the Mount Laurel doctrine (see, Southern Burlington County N.A.A.C.P. v Township of Mount Laurel, 67 NJ 151, 336 A2d 713, cert denied [***4] 423 U.S. 808, and 92 NJ 158, 456 A2d 390, in which the New Jersey Supreme Court invalidated a local zoning ordinance on the ground that it did not affirmatively provide a realistic opportunity for the town's fare share of low-income housing), it is the opinion of the court that it is now appropriate to adopt the Mount Laurel doctrine as the law of New York, notwithstanding the fact that New York courts have previously been hesitant to adopt said doctrine because it places a heavier burden upon municipalities, since consideration of the important constitutional obligation to zone for the general welfare along with the lack of success in promoting the interest of low-income people resulting from the current zoning law requiring only a "properly balanced and well-ordered plan" for the community, leads to the conclusion that the New Jersey law shall govern.

Municipal Corporation -- Zoning -- Failure to Provide for Low-Income Housing

6. In an action to challenge a zoning amendment on the grounds that, contrary to the Mount Laurel doctrine, a New Jersey decisional law requiring local zoning laws to affirmatively provide for low- and moderate-income housing, the general [***5] welfare of the Chinatown's residence has not been addressed, plaintiffs state a cause of action by alleging that defendants have impermissibly overlooked the housing needs of current and future residents, and that implementation of the amendment will contravene the general welfare by promoting development which will displace predominantly low-income Asian Americans from Chinatown and preclude any reasonable opportunity for future development of low- and moderate-income housing. The fact that the zoning amendment uses incentives to discharge the municipality's obligation toward plaintiffs does not necessarily mean that it is valid as a matter of law, but, rather, presents an issue which must be explored a trial.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Well-Balanced Plan

7. In an action challenging a zoning amendment on the grounds that it fails to provide the community of Chinatown with a well-balanced plan which will serve the needs of low- and moderate-income people, the complaint states a cause of action under the standard set forth in Berenson v Town of New Castle (38 NY2d 102) where the amendment does not articulate the construction of low-income housing as one of [***6] its goals, where the complaint alleges that the study upon which the amendment was based was piecemeal, inconclusive, discriminatory and based upon insufficient data, where, even accepting the study, the complaint alleges that it offers no basis upon which a mixed-income district may be created, were plaintiffs allege that the amendment does not relate at all to city-wide or regional needs and resources, where the incentives provided to developers pursuant to the amendment are allegedly illusory and may never result in the construction of low-income housing, where there is an apparent ambiguity concerning the implementation of a "floor area bonus" system whereby developers might not ever have to provide for low-income housing, and where a trial is required to resolve whether the zoning amendment facilities the construction of quality low-income housing, one of the needs of the Chinatown community.

Limitation of Actions -- What Statute Governs -- Challenge to Grant of special Building Permit

8. In an action challenging the validity of a special building permit issued to developers of real estate in New York City's Chinatown, the four-month Statute of Limitations ( CPLR 217)  [***7] is not applicable because plaintiffs' attack of the grant of the permit is on constitutional grounds, and is not based on the reasonableness or propriety of defendant municipality's actions.

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- Tax Exemption

9. Plaintiffs' attempt to enjoin a municipality from granting any form of tax exemption to a developer is premature and fails to allege the existence of a justiciable controversy because the developer has not yet applied for an exemption; accordingly, declaratory judgment is not available when the existence of a controversy is dependent upon the happening of future events which may, in fact, never occur.

 

1600 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Marchand


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Town of Woodstock, Ulster County


129 Misc. 2d 323; 493 N.Y.S.2d 72; 1985 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2708



August 6, 1985 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action that was brought by the State against defendant, defendant challenged the constitutionality of Woodstock, N.Y., Local Laws No. 3, § 2 (1985), which regulated public possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that Woodstock, N.Y., Local Laws No. 3, § 2 (1985) was invalid. Woodstock, N.Y., Local Laws No. 3, § 2 (1985) provided, in part, that no person shall have in his possession with the intent to consume the contents thereof in certain places any open or unsealed bottle containing liquor. In finding that Woodstock, N.Y., Local Laws No. 3, § 2 (1985) was void because of vagueness, the court found that it failed to meet constitutional standards because it did not distinguish between innocent conduct and action that was calculated to cause harm. A reasonable person could not say that any person carrying an unsealed container of an alcoholic beverage was intent upon drinking the alcohol publicly in violation of Woodstock, N.Y., Local Laws No. 3, § 2 (1985). While a container had to be opened or unsealed to permit consumption, it could not be presumed that every opening or unsealing was for the purpose of direct human consumption or intended for human consumption in a public place.


OUTCOME: The court found that the section of the ordinance that regulated public possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages was void.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- Validity of "Open Container Law"

A local "open container law" prohibiting the possession with intent to consume an open or unsealed container of an alcoholic beverage in a public place is unconstitutionally void for vagueness; it cannot be presumed that every opening or unsealing is for the purpose of human consumption in a public place, and the ordinance thus fails to meet constitutional standards in that it fails to distinguish between innocent conduct and action calculated to cause harm.
